The worthy and the sages all ask when in doubt, and thus each has a teacher. One must not idly force explanations. Forced speech may suffice for a single utterance, but cannot turn again.

Indeed, indeed—this is why this foolish student dares not force explanations. Your words are right: the great scholar is humble and does not err in this.

Now, the Heavenly Master, in every matter, opens the path to resolve the doubts of the common, answering even what was not asked before. If I now venture another question, it is most unseemly—yet I know not whether it is proper to speak or not.

When in doubt, speak plainly without reserve.

Indeed, indeed. From ancient times to now, the worthy and the sages all had teachers. Yet now the Heavenly Master’s Dao overflows—whom, then, should you take as teacher?

Excellent, excellent—your question truly perceives the subtle intent. When I first began my studies, I too asked my teachers, and not just one. Only after the Dao was perfected and virtue accomplished did I ascend to align my will with Heaven, and only then did I know what Heaven wished to say.

Heaven sent the spirit of the Great Yang to inform me, commanding me to speak. Thus, I take Heaven itself as my teacher. Even when addressing the Perfected Ones, if Heaven does not wish to speak, I dare not recklessly utter these words—Heaven would surely punish me. Do you, Perfected One, understand the gravity of this truth?

You must be cautious.

Indeed, indeed. This foolish student’s every doubt, when asked of the Heavenly Master, finds resolution—my heart rejoices so that I cannot restrain my words. I wish to beg one more question.

Proceed, speak of the Dao.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, Heavenly Master, you have compared me to one benighted and shallow—fully expounding the doctrine of *cheng-fu*. Yet I do not understand: are *cheng* and *fu* the same, or different?

They are not the same. *Cheng* refers to what comes before, *fu* to what follows.

*Cheng*—"inheritance"—means that one’s forebears originally acted in accord with the heart of Heaven, yet unknowingly allowed small transgressions to accumulate day by day, gathering over time into a weighty burden. Now, later generations, though innocent, suffer the consequences of those errors, inheriting their misfortunes and enduring their calamities. Thus, what precedes is called *cheng*, and what follows is called *fu*.

*Fu*—"burden"—means that misfortune flows not from the governance of a single person, but spreads in an unbroken chain of injustice. Predecessors and successors bear the weight of one another, thus it is named *fu*. *Fu* is when forebears impose upon those who come after, and afflictions pass down in an unending cycle—disasters and harms that cannot be easily eradicated.

Yet when eradication does occur, new burdens arise. I reverently received this scripture from Heaven, for this Dao alone can wholly sever such cycles. Thus, it is most solemn, most precious, and without equal.

Perfected One, do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

How profound! How profound! Go now, and ask no more.

Indeed, indeed.

[Right] Explanation of the Master’s Cipher Text: Ninety-Character Formula
True Contract Formula, Fifty-First
[Presented] before the Perfected One.

All matters under Heaven—what is right, and what is wrong? When tested and met with response, when affairs reach fruition, when knotted illnesses are dissolved and dispelled, all this is right. When tested and met with no response, when actions yield no success, when knotted illnesses remain unresolved, all this is wrong—not the fault of one alone.

Excellent! Your words are truly so. Though few in number, they suffice to resolve ten thousand matters; I have nothing to add to your words.

To discern right from wrong, take this as the standard and model. Let no fox-like doubts linger in your heart, for this is the talisman that summons truth.

What does this mean?

Must all matters of trust and doubt be subjected to scrutiny and inquiry? The sages and worthies of old simply observed the evidence of a person’s conduct to know the truth—clear as the sun and moon. Your discourse on the accumulation of good is immutable.

To understand my scripture, seek all proof and validation herein. Perfected One, do you comprehend?

Indeed, indeed.

Go now. Name this the *True Contract*; guard it well, and cast it not into the lower realms. Let it serve as the cipher text and scriptural chapter of the decisive formula.

[Right] *Talisman for Summoning Truth: The Verified True Contract*

*The Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Thirty-Nine—end
*Beginning of The Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Forty

**Striving in the Good Dharma, Fifty-Second [Chapter]**

Perfected One, consider this:

How many predicaments do the people of the world face?

What does this mean?

When all is level and unchanging, how many constraints press upon a person? Though their predicaments are many, are they not nameless?

They cannot be named.

You do not yet understand.

The people of the world face four predicaments.

What are they?

First: when you are born of your father and mother, in your youth you cannot leave their care—this is the first predicament.

Second: as you grow and mature, a woman desires marriage, a man desires a wife; unable to master their passions, they become bound by love and cannot part—this is the second predicament.

Third: once bound in love, they bear children. As husband and wife age, their appearance becomes unlovely, yet their young children are dear; they must now be cared for—this is the third predicament.

Fourth: when their children grow and no longer need support, they themselves have aged and can no longer move freely—this is the fourth predicament.

After these four predicaments, if one meets an enlightened teacher and reflects deeply upon guarding the Dao, those of exceptional talent and celestial mandate may attain liberation. Others may gain longevity, and still others may enjoy fleeting happiness in life. Yet when their hun and po dwell beneath the earth, they will relive those pleasures.

What does this mean?

In the underworld, the newly deceased are questioned about all they did and experienced in life. Based on these deeds, their names are recorded in the ledgers, and they are held accountable accordingly.

Thus, one must prepare in advance—safety and peril are determined by one’s own actions.

Perfected One, be vigilant.

Do you heed this warning?

Indeed, indeed.

The Heavenly Master then instructed with words unseen.

Why this instruction? Seeing your constant good intentions, I feared the Perfected One might grow weary, and so I have made this clear.

Indeed, indeed.

Perfected One, what do you now aspire to in your studies?

Setting life’s end as the limit—how excellent! Your aspiration may be said to have grasped the intent of the Dao.

Yet for ordinary people, all conduct is bounded by the span of life, differing only in whether their goodness or evil reaches its end. What does this mean? I wish to hear it.

Those who maintain goodness and learning, who pass their days in joy and ease, become joyful wandering ghosts, spared from sorrow and suffering. Those who exhaust themselves in sorrow, or whose lives end in wickedness, become wretched ghosts. These are plainly visible matters, knowable to all.

Yet people refuse to do good and delight their hun and shen—truly a grave transgression. What does this mean?

Human life is formed by receiving the pure qi of Heaven and Earth, the convergence of the four seasons and five phases, the inherited body of one’s ancestors. This body, dwelling within Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and five phases, should ever delight in goodness and know no sorrow. Instead, unworthy descendants repeatedly transmit suffering to the body of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and five phases, causing it to endure prolonged hardship and even die in grievance. They further afflict their own hun and po, so that foolish scholars, failing to consider deeply, cannot long endure.

Thus, some wish to hasten their death, and upon dying, feel no regret. Their spirits merely pity themselves, needlessly incurring sorrow and resentment in this lower realm.

Therefore, the great sages of antiquity, with deep calculation and far-reaching foresight, understood this and never ceased their learning. Those among them who became rulers delighted in pursuing Great Peace, aligning with the heart of Heaven, and their merit doubled. Their hun and shen constantly wandered in joy, uniting with Heaven’s virtuous qi.

Those who failed to bring order to their governance acted against Heaven’s heart, forfeiting Heaven’s favor and earning no merit in the celestial realm. When their lives ended, their hun and shen faced solitary reproach in the underworld, dwelling among malign qi.

Thus, the supreme sages of high antiquity understood this and exerted themselves accordingly. Foolish people, lacking deep reflection, incur punishment from Heaven in life and from Earth in death—how terrifying!

Your disciple is dull and ignorant; I do not wish to hear this.

Excellent! Since you have come to study, if you do not wish to hear this, then strive earnestly to do good.

Indeed, indeed.

The Heavenly Master, dwelling in this realm, enables you to know Heaven’s mandate and receive profound instruction. How may one escape this fate?

Excellent! Simply hasten to transmit my writings on the Dao, so that all under Heaven may practice them. Let each reflect on their own body, concentrate their essence, and align their thoughts with the Great Dao. Then they will recognize the origins of their transgressions, and the burden of inherited responsibility will be lifted. Heaven and Earth will rejoice for a great span of years, and the ancient age will be restored and doubled.

Excellent, excellent!

This minor discourse now concludes. Perfected One, exert yourself and persevere. Return another day.

Indeed, indeed.

Study the text carefully, pondering its entirety. If your learning lacks precision, it is called "huhuang" (vague and indistinct). Seeking affairs without form or image, thoughts that do not reach their mark, the spirit has no means to proceed.

Excellent, excellent!

Above: The Heavenly Master’s admonition that failing to exert oneself in life and dying suddenly still subjects the hun and shen to the punishment of inherited responsibility.
Section 53: Explanation of Origins and Ends. The Perfected One advances.

Since you have come to study, you ought to broadly comprehend the intent of the Dao/Way—can the few be followed in practice? Can the many be followed in practice? Yet only when all are fully prepared and numerous may they be followed. Alas, you have not yet broadly grasped the essential intent of the Dao/Way.

Now, Heaven is One, yet it acts contrary to Earth’s Two—what is the meaning of this? Earth is Two, yet it acts contrary to Humanity’s Three—what is the meaning of this? Foolish student, I wish to hear of their mutual interaction.

Thus, Earth serves as Heaven’s agent, and Humanity serves as Earth’s agent. When Heaven rejoices, it causes the myriad things upon Earth in this year to flourish greatly; when Heaven does not rejoice, though Earth may wish to nurture, it causes those things to turn foul. When Earth is good, those dwelling upon it—its people—are inclined toward goodness. This is the clear effect of their mutual agency.

Therefore, order and chaos arise when the many ends fail to align with Heaven’s heart; one must return and revert to the root. When a person’s words are too numerous yet fail to reveal truth, one must return and revert to the essential root—only then may affairs be established through speech.

Thus, a single word that achieves its end is the root text. Two turns of phrase that conclude form a passage. Three words that conclude instead create explanations of difficulties, for distance from the truth gives rise to the need for explanation. Four words that conclude instead form literary expression. Five words that conclude instead produce falsehood. Six words that conclude instead produce deception. Seven words that conclude instead produce destruction. Eight words that conclude instead produce separation and estrangement from the Dao/Way, growing ever more distant. Nine words that conclude instead produce great chaos. Ten words that conclude instead produce annihilation and ruin.

Therefore, when scriptures reach ten, they must be revised, for transmission without change leads to corruption. When all things are ruined, one must return to the root—thus reverting to the One as the primordial beginning. Hence, Heaven’s numbers begin with One and conclude at Ten; this is the natural nature of the Heavenly Dao/Way.

Thus, in ancient times, when the sages inquired of affairs, the first divination revealed fortune or misfortune—this was to guard the root, for the Heavenly spirits descended to inform them. The second divination was when the Earthly spirits emerged to inform them. The third divination was when the Human spirits emerged to inform them. Beyond this, all is deception of others, and divination cannot be trusted, for the hexagrams’ numbers will not be accurate.

When human speech and writing are excessive, they lose their value.

Excellent, excellent!

Now, as the Heavenly Master ever pities those who fall short, he once more wishes to entreat a single word.

*Proceeding evenly.*

Why does the number of divinations stop at three and conclude?

Excellent! You grasp deeply and inquire after this method of affairs. Indeed, Heaven’s numbers begin with the primordial One of Heaven. Descending, it joins with Earth to become Two, and with yin and yang complete, all things are born together. The myriad beings first sprout in the north, where the primordial qi arises at *zi*. Turning to the northeast, roots spread at *jiao*; turning to the east, life emerges and reaches forth; turning to the southeast, branches and leaves fully grow; turning to the south, they flourish in abundance; turning to the southwest, they incline toward fullness; turning to the west, they ripen; turning to the northwest, they come to an end. When things end, they must return to the beginning—thus at *hai*, two persons embrace the One, forming the Three Sovereigns’ origin.

Therefore, *hai* is the kernel, the first coagulation of the seed—hence water begins to congeal in the tenth month. *Ren* means "to bear," for once borne, it must burgeon, growing ever greater—thus *zi* means "to burgeon." When Three achieves the harmonious qi of yin and yang, all is complete, and it returns to the initial arising—hence reverting to the root, it is named *jiazi*.

The Dao/Way of Heaven in generating things must circulate and fully possess all. Only when one beholds the qi of Heaven and Earth’s four luminaries and five phases does completion come. If one qi is insufficient, then insufficiency immediately follows. Thus, it is rooted in Heaven and Earth’s circulation through the eight directions, and all numbers reach their fulfillment at Ten.

Perfected One, do you now understand this?

*Assenting, assenting.*

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed. Such profound grace is received—yet you must not express gratitude. Why? The merit of master and disciple is vast and weighty, comparable to parents giving birth to a child, which cannot be repaid or undone. What does this mean?

Before parents give birth to a child, if the foolish merely cast their essence into the wild, it takes root in the earth and becomes grass or trees, unaware that it was meant to become human. How could such blind bestowal ever be spoken of? Thus it becomes mere vegetation. Only when yin and yang unite does a human take form—how different from becoming grass or trees!

Once born, if a person, though naturally endowed, does not seek a worthy master but instead follows a base and ignorant teacher, they are taught evil ways, led into depravity, and may even bring about their own destruction. Their sins persist beyond death, consuming their entire household. Some are born yet never pursue learning, remaining fools. Such ignorant ones suffer in life and die in sorrow, yet their transgressions follow them below. Their souls, denied joy, cannot even become benevolent spirits after death.

Now, a virtuous master teaches the foolish and lowly, transforming them into good people. Goodness pursued without cease leads to ever greater virtue; virtue pursued without cease leads to sagehood. Sagehood pursued without cease leads to profound understanding of the true Dao/Way. Guarding the Dao/Way without cease leads to immortality as a transcendent. Transcendence pursued without cease leads to perfection as a Perfected One. Perfection pursued without cease leads to divinity. Divinity pursued without cease leads to virtue/power equal to Heaven. Divinity pursued beyond divinity leads to virtue/power equal to the primordial qi. The primordial qi envelops Heaven and Earth; all eight directions receive its breath and come to life. Its virtue/power then blankets Heaven and Earth in all directions, and spirits draw sustenance from it. All under Heaven partake in its offerings, yet still fear they cannot fully honor it.

Such is the merit of a virtuous master who cultivates a worthy disciple—how could one ever express sufficient gratitude? How astonishing! My foolish words have touched upon taboos and overstepped—yet why do you persist in humility, Perfected One? You have made me understand whether gratitude is fitting or not.

*Assenting, assenting.*

Here concludes the explication of the fundamental and ultimate principles, the essential text on the merits of father and son, master and disciple.

**Joy in Life, Attaining the Heart-Method of Heaven, Fifty-Fourth**
The Perfected One advances.

Among the conduct of common people and the governance of kings, what is most excellent? To extend compassion without harm—this, like the movement of Heaven, is most excellent. Your words may be said to grasp the intent of the Dao. Yet in governance, nothing surpasses emulating Heaven. Even so, there must be an order of precedence.

What does this mean? Though this foolish one may speak once, I shall not repeat myself. May the Heavenly Master expound it.

Now, in the conduct of common people and the governance of kings: the most excellent is to constantly desire the joy of life, ever thirsting for it as one parched—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in delighting in accomplishment, ever yearning to bring things to fruition as if grieving for one’s own body—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in benevolent giving, seeing others in poverty and want and sorrowing for them as if grieving for one’s own hunger and cold—only then is it fitting. Next is to excel in establishing laws, not delighting in harm but merely acting from fear—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person errs, nothing is better than governance that does not ensnare them in crime—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person has already fallen into crime, if the heart does not desire to deeply harm them—only then is it fitting. Next, when a person’s transgression incurs a capital offense and nothing can be done, if one can avoid implicating their family and neighbors—only then is it fitting. Next, when the crime extends to family and neighbors, if one wishes to single out the guilty and takes care not to exterminate the human kindred entirely—only then is it fitting.

For humans are the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth. Extermination is called severing the divine lineage of Heaven and Earth, causing grievous injury to the body of Heaven and Earth. The harm runs deep, and in time, Heaven will exterminate the human race in turn. It is no easy matter to become the ancestor of a family. One ought to consider posterity and not impose the calamity of inherited burden upon descendants.

Thus, the sage in governance constantly contemplates Great Peace, ensuring that punishments are prepared but unused. The reason for this is to consider posterity. Now, Perfected One, have you seen the subtlety of these words?

*Assenting, assenting.*

The Perfected One advances.

*Assenting, assenting.*

Perfected One, Perfected One—why do you not speak further, only offering humble deference? In a single word, it is so. My lineage strikes the earth, its mandate tied to Kunlun. Now, the Heavenly Master’s command resides in the Purple Palace of the Northern Culmen of Heaven. Today, the earth stands in the void; we must reverently receive Heaven’s bestowal. As disciples, we ought to comply and submit, emulating the earth’s emptiness of heart, respectfully receiving the Heavenly Master’s teachings—only then may the essential words of the supreme Dao be attained.

□□□□□□□ without the bond of master and disciple, merely called an exchange of □□□□□□ by talent, is termed chaotic and impure learning. □□□□□□□□ decreed teachings, causing the Dao to obscure, one right and one wrong—such discourse cannot be transmitted as the law for emperors and kings. Thus, I dare not speak lightly.

Why this deference? I wish to deliberate with the Perfected One on what is good, and there is no harm in speaking. □□□□□—why should there be? Birth comes in sequence, knowledge varies in measure, conduct differs in rank, and dwelling places in elevation. Now, what I might say cannot compare to what the Heavenly Master has declared. The words of a petty man do not match the vision of the venerable elder who beholds the Dao, whose clarity stands at the forefront.

The Heavenly Master has graciously enlightened one as dull and unworthy as I, allowing me to grasp what is right and wrong, what is difficult—how could this be achieved in an instant? I pray you do not abandon me midway, but act for the sake of August Heaven and Mysterious Earth.

Now that these are the words of Heaven, I shall not defer to you. Yet this disciple has long been silent and heavy-hearted, so I merely inquired. I dare not remain heavy-hearted. Today, upon hearing the Heavenly Master’s discourse, I am both overjoyed and startled. Why?

I rejoice at having met the Master. I am startled for fear that my dull and sluggish learning is incomplete, and the Master may depart. Now, I ask eagerly, as one parched and desperate for drink. Why?

I wish the Heavenly Master to transmit the Dao to his disciples and entrust it to a virtuous ruler capable of employing it. Then, yin and yang will each find their proper place, and all the great afflictions of inherited burdens under heaven will be entirely cured.

Excellent indeed are your words. Upon examining my texts, the Dao is nearly complete. Ordering them from first to last, clarifying them like the sun and moon, they will naturally guide one another. If one contemplates and practices them today, all illnesses will be dispelled and cured without exception, and all will exclaim in joy and admiration.

*Assenting, assenting.*

Above: The Secret of Restoring Heaven’s Will on the Order of Governance, and the Discourse on Deference Between Master and Disciple.

*Thus concludes the fortieth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.
Here begins the forty-first scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace.*

Herein lies the fifty-fifth ancient text, titled *The Book of Secrets: "The Sun Grows Dim, Ignorance Deepens, and Life Remains Unenlightened."*

Kneeling reverently, I bow twice and inquire of one matter.

"Speak plainly."

The Perfected One then declared: "Through ceaseless self-renewal and diligent study, you have questioned matters on behalf of Heaven. My duty is to impart the Perfected One’s teachings to you—nothing shall I withhold. Speak swiftly."

"Very well."

"Now, the lesser Daoist scriptures are regarded as the *Heavenly Classics*. They compile and collate the words of sages from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Scriptures of the Sages*. They compile and collate the words of the greatly virtuous from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Scriptures of Virtue*. They compile and collate the words of the wise and enlightened from the high, middle, and low antiquity to form the *Scriptures of the Worthy*. Yet, reflecting on the Celestial Master’s words, I fail to grasp deeply the intent behind this compilation and collation. I beseech the Celestial Master to clarify the proper order of their gateways, that a virtuous ruler may receive them as solemn teachings, and to instruct the assembly of worthies, enabling each to cultivate and refine their understanding within them."

"How refined indeed is the Perfected One’s inquiry—ever should it be thus!"

"Excellent, excellent."

"Very well. I shall expound fully. Follow closely and record my words; take care not to lose a single phrase. For I speak on behalf of Heaven and Earth, composing this for the supremely virtuous ruler, that it may dispel the calamities of inherited burdens since the opening of Heaven and Earth. Dare I speak falsely? Should I do so, I would incur the resentment of the August Heaven and Earth, and betray the enlightened, virtuous, and sagely ruler—my transgression would be profound indeed. Do you understand?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Now, as for the compilation and collation of Daoist texts from high, middle, and low antiquity: imagine the assembly of worthies collectively reading and examining all Daoist writings from past and present. For every scroll, if a single virtuous character or a single profound secret is found, it is recorded and extracted. One scroll yields one virtue; ten scrolls, ten virtues; a hundred scrolls, a hundred virtues; a thousand scrolls, a thousand virtues; ten thousand scrolls, ten thousand virtues; a hundred million scrolls, a hundred million virtues. If a scroll yields ten virtues, that is ten billion virtuous characters; if a hundred virtues, then a hundred billion. Record and compile them, gathering them in one place. The assembly of worthies, having examined all writings from past and present, transcribes them in full, then arranges them by category, each according to its kind. Redundancies are removed, and the essential texts are ordered and bound—thus is the ultimate comprehension of the essence of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things from antiquity to the present day achieved. From this, the *Heavenly Classics* are completed. Do you understand?"

"Excellent, excellent. I have grasped it."

Examine and collate the sacred scriptures of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity—each scroll containing one virtuous character or essential teaching; ten scrolls yield ten, a hundred scrolls yield a hundred, a thousand scrolls yield a thousand, ten thousand scrolls yield ten thousand, a hundred million scrolls yield a hundred million. If a scroll yields ten virtuous characters, that is ten billion; if a hundred, then a hundred billion. The wise and enlightened jointly record and compile them, gathering them in one hall of virtue. Having thoroughly collated them, they arrange them by category, allowing the wise and enlightened to order them together, removing redundancies—thus are the sacred scriptures completed. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes. I have grasped it."

Examine and collate the wise teachings of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity—each scroll recording one great virtue; ten scrolls yield ten, a hundred scrolls yield a hundred, a thousand scrolls yield a thousand, ten thousand scrolls yield ten thousand, a hundred million scrolls yield a hundred million. If a scroll yields ten, that is ten billion; if a hundred, then a hundred billion. Having reached completion, they again arrange them by category, allowing them to follow in order. The wise and enlightened jointly order them, removing redundancies, binding and placing them—thus are the *Scriptures of the Wise* completed. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

"You have indeed understood.

Now, gather and collate all Daoist scriptures and texts, along with the writings of the many wise ones, and all the virtuous words, secrets, and matters spoken by the people. Record only what is good, assemble them all together, and bring them to one place. When this is fully accomplished, then together with the many wise and virtuous ones of great power, deliberate upon them. By category, refine and clarify them further, remove redundancies, order their words and texts, and record and arrange them. This is called obtaining the writings of Heaven and Earth and the words of human nature, thoroughly and definitively determining their virtuous secrets, with nothing lost—even as fine as a silk thread or a hair.

This Dao of the Dao is called the *Scripture of the Utmost Profundity of Heaven and Earth and Yin-Yang*, which for ten thousand myriad generations cannot again be altered.

Excellent, excellent! Proceed with this, Perfected One—you may be said to have truly awakened.

Yet this foolish student falls short. Now I wish to ask one more doubt.

Proceed with your question.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, long ages have passed. The Yellow River and Luo River have produced writings and diagrams; some divine texts have emerged, some have been brought by sacred birds and beasts, spitting forth writings that have accumulated in great number—all differing in origin. The works of sages and worthies have likewise accumulated in abundance, each ultimately having its own matter. What doubt, what observation, what insight did the Heavenly Master have that you simultaneously instructed the many wise ones of later antiquity to gather and collate the writings and words of the literati of ancient and modern times?

Indeed, there was something observed and seen. I dared not recklessly trouble the virtuous ones of later antiquity without cause. Now I have been sent forth into the world to explain to the lord of great virtue and power the concept of *chengfu*—the inherited burden of flowing disasters and accumulated poisons since the opening of Heaven and Earth.

The celestial writings, sacred texts, and words of sages and worthies of ancient and modern times are already fully sufficient, yet I worry that each excels only in one matter. If we now apply the methods of a single school, we cannot entirely eliminate the calamities and transformations of Heaven and Earth. Thus, flowing disasters persist without end, passing on and inheriting one another. Those born later suffer ever-increasing afflictions and illnesses, and so the Heavenly Lord of Compassionate Virtue continues to bear their *chengfu*.

Heavenly harmony cannot arise for those born later; this accumulation of disasters and faults lies truly in the fact that the former sages and worthies each excelled in one area yet all had their incomprehensions and shortcomings. Heaven, knowing their insufficiency, thus periodically produced the writings and diagrams of the Yellow and Luo Rivers, as well as other divine texts—each differing in their words. The great sages and worthies, appearing in different eras, each accomplished one matter, and their words likewise differed. Therefore, each had their inadequacies, each had their strengths and weaknesses.

So it is. Clearly, none could fully comprehend the ultimate and profound meaning of the *Utmost Profundity*. Thus, between Heaven and Earth, residual disasters persist, ceaseless from beginning to end, varying only in severity.

Therefore, Heaven calculated and determined that now, with the writings and texts above and below, all is fully and completely prepared. Even if sages were to arise again, there would be nothing more to create, nothing more to add, no room for further words, nothing more to contribute to the lord of great virtue and power of Heaven and Earth. If Heaven were to produce another sage, their words would still excel only in one endeavor, and residual flowing disasters and poisons would persist without end—no different from the former sages and worthies.

Thus, Heaven commanded me to deeply instruct the Perfected One and entrust the lord of virtue and power with these writings, to show them to the many wise ones. Gather and collate all the texts and spoken secrets of the world, supplementing above and below, removing redundancies, and preserving the essential words, essential texts, and secret matters. Record them to form scriptures. Only then will the true writings, correct characters, and virtuous words of Heaven and Earth all emerge. All that is false and deceptive will be entirely eliminated, the great illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be fully cured, flowing disasters will be utterly extinguished, and the people and the myriad things will each dwell in their proper place, no longer suffering misfortune or hardship.

Thus, Heaven commanded me to gather and collate them.

My writing does not merely imitate words—it imitates verification. Follow my texts and act accordingly: the calamities and transformations of Heaven and Earth, strange illnesses and diseases, treacherous and cunning ministers, inauspicious and deceptive evils—all will be entirely eliminated. This is no different from the sun dispersing the clouds.

By this, my words and my texts are verified—ten thousand times without a single error.

If you do not vigorously apply my texts, even if I respectfully receive Heaven’s words, descend with teachings, and manifest writings, yet they are not used—how can Heaven idly eliminate disasters? If the texts themselves are in chaos, people will likewise be in chaos, and disasters will have no means of being removed.

Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, you have understood. Now, I wish to ask one doubtful matter. Speak plainly.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, divine sages and worthy persons have all been born of Heaven, and those who have successively presided over the words of Heaven and Earth have all established laws for rulers to eliminate disasters and pacify the world. When emperors and kings follow and apply these, they do not deviate from the patterns of Heaven’s will and the regulations of yin and yang, and the texts they produce each bear their own names and titles.

Now, what should the writings on the Dao and virtue composed by the Celestial Master be called?

Excellent indeed is your question, Perfected One. They are to be named *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*.

Why are they properly named *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*?

The *Great* signifies that which is vast—practicing this governance yields the most supreme and unparalleled rule. The *Cavern* means that its Dao and virtue, whether good or ill, thoroughly harmonize with the yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, and its resonance extends without fail to all six directions, inner and outer. All things are made to act with caution and goodness, and every being attains its rightful place.

This Dao gathers and examines the celestial, terrestrial, human, and divine texts since the opening of Heaven and Earth, selecting only the finest to compile into the scriptures of the *Cavern-Reaching* canon. When emperors and kings follow and apply these, enlisting the collective efforts of all worthy persons to practice them, disasters within the four seas and four borders will be entirely swept away. Such governance becomes as luminously clear as the Cavern itself, resembling the state of Heaven, Earth, and the divine spirits.

Thus, it is named *The Governance of the Great Cavern Reaching Heaven*. Do you understand, Perfected One?"

"Yes, yes."

How astonishing! How astonishing! Perfected One, have you now awakened to this?

Above are the collated texts and oral transmissions of the Upper, Middle, and Lower Antiquities.

*The Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Forty-One concludes here.
*The Scripture of Great Peace*, Scroll Forty-Two begins:
**Method Fifty-Six: The Nine Heavens’ Dispersion of Former Kings’ Disasters**

In all, Heaven ordains nine kinds of people—what then do yin and yang attain?

Humanity is the chief regulator of the myriad things.
The formless spirit-people of entrusted qi are charged with governing primordial qi.
The great spirit-people are charged with governing Heaven.
The Perfected are charged with governing Earth.
The Immortals are charged with governing the four seasons.
The Great Dao-people are charged with governing the Five Phases.
The Sages are charged with governing yin and yang.
The Worthy are charged with governing texts and transmitting teachings.
The common people are charged with governing grasses, trees, and the five grains.
Servants and bondmaids are charged with governing wealth and goods.

Why is this so?
All matters are governed according to their kind.
The formless spirit-people of entrusted qi resemble primordial qi, thus they govern primordial qi.
The great spirit-people possess form and great spirit, resembling Heaven, thus they govern Heaven.
The Perfected are devoted and trustworthy, resembling Earth, thus they govern Earth.
The Immortals transform and change, resembling the four seasons, thus they govern the four seasons.
The Great Dao-people excel in divining fortune and misfortune, resembling the Five Phases, thus they govern the Five Phases.
The Sages preside over harmonious qi, resembling yin and yang, thus they govern yin and yang.
The Worthy manage texts and articulate teachings, resembling written words, thus they govern texts.
The common people are chaotic and ignorant, resembling the myriad things, thus they govern the myriad things.
Servants and bondmaids produce wealth, resembling goods and currency—abundant when rich, absent when poor, capable of circulation—thus they govern wealth and goods.

When August Heaven assigns duties, it does not override their nature; each follows its kind without error. To act contrary invites great harm.
Thus, all the common people ordained by Heaven must comply with this.
The Sages of antiquity deeply understood this principle, never losing the Will of Heaven and thereby gaining Heaven’s favor.

Perfected One, do you now comprehend this?
Excellent! Excellent!
What I have spoken serves as a warning to you, Perfected One, that you may not lose it.
"Yes, yes."
Go forth and strive.

The foolish student’s heart remains knotted and unresolved: "You speak of nine persons, each with distinct affairs—how does this benefit the king’s governance?"

It does not. When governance aligns with the Will of Heaven, these nine *qi* harmonize, and the nine persons unite in purpose, thereby achieving the Great Peace of the Supreme August. If these nine matters diverge and act in discord, the Great Peace cannot be attained.

These nine affairs are interdependent, mutually generating and completing one another—yet people fail to comprehend them deeply. The former sages and worthies did not expound upon them, and so they have long remained obscured.

Now, if even one matter is left ungoverned, peace cannot be achieved. Why? When the *qi* of the Supreme August arrives in full, these nine persons all come to assist the king in governance. If a single *qi* falls out of harmony, there will invariably be discord, and thus the governance of yin and yang cannot be fully harmonized.

How do they come? Invisible spirit-persons arrive to instruct the king, and his heart grows daily brighter. Great spirit-persons appear from time to time to teach the principles of governance. Perfected Ones, immortals, and great Daoists all come as teachers to aid in instruction and transformation. Sages and worthies emerge, reclusive scholars come forth as ministers, and the common people—servants and bondmaids alike—submit to goodness, refraining from wickedness. This is the sign of Heaven and Earth’s great joy.

If a single *qi* fails to harmonize, what then? If the Primordial *qi* is disharmonious, invisible spirit-persons do not come. If the *qi* of Heaven is disharmonious, great spirit-persons do not come. If the *qi* of Earth is disharmonious, Perfected Ones do not come. If the four seasons are disharmonious, immortals do not come. If the Five Phases are disharmonious, great Daoists do not come. If yin and yang are disharmonious, sages do not come. If written words are not true, great worthies do not come. If the myriad things are not in harmony, the common people grow chaotic and wealth diminishes. Servants and bondmaids flee, and all affairs lose their proper order. This is the very essence of harm.

Now, Perfected One, since you wish to save the world from chaotic *qi*, you must strive to harmonize it with diligence and without weariness. Be cautious.

"Yes, yes."

When *qi* is attained, these nine kinds of persons all guard the Dao, and the accumulated disasters of past kings across ten thousand generations dissolve entirely. When these persons all lose their proper place, the harm of accumulated burdens daily increases.

These nine kinds of persons range from the formless above to servants and bondmaids below, each regulating one *qi*, and thus the nine *qi* and yin-yang are harmonized. Now, if Heaven intends to harmonize and regulate *qi*, one must first consume *qi*. Therefore, when superior scholars are about to enter the Dao, they first abstain from eating the formed and consume *qi* instead, thereby merging with the primordial *qi*. Thus, they should be nurtured in thatched chambers, made to fast and abstain, shielded from evil and wickedness, daily refining their forms, and not depriving them of their desires. They can then depart without obstruction, ascending to assist the Perfected Ones and primordial *qi* in Heaven’s governance. These are the divine scholars, the officers of Heaven. Do not forbid or hinder them; if one can truly attain this, they are called Heaven’s scholars. Heaven examines and selects the good, greatly rejoicing in them, and in turn benefits humanity.

What does this mean? Those who attain the Dao and depart, though not of immediate use to the eyes of men, all together harmonize the *qi* of yin and yang. In ancient times, when the emperor-kings sacrificed to Heaven, the spirits above descended to partake of the offerings—this is what it means.

But do only the spirits of Heaven descend to partake? Excellent indeed, your words are correct. Now, these persons serve as Heaven’s officers, and the spirits of Heaven are their sovereigns and superiors. Sovereign and officer act as each other’s emissaries. The duty of the officer lies in carrying out all affairs; when Daoists perform good deeds and merit, the sovereign and their subordinates descend, and upon descending, they rejoice and are pleased, thus eliminating the accumulated burdens of humanity. If the officers are displeased, then Daoists have transgressed against Heaven’s sovereign, and the officers will not descend to partake of human offerings. Thus, transgressions and reproach daily multiply. If one’s own person still incurs grave transgressions, how can one eliminate the lingering disasters of past kings?

Perfected One, do you not also understand this? How astonishing!

I tremble with great fear, as if bereft of qi. Now I have come to inquire of the Heavenly Master, yet never expected to hear such words. Go forth, and exert yourself. When your discourse is complete, I shall depart." "Yes, yes."

On the right: After examining the nine bamboo slips, none among the nine had fulfilled their aspirations. Yet when King Ping governed the realm, he rejoiced and dissolved the accumulated burdens of past kings.

**Verifying the Authenticity of the Dao: Fifty-Seventh Formula**

The affairs at hand will soon be completed. Perfected One, come forward to receive instruction in detail. "Yes, yes."

Since practicing this Dao, the burdens of the past have grown ever more distant, and accumulated afflictions, knotted qi, calamities, and lingering poisons have indeed multiplied—none can be dispelled in but a moment. Yet once you know and practice this, the afflictions of past burdens will daily diminish, monthly dissolve, and yearly vanish. How can this be known?

Excellent indeed is your question—it has grasped the intent of the Dao. Now listen carefully. After practicing this, all documents under Heaven will be set right, and all people will likewise be rectified, entering the true Dao without further falsehood or deception. People will restrain themselves, and those born thereafter will do so even more, emulating one another and all understanding the inner Way. Seeing their own bodies, they will each cherish and value themselves. Those born later will be filial and long-lived, all skilled in caring for the aged. Their countenances will differ from those of the Dao-less era. Later generations will daily comprehend its profound meaning, regarding it as their very home. Their learning will surpass that of their predecessors, daily growing closer, more affectionate, and intimate. They will revere those of the Dao, and weapons, deceit, and treachery will cease to exist. Thus, the afflictions of past burdens will daily dissipate—this is the natural art, □□ with not a single error. This is the great efficacy of my writings, not mere empty words of goodness. Only when verified by evidence do they resonate with Heaven and Earth—how could one speak falsely?

Thus, the texts before and after were not produced by a single hand, and their accumulated subtleties are difficult to fathom. Therefore, my Dao is founded on sincerity. You have persistently □□ inquired, surely desiring to know its great efficacy. Its effects are inverse, like cold and heat: when heat is abundant, cold is scant; when cold is abundant, heat is scant.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, those who have taught others have often concealed the true Dao, instead imparting superficial learning that yields but slight and fleeting benefit. Later generations have daily compounded this, worsening the original state, perpetuating false learning through transmission. Though the Dao of Heaven is vast and distant, the initial authors of such texts have become the great ladder of deception. Once deception takes root, later generations employ it for profit. Now, the superior have nothing to trust, and the inferior have nowhere to entrust their lives. Thus, mutual suspicion arises, leading to disorder. Later generations inherit these burdens in succession, and the afflictions of their predecessors accumulate—hence, it is called worsening.

Heaven is now aggrieved, which is why I speak to you □□. Perfected One, exert yourself and take care to encourage yourself. You will remove illness from Heaven and dispel afflictions for the emperors and kings. The heavens above will know you have rendered great merit. "I dare not, I dare not."

On the right: *Verifying the Efficacy of Practice and Discerning the Authenticity of the Dao*.

**The Four Roots and Branches of Conduct: Fifty-Eighth Formula**

Perfected One, come forward. "Yes, yes."

How many kinds of conduct do people have? There are a hundred conducts and ten thousand variations. Not so. Perfected One, your words resemble those of common folk. People have four kinds of conduct. The first is *or*.

What does this mean? When people act without goodness, it is evil; when they act without goodness yet not evil, it is superficial and mediocre conduct. When they alternate between goodness and evil, it is impure and inconstant conduct—neither can be relied upon, and fortune or misfortune cannot be determined.

Excellent. How many kinds of fortune and misfortune are there? There are a thousand strands and a hundred million variations. Perfected One, your words again resemble those of common folk. There are four kinds of fortune and misfortune. The first is *delusion*.

What does this mean? In all affairs of conduct, if it is not greatly fortunate, it will be greatly misfortunate; if it is neither fortunate nor misfortunate, it is a superficial and mediocre fate. If it alternates between fortune and misfortune, it is mixed and impure, an inconstant fate that cannot be divined.

Excellent. How many kinds of good and evil are there in the nature of Heaven and Earth, in years, months, and days? They cannot be fully enumerated. You are thoroughly intoxicated—your words are as if shrouded in mist. Heaven and Earth, years, months, and days have four kinds of conduct. The first is *impurity*, which governs transformations and anomalies.

What does this mean? Now listen carefully, Perfected One.

Now, when Heaven and Earth and the years are not greatly joyous, they verge on great evil; when they are neither joyous nor evil, it is a mediocre year. When good and evil alternate, it is a year of celestial anomalies and delusion.

Today, if the day is not greatly good, it verges on great evil; if it is neither good nor evil, it is a mediocre day or month. When good and evil alternate, it is a deluded course, governing conduct that is strange and calamitous.

I have merely outlined the guiding principles to reveal the beginning—all matters under Heaven follow this pattern.

What does this mean?
Now, all the myriad things and people of the world, if they do not enter into goodness, must fall into evil. If they are neither good nor evil, it is a mediocre course. When good and evil alternate, it is a course of deceit and falsity—nothing can be established upon it.

The mediocre course cannot be encouraged, while great goodness and great evil achieve renown.

Why are there precisely these four courses?
Excellent! Your questioning is profound and grasps the intent of the Dao.

Now, great goodness is the pure course of Grand Yang. Great evil is the course of Grand Yin’s destructive force. The blending of good and evil is the course of harmony. The inconstant course arises when Heaven and Earth, ruler and ministers, the people, and the myriad things lose their proper Way.

Thus, in conduct, one should seek rectitude: following the Yang yields more goodness, following the Yin yields more evil, and following harmony results in mediocrity. As for the inconstant fortune and misfortune, such conduct has no recurring pattern or measure.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of antiquity deeply observed Heaven and Earth, years, months, and days, the people, and the myriad things, examining their rise and decline, mediocrity and advancement, to know whether their own conduct was aligned or misaligned. It is like using a luminous mirror to reflect one’s form—how could it be otherwise?

Excellent, excellent! What is to be done now?
Now, in conduct, to model oneself after Heaven is the beginning; to model after Earth is to invite many harms; to model after harmony is secondary; and inconstancy is the end of conduct.

Why do people now arrive at the inconstant course?
At first, their forebears made minor transgressions, then slight errors, then greater errors, then grave mistakes. The roots of the Way became ever more confused, leaving nothing to rely upon in their intent. Thus, they turned to inconstant conduct, altering their words to justify inconstant years.

This shows that the decline of the Dao has not yet reached its limit—one must return to the root.

The sages of antiquity saw this and knew it was the end of the current. When the limit was reached, they returned to the origin, thus never losing governance and preserving their Mandate of Heaven. Therefore, the greatly wise and sagely see matters clearly and so always enjoy unique good fortune.

Perfected One, do you delight in further understanding its truth and effects?
It is only for the Heavenly Master to reveal this.

When the root of a year flourishes but its end turns evil, it is the extreme of Yin and Yang. When later generations grow increasingly wicked and shallow, it is the extreme of the age. When the myriad things flourish at the root but yield no harvest at the end, it is the extreme of things. When later generations speak much but with empty deceit, lacking substance, it is the extreme of speech. When writings accumulate in abundance yet lack truth, it is the extreme of literature.

All these arise from forsaking the root for the branches, abandoning substance for ornamentation. Thus, Heaven and Earth generate the myriad things, yet many lack a true root or fruition. The fault lies in forsaking the root to pursue the branches, abandoning truth for falsity, abandoning depth for shallowness, and making this the norm.

Customs become so ingrained that people no longer recognize their mutual harm, and alone they accumulate opposition to the laws of Heaven. Later generations grow ever more frivolous in affairs, crafting deceit and falsity. Habit solidifies into nature, and they can no longer restrain themselves, instead claiming to understand matters. Thus, they inherit and compound one another’s burdens, creating Heaven’s blame and Earth’s calamity. These spread in all directions, unrestrained and unchecked.

Even if a ruler is benevolent and wise, how can he sever this flow of errors spanning myriad generations? The initial losses were minor, each no more than a grain of millet. Yet the Way of Heaven loses a hair’s breadth, and the error extends a thousand miles. Grain by grain they accumulate, filling granaries with tens of thousands of *hu*.

Raindrop by raindrop they follow one another, and the flowing waters never cease, forming the hundred rivers and filling the Four Seas. The root cannot be removed, so one must correct it with the true Dao, returning from the extreme of the branches to the root, returning from ornamentation to substance, returning from falsity to truth.

When the branches reach their limit, one should return to the root; when conduct reaches its extreme, one must return to the origin—this is the Way of Heaven.

To lose the true Way is no minor illness. It extends even beyond the end of one’s life, as errors are inherited and compounded. Later generations grow ever more confused and lost, the true Way grows ever dimmer, and the darkness of losing the Way deepens. The qi of Heaven becomes contrary and rebellious—how can governance be peaceful?

People suffer its poison and harm—how can they attain longevity? The myriad things are injured and die prematurely in great numbers.

Thus, I repeatedly enjoin the Perfected Ones to transmit my writings, so that each person may reflect on the meaning of losing the Way, and each may worry and labor over their own illnesses. Then Heaven and Earth, the Thearch, the people, and the myriad things will all be at peace.

Perfected One, if you delight in aligning with the heart of Heaven, you must not be negligent or careless.

Indeed, indeed! I wish to ask one more question.

The Celestial Master speaks now of fortune and misfortune—are these merely the workings of the times?

Excellent, Perfected One, in your questioning you have grasped the meaning of the Dao. What reaches its utmost above must return below; what extends to its farthest outward must return inward. Thus, when yang reaches its extreme, it turns to yin; when yin reaches its nadir, it reverts to yang. What has gone to its end must return to its root.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, even minor deviations from the Dao’s intent have accumulated, passed down through generations, until falsehood and deceit have reached their extreme. How do we know this? Observe that among the myriad things and the people, many begin with goodness but end in evil—few complete what they start. Their words begin with substance but end in emptiness. The sages of old constantly observed the movements of the people to understand this, and thus they never lost the Way.

Excellent, excellent indeed. I wish to ask one more question.

Proceed.

If, as the Celestial Master says, things have their nadir and their zenith—take, for example, nine ranks of people: at the highest extreme are the ethereal spirit-people, and at the lowest, slaves and servants. If those below study and ascend, can those at the highest extreme also descend again?

Excellent is your question. Perfected One, you still seem unenlightened, not yet having penetrated the Dao of the Great Ultimate. These ethereal spirit-people merge their forms and powers with primordial qi, coexisting with the four seasons and the five phases. All spirit in humanity is received from Heaven’s qi, and Heaven’s qi is received from primordial qi. Spirit rides upon qi to move, so where there is qi, there is spirit; where there is spirit, there is qi. When spirit departs, qi is cut off; when qi perishes, spirit departs. Thus, without spirit, one dies; without qi, one dies.

Could an ethereal spirit-person enter a human’s belly?

Indeed.

Moreover, the five phases arise and flourish from primordial qi, and spirit moves in unison with primordial qi, sharing the same body. Now, the five phases enter to become the human’s organs—among these nine ranks of people, can the highest extreme descend and re-enter the human body?

Excellent, excellent. Though you have studied for a long time, you have only now glimpsed this teaching. You must refine your learning—without refinement, there is no benefit.

Indeed.

From the Celestial Master’s words, is the Dao of Heaven truly like a cycle?

Yes, you may be said to have understood it. Go now, and if you have further doubts, do not hesitate to ask.

Indeed.

The right-side bamboo slips record the four celestial phases, their true origins and ends in the Great Ultimate, returning to govern.

*Beginning of Scroll Forty-Three of the Scripture of Great Peace*

**Chapter Fifty-Nine: The Great and Small Methods of Admonition and Rectification**

The Perfected One bowed and said: "This foolish student is benighted and dull, truly ignorant of the Dao. Now that I have been charged with observing Heaven’s safety, peril, fortune, and misfortune, I dare to inquire fully into the essentials of the Dao.

In this age, do the divine laws of spirits and deities also include admonition and rectification?"

The Celestial Master instructed: "You have been shown the profound intent of the supreme Dao.

Your question—how wondrous, essential, and far-reaching it is!

I have observed that humans admonish and rectify one another, so I ask: does Heaven also admonish and rectify?"

Excellent! Your question has grasped the true essence of the Dao of Heaven. The celestial spirits have emerged, and the deities rejoice.

Now, I shall explain its great essentials for you, so that for ten thousand generations it may never be forgotten."

"Yes, yes."

"Now, when Heaven offers minor admonition, its countenance changes; when it offers great admonition, Heaven itself trembles and its body splits. If its admonitions are unheeded, it will thereby fade and perish.

When the Three Luminaries offer minor admonition, minor affairs cause the stars to alter their hue; when they offer great admonition, the Three Luminaries lose their measure and cease to shine. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When Earth offers minor admonition, it quakes and sways; when it offers great admonition, mountains collapse and the earth splits. If its admonitions are unheeded, it will thereby fade and perish.

When the Five Phases offer minor admonition, disasters arise; when they offer great admonition, creatures of the east slay people, poisons of the south kill people, tigers and wolves of the west kill people, water creatures of the north kill people, and in the center, officials and commoners use toxins to murder one another. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When the Four Seasons offer minor admonition, cold and heat slightly lose their balance; when they offer great admonition, cold and heat reverse their positions, and the qi of the seasons no longer follow their proper measures. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When the qi of the six directions jointly offer minor admonition, disorder and calamity arise repeatedly, with creatures—some flying, some walking—emerging as disasters. Clouds and winds gather but bring no rain, leaving the skies empty and barren. When they offer great admonition, floods and droughts lose their regularity, harming and killing the myriad beings and the people. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When flying and walking birds and beasts offer minor admonition, they bring harm to people; when they offer great admonition, birds and beasts devour people, and locusts swarm in great numbers. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When the spirits and deities offer minor admonition, they subtly afflict officials and commoners with illness; when they offer great admonition, they cause families to be torn apart and destroyed. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby perish.

When the six directions offer minor admonition, winds and rains erupt chaotically, moving with malevolent poisons to harm people; when they offer great admonition, they act perversely and without reason, hurling tiles and stones, causing the earth to rise and strike the august Heaven, shattering houses, and shaking mountains and hills. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When the sounds of Heaven and Earth offer minor admonition, thunder and lightning grow slightly urgent in tone; when they offer great admonition, people engage in widespread corruption and evil, causing thunderbolts to strike repeatedly. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When officials and commoners offer minor admonition, their countenances change; when they offer great admonition, they harm and injure one another. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will thereby fade and perish.

When Heaven, Earth, the six directions, and the eight limits all offer great admonition together, they seek to rectify the patterns of the Yellow and Luo Rivers, making Heaven’s clarity manifest, and the great auspicious signs of the world appear in written form to admonish and rectify the ruler. All under Heaven respond in unison. If their admonitions are unheeded, they will fade and perish.

The cyclic meetings of the Dao of Heaven must be employed and followed in proper sequence.

Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity, upon witnessing events, would always ponder and reflect upon their meaning, never daring to be negligent even in the slightest. By perceiving the subtle and knowing the manifest, they never lost the will of August Heaven. Therefore, they preserved their bodies, secured their dwellings, knew no sorrow or peril, and no misfortune could befall them. In their calculations and assessments, they truly aligned with the intent of Heaven.

Excellent, excellent! This foolish student now understands."

Now that the Illustrious Heavenly Master has expounded the method, I wish to understand the reasons behind its fading and perishing—pray, elucidate this.

Excellent, excellent! Such is the sincerity of your heart.

Yet the Dao of Heaven aids those who are teachable, aids the utmost sincere, aids the reverent and compliant, aids the readily enlightened, aids the easily admonished. It seeks to enrich the ruler, hence it instructs him. If it does not seek his enrichment, it will not deign to instruct him.

Its manifestations are akin to how, when people share deep intimacy, they teach and guide one another in affairs. If their bond is not profoundly close, they will not teach or guide. Should one instruct and not be heeded, should one’s timely counsel be disregarded, then it will be abandoned and set aside, never again to be earnestly taught or shown.

Thereupon, calamities and omens arise, and Heaven no longer reveals its admonitions to mankind. In such a state, even the sagely and wise become as though deaf and blind, devoid of understanding. Their clarity and insight obstructed, the gods and spirits of Heaven and Earth will no longer correct them.

Disasters and anomalies daily increase, unremoved; mankind daily declines and perishes, losing its proper office. Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity, from dawn to dusk, remained composed yet deeply reflective, never daring to lose the will of Heaven. Therefore, they served August Heaven as a father, August Earth as a mother, the sun as an elder brother, the moon as an elder sister. They rectified Heaven’s fatherly role, safeguarded the Five Phases, followed the Four Seasons, observed their advances and retreats, and thereby illuminated and corrected their own conduct. Thus did they profoundly comprehend Heaven’s gains and losses.

Only when Heaven and Earth adhere to the essential Dao, taking the responsive charts and texts of the Celestial Mandate as their great charge, do all their actions attain responses as though divine—this alone is to deeply grasp the intent of Heaven. It is like aligning a double mirror with the carpenter’s square, speaking face to face.

Therefore, the numinous spirits are stirred by such alignment. But if one resists and refuses to heed their corrective counsel, then Heaven and Earth become inverted and disordered, the Five Phases and Four Seasons fall into chaos and rebellion, losing their proper principles. Thus, all undertakings miss their mark, and great misfortune ensues—this is what is meant.

Do you now understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, the nature of Heaven and Earth is such that the lower rectifies and admonishes the upper, just as the upper rectifies and admonishes the lower. Each possesses strengths and shortcomings, and by mutually compensating for these, the myriad affairs of the Dao of Heaven all find their proper place.

Therefore, though August Heaven is numinous and sagely, it has its shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of Earth. Thus, the myriad things receive their mandate from Heaven yet nourish their forms upon Earth. The Three Luminaries have their shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of fire. Though the Three Luminaries are numinous and bright, they cannot illuminate the depths of inner chambers, whereas fire shines within them. The greatest sages have their shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of the worthy. Humanity has its shortcomings, which do not match the strengths of the myriad things.

Thus, when admonition extends even to the lowest and most minute, the Dao is not lost, and the heart-mind of Heaven is attained. Therefore, Heaven generates all affairs, causing their seasons to undergo transformation and reform, all to admonish and correct the lord of men, thereby manifesting the signs of utmost virtue. One cannot but be greatly cautious in this.

The transformations and reforms of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—these are their admonitions.

Indeed, indeed.

Since the August Celestial Master has now made this clear, I wish to apply it to humanity.

Understood.

You must carefully heed my words and ponder them deeply.

When a minister possesses loyalty, goodness, sincerity, and trustworthiness, and admonishes and corrects his superior, yet the lord does not heed and employ him, but instead seeks to harm him, the minister is alarmed. Thereupon, he ties his tongue and becomes mute; the six directions close off and do not communicate. The worthy and learned, fearing trouble, thus conceal themselves; loyalty and trustworthiness lie hidden; the true Dao cannot be seen. Though the lord may be sagely and worthy, he hears nothing, and thus becomes deaf and blind, unable to perceive anything extraordinary. Day by day, darkness and obscurity prevail; the lord is deaf, the ministers are mute. Such calamity cannot be restrained. When ministers are benighted and the lord is blind, treachery and villainy run rampant. When ministers are mute and the lord is deaf, the world is cut off; good and evil are not distinguished. Heavenly disasters converge; the Six Extremities wage war; the world is wholly inauspicious. Can one not be cautious in this?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity took omens, disasters, and prodigies with utmost gravity, using them to align and correct themselves. Therefore, in ten thousand cases, they did not err even once. In truth, this was because they acted in accord with the essential texts and the great Dao, exhausting their loyalty without further misfortune.

You must take these warnings to heart and carefully heed my words.

Indeed, indeed.

Yet the loftiness and clarity of Heaven are not the achievement of a single essence’s virtue and power. When the emperor-king governs in accord with the heart-mind of Heaven, it is not the achievement of a single worthy minister. Now, my words merely raise the guiding principles to reveal the beginning. All affairs cannot be exhaustively recorded and explained; you must deeply ponder their intent yourself.

Indeed, indeed.

Go now. How could such discourse ever end? There is nothing more to ask.

Indeed, indeed.

**Right: The Heavenly Admonitions and Correct Writings, Concluded**

*Great Peace Scripture, Scroll 43, Ends*
*Great Peace Scripture, Scroll 44: "Examining the Writings on the Methods of Punishment and Virtue, Section Sixty"*

The Perfected One, in utmost reverence and caution, prostrates and respectfully bows. What I now ask will surely incur profound reproach. Yet when I reflect upon the words written by my returned teacher, all is correct—nothing can be altered.

But this humble disciple, dull and benighted, remains bound in melancholy, unable to discern from whence the August Heavenly Spirit-Person derived these models and laws.

Now, I marvel at the master’s accumulated wisdom, vast and unspoken. I beseech the master, in compassion, to reveal the celestial proofs of the yin-yang secrets and the essential divinations of the gods and spirits.

At present, my thoughts are in turmoil, my heart greatly disturbed. What I say must surely transgress the master’s taboos. Yet though I long to speak, I cannot restrain myself. Even if the Heavenly Master reproves me, I pray for the enlightening methods of celestial verification to be shown, so they may be transmitted for ten thousand generations, radiant and unquestioned—like the brightness of the sun at noon—unchanging from beginning to end, never to be abandoned.

Yet, do you truly still not believe my words?
You remain as one who has not yet fully awakened, who does not comprehend the heart-mind of Heaven.
Are you not still foolish? You differ little from the common people.
To oppose my words is to invite chaos; to defy them is to court ruin.

What I now say to you has all been examined and verified against the celestial patterns, aligned with the great secrets of yin and yang before being spoken.
You come to inquire of Heaven’s affairs; I transmit Heaven’s words and establish its laws—not daring to utter empty, false, or flattering speech.

You have lived through many years and days—how is it you have not observed the teeming myriad creatures, all of which dwell in accord with virtue while shunning the qi of punishment?
This is the luminous and essential proof of August Heaven.
It is the manifest evidence by which the governance of the ruler is measured in success or failure.

Indeed, indeed.

If you are now awakening yet still not fully awakened, I wish to further question your teachings and admonitions.

Now, punishment and virtue are the clear manifestations of the divine governance of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang—the standards for the myriad creatures and the people.

Thus, in the eleventh month, great virtue resides in the *nine-one*, dwelling beneath the earth. The season of virtue is within the chamber, so there is qi within, and the myriad things return to it. The season of punishment is in the *six-four*, in the distant wilds, so there is no qi without, and it is clear and empty. The outer world is void of things, and the multitudes all return, following the king’s virtue into the Yellow Springs below.

In the twelfth month, virtue is in the *nine-two*. The season is in *chou*, dwelling in the center of the earth, not yet emerged. The season of virtue is in the Bright Hall, and the myriad things follow virtue upward, yet dare not emerge to be seen, for punishment is above.

In the first month, *yin*, virtue is in the *nine-three*. The myriad things, without exception, follow the flourishing virtue and delight in its abundance, being born between Heaven and Earth. The season of virtue resides in the courtyard.

In the second month, virtue is in the *nine-four*, in *mao*. It has departed from the earth but not yet reached Heaven, lingering at the boundary. Virtue is at the gate, so the myriad things all delight in emerging to peer through the gate.

In the third month, flourishing virtue is in the *nine-five*. In *chen*, it reaches the center of Heaven. The season of flourishing virtue is in the outer roadways, so the myriad things all emerge to dwell without.

In the fourth month, *si*, virtue is in the *nine-six*, extending to the six distant and eight borderlands. Flourishing virtue pervades the eight directions; good qi and yang qi respond and generate one another. The teeming creatures depart from the inner chambers to dwell in the wilds. The season of punishment is at the roots of the myriad things, residing within the inner chamber, so below is empty and without things, while above is lush and flourishing. None fail to delight in following virtue to govern. This is the great and luminous proof of governance through virtue.

Now that I have reverently heard of the use of virtue, I wish to hear of the use of punishment.

Thus, in the fifth month, punishment is in the *six-one*, in *wu*, beneath the earth. Below and within, it is clear and without qi; the earth below is empty. The season of punishment is within the chamber, so there is nothing within, and all dwell without.

In the sixth month, punishment resides in the *six-two*, in *wei*, dwelling in the center of the earth, not yet emerged. The season of punishment is in the hall. The qi of punishment is within; the qi of virtue is without. The teeming creatures, without exception, delight in baring themselves and returning to the one of flourishing virtue.

In the seventh month, punishment is in the *six-three*. The season is in *shen*; punishment is in the courtyard. The myriad things dare not enter and firmly delight in dwelling without.

In the eighth month, punishment is in the *six-four*, in *you*. It has not yet reached the boundary of Heaven. The season of virtue is at the gate, and the myriad things all delight in gathering at the gate, rejoicing in entering and following virtue to return.

In the ninth month, punishment is in the *six-five*, in *xu*. It reaches the center of Heaven. The season of punishment is in the roadways, and the myriad things, without exception, are on the verge of death and distress, following virtue to conceal themselves. Thus, within, things daily flourish, while without, all is empty and perishing.

In the tenth month, punishment is in the *six-six*, in *hai*. Punishment extends to the six distant and eight borderlands and the four wilds. The teeming creatures, without exception, conceal themselves and flee, following virtue to the Bright Hall. Crawling creatures carry their young within; the wilds without are empty of multitudes. Is this not the consequence of those who delight in employing punishment, driving away the perverse?

Yet if the heart-mind desires to harbor punishment within to govern the multitudes, it will daily diminish them.

Thus, in the fifth month, harboring one punishment within causes one group of multitudes to rebel.
In the sixth month, harboring two punishments within causes two groups of multitudes to rebel.
In the seventh month, harboring three punishments within causes three groups of multitudes to rebel.
In the eighth month, harboring four punishments within causes four groups of multitudes to rebel.
In the ninth month, harboring five punishments within causes five groups of multitudes to rebel.
In the tenth month, harboring six punishments within causes six groups of multitudes to rebel.
Thus, without, all is void of things, and all flee within. This is the clear proof and evidence.

Therefore, those who govern with punishment are outwardly respectful yet inwardly rebellious, so the multitudes daily diminish.

Thus, in the eleventh month, harboring one virtue within causes one group of multitudes to enter and follow.
In the twelfth month, harboring two virtues within causes two groups of multitudes to enter and follow.
In the first month, harboring three virtues within causes three groups of multitudes to enter and follow.
In the second month, harboring four virtues within causes multitudes from the four directions to enter and follow.
In the third month, harboring five yang virtues within causes five groups of worthy multitudes to enter and follow.

In the fourth month, harboring six virtues within causes the myriad things to emerge and appear together, all bustling without exception, both within and without submitting to it. This is the clear proof of Heaven’s law.

In the second and eighth months, virtue and punishment are evenly matched, so in the second month, half of the things are harmed by cold, and in the eighth month, half of the things are likewise harmed by cold. At the time of the second month, virtue desires to lead its multitudes forth through the gate, while punishment desires to draw its multitudes back within the gate, both standing at the boundary. Thus, in the second and eighth months, the myriad things encounter virtue and punishment in equal measure, life and death balanced, and so half are harmed.

You now delight in knowing the constant laws of Heaven and Earth, the clear proofs of yin and yang—this is precisely it. Punishment daily harms and kills, and though the people dread it, they cannot be made to yield their strength; instead, they say there are no people. Virtue daily unfolds and grows, without punishment or fear, yet the myriad things submit and surrender, all coming to assist the king in governance. This is the clear proof of Heaven, evident and beyond doubt.

Now, if people cannot be governed without awe and fear, what is to be done? Yet the sages and noble men of antiquity ruled others through the Dao and virtue, not through physical force or punishment. Those who take no joy in goodness and whose virtue is weak instead seek to govern through the threat of punishment—yet they only see their people depart.

Punishment can only be used to relieve distress and resolve entanglements; it is not sufficient to give life to the myriad things. Clearly, the bustling multitudes belong to virtue as their leader. Now, if people do not submit inwardly but instead deceive and betray, the great fault lies here.

You have come repeatedly over time to study and ask about many matters, accumulating much written knowledge, yet you have not yet fully trusted my words. Have you now gained some understanding?

Chun prostrates himself in reverence, bowing deeply. My transgressions are grave, and I have failed the teachings of my enlightened teacher and divine person. Inwardly ashamed, I sweat with remorse. Though my virtue is meager and my station low, and though I have studied for many days, my heart remains dull and cannot fully grasp the words of my enlightened teacher. Thus, I dare not refrain from asking again and again—greatly lacking in humility, I have long caused you, my teacher, concern. It is only that my learning remains unrefined. You must be cautious.

Heaven hangs forth its signs and establishes its laws for humankind, setting forth teachings and commands for emperors and kings to follow in governance, not erring even once. If you wish to understand its meaning, this is precisely it.
