If the *Jia* meridian is afflicted yet the *Yi* is treated, this is called confusion, for the meridian is uniquely injured and severed. Thus, to discern whether the celestial way is spiritually efficacious or not, whether it corresponds or not, simply place a patient before you—this is the meridian’s root text, akin to the foundational text of the Daoist scriptures. Gather many worthy ones to discuss the illness: some may excel in the upper body, others in the lower; each of the three hundred and sixty meridians has its observable aspects. Record the methods of those whose treatments consistently succeed in ten out of ten cases—these are correct; all others are not. Compile the successful treatments into a scripture, and there will be no unresolved formulae in what is treated.

The celestial way governs the meridians, whether externally or internally, yet it cannot be fully known. Where treatment succeeds in ten out of ten cases, that is where the meridians converge. Though people vary in size, with differing measurements, their proportions remain the same, and one must rely on the divisions of *Dan* and *Pi* to achieve correspondence. Daoist texts, accumulated over time from diverse sources, are called "chaotic meridians." Treating yin when yang is disordered reverses the cure, bringing misfortune upon people, harming the innocent, and shortening lives.

The meridians resonate with heaven, earth, and the myriad things, rising with the qi and cycling back to their origin. Those who grasp their patterns may thereby cultivate their nature and discern the arrival of seasonal qi. If there is disharmony, they restore balance. In ancient times, sages and worthies sat in pure stillness, palpating their own meridians, observing the cycles and movements of their pulses to know the gains and losses of the four seasons and five phases, thereby understanding the waxing and waning of their own bodies. This is how they secured the state, nurtured life, and preserved their forms—how could one not be cautious?

Those who are deluded by indiscriminate moxibustion and acupuncture injure the proper meridians, harm the correct qi, and disrupt the four seasons and five phases, bringing forth calamities and anomalies. The great are greatly harmed, the small are slightly harmed, and all may be moved or unsettled—this is the natural course of things. Thus, the ancient sages and worthies held these practices in high regard. The sage emperors and kings observed the movements of the meridians to divine the auspices of the six directions—this is what is meant by "knowing the distant through the near, the external through the internal," and thus it is called the divine and essential way.

**Divine Incantations Formulae, Chapter Seventy-Five**

In the heavens, there are constant divine and sagely essential words, periodically bestowed upon people for use, dispatching spirit-officials to respond to the qi and come and go. The people who receive them call them "divine incantations." When incantations cure a hundred out of a hundred, or ten out of ten, they are the transmitted scriptural words of the celestial divine texts. Only those incantations that can summon the spirits’ trust, cure illnesses, and consistently succeed in ten out of ten cases are used—there is no direction in which they do not heal. Simply using words to cure illness is the divine prophecy of the heavens.

These are what good teachers and emperors should employ, compiled into scrolls and named the *Incantation Prophecy Scriptures*. They serve to summon the host of spirits, hence their tenfold efficacy. When nine out of ten are cured, the true spirits do not arrive, but lesser spirits do, and great ministers possess them. When eight out of ten are cured, human spirits arrive, and officials possess them. These are the words of the celestial spirits, originally meant to summon them. Their names and times occasionally leak down to earth, and Daoists who learn of them transmit them to one another, thus enabling the treatment of illness. Like sending a messenger with words, they cannot cure illness.

In matters of change, one cannot rely on others even for a moment. Heaven values human life, fearing that rare methods are difficult to perfect quickly, and that great physicians may lose the meridian scriptures, failing to comprehend matters of life and death. Thus, the essential way is placed in people’s mouths—this is the art of emergency relief. To obtain these essential words, simply place a patient before you as the root text of the incantation, and let each recite their secret oral formulae. If the illness is immediately cured, it is genuine; otherwise, it is entirely false, the response of deceptive and reckless words, and cannot be taken as a model.

Some incantations may cure when used alone, yet others fail to achieve the same effect—such words cannot be recorded. These are the leaders of ghosts and spirits, naturally employed by people, called "solitary words," not the true way of summoning spirits. Though people and heaven are distant, how can one discern whether the way is true or not? That which is true or false corresponds and harmonizes, fitting like tallying tokens—this is genuine; otherwise, it is not.

**Burial and Residence Formulae, Chapter Seventy-Six**

Burial is the original hillside dwelling of one’s ancestors, called the initial planting of roots. A residence is the earth to which the hun and po souls should return. If the land is auspicious, the souls return to nurture the descendants; if inauspicious, they return to harm them. When the qi of the five ancestors is exhausted, they are reborn as people.

**The Dao of Heaven and the Efficacy of Earth, Chapter Seventy-Six**

The Dao of Heaven follows the law by which qi circulates and returns to its origin. To discern the efficacy of earth, plant a small, humble seed in the soil; if later days bring flourishing growth and great goodness, it is a land of great vitality. If a fine seed is planted yet later days yield evil, it is a land of inversion. If daily fortunes wane and diminish, it is a land of depletion. Test this with twenty-five families’ burial mounds and hills: if ten, a hundred, or a thousand correspond in harmony, these are the texts of the *Treasured Writ of Earth’s Yin*. If nineteen correspond, it is the *Treasured Record of Earth’s Yin*. If eighteen correspond, it is the *Disordered Writ of Earth*—unfit for regular use. Anything below this is heretical script, harmful writings of the common folk. To verify their truth, record past events and compare them with later outcomes; only then will true and false be distinguished. Know that my writings are like Heaven’s *jia* and Earth’s *yi*, unalterable for ten thousand generations. The root matters of burial and residence, where human life is nurtured, must not be treated lightly. Once affairs are settled carelessly, heretical writings bring harm, causing disasters and misfortunes to arise frequently, bringing great suffering to the worthy and the people. Thus, whether noble or humble, those who wish their descendants to inherit in perpetuity must carefully examine the hills and mounds, clearly discern their principles, and divine future events. Take twenty-five burial mounds as the foundational text, compare them with past events, and record the outcomes to validate present and future affairs. True masters should study these writings closely, dispelling confusion and delusion—this is called the *Divination of Yin’s Concealment*, which discerns how ancestors benefit their descendants, transmitting blessings for ten thousand generations. Guard this well and do not conceal it.

**Discerning the True and False in Ancient Writings, Chapter Seventy-Seven**

All music serves to convey sound and transform the qi of the six directions and eight extremes. When its tones harmonize, responses come in accord with goodness; when they do not, responses arrive in conflict and opposition. Each sound has its own affiliation—east, west, south, north, *jia*, *yi*, *bing*, *ding*—and the twenty-five qi each have their own domain. At times, sounds converge to form coherent phrases, allowing one to perceive subtle words through listening, divining fortune and misfortune. When music aligns with the *Blowing-Hair Pitch-Pipe*, the tones of strings are known. The five notes—*gong*, *shang*, *jue*, *zhi*, and *yu*—distinguish the six directions’ distances and define the auspicious or inauspicious nature of names. How so? Only the refined can perceive the spirits’ responses to events. Thus, the sages of antiquity regulated music to move all things, harmonize yin and yang, and stabilize the four seasons and five phases. When yin and yang are balanced, the sounds are pleasing to hear; when they are disharmonious, discordant and chaotic, the music is harsh, and the strings must be tuned. The silk strings should be arranged in nine-by-nine sequences, with loud and soft sounds in harmony, so as not to harm the viscera and spirit. If untuned, the dance becomes disorderly, the music loses its proper tone, and it cannot be endured, injuring the viscera and spirit—thus, numinous beings and auspicious omens do not appear. Only those who are capable and skilled in sound can harmonize yin and yang’s transformations. How is this known? When the divine and numinous respond, auspicious omens gather—such is the person. Otherwise, all is chaotic noise, incapable of moving anything, and thus no response comes. Therefore, all matters depend on finding the right person. Without the right person, even the divine is as unreliable as reckless speech. With the right person, no matter is too difficult or easy—all can be accomplished. Without the right person, no matter is too great or small—none can be done. Thus, the sages of antiquity valued action and sought the worthy without concealment, as was the way of old. With the right person, order prevails; without them, chaos reigns.

Ancient writings are too numerous to record in full. Use one matter to analogize ten, ten to analogize a hundred, a hundred to analogize a thousand, a thousand to analogize ten thousand, ten thousand to analogize a hundred million, and a hundred million to analogize the boundless. Each matter has its own category and affiliation. Place the foundational text of each matter first, so that the knowledgeable may grasp its essence, and those skilled in application may expound upon it. Examine their correspondence and harmony—what aligns is true; what does not correspond or align is false. To discern whether the ancient sages’ writings on the Dao are authentic: this is like calling a person by their surname and given name—only then will they respond. Ghosts and spirits are the same. Without the correct name, there is no response; even if one wishes to harmonize, there is no means to reach them, and thus no response. Thus, the ancients called the study of names *Attending to Essence*. Essence means focusing intently on the matter’s image and suitability, then reflecting on its words. Thoroughly contemplating these writings and strategies completes all matters. Though the texts above and below are numerous, each has its proper application. Study them carefully, supplementing one with another, to fully grasp their meaning. Without deeply understanding their essential intent, words on the Dao are ineffective, and one cannot resolve the conflicts of yin and yang’s struggles.

My writings are for the benevolent and worthy, entrusted to those of virtue. Those of virtue who receive them treat them as treasures. If received but not read well, one may dismiss them as false Dao, unable to bring joy to the self or avert calamities. When the great Dao is revealed, does it not seem insipid? Yet its use is inexhaustible. Let the worthy reflect on this: can it not harmonize hardness and softness, exhaust the positions of yin and yang? Once all writings are settled in their proper places, is there still confusion? Evil is entirely dispelled, the Supreme Lord rejoices greatly, and the people are free from misfortune. Blessings extend even to the humble, and the teeming myriad things do not lose their qi. They return to the Great Beginning, Heaven and Earth take their places, heretical writings vanish, and the primordial qi is preserved. The One is the warp of the Dao; the Two, its weft. The Three brings chaos—it cannot be made clear. My Dao follows *jiazi* and *yichou*, the six *jia* succeeding one another, the five phases following in turn, the four seasons cycling back to their origin. Though the writings are many, each has its own record.

Just as in a person, where head and feet alternately serve one another, one word departs and another arises, the worthy take their turns to fill in, harmonizing yin and yang through speech, outer and inner aligning like compass and square—at first recitation, it seems flavorless, but with time, its depth unfolds. Persist in contemplation without ceasing, and verification will come: disasters depart from the body, spirits gather anew, people naturally become prudent and virtuous, free from malevolent offspring. This is called "the absence of punishment," the ultimate beauty of Dao-transformations.

Examine my writings to avert misfortune: treachery and calamity will cease of themselves, and the people will enjoy long life. Trace back to the origin, and you find no end or beginning. The texts where ten correspond with ten are the *Taiyang* writings. Those where nineteen correspond are the *Taiyin* writings. Eighteen correspondences form the *Zhonghe* writings. Seventeen correspondences make the *Poruined* writings. Sixteen correspondences mark the *Encountering Central* writings. Fifteen correspondences are the *Ignorant* writings—these may be called half-auspicious, half-inauspicious. Fourteen correspondences denote *Heretical* writings. Thirteen correspondences signify *Great Chaos* writings. Twelve correspondences are *Abandoned* writings. Eleven correspondences are *Alternating Central* writings. Those with ten or fewer correspondences are unusable, misleading texts. The harm they inflict varies in degree, but ultimately rebounds upon the user. Prolonged use without cessation violates the law, leading to the extinction of one’s lineage and the destruction of one’s household—these are the writings of ten correspondences.

Above are the methods for repelling the heterodox and establishing the orthodox.

*Tai ping jing*, Scroll Fifty, concludes.
*Tai ping jing*, Scroll Fifty-One begins.

The fifty-second scroll is missing.

**Collating the Orthodox and Heterodox Texts, Method Seventy-Eight**
Chun prostrates in trembling reverence and bows twice.

"What further would you ask?"
"Now that I have seen the true writings of the enlightened master and the orthodox texts of the multitude—these are the discourses of Heaven—I fear and tremble, not knowing which should come first or last, nor by what means one may truly rectify these texts."

"If you wish to grasp their truth, simply examine the sacred words of the High Antiquity, the sacred words of the Middle Antiquity, and the sacred words of the Lower Antiquity. Compare their language and observe their deeds—thus may you know. Further, examine the Daoist texts of the High Antiquity, the Middle Antiquity, and the Lower Antiquity. When these three are harmonized by like calling to like, the truth becomes clear once more.

"Yet now all writings are deemed the discourses of Heaven—why then do they bring order at times and chaos at others? I wish to hear the reason."
"Indeed, those who rectify their words and clarify their texts bring order; those who do not bring chaos. Upright speech and careful phrasing必 lead to goodness; perverse speech and ominous phrasing必 lead to evil.

"You persist in questioning, and as I see your eagerness to know, I shall explain: If you wish to bring forth goodness, simply rectify the root. When the root is upright, it aligns with the celestial patterns and accords with the sacred words. In its second transformation, it aligns with earthly principles; in its third, with human culture; in its fourth, with the myriad things. Then the myriad things flourish in extravagance, and extravagance leads to chaos and ruin.

"When the celestial patterns and sacred texts emerge in their time, they serve to examine the primordial and rectify the origin, removing excess and establishing truth. To clarify all writings is the Dao of Heaven. Those who grasp upright speech align with the will of Heaven. Heterodoxy brings forth evil qi, causing Heaven and Earth to fall out of harmony, the myriad things to lose their proper places, and the emperor’s heart to be weighed down with sorrow. Chaos returns, and thus one must urgently collate and rectify these texts.

"From antiquity to the present, all writings have been compiled, yet we lament their assembly without purity, their mingling in disorder. Thus the wise and enlightened are left in doubt and confusion, not knowing what to follow or trust. They lose the utmost sincerity of Heaven and each turns to what contradicts it. This causes their intentions to diverge far from the subtle and profound guidance of the Dao of Heaven. All become heterodox words and heterodox texts, written in perversity, unable to rectify yin and yang. Disasters arise in succession, and the fault lies herein.

"Seeing your persistent questioning, I cannot bear to withhold my answer. Thus I have expounded repeatedly for your sake. Quickly set down my words and ponder them deeply. For in all matters, if one obtains the truth but cannot practice it single-mindedly, it is of no benefit. If one can practice it, great calamities are averted.

"When the celestial patterns are in chaos, the desire to see order restored is like a gravely ill person longing for a cure. How can this be achieved? Are you truly so foolish as to remain ignorant? If a grave illness is not treated in time, it leads to death. If the celestial patterns are not rectified, they lead to great chaos. The four seasons lose their qi, the Five Agents turn against one another, the Three Luminaries lose their proper brightness, all deviate from their true paths, and thus perish. The people are thrown into turmoil, all lose their dwellings, the old and weak carry burdens on their backs, half die prematurely, the state falls into darkness and confusion, the supreme Dao and virtuous power are cut off, the worthy are concealed and cannot aid one another—is this not a grave illness?

"Thus one must strive to rectify it. Now, fools daily study superficial and frivolous texts, competing to contradict one another and vie for superiority, not deeply understanding the great harm they cause, dismissing it as a trifling matter. How could they know that within, it is a grave illness for yin and yang and Heaven and Earth? The world’s inability to rectify itself stems precisely from this.

"The spirits and deities suffer from this affliction, which is why they have sent you to question me repeatedly. You should ponder their essential meaning day and night, without negligence, for this is no light matter before the August Heaven. Now, the emperor has no place to turn his heart—his fault is grave indeed.

"Though I speak with you now as but two individuals, within, I am rectifying the discourse for the August Heaven. I dare not speak carelessly or in vain, for the fault would rest upon me, and the sin would be too heavy to absolve. The punishments of the spirits and deities cannot be evaded or escaped like those of mortals.

"Do you dare to follow my light words as if they were mere worldly chatter, competing for superiority? Truly, I dare not."
Chun, hearing the words of the Heavenly Master, trembles yet rejoices. "I shall exert all my strength, hoping to align with the will of the spirits and deities, to relieve the world’s sorrows, pacify the emperor, and allow the myriad things to each find their proper place. This is my wish."
"Do you wish only for your own goodness, unable to extend it further?"
"The reason I alone have maintained good intentions is that my learning stems from reflecting on goodness. Thus, while others all grow old and perish, I alone remain. My ancestors’ descendants have all passed away, yet I alone have not died. Truly, I have received a profound mandate, and I am ashamed before the August Heaven, unable to repay it. I constantly think of exhausting my strength, yet I do not know how to make amends.

"Seeing Heaven and Earth out of harmony and wind and rain unregulated, I know it is a grave illness for the world, and I pity it. Now, having heard the words of the divine person, I am greatly awakened. I wish to devote myself to the death to serve the enlightened Heaven, to resolve the great illness and pacify the earthly principles, thereby aiding the emperor and allowing the myriad things to each find their proper place. In this way, I may repay the profound merit of Heaven. Yet I do not know if I am capable or not. I humbly ask further, for I fall short of the enlightened master."
"Excellent are your words! Hearing them now, I rejoice—what need is there to speak of Heaven? My words are flawless, not one in ten thousand is lost. You need only strive diligently without slackening to rectify them—this can restore the merit of Heaven, and there is no doubt. If the emperor practices this, he will swiftly gain its power—how much more so for you? Seeing your words, I dare not hold back my strength."

Though I am your elder, my aspirations do not match yours. Now, as we both share this Heaven and Earth, I wish to join you in pacifying them. I would prefer not to speak, yet I fear I would incur greater fault with you and suffer heavier punishment from Heaven. Listen carefully once more, and I shall explain it to you again in full detail, turning it over and back.

The correct text embodies the heart of Heaven and Earth, preserving the primal qi and its principles. In ancient times, sacred texts emerged in their seasons; examining their original characters and proper forms, the Dao was transmitted through mutual dependence. Subtle words and explanations—all were essential to the primal qi. The second transmission contains esoteric phrases; the third forms chapters and verses; the fourth becomes florid embellishment; the fifth diverges into disparate meanings, each asserting its own opposition; the sixth becomes deceptive rhetoric. Even in chapters and verses, only a small portion retains the original intent. Beyond this lies grave illness, causing the Dao of Heaven to lose its way. For this reason, emperors and kings have long suffered, unable to deeply grasp its principles.

You, fortunate one, wish to repay Heaven’s grace and restore its profound merit. Heaven does not delight in people offering their wealth or rare and counterfeit goods; it delights only in people ordering its texts without confusion. When I first saw you come to study, I thought you would ask but one or two things before leaving—how could I have imagined you would seek to master the Dao of Heaven in its entirety? Though my words may not be perfect, the Dao of Heaven can already be glimpsed through them.

If you delight in ordering Heaven and Earth, take the subtle words and trace them back to their origins, aligning them with their primal essence—thus you will grasp the heart and intent of Heaven and may pacify the world. Collate the texts of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, summoning them by category to assemble their correspondences. Let one who holds to the root oversee the work, for each text has its own fundamental matter. All written works belong to distinct lineages; let ordinary people each contribute their talents, gathering to discuss the two interpretations. The original matter, the true nature of the characters, and the factual essence will all emerge of themselves. Gather the essential words within and fashion them into explanations—these are the chapters and verses, wherein the true heart of the Dao is found.

This may be called resolving Heaven’s anxieties; the great illness is dispelled. This may be called removing the sufferings of the earth. This may be called allowing the emperor to wander in harmony with the heart of Heaven. This may be called enabling the myriad things to each find their proper place. In this, not one in ten thousand is lost.

I see from your words, spoken so earnestly, that you are Heaven’s messenger—I dare not deceive you. To deceive you now would be to deceive Heaven itself. Should Heaven grow displeased, it would shorten my years, bringing harm upon my person, and I would stand ashamed before the August Sky, all while failing the myriad people. The fault would be grave indeed. Strive to remember this: know only that I dare not hold back the least effort.

“Yes, yes,” came the reply. Hearing the master’s words, the heart trembled with awe.

Since this is a matter Heaven has inquired about, I dare not delay or halt—only press on to its completion. May the master graciously pardon my shortcomings and show me what is difficult and what is easy, that I may venture to ask in full.

Now, the written works have accumulated in great number, and I wish to discern their truth or falsehood. Yet the principle remains as you asked before: what resonates in tenfold or hundredfold accord is true; what does not is false. What is governed and yields response is true; what does not is but deceitful practice. To obtain such response, the people and ministers must all be good, loyal, and trustworthy.

Why say this? If a child is virtuous, parents remain at peace, finding their rightful place. If a wife is good, her husband commits no transgressions, gaining her strength. If a minister is upright, the state enjoys enduring stability. When emperor, king, people, and ministers are all good, Heaven sends no calamities or omens—this is the very truth of it.

Do you understand? Or do you not?

Come now, I wish to discuss a matter with you. If you deem my writings worthy of selection, would you thoroughly examine and master them? You are but a youth of unopened understanding and have not yet grasped their meaning.

Try to speak of it, and I shall observe whether you fully comprehend. My humble thought is this: I wish to compile and unify all that is useful, so that high and low may complement one another. We shall take each matter, compare a hundred to a thousand, a thousand to ten thousand, and cross-examine them to ensure sufficiency. Otherwise, I fear we cannot fully encompass the ancient texts.

What you say now is truly correct.

Have you not recorded in my writings that one is compared to ten, ten to a hundred, a hundred to a thousand, a thousand to ten thousand, and ten thousand to a hundred million? This is precisely the principle.

Indeed, indeed.

Whom should we employ to carry out this collation? Each shall attend to their proper role. Those who are clear about the fundamentals shall rely upon them. Those skilled in knowledge and application shall gather together to expound upon them, circulating their discourse from the emperor and kings down to the common people. All shall abandon their former practices and come together in unified deliberation.

Those of lesser understanding shall first gather among themselves, then submit to those of middling understanding. Those of middling understanding shall gather and submit to those of greater understanding, and those of greater understanding shall gather and submit to the emperor and kings. Then, all the worthy shall assemble to harmonize and refine their discourse, ensuring stability. This is how counsel reaches even the lowest, leaving no calculation unconsidered, no word abandoned, and no text discarded.

The lesser worthy shall gather and collate, then submit to the middling worthy. The middling worthy shall collate and submit to the great worthy, and the great worthy shall collate and submit to the emperor and kings. When the principles and texts are thus orally and textually perfected without error, truly aligning with the heart of Heaven and the division of yin and yang, the emperor, kings, and all ministers shall together recognize their authenticity. Only then shall they be disseminated among the people.

Let the entire world recite and read the correct texts. Thus shall the qi of Heaven be attained, Great Peace arrive, the qi of Supreme Peace descend, songs of praise arise, all things enjoy enduring stability, the hundred clans fall silent, heterodox texts vanish of themselves, the ailments of Heaven be cured, the afflictions of Earth disappear, the emperor and kings wander in ease, yin and yang rejoice, perverse qi withdraw, bandits and thieves be cut off, the Central Kingdom flourish and rise, and its glory equal that of the Three Sovereigns of antiquity. The barbarians shall retreat, all things thrive in abundance, and the world be most fortunate, all acclaiming "ten thousand years!"

Do not conceal or obstruct my writings.

Indeed, indeed, I dare not hide or withhold them.

Having received the master’s instructions, I truly report and return them in earnest, for to conceal them would risk incurring grave transgression. Well said, your words are most excellent. You have already aligned with the heart of Heaven, and your name shall be recorded as one who has repaid Heaven’s profound merit. Indeed, indeed. Truly, I may now retire to a quiet place to ponder their deepest meaning, never slackening in diligence. Go forth, and doubt no more.

[End of Textual Verification]

*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 51 concludes.
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll 53: "Distinguishing the Four Methods of Governance" #79

The Perfected One, Pure and Reverent, bows in trembling reverence. I now wish to pose a further question, though it may not pertain to the Dao. Having witnessed the Illuminated Master resolve every matter without fail, I dare, despite my shame, to step forward once more to ask of a single doubt: what is it? Speak plainly, and I shall explain it to you.

The ministers of emperors and kings ought all to be elders; the young are fundamentally unfit to govern the world. Why do you ask this? I observe the qi of Heaven—of late, it has repeatedly fallen into disharmony. The fault may lie with officials who fail in their duties, causing the seasonal qi to fall out of balance. The sovereign lacks clarity, disasters multiply, and even Daoists suffer harm. Now, the Three Luminaries of Heaven and Earth themselves are afflicted—where can a true and enlightened Daoist flee to escape unscathed? Thus, though I alone have long been favored by Heaven’s grace, I dare not presume my own safety. From my earliest years, I have sought instruction from masters, yet none could fully resolve my questions. Today, I dare not shrink from shame and must once more inquire of the Heavenly Master, that he may clarify the essential meaning, lest I never come to understand it. Out of kindness, the Illuminated Master cannot refuse and must explain to his disciple what he has not yet grasped.

Well said, your words are most excellent. From what you have spoken today, I know that the governance of Great Peace is already at hand. Nevertheless, I shall explain it all in full; you must record it in detail.

There are four methods of governance: the governance of Heaven, the governance of Earth, the governance of Man, and when the three qi reach their utmost, the governance of the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth. I wish to hear their meaning.

The governance of Heaven: its ministers are elders, and the ruler treats them as fathers and teachers. Though ministers hold lowly positions, why treat them as fathers and teachers? While their rank may be humble, their virtue and power are most exalted. To treat them as fathers and teachers is to honor their virtue and power, to join with them in counsel and bring peace to the world.

The governance of Earth: the ruler befriends his ministers, as if sharing the same aspirations and heart. Earth is yin and compliant, like mother and child standing side by side, sharing the same embrace and sorrows. Though ministers may hold lowly positions, their virtue brings harmony, pacifying the ruler’s governance.

The governance of Man: it diminishes their utility. Ministers are young and small, like a father’s young child, who cannot yet devise strategies for his father. Thus, their governance is slightly disordered.

The governance of the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth: the ruler regards his ministers and people as dogs or grass and trees, no longer carefully selecting them for office. He merely fills positions as they arise, as if mimicking men without understanding. Why is this? Those who mimic men merely resemble human form but act carelessly, without regard for the ruler’s interests. Thus, they engage in constant strife.

To emulate the governance of Heaven: the ministers of the world become the ruler’s fathers and teachers, and so he treats them as fathers. A man loves his child—what danger could there be in such times? Fathers and teachers can resolve the crises of the eight directions—how could there be any misfortune?

To emulate the governance of Earth: the ministers of the world become the ruler’s friends. Sharing the same aspirations and strategies, they unite in bearing sorrows and hardships, seeking to secure their positions together. Earth is compliant and upholds what is above, fully aligning with Heaven’s will and heart—how could there be any time of instability?

To emulate the governance of Man: it attains the qi of harmony, which is difficult to discern, advancing or retreating unpredictably. It resembles a young child who cannot yet plan for his father and thus deceives him. Ministers who are young cannot deeply consider the ruler’s interests and so deceive him. The young have seen little of the sun and moon, their learning is shallow, and they inspire no awe—thus they deceive, and their governance is slightly disordered.

To emulate the governance of the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth: such creatures lack propriety and righteousness, and the myriad things possess little understanding and no virtue or power. The nature of creatures that walk upon the earth is without hierarchy, seeking only to prevail—thus, their governance leads to chaos and ruin.

The governance of Heaven is benevolent, cherishing life and avoiding harm. The governance of Earth is compliant and good, though it may cause minor harm. The governance of Man is mutually beneficial and desirous, often leading to mutual injury, deceit, and negligence. The governance of the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth ultimately achieves no success, regardless of scale, seeking only to prevail.

Observing these methods of governance, one can discern whether the qi of Heaven—above, below, and at the center—has lost its proper order. Those who desire the highest joy should emulate the governance of Heaven; those who desire the second joy should emulate the governance of Earth; those who desire the third joy should emulate the governance of Man; and those who desire the fourth joy should emulate the governance of the myriad creatures.

Those who emulate Heaven alone enjoy long life and align with Heaven’s heart. Those who emulate Earth enjoy slightly shorter lives and align with Earth’s intent. Those who emulate Man have diminished lifespans, while those who emulate the myriad creatures die unpredictably and without number.

Those who emulate Heaven practice the Three Ways of written communication. Heaven possesses three luminous texts, forming the Three Illuminations: the sun, the moon, and the arrayed stars. The sun examines yang, the moon examines yin, and the stars examine the center. Thus, the Three Ways of written communication must be employed, striving to attain wisdom and clarity. When documents are sent, they bear the name of the sender alone, without inquiring who the recipient may be.

Those who emulate Earth practice the Two Ways of written communication. Those who emulate Man practice the One Way of written communication, yet still appear to linger carelessly. Those who emulate the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth merely utter words without any written documents.

Is this the will of Heaven, or do men act of their own accord? Is it the work of fate? Nevertheless, when an emperor or king governs toward Great Peace, he should follow Heaven’s will, delighting in goodness and joy, emulating the governance of Heaven. For those aiming at moderate peace, emulate the governance of Earth. For those facing minor disorder, follow the governance of Man. For those facing great chaos and ungovernability, follow the governance of the myriad creatures that walk upon the earth.

Why is this so? And how should it be remedied?

Now, when Heaven intends to exalt a ruler, auspicious omens and sacred texts emerge, bestowed upon him to awaken his profound understanding and entrust him with their wisdom. When decline is imminent, Heaven conceals these texts, ensuring they remain unseen, and further causes the ruler to lose all desire to seek them.

Are worthy ministers merely those who grow old in service? No. To grow old is to be venerable and seasoned, aged in virtue and power, emulating Heaven’s singular constancy in upholding the Dao and acting without the slightest deviation. Thus can they bring stability to their emperor or king. Yet one who grows old without a single insight is unfit for office.

What, then, of one who serves as a father to the ruler? Or as a friend? Or as a son? And what of the myriad creatures?

To serve as a father is to receive instruction as a son does from his stern father, or as a disciple does from his enlightened master. One must grasp the ruler’s innermost strategies and secret sagely writings, employing them to pacify the realm, repay the ancestors, and offer sacrifices in the ancestral temple. By this virtue, one repays Heaven’s profound merit, thereby winning the hearts of all under Heaven. Yin and yang harmonize, and disasters cease.

To serve as a friend is to join in loyalty and trust, devising strategies together and deeply weighing good and evil, ease and difficulty.

To serve as a son is to conceal matters as a father might hide something from his child, or as a child might conceal a fault from his parents—each deceiving the other, using this as a means to an end.

As for the myriad creatures: in times of great chaos, they are countless. In spring and summer, they contend for life; in autumn and winter, they contend for death, granting one another no respite.

Chun bows twice. Your questions are many and earnest, far exceeding what is proper—indeed, they surpass even what is due to a master. Yet I dare not conceal these texts. To see them and fail to act would risk offending August Heaven.

Where, then, should I place this book? Since you have asked, you must exert yourself to carry it forth. When you encounter one who can comprehend it, entrust it to him, that he may deliver it to a virtuous ruler. If the emperor or king models his governance upon it, his rule will surely be divine.

Yet if one receives it but fails to ponder and apply it deeply, Heaven will hold him no further accountable.

“Indeed, I dare not oppose my master’s words.”

Still, my words must not be greatly contradicted. For Heaven and Earth desire peace and have revealed this supreme Dao, sending you from afar to inquire of this method. Heaven has commanded me to speak, to transmit these words to you, and I do not speak in vain. Were Heaven unwilling, and I still spoke, recklessly divulging its essential Dao, I would incur punishment. But if you take my words and deliver them, you shall suffer no harm or doubt.

I tell you this in utmost sincerity: Heaven will bestow even greater favor upon the emperor or king, and thus I warn you. Heaven’s course has its appointed times for fortune and misfortune. Those who obtain this and act upon it shall know good fortune without doubt.

I humbly ask: who is the one who will carry this forth? What is his name?

Heaven bestows upon all things without partiality. The one who first delights in practicing it—that is the person.

The Great Dao is most weighty and cannot be entrusted to private hands. To practice it is auspicious; to neglect it is to invite doubt.

I humbly ask again: what do Heaven and Earth observe? What do they witness? Is there but a single word to be spoken?

Truly, there is something to be observed and witnessed—this is no empty speech. Heaven rejoices in tranquility and peace, free from illness, and delights in perfect equilibrium. Thus it ensures that the people remain serene, without evil words or strife, each dwelling in their proper place. Then there is no illness, and joy abounds, so Heaven speaks without falsehood.

But if yin and yang clash in opposition, disrupting and harming one another, if all things cannot abide in their proper places, if the sun and moon lose their clarity and the stars stray from their courses, then Heaven is afflicted with illness, distressed and unresolved. It does not transmit its words, and the malady persists.

Thus, in times of disorder, discourse arises—minor disorder calls for minor discourse, and great disorder calls for great discourse. From ancient times to the present, divine perfected sages have served as Heaven’s envoys, receiving Heaven’s intent and acting as its voice to speak for Heaven and Earth. Since Heaven and Earth established their work, this has been the constant principle. The writings of sages, past and present, are Heaven’s discourse, Heaven’s words and affairs.

What, then, are these words and discourses? They address the sufferings and hardships of the age. Those who lose the essence of the Dao are its substance; those who lack understanding are its refinement. To condemn evil and wickedness is to rectify and perfect the Dao, awakening the people.

Yet Heaven and Earth are most exalted and divine, capable of illuminating the highest positions. Why do they not eliminate their own afflictions, instead transmitting words through men?

Heaven and Earth are the parents of the myriad things. Though the parents may be good, if their children act wickedly, dwelling at the center and presiding over their perversity, if governance above and below is inverted and chaotic, then even good parents become a troubled household. It is like a son who brings disorder to his father, a minister who brings disorder to his ruler, a disciple who brings disorder to his master, or a wife who brings disorder to her husband. Such mutual harm and great chaos obscure all goodness.

Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things originally share a single endeavor. When good prevails, all rejoice; when misfortune strikes, all suffer. Thus they share a common sorrow. If they did not share this endeavor, they would not take turns bearing one another’s burdens.

Therefore, when Heaven and Earth desire goodness and peace, they must employ divine perfected sages to transmit their words, revealing sacred texts to convey their message. This is like an emperor or king who, wishing to delight in goodness, issues good teachings—such is the meaning here.

If you wish to delight in knowing Heaven’s intent, to repay Heaven’s merit, and to rescue the realm from baleful qi, then this book is the answer. Obtain it, ponder it deeply, and Heaven’s intent will be known.

“Indeed, I dare not be negligent.”

I hope my master will offer one or two more instructions.

Now, good and evil each pertain to the self. The good benefit themselves; the wicked harm their own bodies. Since you possess such a fervent desire for goodness and grieve over Heaven and Earth’s afflictions and the ruler’s unrest, your merit is already vast.

But ponder this carefully: your practice of goodness is unparalleled—do not grieve over it again, and let your devotion to goodness remain constant as it is now.

“Indeed, I dare not grow lax, dare not grow lax.”

**[Section on the Symbols of Stability and Peril in the Four Governances]**

*Here concludes Scroll Fifty-Three of the* Classic of Great Peace. *#1 According to the Dunhuang manuscript* Catalog of the *Classic of Great Peace*, *this chapter should be titled* “Distinguishing the Four Governances, Part Eighty.” *The preceding Scroll Fifty-Two,* “The Yin-Yang Formula of Embryonic Transformation, Part Seventy-Nine,” *is missing. The lacuna appears in* A Collated Edition of the *Classic of Great Peace*, *Scroll Fifty-Two.*

**Scroll Fifty-Four of the** *Classic of Great Peace*
**Method for Preventing Litigation, Part Eighty-One**

I have asked many questions, and the Heavenly Master’s responses flow without end—my inquiries know no bounds. I humbly beg for one or two more instructions.

Proceed.

Now, I wish to understand the intent of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the aspirations of the people and all creatures, and the essence of all things, so that they may perpetually delight in goodness, wander freely without duties or affairs, each correcting themselves, no longer turning to mutual sorrow and reproach. Might I hear how this may be achieved?

You now ask: what is the most singularly excellent and extraordinary question? What is the unparalleled devotion to goodness?

If your inquiry is as you describe, then matters should follow their natural course, each attaining their heart’s desire. One should act according to their abilities, never forcing what lies beyond their capacity. In this way, each obtains what they seek. When each obtains their desire, none will suffer sorrow. Then, each attains their heart’s intent and may be said to wander without duties. Between Heaven and Earth, if one is constantly compelled to act beyond their ability, forced to do what they cannot, and burdened with what they cannot bear—if, when they fail to act or speak, they are not shown compassion and taught but instead reproached, their grievances will fester. Resentment and litigation will multiply, the people will suffer in distress and poverty, and they will lift their voices to Supreme Heaven, crying, “Truly, we are wronged! Truly, we are wronged!” Their qi will stir the six directions. Thus, disasters and anomalies will arise in profusion, accumulating in myriad forms, impossible to swiftly eradicate. The harm will be severe, for this is to lose the hearts of all under Heaven. In the end, no success will be achieved, and strange omens will never cease. How then can the qi of Great Peace arise? Thus, Great Peace cannot be attained—this is precisely the fault.

Though one may claim to govern with constant equanimity, if internal chaos persists, how can the realm be purified? You now ask this, wishing to know it thoroughly.

The nature of Heaven and Earth is such that all things have their proper place. One should employ their strengths and abilities, but never force what they cannot do. Though all things receive the qi of yin and yang, it is like fish that cannot live without water—they cannot swim upon high mountains. Yet when water is present, regardless of depth or shallowness, they can swim freely. Great trees cannot grow without soil—they cannot thrive in the midst of rivers and seas. Thus, the sage-kings of antiquity, when assigning tasks, selected from the five types of soil according to their suitability. Only then did things flourish and prosper, the state grew wealthy, the ancestral temples offered rich flavors, and all under Heaven enjoyed peace without suffering. Baleful qi ceased to spread and cause harm.

If one does not divine and assess the land before planting, the myriad things will fail to complete their natural lifespan. They will harbor unresolved grievances, die prematurely, and their distress will ascend to move Supreme Heaven. Nothing will be reaped, the state will grow impoverished, food will lack richness, the ancestral temples will hunger and thirst, and all under Heaven will suffer. The people will turn to mutual harm, ruler and minister will deceive one another, and internal and external affairs will diverge in speech. This is where the fault truly begins. If even the myriad things cannot find their proper place, how much more so for humans? The world cannot be governed rightly—this is the reason.

This is the root of great harm, the path to peril and ruin. How can one not be cautious? How can one not ponder it deeply in their heart?

Thus, the great sages and worthies of antiquity, when appointing officials, first tested their strengths and weaknesses before assigning them duties. They entrusted them accordingly. If a person erred, they reproached them, but only regarding their strengths, never their shortcomings. This does not offend Heaven. Instead, it encourages the refinement of their learning, and thus they gain the hearts of all under Heaven.

In later ages, matters were neglected. People did not deeply reflect on the words of the ancient sages. Instead, they appointed people to positions beyond their competence, reproached them for what they could not achieve, and questioned them on what they could not perceive. The blind cannot see the sun, the mute cannot speak—yet they hastened to expose their shortcomings, treating them as grave faults, and punished them. They did not seek to bring joy and mutual benefit but instead engaged in cunning manipulation, harming one another in turn. This is the great ruin of all under Heaven.

The lords of antiquity who brought Great Peace possessed no extraordinary divine methods. They simply employed people according to their abilities and hearts’ desires, and thus they summoned the qi of Great Peace without grievances among the people. When calamity and chaos arise, it is always because people are assigned tasks beyond their competence, forced to perform duties unsuited to them, and heavily reproached. Even if punished with death, they cannot fulfill their duties. Disasters will arise in succession, impossible to suppress, leading to ruin and defeat. Good and ill fortune, safety and peril—all originate here.

Thus, when the ancients selected officials for the emperor or king, they first examined and tested their abilities, determining whether they aligned with the auspicious responses of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang. Those who did not align were deemed false in conduct. How does one achieve such alignment? Great persons receive great responses, lesser persons receive lesser responses. Wind and rain arrive in their proper seasons, the myriad things flourish and thrive, the people are free from complaint, and birds and beasts move and act in tranquility. These are the signs.

Thus, those who govern with music and desire to pacify the state must carefully examine their appointments. For Heaven generates the myriad things, each endowed with its own talents and capacities, each suited to its proper place—just as dragons ascend to the heavens and fish swim in the depths. This is what is meant.

Since the establishment of Heaven and Earth, governance has taken myriad forms, and the transformations of Heaven shift with the times. The essential principle is to accord with the intent of Heaven and Earth, fulfilling what they desire. Heaven uses the Three Luminaries as its script and records, marking cycles of rise and decline, with wind as the sovereign. Earth employs mountains and rivers, fields and paths as its veins and textures; mountains exhale qi, waters flow through channels, and their decline, flourishing, movement, collapse, and convergence are reflected in the winds and anomalies of ministers. Humans transmit through speech and language, their writings and records evolving over time. The myriad things speak through their flourishing and decline, allowing people to perceive and understand them.

Humans stand at the center of yin and yang, serving as the teachers and leaders of the myriad things. Their abilities are most numerous, embodying the spirit while possessing form, advancing and retreating in transformation. They must meticulously record these changes and report them to their sovereign. Thus, if one matter is not communicated, grievances accumulate; if two are obstructed, blockages arise; if three are cut off, isolation follows; if four are unaddressed, harmony fails to respond, and the generation of things becomes irregular. If five are uncommunicated, the circulation of qi and the Dao falters; if six are obstructed, the six directions breed malice; if seven are cut off, ruin ensues; if eight are unaddressed, governance becomes fragmented among factions; if nine are obstructed, mutual harm arises; if ten are uncommunicated, mutual upheaval follows. Therefore, one must strive to ensure the free flow of communication.

In ancient times, when there was no writing, how was communication achieved? Writing arose precisely for this purpose. Yet how often does it align with Heaven and Earth, how often does it cease? Later generations simply have not witnessed it. In the middle antiquity of the Three Sovereigns, words were established without writing. In later antiquity, the qi of Heaven and Earth rose and fell in cycles, and only divine beings, untouched by age, knew their origins. Through many vicissitudes, they understood that inherent patterns must contain writing, though later generations have not seen it. Why, then, does writing sometimes exist and sometimes not? As Heaven’s qi declines, people grow foolish, feeble, and short-lived, unable to inscribe records. Thus, writing was commanded to enable transmission across time, preserving knowledge of antiquity. Without writing, disputes could not be settled, each party claiming rightness, so writing was instituted. This was due to the foolishness of the age, and thus writing was created, as Heaven issued its covenant.

Having heard the master’s words, I now understand. I wish to know: how should one ensure the free flow of qi today? Simply let the Three Dao circulate the writings of the eight directions, and let the words of officials and commoners alike not be arbitrarily delayed. Urgent matters should be resolved in their time; non-urgent ones may follow the rhythms of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. After seven months, when things reach their end, review them in the eighth month, reorder them in the ninth, and by the tenth month, those unresolved should be recorded. After three years, those whose records demonstrate utmost sincerity should be sought out and appointed. Such individuals are the state’s finest ministers—keen of hearing and sight, able to observe and listen without fail to the signs of the four directions. When the emperor or king obtains them, the state is at peace and enlightened; thus, they must be entrusted.

How, then, should they be entrusted? Each must be questioned about the extent of their abilities, allowing them to record what they can do, what they can resolve, and what they excel in. Appoint them according to their innate nature, and their governance will be without error. Thus, they will win the hearts of all under Heaven, and their rule will daily advance toward Great Peace—without punishments, without scarcity, without grievances. Heaven and Earth will achieve perfect harmony, all things flowing freely. This is how one attains the longevity of the Supreme Sovereign. Those who live long do so because they avoid punishment and harm; those who inflict much harm bring it back upon themselves.

Thus, in high antiquity, the sagely and worthy refused to favor punishments. In middle antiquity, punishments were used sparingly, so longevity was halved. In later antiquity, punishments were used extensively, so longevity was greatly diminished. Punishment is an evil that offends Heaven, disrupts yin and yang, and accumulates as malevolent qi, returning to harm people. The sages of high antiquity avoided its heavy use out of care for their own lives. The people of middle antiquity were half foolish, lightly employing punishments, and thus half destroyed themselves. The people of later antiquity were greatly foolish, treating punishments as routine, and thus most did not attain longevity. The fault lies here.

Those who read this scripture should reflect on it repeatedly, valuing and heeding it. Life and death are weighty matters; they must not be treated lightly. A worthy and wise son plans deeply for his father; a worthy and wise minister plans deeply for his sovereign. An unworthy son does not plan deeply for his father; an unworthy minister does not plan for his sovereign. The young of today—are they not their own selves? The fortunes and misfortunes that befall them are the legacy of these patterns for later generations.

Therefore, when the sagely emperors and kings of high antiquity appointed ministers, they carefully selected those of Dao and virtue who did not delight in killing or harm. This was not merely for the sake of the people but for their own deep well-being. Thus, they aligned with the hearts of Heaven and Earth, their actions moving as if in concert with the spirits. This is what is meant by "careful selection yielding the right person"—a ruler who gains the strength of others. Such rulers move the gods and spirits, and the true spirits of Heaven above come to love them, granting them unique longevity. Those who favor punishments align with yin qi, and yin is killing; thus, they do not attain great longevity. The decree of Heaven is discernible and knowable—what Heaven, Earth, and humans detest is the same.

To the right: Those who win the hearts of Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things, whose states prosper and families are secure, whose realm knows no disputes—this is the conclusion of *The Scripture on Great Peace*, Scroll Fifty-Four.
Here ends *The Scripture on Great Peace*, Scroll Fifty-Five.

**Forceful Practice and Broad Learning, Formula Eighty-Two**

Now, can the great mandate be known or not? Though it may be known, having met an enlightened teacher and heard their words, the greatest delusions are already dispelled—yet still, out of necessity, I wish to reiterate this earnestly.

Thus, the intent of my Dao may be discerned. Those who obtain these writings and read them often lament their lack of mastery; only the mastered may fully comprehend them. Without profound reflection on their deepest meaning, without meticulous study, even possessing these writings brings no benefit. To obtain them yet fail to practice forcefully—how does this differ from never having obtained them? To see food yet not eat—how does this differ from having no grain? To see broth yet not drink—thirst remains unquenched. This does not harm others but harms oneself—can one not be cautious?

Therefore, the sage exerts forceful thought, the noble person exerts forceful study, day and night without ceasing, delighting in emulating Heaven, which revolves unceasingly. The hundred rivers flow and gather to form the great seas. Heed my words, remember my repeated admonitions—your heart’s devotion may be seen.

Do good and share it with the worthy; take care not to monopolize the market. For if the market has few, what one seeks cannot be obtained. Thus, those who do not study broadly cannot see clearly. This is why, though one may glimpse the true Dao, its essential meaning remains elusive. Without faith in the Dao, doubt lingers—each person’s self-imposed limitation lies herein. Therefore, one must deeply ponder its intent to enable self-rescue and assistance.

**To the right: Pointers on Longevity and Life Span.**

---

**Knowing Prosperity and Decline, the Method of Restoring Years and Lifespan, Formula Eighty-Three**

Heaven bestows affairs, each with its own laws. Mandates may be entrusted, the Dao may be practiced; some emerge sooner, some later, their signs gradually appearing. It is like the myriad things: sprouting at *zi*, growing at *mao*, branching at *wu*, ripening at *you*, and ending at *hai*. Though signs appear in advance, they cannot be guaranteed.

Each affair has its moment of action. When the first glimmers of light appear, though the matter is not yet at hand, its path is prepared in advance. Heaven’s portents always precede, never following behind. When the right person is found and the way is opened, they receive aid and support. Without opening, without passage, no success is achieved—this is not the right person.

This serves as clear evidence. The Dao is precise in its pronouncements; ten thousand times, not once does it err. If it is the right person, the way is opened for them; if not, it remains closed. When the right person is found, illnesses may be dispelled, calamities and omens vanish of themselves, barbarians submit without need of arms, and all dissipates naturally.

The generation of the myriad things has its own arrangements. With the right person, it unfolds of itself; without, it withdraws. In all matters, without the right person, one cannot force action. What is not theirs cannot be forcibly taken; what is not their land cannot be forcibly planted. If planted, it will not grow. To speak of poor seeds—if they do not find their proper place within, how can they endure? The six directions and eight quarters each have their suitability; their phenomena appear differently in each.

For example, the Metal phase resides in the West, the Wood phase in the East. Each thrives in its proper place and perishes when misplaced. Thus, the myriad things take root in the earth to live; they cannot take root in Heaven. The sun, moon, stars, and celestial stems and branches, by contrast, attach to Heaven to generate light.

The Dao is like this. When the right person exists, stars in the sky shine brightly; if they fall to earth, they lose their light—this is not their proper place, and thus the constant Dao is disrupted. What can be done does not proceed recklessly. If it is the right person, it becomes clear; if not, it cannot be enacted.

The Dao is profound and distant, beyond measure. Those who lose it fail; those who attain it prosper. To know one’s own prosperity and decline, observe where the Dao takes root—spiritual numina may then flourish. Within, there are signs of longevity; by this, not once in ten thousand times is there error.

This is a divine scripture, a method for restoring years. Its Dao is of utmost importance—how can one not ponder it? Therefore, transmit it to the benevolent and wise, testing them to see if they may preserve their lives.

When the right person appears, worthies and sages emerge together, divine scriptures arrive, and extraordinary methods arise of themselves, bringing joy to all—this is the right person. This is the proof. If it does not accord with these words, though signs may appear first, they cannot be enacted.

It is to be passed to later generations; the Dao does not emerge recklessly. There are those for whom it is fitting—only ask the person to reflect for themselves. The Dao’s return cannot be forbidden, nor can it be compelled. One must allow it to proceed as it will, observing its success. The Dao cannot be empty.

Nevertheless, talent is not as good as effort, and effort is not as good as unceasing action. All affairs under Heaven are tested through trial and failure. Heaven, Earth, and the spirits all test people; thus, people emulate the Heavenly Dao in testing one another.

Those who encounter goodness—their mandate is already good. Those who encounter evil—their mandate is already doubtful. From ancient times to the present, nothing moves Heaven except utmost sincerity. To demand forcefully is called coercion; though one may sometimes obtain it thus, what is coerced is not truly theirs. How can it be forcibly taken? Such affairs are not harmonious and good, but discordant and chaotic.

Human mandates have three grades. Entrust the Dao to the wilderness, to those capable of using it. For those incapable, entrust it to the capital, place it in the marketplace—take care not to cut it off, lest later generations have no heirs. Transmit the scriptures to sages, worthies, and Daoists. Without a master, without a name, entrust them to those who can use them.

The Dao has its own fitting recipients; it cannot be given to just anyone. It may be conveyed through words. Like great trees returning to the mountains, like water flowing to the sea—it cannot be stopped. This is the nature of Heaven. Those who follow it prosper; those who oppose it perish.

Divine scriptures seek to emerge; they cannot be concealed. With the right person, they will surely manifest. Without, they remain dark, deaf, and blind—body unjoyful, eyes without light. To study this text with focus brings delight.

All that pertains to the flourishing of Heaven and the extension of life’s span lies herein.

The qi of Great Peace has already manifested in full. The people’s kindness, love, reverence, and goodness all arise from it. The wise and sagely rejoice in it. Rare texts from distant lands have all been entrusted to it. Strive to practice without slack, and thereby strengthen yourself. Enlightened kings and sagely rulers all flourish through it. Barbarians retreat and submit, all departing from it.

The myriad people are most fortunate, all without complaint. Heaven’s mandate of longevity is now in effect; none bring suffering upon themselves. The old depart according to fate, while the young are preserved whole.

This scripture will be transmitted through ten thousand generations without end. Descendants will pass it down, teaching one another day by day. It is called the True Text, unchanging through all ages, bringing good fortune to all.

The Dao is now complete and naturally perfected. Blessings arrive of their own accord; none dare refuse them. The great person who obtains it governs the state with peace. The middling person who obtains it becomes a worthy minister. The humble person who obtains it escapes peril.

Above is the text that clarifies the Dao’s intent and resolves right and wrong.

*Thus concludes Scroll Fifty-Five of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Thus begins Scroll Sixty-Five of the Scripture of Great Peace*

**The Ninety-Ninth Method of Severing Metal: Military Strategy**

The Six Perfected Ones of the Six Directions, in pure reverence, bow twice and declare: We wish to inquire of the celestial laws, yet dare not speak hastily. May the August Celestial Master grant us this audience, allowing our words to be heard?

Speak without doubt.

We obey.

Now, the Celestial Master alone can resolve the inherited disasters of emperors and kings, crafting methods to exalt the sovereign and eradicate all calamities, omens, and inauspicious signs under heaven. We, though foolish, wish to assist the heavens, allowing the qi of Great Yang to shine brightly, the emperor’s power to flourish daily, treacherous cunning to be extinguished, evil men to be barred from action, bandits and thieves to vanish, and malevolent spirits to conceal themselves, never again to arise. May we hear of this?

Excellent is the question of the Six Disciples! The heavens command the Perfected Ones to speak.

We obey.

When the noble man is free from worry, the malevolent ministers and petty men dare not act. Victory is already assured, and disasters will naturally cease.

Now, I shall fully expound the celestial model for you, disciples, so that not a fraction is lost. Record it as you follow.

We obey.

Thus, the celestial laws manifest signs, which the sages of antiquity constantly emulated, never daring to transgress. They perpetually suppressed inauspicious forces, severed cunning, and prevented malevolent ministers from acting—all by adhering to the celestial laws. Their aim was to ensure the daily rise of yang qi, the radiance of fire to grow ever brighter, never knowing decline. To achieve this, they swiftly severed the qi of metal, preventing its dominion.

When metal qi is severed, wood qi gains dominion, and fire qi shines brilliantly without end. What does this mean?

The ruler must swiftly abolish weapons, for weapons belong to the category of metal. This is why they must be swiftly abolished. Yet now, rulers in their dominion frequently bestow blades and arms upon their ministers—weapons of metal, which the emperor himself grants to reign. This is called the "reign of metal." When metal reigns, it suppresses wood and weakens fire. When metal reigns, it deprives the movements of jia and yi wood of their qi. If wood is severed and yi qi is cut off, fire cannot shine. When wood reigns, earth cannot be born. If fire does not shine, earth qi rises daily, the qi of the earth stirs repeatedly, and inauspicious omens arise. Thus, they must be swiftly eradicated.

It is said: the category of weapons must not be bestowed; metal objects and arms must not be granted, for they suppress and sever inauspiciousness.

The heavens’ aversion is no different from that of the spirits. We wish to know: why does the rise of metal suppress wood, and in turn, cause fire to wane?

Excellent is your challenging question! It may be called an entry into the Dao. The Perfected Ones wish to delight in knowing its great effects. Thus, when metal weapons are deployed in spring, they injure the movements of jia and yi wood, causing the Azure Emperor of Heaven to be displeased and the Vermilion Emperor to rage greatly. Bing, ding, si, and wu become disobedient. Seeking to avenge the grievances of their parents, they compel the fire phase to act, generating many calamities, omens, inauspicious signs, malevolent harms, and treacherous cunning. The law, in reverse, causes fire to govern in chaos—is this not impermissible? The great fault lies here.

Excellent indeed!

We wish to know: why must there be many malevolent ministers, cunning treacherous men, and bandits?

I shall explain again for the Perfected Ones, so that you may clearly understand. The celestial model decrees: when parents encounter harm, their children must avenge it. Those who avenge grievances inevitably gather inauspiciousness. The deceitful, flattering, cunning, and reckless youths—those capable of lawlessness—are the ones who avenge grievances and commit rebellion.

Thus, from the bestowal of metal weapons arises the suppression of wood, and the governance of fire cannot be pacified. This is the eternal model of the heavens, not to be altered for any reason.

If the Six Perfected Ones do not believe my words, then swiftly sever metal weapons. Whoever dares to wield them shall bear grave punishment. Immediately, fire disasters will be eradicated, governance will be swiftly pacified, and all under heaven will say, "Excellent!" The reason is this: fire represents the ruler, and thus its transformations and omens are the most severe. The other four phases cannot compare.

If you wish to further know its clear effects, observe Mars, whose transformations are the most severe—this is the evident proof. The other four stars cannot compare.

Take heed of my words and writings; the celestial laws do not err by even a fraction.

We obey.

Proceeding, I shall again clarify the celestial laws for the Six Disciples. Thus, when metal qi is entirely eradicated and severed, wood qi gains great dominion, suppressing the earth phase below. Yellow qi cannot arise, and so in spring, wood reigns and earth dies.

Thus, in spring, the heavens forcibly sever metal qi at wu, allowing wood to flourish, fire qi to grow ever brighter, and metal qi to be imprisoned. Cunning men are severed and eradicated. When metal is imprisoned, water qi rests. Yin does not dare harm yang, and life below flourishes. Be cautious, and there will be no disasters or omens.

When wood qi reigns without metal, it gains ascendancy and acts. Earth qi dies. The people and ministers are loyal, reverent, and trustworthy, daring not to transgress. This is the celestial model, the contract of the heavens—a constant nature and eternal principle of heaven and earth. Do you understand?

We obey.

Proceed. You have already understood.

Now, I shall again clarify the celestial laws for the Six Disciples, to be passed down orally.

Today, the world follows weapons—metal qi. Moreover, rulers, at the beginning of the year, bestow blades and arms, or during tours of the four directions, grant metal weapons upon halting. The ruler is king, and to bestow metal weapons upon others is called "king of metal." When metal reigns, water is minister. When metal reigns, it harms wood. When water is minister, it harms fire.

The northwest is yin; the southeast is yang. When lesser yin gains dominion, greater yin becomes minister. This is called the two qi both overcoming yang. Disasters arise below, treacherous men act lawlessly, yin qi stirs and generates many false words, and bandits arise. This is the celestial model. Do the Six Disciples understand?

We obey.

Thus, the Six Perfected Ones have understood. Take heed of the celestial laws.

"Yes, yes. Now we humbly ask: the southeast is yang—why then is it called the 'Earth Gate'? And the northwest is yin—why is it called the 'Heavenly Gate'?

Indeed, gates and doors are where the qi of Heaven and Earth first arises, where all things enter and exit. Thus, the southeast is the utmost yang; when yang reaches its extreme, yin is born—hence the southeast is called the Earth Gate. The northwest is the utmost yin; when yin reaches its extreme, yang is born—hence it is called the Heavenly Gate. If the Perfected Ones wish to know its proof: when the first yang line rises at *jiazi*, and the first yin line rises at *jiawu*—this is what it means.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven is like a cycle: when it completes its circuit, it returns to the beginning. How could it ever cease? When a king takes up his mandate, the subtle qi of the corresponding phase will follow and arise.

Excellent, excellent. Let me now explain one matter fully to the Six Perfected Ones. When a ruler greatly mobilizes troops, it causes the phase of Wood to be greatly startled and lose its qi, allowing Earth to gain dominion. When Earth gains dominion, Metal becomes its great minister. When Metal is great minister, it causes weapons and armor to be frequently deployed. The qi of *Qian* and *Dui* stirs, and in the northwest, barbarians, treacherous bandits, and thieves arise in great numbers—this is the natural law. The spirits of Heaven and Earth cannot prevent it. Therefore, one must urgently suppress and sever Metal’s implements to prevent its phase from flourishing.

Excellent, excellent. Having heard the Master expound the celestial laws, we now know their awesome power. If one knows to revere them, good fortune follows.

Now, the Radiant Master of August Heaven, in compassion for our ignorance and blindness, has deigned to explain the celestial laws in full. But is this teaching meant for only one ruler’s reign? Or are these the universal laws for all under Heaven?

Indeed, Heaven establishes this as the constant celestial model. Yet if the phases of Wood or Fire recklessly rise, or if Metal’s peaks and coins spur the frequent dominion of thieves, it brings great harm and makes governance difficult to stabilize. If Metal’s qi gains great dominion, the harm is severe. Only by aligning with our celestial laws and severing it will good fortune immediately follow. When governance flourishes, treacherous ministers vanish—Heaven’s laws do not deceive.

We humbly wish to hear the essential intent behind Heaven’s establishment of this model.

Ah, how thorough are the Six Disciples’ questions! Know then: Heaven and Earth regard the east as lesser yang—the beginning of the ruler’s birth. Thus, the sun rises in the east. The south is taken as greater yang, and the ruler is yang. Thus, *Li* is the sun, and the sun is the ruler. The south is Fire. Fire is the ruler, and the south is summer—the season when the four seasons nurture growth, when pregnancy and flourishing are at their peak. Its virtue is the greatest, hence it is the ruler. This is the celestial model.

Though *jue* tone belongs to the east, it is aligned with the east’s position, and Fire’s position is aligned with the south. Now, as the qi of Great Peace flourishes and arrives, Heaven will exalt yang qi. Seeing the Six Perfected Ones’ questions, I know you are sent by Heaven. Thus, I have explained in full the methods for exalting the greater yang ruler’s phase. Take heed, Perfected Ones.

Yes, yes.

**The First Hundred Methods for Bestowing Upon Subordinates**
Now, the Heavenly Master, in compassion, has fully expounded the celestial laws for us unworthy ones. We humbly ask one further matter: when the emperor meets with his ministers and even the common people—Heaven’s laws regard the ruler as their father and mother. When he meets his ministers, they are the ruler’s worthy sons, assisting in governing Heaven and Earth. The people are the ruler’s unfilial children, managing the fields and livelihoods. When meeting them, should there not be something to bestow? If nothing is bestowed, grace and love do not extend to the people and ministers, leaving the Red Children with no Way to recite. What is to be done?

Excellent, Perfected One, is your question! When meeting the worthy, bestow culture; when meeting the hungry, bestow food; when meeting the cold, bestow clothing. Why bestow culture upon the worthy? Culture arises in the east and is illuminated in the south. Thus, celestial patterns arise in the northeast, and scriptures emerge from the northeast, where Heaven reveals its images. The tiger has patterns and dwells in *yin*; the dragon has patterns and dwells in *chen*, ascending to Heaven. *Li* is the locus of culture, governing the southern phase. Thus, the Three Luminaries embody culture, and the sun is the greatest illumination.

Therefore, culture arises in the east and flourishes in the south. Thus, the sun rises in the east and is at its peak in the south. Heaven commands the emperor to model himself after Heaven’s laws. Thus, he must bestow culture to foster its flourishing. Greater yang is the phase of Fire, and the sun, rising with Fire, can distinguish and perceive culture—what is cultured and what is not—just as it records right and wrong under Heaven.

Excellent, excellent. Go forth, Six Perfected Ones—you have now awakened to the great Dao of Heaven."

Now the August Heaven’s Illuminated Master has fully expounded the laws of the Dao for Heaven—yet nothing remains obscure. We wish to know: by what culture should these be bestowed?

How thorough, Six Disciples, in your questioning of Heaven’s affairs! It should be thus:

In all matters, one often suffers from [lacuna]—yet those who delight in modeling themselves after Heaven’s laws and swiftly attain Great Peace need only gather the true Daoist texts of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, selecting from them the most excellent, and compile these into a Heavenly Canon. This shall be bestowed upon the multitude of worthies, that each may depart and recite them.

Now, considering the essential meaning of past and present, what is the great principle for transforming the people and ministers?

It is this: that each nurture their nature and settle their bodies. Thus shall the great worthies and scholars rejoice without exception, harboring no ill will. Each shall reflect upon the laws of Heaven and Earth, and knowing them, shall cause people to revere and cherish their lord above all, while treasuring their own lives. They shall deeply understand how rare and precious a wise ruler is. Among them, the greatest worthies and benevolent ones shall constantly fear their lord’s aging, and so seek out extraordinary and uncommon methods. These shall be presented to the emperor—therefore, the Daoist texts and writings must be bestowed.

Excellent, excellent. You have now understood.
