Yang is most radiant in the sun, which governs all and stands as the eldest. Thus the celestial prognostication always takes the sun as the omen for the ruler’s prosperity or decline. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed. We have come to understand it."

The pattern for a human ruler is ever to seek kinship with the benevolent and to govern with those who possess a heart. Those with whom one may govern together must ever practice the Dao and cherish life. Even the young and weak, or those ministers and worthy ones who are still maturing, the ruler ought to nurture—not harm. Thus the east cherishes life, while the south cherishes nurturance. Those who lack benevolence and act with intent cannot long endure, and those whose dealings are unclear cannot serve as rulers. Thus the east, being wood, embodies benevolence and heart, while the south, being fire, embodies clarity. The celestial pattern decrees that emperors and kings who govern must ever do so through the Dao and virtue. Thus the east represents the Dao, for the Dao governs generation, while the south represents virtue, for virtue governs nurturance—hence the south governs nurturance. Those who govern ought to emulate Heaven by civilizing through culture. Thus the east represents culture, for the dragon emerges bearing it, while the south represents refinement—hence rectitude becomes the pattern of culture. Refinement is great clarity, so culture arises in the east and becomes luminous in the south. Thus the celestial pattern is red, and red is fire. Benevolence and rulership move upward, and the sun ought to stand high and bright, serving as the model for humanity. Thus when wood and fire move, they invariably ascend—this is the image of the ruler. Therefore, dwelling in the east, one relies on benevolence to ascend, and thus those who govern ought to reside in the south. The east is Lesser Yang, the ruler’s beginning; thus the sun rises in the east. The south is Greater Yang, the ruler’s radiant flourishing. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family and parents, while Greater Yang is the ruler’s person and position. Lesser Yang is the ruler’s family, for wood is the parent of fire, and the ruler takes Lesser Yang as their family, while fire is called the child of wood. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this. Lesser Yin is the minister, and ministers bend and yield in righteousness, submitting to Greater Yang. Thus metal follows fire in bending and yielding. Among people, what is desirable is that ministers always yield in righteousness to assist the ruler in what is desirable—hence Lesser Yin is called the minister. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Greater Yin is the people, who flow and do not cease, just as water flows without knowing rest. The people are charged with the duty of sustaining the state and providing for the kings and lords. Thus water ought to follow in nurturing and fostering wood. The east is the ruler’s family. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Proceed, for you have already understood this. The celestial omens decree that Lesser Yang fears Lesser Yin. Thus ministers may seize control of the state and the offices of kings and lords. Greater Yang fears Greater Yin; therefore, when a state possesses the Dao and virtue and is ruled by the worthy and enlightened, the people follow. When a state lacks the Dao and virtue, the people rebel. Thus the great essentials of governing a state are these: many people mean wealth, while few people mean great poverty. Do all the Perfected Ones comprehend this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"Now you have awakened to this. The celestial patterns and laws divide into six parts. The southeast and above belong to Heaven, thus all things in growth ascend, and crawling creatures and people all emerge and dwell without, belonging to Heaven. Therefore, Heaven’s color is outwardly azure, resembling wood, and inwardly red, resembling fire. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed. Now you have comprehended this."

"The celestial and terrestrial patterns and omens decree that the west and north below belong to Earth, thus when things reach autumn and winter, all fall and return to the soil. Crawling creatures and people, when autumn and winter arrive, all enter their burrows to dwell. Therefore, Earth’s color is outwardly yellow and white, resembling soil and metal, while inwardly it contains water, differing thus, resembling the northward movement. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"The celestial patterns and omens decree that the east and south, being noble in position, belong above to Heaven and govern as rulers, lords, teachers, and fathers. The west and north, being lowly in position, belong to Earth and serve as ministers, the inner palace, and the people. Thus, the *ji* stems from the inner palace of *jia*. *Jia* is Heaven, the fundamental position of kings. Thus, *jia* is the Heart Star; the Heart Star is fire and belongs to kings. Therefore, the east is also the precursor of kings. The Heart Star is fire and moves to belong to the south. It is like the sun rising in the east yet residing in the south. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, disciple. The celestial patterns and omens decree that *bing* is the chief of fire, the most radiant of all, and thus the position of the ruler. *Xin* belongs to *bing*; *xin* is the inner palace of *bing*. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, disciple. Now, *ji* is also called the Empress, and *xin* is also called the Empress—how can this be?"

"Excellent is your inquiry, disciple, for it grasps the meaning of the celestial omens. Now, *ji* is paired with *jia*, and *shen* is the father of *bing*; thus, *ji* is the palace of the Grand Empress. *Xin* is paired with *bing*, and *bing* is the son of *jia*; thus, *xin* is the palace of the Lesser Empress. *Bing* is the rightful son of *jia*, the ordained sovereign ruler. Do the Perfected Ones understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

"You have already understood this, Perfected One. *Geng* belongs to *yi* and represents the feudal lords and kings of the state. *Ren* belongs to *ding* and represents the younger sisters of the emperor. *Gui* belongs to *wu* and represents the maternal family of the Grand Empress. Excellent, Perfected One, you have already understood this.

Now that the ten celestial stems have been explained, each with its proper affiliation, we wish to hear of the twelve earthly branches—how are they to be understood?"

"Excellent! The Dao of Heaven operates thus: though yin and yang move in succession, each has its own household in matters of governance. The Dao of Heaven is uniform, yet without households, all would simply follow one another to cessation. *Jia* takes *yin* as its household; *yi* takes *mao* as its household; *bing* takes *wu* as its household; *ding* takes *si* as its household; *wu* takes *chen* and *xu* as its household; *ji* takes *chou* and *wei* as its household; *geng* takes *shen* as its household; *xin* takes *you* as its household; *ren* takes *zi* as its household; *gui* takes *hai* as its household.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven operates in reverse to govern, while the Dao of Earth is still. Therefore, there are divided lands but no divided people—this is to have states and territories but no state in the absolute. Thus, Heaven and Earth do not shift: Heaven reverses its course day and night, circulating through one full cycle, and this is its constant way. Therefore, the twelve earthly branches each reside in their place and do not follow the ten celestial stems in their movement. Do you understand this?"

"Indeed, indeed."

To practice the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons and five phases complete one another in their cycles. Though their expressions differ as they revolve, they circulate through the hidden and obscure without end—only the great divine sages of antiquity knew this in every age.

To explain it all to you would exhaust resources and prove overly elaborate, only deepening confusion and leaving the lords of earthly virtue bewildered, uncertain of what to follow. Thus, I have ceased.

Not that I begrudge explaining it to you—rather, the explanations would be endless. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

You have gained some insight. The Virtuous Lord governs according to our celestial prognostication, and not one thing in ten thousand will go amiss.

Thus, the Dao of Heaven has its fixed boundaries. The east and south are assigned to the lord and king, symbolizing Heaven, hence the title "Son of Heaven." The west and north are assigned to the rear palace, subjects, and ministers, symbolizing Earth, hence Earth is called the "rear palace." Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

The celestial patterns of prognostication show that the east fears the west. Thus, since the opening of Heaven and Earth, when rulers have followed military methods, exalted the qi of Metal, and employed martial forces, the symbolic qi of the lord has been depleted. Fire is greatly weakened, and governance becomes inauspicious and chaotic.

If you, Perfected One, wish to know the truth of celestial prognostication, observe from high antiquity through middle antiquity to recent times: when rulers abandoned the Dao and virtue, exalted the qi of Metal, and employed military methods, their governance was entirely inauspicious, plagued by bandits, thieves, and omens of misfortune.

Therefore, the sages of high antiquity deeply understood the fixed patterns of Heaven and dared not govern by means of weapons, armor, or martial forces. If emperors and kings wish for long-lasting peace and good fortune, they should follow these celestial prognostics, swiftly restrain and abolish metal weapons and military preparations, and urgently promote the Dao and supreme virtue to emulate the patterns of Heaven, align with the will of August Heaven, and forever suppress all treacherous and inauspicious elements. The response will be immediate and unmistakable. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

"Indeed, indeed."

The celestial prognostic patterns decree that though the Great Yang serves as the ruler, it paradoxically fears the Great Yin—the movement of Water. The purest and finest of waters is wine. Wine is the king of waters, its elder, the most excellent of all beverages, its qi aligned with the Kan position, governing theft and banditry by night. Thus, its name derives from "indulgent abandon," for as the king and elder of waters, when Water reigns, the Great Yang wanes.

Perfected One, if you wish to truly understand the veracity of celestial prognostics, observe this: from the highest antiquity through the middle ages, whenever rulers indulged in wine, none achieved great peace. Their governance turned to chaos, their officials engaged in constant strife, and bandits arose—this is the clear consequence. Therefore, when a virtuous sovereign governs in an era of Great Peace, the essence of Fire should shine brightly. One must not follow the Great Yin, allowing the power of Water to dominate and thereby suppress and harm the governance. Thus, wine must be prohibited.

Would you hear of the method of prohibition? Which wine should be banned? Simply the wine sold in markets. Now, Master, what have you seen or witnessed that compels you to ban only market wine? Indeed, the market corresponds to the movement of Water. Thus, people and goods from all four directions flow and gather there. The rivers and seas, too, are the kings and elders of waters, for all streams and wealth likewise flow and converge there. Water, being the movement of the Dark Warrior of the north, is inherently greedy, plundering others' wealth. The market, where goods from the five directions flow and gather for profit, gives rise to bandits, rogues, and treacherous elements—all governed by Kan, the Water trigram.

Heaven’s law operates through resonant correspondence by category. Thus, the market embodies the movement of Water. To indulge its wine is to amplify it further, once more crowning it as the king of waters. Market-dwellers, rejoicing in wine, also proclaim it king—this is a double reign of Water. The fault is sixfold: it suppresses the fiery qi of the Great Yang, causing the ruler’s governance to weaken and instead empowering treacherous ministers.

Have you, Perfected One, understood this? Now, seeing the Heavenly Master’s secret instructions, you are bewildered and do not comprehend—may I hear the great secret?

Excellent indeed are your words. Yet the various Perfected Ones have come from afar, inquiring of Heaven’s affairs, to resolve the harms of karmic inheritance for the virtuous lords, emperors, and kings. I shall withhold nothing.

Be seated in peace, and I shall distinguish and explain all for the Perfected Ones, expounding the essential meaning.

Very well.

The celestial prognostication’s secret instructions state: when gold and jade rise to prominence, affairs are governed by them. When the martial departments flourish greatly, the Wood qi is cut off at its root, and Earth gains sovereignty. When Earth is greatly exalted, it is the palace of the Grand Empress. Its qi belongs to the northwest, and when the Great Yin attains great sovereignty, it gives rise to treacherous ministers who act within the inner palace, losing their proper path and surging forth. When Earth rules, Metal becomes its minister, and together they surge upward in succession. The qi of *ji* and *xin* both attain sovereign flourishing, surging and rising greatly. According to Heaven’s standard laws, this breeds many treacheries in the inner palace—yet this is not the fault of the inner palace. Rather, it is called a failure in governance to align with celestial prognostication, a loss of the great departmental boundaries, causing disasters to return and overturn one another. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the cycles of celestial timing have not yet reached the point where the former masters could fully distinguish and explain the great departmental boundaries of Heaven. Thus, the emperor loses the governance of Heaven’s law, giving rise to these calamitous transformations.

Do you, Perfected One, deeply understand this?

Very well.

The celestial prognostication states: indulgence in wine belongs to the category of Water. The market is the movement of Water, the great gathering place of the human sovereign—yet to indulge in wine within the market is called "Water and Wine as Great Sovereigns." When Water rules, the Fire qi diminishes; when Fire qi diminishes, it transforms into ashes; when it transforms into ashes, it changes into Earth, thus becoming Fire surrendering its qi to Earth. When Earth gains sovereignty and rises from the ground, it aligns with Metal and Water in the northwest. The Great Yin pertains to the people, yet ministers gain sovereignty instead. The inner palace gives birth to treacherous ministers, the qi of *ji* again takes action, and the inner palace commits transgressions, stirring and rising once more. The resulting disasters bring theft, and bandits never cease. All lies in the indulgence of Water, which injures the yang virtue.

Now, the reason I distinguish and explain this for the Perfected One is that I see you have come to inquire with such earnest devotion, knowing that August Heaven desires to protect the virtuous lord. Therefore, I clearly expound for the Perfected One the great divisions of Heaven and Earth’s governance—what ought to be emulated, and what must no longer be transgressed. To transgress again is to invite confusion and chaos.

Do you understand this?

Very well.

Would you permit me to raise one doubt? Proceed.

Now, the capital gathers a multitude of people and wealth at its center—does this mean the capital corresponds to the Water phase?

Alas! How is it that all you Perfected Ones study yet remain so often in darkness, so seldom in clarity? Not all can be grasped—how could everything be fully understood?

Yet know this: the capital corresponds to the central Earth, the place where Fire may securely rest. It is not like a marketplace, merely a place to amass wealth. The capital ought to gather together the Dao and virtue, benevolence and worthies, to govern the realm as one. Why then do you claim the ruler of the capital should merely amass wealth?

How profoundly foolish you are! If you doubt my words, let me explain for you. From ancient times to now, wherever capitals have gathered the virtuous and wise, the realm has known perfect order. But where only treasures and wealth are amassed, without worthy and enlightened ones, all falls into chaos contrary to the Perfected One’s intent. Can the capital be like a marketplace, merely a place to gather wealth? Is this not so?

Very well.

The Perfected Ones reaffirm the celestial omens and the laws of cosmic patterning.

The sun arises from Lesser Yang and flourishes in Greater Yang. The moon arises from Lesser Yin and flourishes in Greater Yin. The sun is the essence of Heaven, the radiance of Yang—thus it is the sovereign, its position in the south. The moon is the essence of Earth, the radiance of Yin—thus it is the minister, its position in the north. The south governs day, the north governs night; therefore, when the sun reigns and acts, the moon and night wane and diminish; when the moon reigns and acts, the sun and day wane and diminish. Thus, when the qi of the north prevails, the qi of the south declines; when the qi of the south prevails, the qi of the north declines. Therefore, one must swiftly cease the reign of wine, to sever the decline of Water and Metal.

Do the Perfected Ones clearly understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

The cosmic patterning divides thus: Yang is Heaven, male, sovereign, father, elder, and teacher; Yin is Earth, female, minister, child, the people, and mother. Therefore, the southeast pertains to Yang, the northwest to Yin.

If the Perfected Ones wish to know the truth of celestial omens, observe this: since the opening of Heaven and Earth, whenever rulers have indulged in military force, allowed sovereigns to indulge in wine, or followed the counsel of women—when governance heavily favors their words and the sovereign yields to them—Lesser Yin, Greater Yin, and Earth, all belonging to the northwest, have prevailed. From such commands, disorder and calamity have always followed. But benevolence, wisdom, virtue, and enlightened sages all belong to the southeast, to Yang, to Heaven. From such counsel, order always follows.

I wish to hear why the worthies and sages belong to the southeast.
The essence of Fire is the heart, and the heart is sagacity; the essence of Wood is benevolence, thus its symbol resides in the east. The southeast nurtures and fosters all things, and the worthies and sages, in their gentle clarity, likewise nurture all things without harm. Thus, the nature of sages and worthies is gentle and luminous, all benevolent and bright: benevolence resembles Wood, brightness resembles Fire—therefore, they all reside in the southeast.

Excellent, excellent! Hearing the words of the Heavenly Master, I have gained great understanding.

Moreover, in the laws of celestial omens, the southeast is the guiding net of Heaven’s Dipper; wherever the Dipper’s handle points, the four seasons turn, and the mandate is received in kingship. The northwest belongs to Earth, struck by the Dipper’s bowl—there, qi is cut off and extinguished. Thus, when Lesser Yin, Greater Yin, and Earth prevail and overcome Yang, it is called “reversing Heaven and Earth,” and disorder often results.

Do the Perfected Ones understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

The foolish among us mortals, moved by the Heavenly Master’s compassion, have been taught the celestial omen formulas. We humbly ask to be instructed in even a single word of this matter.

Now, the south is Yang, yet in reversal it corresponds to *Xun*, *Li*, and *Kun*; the north is Yin, yet in reversal it corresponds to *Qian*, *Kan*, and *Gen*.

Excellent, your question! You have glimpsed the subtle intent of Heaven.

Yet the *Yi* (Changes) is rooted in the subtle qi of Heaven and Earth’s Yin and Yang, beginning with primordial qi. Thus, the south, being the extreme of Yang, generates Yin—hence it records Yin. The north, being the extreme of Yin, generates Yang—hence it records Yang. Subtle qi, however, cannot yet govern affairs. Therefore, in the *Yi*, the first *Nine* of *Zi* is the "hidden dragon, do not act"—it cannot yet govern affairs, hence it is not used. This merely marks the inception of primordial qi.

Excellent, excellent! Proceed, Perfected One—you have understood.

Now, what I record in the celestial omens are the great celestial divisions that govern and regulate the qi of Heaven’s administration, serving as the guiding principles for all under Heaven. Do the Perfected Ones comprehend this?

Indeed, indeed.

What I now speak of is precisely what the rulers of the world must follow as their method of governance. Your question concerns the inception of the correct qi.

If the Perfected Ones still harbor doubts about my words, I shall explain in full the eight boundaries of Heaven and Earth.

Indeed, indeed.

The solar boundary is defined by the sun rising in *Mao* and setting in *You*, with the south as Yang and the north as Yin. The boundary of Heaven’s Gate and Earth’s Door is defined by *Xun* arising in the southeast corner and *Qian* arising in the northwest corner, with the northeast as Yang and the southwest as Yin. The *Nine* of *Zi* and the *Six* of *Wu* mark the east as Yang and the west as Yin. The establishment of spring is at the northeast corner, and the establishment of autumn is at the northwest corner, with the southeast as Yang and the northwest as Yin. These are called the eight boundaries of Heaven and Earth, dividing and distinguishing the positions of Yin and Yang.

Do the Perfected Ones now understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, the understanding is achieved.

Therefore, the Great Canon takes the southeast as Heaven and the northwest as Earth, with Earth yielding in compliance. Should a ruler subdue Heaven, it is because Heaven and Earth are reversed—hence, inauspicious. When Heaven fulfills its course and the ruler submits to Earth, this is compliance, each attaining its proper place—hence, auspicious.

Perfected One, having received this text, ponder it deeply and entrust it to a sovereign of supreme virtue. Reflect upon my words and enact them, and you shall differ not from the divine. Then Heaven shall protect and aid you, for this is no trifling matter.

Proceeding, I have expounded to you the lesser completion of celestial portents and proofs. Should I now reveal to the Perfected One the greater discourse—of all between Heaven above and Earth below, the farthest reaches of the eight directions, and the constellations arrayed therein—I would speak of each in turn, circling through the subtle wonders of the celestial Dao. Yet some may grow dizzy, lost in confusion, and thereafter the true Dao would fall into disuse, leaving no means to resolve ancient calamities, thus deepening the sorrow of those above.

Therefore, I have spoken only of what is easily grasped in the Great Canon, that you may awaken and no more. I do not speak of the subtle and abstruse, not out of reluctance, but for this reason.

Indeed, indeed.

I humbly request to inquire of one final matter.

Speak.

Now the Celestial Master expounds for this unenlightened student the ten Celestial Stems, each paired in correspondence, while the twelve Earthly Branches of the terrestrial Dao likewise share yin and yang, odd and even. Why then do only the Celestial Stems achieve such pairing?

Excellent indeed is your inquiry—it may be called the essential crux of the Dao.

Yet Earth is but the counterpart of Heaven. Though purely yin and dwelling alone, it too possesses its own yin and yang. The laws of Heaven and Earth correspond above and below: Heaven has *zi*, and Earth has *zi*; Heaven has *wu*, and Earth has *wu*; Heaven has *kan*, and Earth has *kan*; Heaven has *li*, and Earth has *li*—thus do they align in mutual resonance.

Therefore, *chou* and *wei* are the rear palaces of *yin*. *Shen* belongs to *mao*, the son-in-law of the feudal lords and kings. *Hai* pairs with *chen*, while *mao* pairs with *xu*. *Chen* and *xu* are the consorts of the Grand Empress Dowager’s household. *You* belongs to *wu*, the Lesser Empress. *Zi* belongs to *si*, and *si* is the son-in-law of the Emperor’s younger sister.

Do you understand, Perfected One?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus the Stems are the Emperors and Kings, and the Branches are also the Emperors and Kings. Therefore, *yin* is the Branch of *jia*, so *chou* and *wei* are called the rear palaces. *Wu* is the Branch of *bing*, so *you* is called the Lesser Empress. *Mao* is the Branch of *yi*, so *shen* is called the son-in-law of the feudal lords and kings. *Chen* is the Branch of *wu*, so it is called the household of the Grand Empress Dowager. *Hai* is the Branch of *gui*, so it is called the consort of the Grand Empress Dowager’s household. *Zi* is the Branch of *ren*, so it is called the son-in-law of the Emperor’s younger sister. *Si* is the Branch of *ding*, so it is called the Emperor’s younger sister. Such is the law of Heaven and Earth in harmonious resonance.

Excellent, excellent.

I wish to inquire further regarding these *chen* and *xu* lords: when unmarried, the men gather together, and the women marry together—why is this?

Most subtle indeed is your inquiry.

Now, Heaven is the utmost yang, and Earth is the utmost yin. Earth is multitudinous, the chief of all yin. Yin is ever even in number, thus they pair. Yet *wu* and *ji* both belong to Earth—why do they not pair?

Excellent question. *Wu* and *ji* are the fifth Stems, the yang of Earth, their position belonging to Heaven—thus they do not pair.

Do you understand, Perfected One?

Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, you have grasped it. Now your questioning of this is most apt.

The Five Phases’ names cycle and complement one another, encompassing all matters under Heaven. When you receive my writings, you must reflect upon their categories and ponder their deeper intent. From the six directions above and below to the farthest depths, all is already complete. Thus the sage, seeing one, knows ten thousand things; the great worthy, seeing one, knows a thousand; while the foolish, though straining to comprehend, remain confused and fail to attain the true Dao.

Therefore the Dao and its virtue are entrusted to the Perfected One—do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, you have understood. I now wish to ask one further matter.

Now, the four seasons of Heaven above and the Five Phases of Earth below—all are said to correspond to the households of emperors, kings, feudal lords, and palace consorts. Heaven’s Dao exhaustively assigns these pairings. But do the myriad common folk and all things also have their own correspondences?

Excellent is your question—you have glimpsed the essentials of the great Dao.

In truth, these pairings are all of the same nature.

The Five Phases: at their apex are the emperors and kings; next are the ministers; then the subtle qi. The king occupies the position of emperor; the minister, the position of great official; the subtle qi, the position of petty officer. After the king comes the aged qi—this is the position of feudal lords. After the aged qi comes the declining qi—this is the position of the imperial clan. After the declining qi comes the ailing qi—this is the sign of the imperial clan’s transgressions and loss of succession. After the ailing qi comes the imprisoned qi—this is the sign of the common folk and the myriad people. After the imprisoned qi comes the dead qi—this is the sign of slaves and servants. After the dead qi comes the vanished qi—this is the sign of the dead in their tombs.

Thus Heaven displays its signs: the four seasons and Five Phases circulate in ceaseless flow, each rising and declining in turn. The people and the myriad things all follow the law of Heaven’s signs, likewise rising and declining.

Therefore the myriad common folk are all descendants of the hundred kings. In ascent, they become rulers of men; in decline, they become the people.

Perfected One, do you understand?

Indeed, indeed. You have now grasped it.

To the right, these celestial portents govern the state of Chang’an, suppressing inauspicious ministers and eradicating treacherous deceit.

*Thus concludes Scroll Sixty-Nine of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Scroll Seventy of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Chapter One Hundred and Six: The Knack of Gains and Losses in Learning*

The Perfected One respectfully inquired: I now wish to compile and rectify all the texts you have written before, so that scholars may not speak recklessly. May I hear of this?

Excellent! How your mastery grows day by day.

Indeed, my Way and its methods emerge to regulate the yang and enter to regulate the yin; emerge to regulate conduct and enter to regulate the spirit; emerge to regulate the multitude of texts and enter to regulate the multitude of diagrams; emerge to dispel disasters and enter to rectify the self; emerge to regulate the learning of the court and internally regulate the chamber of seclusion.

In all matters, set limits. Those who strive diligently in learning, each according to their capacity, yet deviate from the constant method—externally, their learning leads them into superficiality, unable to restrain themselves; internally, their learning fails to align with the proper path, turning instead toward great deviation.

Scholars invariably suffer from a grave flaw: they cannot recognize it themselves.

Those who favor external learning and whose talent exceeds the norm often fall into superficiality, causing the Way to become greatly deviant. Lacking proper texts, they falsely claim it as the true Way and deceive others with their requests.

Those who favor internal learning and whose talent exceeds the norm often plunge into great deviation, believing they have attained it. Refusing to speak with others, they lose the proper measure and transmit reckless words.

Now you harbor doubts, so you have come to ask again. Your intent is earnest and unwavering, free from carelessness. I shall establish rules and limits for you, so each may have boundaries to observe.

Ancient and modern texts are too numerous to count. In all learning, those who delight in truth must not deviate from the root.

Those who learn from a master’s oral instructions must not deviate from the master’s words—this is the great essential.

The greatest harm in learning lies here: when external studies align with superficial chapters and phrases, they become shallow and lead to reckless speech.

When internal texts align with apocryphal diagrams, one cannot deeply grasp their essential meaning and instead speaks in error.

Those who study longevity yet emerge to align with superficiality deceive others.

Those who align internally yet fail to grasp the essential meaning fall into great deviation.

Now you return to ask repeatedly, so I shall expound these texts for you, revealing their limits. What aligns with the proper measure is correct; what does not is wrong. This is clear.

From this, you may understand: all scriptures are the discourse of Heaven. When ten correspond with ten, it is correct. When ten correspond with nine, it is a minor deviation. When ten correspond with eight, it is a minor disorder. Beyond this, it is not the true Way and cannot be used. It is called "disordering the celestial patterns and earthly principles," displeasing yin and yang, causing the myriad things to struggle and the people to suffer great misfortune.

The method of nurturing one’s nature is to internally perceive one’s form and countenance clearly—this is correct. To externally perceive the spirits of the myriad things is wrong.

In learning all matters, one must constantly uphold the root text and seek the multitude of worthies to explain and settle it—this is correct. To cling to the multitude of chapters and phrases while forgetting the root is wrong, losing the intent of the Way of Heaven.

To transform one’s body into a spirit is correct. To lack the Way yet fail to become a spirit, yet claim to command spirits, is wrong—it is merely a technique of driving others through texts.

To explain all matters such that root, branch, and center resemble one another is correct. What does not resemble is wrong.

To enter seclusion and initially eat little, gradually consuming qi until it dissolves and disappears—this is correct. To seek the Way, claim attainment, and not return, yet answer questions, is wrong.

All who depart must return. Those who teach and answer questions are correct. Those who do not teach or answer, yet tolerate death, are wrong.

To maintain purity and stillness in a secluded chamber and succeed is correct. To claim attainment of the Way yet speak in anger is wrong—such a one has lost their essence.

To enter learning and daily improve, surpassing one’s former state, is the correctness of attaining the Way. To enter learning yet daily worsen, lacking loyalty and trust, is wrong—one has fallen into great deviation.

To read texts and grasp their meaning, then uphold the master’s instructions to seek explanations, is correct. To read texts without a master’s instructions, yet claim deep and solitary understanding, is wrong—one has lost the great intent of the Way.

To have attained the Way yet steadfastly serve the multitude of masters and worthies without slackening is correct—this is the path of daily progress.

Thus the ancient sages, having attained the Way, naturally served their masters without ceasing. After leaving their masters, they read the texts without slackening. To learn yet claim solitary attainment of the essential meaning, no longer diligently reading the ancient texts and sagely words, and claim not to serve the multitude of sages—this is wrong. Such a one is a fool.

In all learning, to exhaustively investigate what may be sought is correct. All things are thus: once born, to fulfill their lifespan and bear fruit is correct. To merely be born yet fail to fulfill their lifespan, lacking trustworthiness, is wrong.

To do good and attain its proper fruit is correct. To fail to attain its proper fruit, appearing correct externally yet wrong internally, is wrong.

To thoroughly study my texts without departing from the guiding line and attain their truth is correct. To read texts and display cleverness, possessing great talent yet failing to grasp their essential truth, is wrong.

Heaven has wind and rain, and the myriad things are born in season—this is correct. When wind and rain harm the myriad things, it is wrong—it is poisonous.

For the scriptural Way to daily flourish is correct. To not daily progress but instead daily decline is wrong—one has lost the internal intent.

Thus the nature of Heaven and Earth is to do good. If it does not immediately manifest in one’s person, it flows to later generations to illuminate one’s conduct.

To do evil also does not immediately cease in one’s person but must flow to later generations, likewise revealing one’s conduct through error.

Therefore, the good and evil one does will inevitably be seen.

But those who do good are like facing the rising sun—bright as the break of dawn. Those who do evil are like facing the setting sun—dark as the gathering dusk. Such is the natural nature of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang.

Heaven gives life to the myriad things, each manifesting according to its conduct, revealed without concealment. Thus, the good ascend in their deeds, their fate belonging to Heaven, just as the living belong to Heaven. The evil descend in their deeds, their fate belonging to Earth, just as the dead—being impure—return below to the Yellow Springs. This is what is meant.

Those who obtain my scripture must entrust it to a ruler of supreme virtue. I possess this scripture and dare not obstruct or withhold its transmission and study.

The Dao of Heaven governs Heaven, yet it cannot be fully known; one must not heed the words of a single person alone. Therefore, I have now established the writings of the ancient sages for you, once more distilling their essential concordance. The scripture’s beginning and end mutually confirm one another, serving as proof.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, though the worthy and sagely have lived in different ages, separated by vast spans of time, what they detested was the same. Together they spoke for Heaven, remedying the world’s gains and losses. Their words resemble one another like overlapping compasses or aligned squares—turning to mutually illuminate, unavoidably so.

For things of the same kind gather and arise together; their principles all summon one another through likeness and resemblance. This is clear evidence. What was lost in the past is regained in the future, and by examining similarities and differences, the text is completed.

Adhering to antiquity to clarify the present, discussing matters collectively to compose the inner text, and using the outer text to elucidate the inner—then returning to verify the inner text through the outer—ensures it may be transmitted for ten thousand generations without compounding Heaven’s transgressions.

The words of one person cannot be followed alone. The words of many, deeply weighed and drawn from the sayings of ancient worthies and sages, inwardly align with Heaven. Together they are settled and established.

If the emperor daily clarifies the decisive principles, all confusion, disorder, disasters, and evils will be eliminated. Heaven will have no repeated sorrows; those who work together will prosper, while those who resist will find their misfortunes unremoved.

Here ends the decisive teachings on the scholar’s gains and losses.

*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Seventy Concludes
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll Seventy-One Begins
*True Dao: Nine Essentials on Gains and Losses*, First Section of the One Hundred Seventh Text

The Perfected One bows twice and asks to inquire of one matter. Pray, speak.

Here the Celestial Master bestows the qi of Great Peace to transmit the Dao and its virtue, thereby establishing the supreme emperor. Above, there is a ruler who delights in the Dao and virtue; below, even the foolish and lowly common folk are reached. Its grace pervades the six directions, harmonizes the eight extremities, and encompasses all without exception.

Now, worthy disciple, you have received the Master’s literary teachings and pondered them to attain the Dao. What marks its ultimate height above, and what defines its utmost depth below?

Excellent indeed is the Perfected One’s question—how subtle and essential! Do you wish to hear of its profoundest extremes and know the spirits’ advance and retreat?

Truly, I am dull and benighted; my understanding falls short. Only the enlightened Master may record and reveal it.

Very well.

The Dao has nine degrees, each distinguished by its own name. Now I shall fully expound their meaning for the Perfected One. Follow along and record it, ensuring nothing is lost.

Yes, yes.

First is the Primal Qi of Non-Action. Second is Serene Emptiness and Nothingness. Third is Numerical Measurement and Distinction. Fourth is the Spirit’s Journey Forth and Return. Fifth is the Great Dao’s Spirit, akin to the Four Seasons and Five Phases. Sixth is Piercing Joy. Seventh is Community Counsel. Eighth is Overflowing Spirit. Ninth is Ancestral Spirits.

Each of these nine is further divided into nine, yielding eighty-one sections, each with distinct principles and secret applications. Together, they form one great root, with spirit as its agent and humanity as its gateway.

Now I shall arrange them for you in ordered teachings. It is impossible to record them all in advance. Reflect upon their meaning: the upper three nines—twenty-seven in total—can transcend the world. The central three nines—another twenty-seven—can summon true spirit officials. The lower three nines—twenty-seven more—abound in heterodoxy. Their spirits and essences cannot be constantly employed, causing people to become confused and disoriented. Among them, those of impure essence often err and speak falsely, as if losing their qi.

Now, this humble student, upon hearing the Master’s words, is dazzled and knows not east from west. I pray you distinguish and explain it for this dull disciple.

Very well.

The first, the Primal Qi of Non-Action, is to contemplate one’s body without acting in the slightest. Simply envision it as radiantly pure, like qi released without form. Constantly take this as your method. Once perfected, there is nothing you cannot do and nothing you do not know. Thus, when one lacks the Dao, they remain merely human. With the Dao attained, they transform into divine immortals, their spirits ascending to Heaven, following its transformations—this is what it means to be capable of all things.

The second, Natural Emptiness and Nothingness, is to guard the form in profound emptiness, naturally without flaw. The body’s interior shines white, above and below like jade, without blemish. Practiced over time, this too is a method to transcend the world. It follows the image of the Primal Qi of Non-Action.

The third, Numerical Measurement, is to accumulate essence and observe oneself. Count from the hair on the head to the feet, distinguishing each of the five fingers. The body’s external and internal aspects are all enumerated without omission. Know its meaning and constantly hold this in mind. Not losing even a fraction, this is also a lesser method to transcend the world. It follows Serene Emptiness.

The fourth, the Spirit’s Journey Forth, is to contemplate the spirits of the five viscera, all emerging and entering, visible in their movements. You may speak with them. The mind follows the spirit’s comings and goings, perceiving the body’s interior with clarity. This enables knowledge of fortune and misfortune, following Numerical Measurement.

The fifth, the Great Dao’s Spirit, is when the human spirit emerges and aligns with the Five Phases and Four Seasons—green, red, white, yellow, black—all harmonizing with the visceral spirits. Their comings and goings are directed by the spirit officials of the Four Seasons and Five Phases, called the Complete Dao. It can subdue all heterodoxies.

The sixth, Piercing Joy, involves piercing and binding the earthly spirits of the Dao, each with its own canon. Following their household methods, spirits are summoned to wander. Half resemble the true, half the heterodox, often enticing people with cleverness. They cannot be constantly employed, for over time they bring sorrow.

The seventh, Community Counsel, involves the spirits of Heaven and Earth, the Four Seasons, altars of soil and grain, mountains and rivers—sacrificial spirits who descend to humans. They cause confusion, prompting reckless speech about spirits, violent enmity, and wild heterodoxy. One must not act recklessly.

The eighth, Overflowing Spirit, speaks of spirits that overflow, their Dao unattached to any system. They are the refined qi of the world descending upon people, causing reckless speech. Half resemble the true, half the heterodox.

The ninth, Ancestral Spirits, involves purely seeing ghosts, without any true Dao. Those who summon them attract only the ghosts of the dead. This is the lowest extreme of the Dao, called the path of the inferior scholar.

One who attains the upper Dao can also employ the lower. One who attains the lower Dao cannot employ the upper.

Now, I wish to know: why are there these distinctions of upper and lower?

This arises from human conduct. Those who guard the root attain the upper. Those who delight in the spirit’s exit and entry into the body attain the middle. Foolish people harm the root and guard the branches, wandering with other spirits to attain the lower.

Those who guard the root can fully perceive it. Those who guard the middle perceive half. Those who guard the branches cannot return to see the Dao’s mirror.

Thus, all learners must find an enlightened master. Without one, they lose the path. Therefore, the transmission from master to master is as enduring as metal and stone. Without such transmission, it is called reckless practice, leading to misfortune and heterodoxy.

Perfected One, be cautious, be cautious.

Yes, yes.

Thus, in ancient times, the highest learners among sages and worthies, having found enlightened masters, were called reborn. Those without enlightened masters were called disruptors of the scriptures. Therefore, all worthies and sages served masters to achieve completion. Without a master, the Dao does not arise spontaneously.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed.

Perfected One, if you wish to know its effect, consider this: dwelling in a village of great worthies makes one greatly worthy. Dwelling in a village of middling worthies makes one middling worthy. Dwelling in a village of the unworthy makes one unworthy. This is what it means to never surpass such influence.

Those who study this Dao must examine it carefully and in detail. This is the essential Dao of Heaven.

Be cautious, be most cautious.

Yes, yes.

When one departs, the Dao returns to its rightful recipient, to be entrusted to the worthy and enlightened.

Yes, yes.

This is the divine secret and essential Dao.

*(Right: The Nine Principles of the True Dao on Gains and Losses.)*

**Text 108: The Text on Inducing Goodness, Eliminating Evil, and Receiving the Dao’s Precepts**

The Perfected One asked the Divine Person: "What are the precepts for receiving the Dao?"

The Divine Person replied: "The Dao has great precepts—one must not fail to be cautious. When one is about to attain the Dao, at the moment of near-completion, one will commune with all spirits, dwell as neighbors with the spiritual and the numinous, and meet them in all goings and comings. One will love others as a father loves his child.

The Dao is a weighty matter. Some may regret bestowing it upon others and seek to wrest it away. Thus, they first test a person to see if they are steadfast. They may come together to deceive, causing one to speak recklessly. If one obtains their words and firmly seals them, taking care never to transmit them, one may attain longevity. With time, one may attain the true Dao. To transmit them is to invite gradual decay. Moreover, it causes one to cherish life and abhor harm."

The Perfected One said: "I wish to hear the meaning of 'gradual decay.'"

The Divine Person replied: "When the spirit decays, the body dies. The Dao of emptiness and absolute profundity constantly urges one to cherish life and abhor killing, to seal the mouth and prevent leakage—only then can one endure for ten thousand myriad years."

The Perfected One asked the Divine Person: "I wish to hear the prohibitions against leakage."

The Divine Person said: "Thus, if a great person leaks it, they lose their position. If a middling person leaks it, their qi is severed. If a petty person leaks it, their lineage is extinguished. The reason is this: Heaven and Earth use this to distinguish themselves and maintain their exclusivity, and thus the divine holds it in the utmost reverence. If Heaven and Earth did not profoundly know the Dao of absolute profundity, how could they be divine? How could they be eternal?

Remember this: treasure its essence, value it, and be cautious."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes," and dared not speak recklessly.

The Perfected One bowed and asked: "When they seek to corrupt a person, what is to be done?"

The Divine Person replied: "When evil intent arises in a person’s heart, great malevolence comes to deceive. If one can firmly seal their ears and refuse to heed their words, it is auspicious. To listen to their words is to invite misfortune and harm.

If a ruler listens, they will despise their ministers, accusing them of disloyalty and plotting rebellion. If a minister or child listens, they will despise their ruler or father, and the deceiver will approach, saying, 'You shall soon become a sage' or 'You shall soon become a ruler.' If a petty person listens, they will be made to boast of their own greatness. If a father listens, they will despise their child; if a child listens, they will despise their father. Their words shift and twist, confusing the heart and mind, speaking now of good, now of evil, disrupting governance. With one moment of joy and the next of anger, this is the great flattery of malevolence, ever seeking to harm others.

From ancient times to the present, all who have studied long life have failed to transcend these words."

The Perfected One asked: "What is to be done?"

The Divine Person replied: "Seal your ears and do not listen; seal your mouth and do not speak. These are but flatteries of malevolence—there is nothing worth hearing. To listen is to lose the true Dao, and to lose it is to die. If you wish to endure, be cautious of these words.

I have already warned you of this, for how often have you nearly fallen prey to this great malevolence? I constantly rectify my own heart and no longer employ such things. This great malevolence constantly accumulates, seeking to observe whether a person is steadfast. The cunning and malevolent may even enter a person’s belly, stirring their heart and causing them to act recklessly. They provoke joy and anger, making it impossible to restrain oneself—all are led astray by malevolence. Driven by malevolence, the many are swept away to destruction.

In such matters, the accumulated cases are many. One must carefully observe these weighty precepts, and the heart must not be swayed—not only for those who study the Dao. The common people, too, are subject to unpredictable joy and anger; the same applies to you. Be cautious and refine yourself."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes."

The Perfected One said: "I myself have been afflicted by great malevolence, which made me wish to boast, saying, 'I shall become a ruler, and later ascend as an immortal to the heavens.' I believed their words and rejoiced greatly. Later, I fell ill for three months with madness, but when I saw the Divine Person and Heavenly Master, my heart filled with joy. I have personally experienced this affliction and nearly succumbed to severe illness. Later, the madness ceased, and I recovered, attaining several thousand years of life. Now, I am fortunate to meet the Divine Person again, to receive the Dao’s precepts anew, and to see the gateway, hoping to endure long and become an official of the heavens."

The Divine Person said: "If you hold your heart and will so steadfastly, why fear you will not ascend to the Nine Heavens and traverse the Twenty-Five Heavens? All those who ascend to the heavens now have held their hearts firm and unyielding—none may err.

All who are misled by confusion and deception die prematurely and fail to transcend. If you wish for long life, study this text and take it as a weighty precept. This is the precept of life and death—one must not fail to be cautious.

Thus, the sages and worthies of ancient times who first transcended the world did not rely on this power. Those who study the Dao yet fail to transcend and do not endure long do so because they listened to this and were ensnared by its harm. The great spirits of the heavens do not permit harm to be done to others; they cause such harm to rebound upon the perpetrator, leaving them without great fortune. Those who were to live are turned to death, becoming thieves of Heaven.

Now, all that I have taught and shown to you, Perfected One, may lead to great longevity. Some may transcend the world, but you must carefully guard yourself and not allow this to become harm. If you can focus your heart single-mindedly, you may endure for ten thousand myriad years."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes. I dare not act wrongly; I beg to receive the enlightened precepts."

The Divine Person said: "Your devotion to the Dao is such that you shall accomplish the task and ascend the steps to Heaven."

The Perfected One asked: "Are these the only precepts against malevolence? Are there deeper ones? Are there precepts of the heavens above?"

The Divine Person replied: "There are indeed the unyielding precepts of Heaven, which firmly admonish people’s ears. The primary precept is against colluding with others to deceive, telling them they shall soon be exalted and noble—this is how one is admonished."

Thus do men transgress the prohibitions and incur execution. Again, they are repeatedly tested with jade maidens, made to wander in their company; those who succumb laugh at others’ baseness, only to bring harm upon their own bodies in return. Yet if one remains ever silent, for ten thousand years there is nothing to hear—only guarding one’s own life to its end, what harm could there be? Between life and death, this alone is paramount.

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes."

The Perfected One asked: "Why does the Dao specifically send evil spirits to test men?"

The Divine Person replied: "The Dao is weighty and difficult to bestow upon men. Those who grasp it must hold fast, even unto death; thus, none may wrest a man’s aspiration from him. The transcendent scholars of Heaven do not covet honor or nobility. They delight only in life itself—there is no extraordinary path. Remember my precepts, and you shall recite them ceaselessly; my words must never be forgotten for ten thousand generations. Even if one ascends to the boundless heavens of utmost purity, the precepts remain thus—there is nothing extraordinary beyond them."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes," and dared not stray from the guiding line.

The Divine Person said: "If you are truly as you say, you have already attained the Dao. The auspicious shall advance daily, while the wicked shall cease their ascent. Holding the heart thus, you fulfill the divine precepts. Having accomplished this, you shall ride clouds and mount dragons, roaming the eight directions. The great Dao lies open before you; your life shall be long and boundless."

The Perfected One said, "Yes, yes."

The Divine Person continued: "The Dao is truly vast, without inner or outer bounds. Yet one must ever fear being harmed by great evil, for if one does not heed even a single wickedness, how could evil ever prevail? Thus, the ancient emperors and kings who loved the Dao and studied it, refusing to listen to evil, all attained lives of ten thousand myriad years. Those who heeded and employed wicked words all brought ruin upon themselves. My Dao encompasses myriad facets—you must know their benefits and harms."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes."

"Now that you have received the words of the Divine Person, may you attain long life in an instant?"

The Divine Person replied: "Without deep precepts, even accomplished deeds may turn inauspicious, and the Dao will not be fulfilled."

The Perfected One said: "Is my life fated by destiny, or is it mere fortune that I have encountered the Divine Person?"

The Divine Person replied: "Such is the nature of the Six Kinds of Men. Each has their own destiny: first, the Divine Person; second, the Perfected Person; third, the Immortal; fourth, the Daoist; fifth, the Sage; sixth, the Worthy. All assist Heaven in governance. The Divine Person presides over Heaven, the Perfected Person over Earth, the Immortal over wind and rain, the Daoist over teaching and the auspices of good and ill, the Sage over governing the people, and the Worthy assists the Sage in ordering the records of the myriad folk, supplying what is lacking in the Six Directions. Thus, men are born with their own destinies—those fated for nobility cannot be base, and those fated for baseness cannot be noble. Do you wish to know the truth of this? Consider the fish, which though it dwells in water, cannot soar without the water’s qi; the dragon, however, rides the water’s qi to ascend the azure clouds and become Heaven’s messenger. Nobility and baseness are truly matters of destiny—fools who speak recklessly do so in vain. The ancient sage-kings, in their great wisdom, did not record or heed false words, knowing them to be impossible. This is like teaching a man without the Dao to suddenly fly—how could he take flight? Only those who have attained the Dao and become immortals can truly fly. When the common folk play and boast, 'I can fly,' yet cannot, they speak falsehoods like this."

The Perfected One said: "Excellent! I have awakened to this truth."

The Divine Person replied: "Are you still so foolish as to think that Heaven’s mandate can be forcibly obtained?"

The Perfected One said: "Can this Dao also be learned?"

The Divine Person replied: "Only those with Heaven’s mandate may learn it and surely attain great transcendence. Those of middling worth who study it may also attain long life, while the foolish who pursue it may gain a lesser span. Do you wish to see its effects? It is like the common man who studies: the greatly worthy may become high officials, those of middling worth may become middling officials, and the foolish may become petty clerks. Are not petty clerks still set above the common folk? Thus, one should strive to study."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes. I shall practice this without ever daring to slacken."

The Divine Person said: "Then exert yourself and trust in the Dao. Between Heaven and Earth, each takes what is fitting—there is no falsehood in this."

The Perfected One assented, "Yes, yes," and pledged to honor Heaven and revere Earth, respect superiors and cherish inferiors, follow the four seasons and the five phases, and never dare to act wrongly.

The Divine Person said: "Excellent, excellent! You have grasped the meaning of the Dao. I need not instruct you further."

*Here ends the text on inducing goodness, expelling evil, and causing men to receive the precepts of the Dao.*

**End of Scroll Seventy-One of the Scripture of Great Peace**
**Beginning of Scroll Seventy-Two of the Scripture of Great Peace**

The Rites of Fasting, Abstinence, and Meditation on the Divine to Rescue from Death, Method One Hundred and Nine

The Perfected Writings of the Six Directions prostrated again and inquired: "Previously, we received the Celestial Master’s teaching that the qi of Great Peace is about to descend, and that the harmonization of yin and yang depends first upon harmonizing with the divine spirits, each returning to their proper place. Reflecting deeply upon the Celestial Master’s words, we find that those who can reverse illumination and penetrate with radiance see all things clearly, one by one. Yet such persons are exceedingly numerous—how can this be achieved? Can those Daoist masters who possess the reversed light of penetrating emptiness gather them together?"

The Celestial Master sighed, "Excellent, excellent! The imperial qi of Heaven is soon to arrive, and the sovereign shall govern with folded arms, free from care. Thus, Heaven has sent the various Perfected Ones to come and inquire thoroughly into the essentials of the supreme Dao, so that a sovereign of great virtue and luminous governance may arise, wholly eradicating the lingering disasters and inherited burdens of former kings, as well as the malevolent qi, demonic entities, treacherous spirits, and baleful influences that bring harm between Heaven and Earth."

The Perfected Ones came, each asking in turn about these essentials of the supreme Dao. "Do your disciples also not know these things for themselves?" The Perfected Ones replied, "Suddenly, we do not know." "If you do not know now, why do you ask?" They answered, "We have reflected upon the Celestial Master’s teachings and found some points unresolved. Since we do not know, by what means can we gather those who possess the most profound, tranquil, reversed light of emptiness—those who can perceive the malevolent? We find this strange, and so we have come together to ask."

"Excellent! The Perfected Ones’ dedication has advanced, and now you question this. Heaven has sent you to inquire fully on behalf of the virtuous sovereign, that these malevolent influences may be resolved."

"Very well."

"Now, I shall explain fully to the Perfected Ones, distinguishing and clarifying the essential meanings of the Dao. Sit at ease and record them together."

"Yes, yes."

The heavens and earth possess their own divine treasures, each endowed with numinous essence and radiance. These follow the Five Phases in color and wax and wane with the qi of the four seasons, serving as heaven and earth’s envoys to bring forth the myriad people and creatures. Within the interplay of heaven and earth, yin and yang, none escape their transformative virtue and generation.

Those who grasp their intent may witness them at once; those who fail to comprehend their essential meaning find no gateway to knowledge. Those who can broadly open and apply them achieve great fortune, able to dispel the afflictions, sufferings, malevolence, and evils that plague people between heaven and earth. Those who do not know the great method cannot recklessly summon or employ these spirits in vain.

We wish to hear their intent, that it may be transmitted for ten thousand generations without error.

Excellent is your question. To await and obtain this art, there exists a great method: the qi of the four seasons and Five Phases enters the human abdomen, becoming the spirit of the five viscera. Their colors correspond to the colors of heaven, earth, and the four seasons. When depicted as a person, let the three be harmonized—with the ruling qi’s color covering the exterior, the ministerial qi’s color next, and the subtle qi residing innermost—so that their garments and hems reveal them.

First, fast and reside in quietude, in a serene place. Reflect upon and contemplate them, then create their painted images, their length unrestricted. For the five, depict them together upon five feet of plain silk. Let them be well-crafted: men should envision men, women envision women. Such is the method of painting their images. These writings are already numerous, not confined to a single version. From top to bottom, discuss their textual meaning and proceed accordingly, using written words to subtly clarify.

Though my writings are many, they possess a grand division: texts are grouped by category, and characters elucidate one another, so that their essential meaning is fully attained.

Yes, yes.

This spirit of the four seasons and Five Phases enters to become the spirit of the five viscera and emerges to become the numinous essence of the four seasons and Five Phases. Those closest to humans are called the spirits of the Five Powers, resembling the spirits of the viscera. Those more distant are called the Solar Calendar, styled as the Four Seasons’ Troops and Horses, capable of repelling malevolence. They too act in accord with the waxing and waning qi of the four seasons.

For their method, prepare their painted images: let the person be clad in three layers of robes, with the ruling qi’s color on the outside, the ministerial qi’s next, and the subtle qi innermost. All wear caps and ride horses, the horses also arrayed in the colors of the Five Phases. First, paint the images on one side: two zhang in length, loosely depicting twenty-five riders upon five silks. Craft them well.

The riders of the east hold spears; those of the south, halberds; those of the west, bows, crossbows, and axes; those of the north, bucklers and sabers; and those of the center, swords and drums. In contemplation, one should first perceive the inner spirits, then the outer spirits. Or one may first see the yang spirits before the inner spirits. To perceive them thus is the method of formless images. One must also receive oral instructions from a master, for there is a crucial point at the outset. Those who know it find it easy to transmit and achieve; it is fitting to keep it distant from others and practice in seclusion. If it is easily gathered near people, it will surely be difficult to accomplish.

When this Dao is accomplished, it is called "illumination." Those of the utmost reversal and profound emptiness gather it. The forms of illness are not many; many is auspicious, few is inauspicious. If some remain untreated, unresolved, or uncured, how many must one obtain to suffice?

The highest obtain ten thousand, the middling four or five thousand, the lowest several hundred, or merely dozens. Why so many?

Ah, have the Perfected Ones reverted to their former ignorance? Be seated, and I shall now explain the essential meaning to you.

After the present era of bearing and shouldering [karmic burdens], heaven and earth suffer abundant calamities. Ghosts, old spirits, and baleful misfortunes—corpse-related omens are not singular. There are also wind-damp sores, scabies, and the manifold disasters of this degenerate age, too numerous to name. One person may have a hundred illnesses, or dozens. Suppose each person could be long or short-lived, or each could dispel one illness. Like a diviner skilled in the arts of milfoil and turtle-shell, removing one baleful affliction; or a great physician skilled in medicinal formulas, dispelling one illness; or an acupuncturist skilled in needling the channels, dispelling one illness; or one skilled in moxibustion, dispelling one illness; or one skilled in exorcism, dispelling one illness; or one skilled in sacrifices, dispelling one illness; or one skilled in commanding spirits to guide and inspect ghosts, dispelling one illness—these seven people each remove one illness, thus dispelling seven illnesses.

In this degenerate age, people suffer many illnesses; some have a dozen, while others claim to have a hundred, all afflicted with every kind of suffering. Though all skilled artisans each remove one illness—thus dispelling seven—the remaining illnesses persist, not fully eradicated. The strength of the seven artisans is exhausted, yet these remaining illnesses continue to torment people. Over time, they become impoverished, and many die, unable to extricate themselves from their plight.

How long is a person’s allotted lifespan? How many illnesses do they witness? They encounter hardships, prosperity and decline, advance and retreat. Heaven’s standard is like the four seasons and Five Phases, which have their waxing and waning. The eight trigrams Qian and Kun are the bodies of heaven and earth, yet they too have times of rest, imprisonment, desolation, and diminished qi. How much more so for humans?

Humans emulate heaven and earth, the four seasons, the Five Phases, the six conjunctions, and the eight directions, ever waxing and waning without cease. Thus, one must prepare in advance, rescuing the sources of fortune and misfortune. In peace, do not forget peril; in existence, do not forget annihilation; in order, do not forget chaos. Only then can one endure long.

Therefore, in the method of treating malevolence, the Daoist does not suffer many illnesses. If one person can dispel one illness, ten people dispel ten illnesses, a hundred dispel a hundred, a thousand dispel a thousand, and ten thousand dispel ten thousand.

A single person’s body—how could it bear ten thousand illnesses? Thus, one who can thoroughly treat and decisively cure them does so. Do you understand this? Indeed, indeed.

Therefore, teaching them to prepare in advance with warnings, those who perfect the Dao gather them. Indeed, indeed. Proceed—you now understand. Proceed, for the Perfected One clearly sets forth this arrangement.

The illnesses thus treated are spectral entities and great malevolence, which together act as thieves and bandits. When the emperor and king enjoy peace, they constantly maintain armies and generals to guard against others; yet if these forces turn against righteousness, they become traitors and rebels.

Thus, if one person dares to die, ten dare not oppose; if ten dare to die, a hundred dare not oppose; if a hundred dare to die, a thousand dare not oppose; if a thousand dare to die, ten thousand dare not oppose; and if ten thousand dare to die, they may advance unchecked in all directions.

Preparing for illness, injury, and harm, the army and its generals thus maintain twelve thousand men to guard against the unforeseen. The two thousand among them serve only to fill gaps and ensure smooth operations—only then can they be subdued. Does the Perfected One understand? Indeed, indeed.

"Proceed, for you have now understood. *Ineffectual Grand Pronouncements Without Practical Methods*, One Hundred and Ten.

Permit me to ask one matter, Heavenly Master: now that the qi of Great Peace is about to arrive, should not the qi of evil be contemplating its own cessation and departure?

Indeed, what you say is both correct and incorrect. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, evil should naturally dissipate. Yet since the opening of Heaven and Earth, evil qi has accumulated over vast ages, amassing in great multitudes, each generation inheriting and compounding the last. Though the governing qi of Great Peace has come, how could it eradicate all this in a single day? Thus, one must prepare in advance. To wait until evil has already wrought its devastation before seeking skilled artisans—this is far too late.

In the highest antiquity, each person knew the true Dao, and there was little evil qi. From the era of the Supreme Middle Antiquity onward, people grew foolish, delighting in superficial adornments and neglecting the true Dao. Evil qi, frenzied spirits, and calamitous misfortunes multiplied, so that many met their end before fulfilling their allotted years. All this arose from benighted minds, clouded and obscured, failing to guard against the root in advance.

Now, under the governance of a ruler of supreme virtue, Heaven cherishes him and does not wish him to suffer like those foolish multitudes, cut short in their years. It desires that he swiftly perfect his great virtue and align his heart with Heaven. Thus, Heaven has sent the various Perfected Ones to inquire of doubts, bidding me expound the methods by which one may suppress and repel inauspicious and malevolent forces. For this reason, I have set forth these teachings in full for the Perfected One.

Yet now you claim that evil should vanish of itself and no preparations are needed—this is incorrect, a grave misstatement that misleads the noble-minded. Your words cannot be heeded. How can this be so?"

Yet when great urgency arises, one seeks remedies only then—such measures cannot be swiftly obtained, leaving one destitute and distressed. Thus, the Perfected One’s words are gravely mistaken and cannot be followed.

Now, when grain is stored to fill the granaries, it serves to prepare against hunger. I have now expounded this Way with utmost clarity for the Perfected One, that it may endure for ten thousand generations without being forgotten.

“Indeed, indeed.”

If one waits until hunger strikes before teaching people to sow grain, instructing them to till and cultivate, awaiting the ripening of the harvest before cooking a meal—how could this possibly suffice in time? By then, they would have already starved to death in distress. Or if one fails to sow in spring and, when winter’s hunger gnaws, only then desires to plant grain—yet the seeds do not sprout—how could this ever suffice to save lives? Not only would the individual perish, but the entire household would be wiped out. This is the height of the Perfected One’s folly, the starkest proof of benighted ignorance.

Let me further illustrate with another example. When people dig wells, it is to prepare against thirst; when they dwell near springs, it is to guard against thirst. But if one waits until parched and on the verge of death before digging a well to seek water—how could it be obtained in time? They would already be ruined. This is the Perfected One’s second instance of folly and blindness.

Let me now recount another matter for the Perfected One.

In ancient times, people built shelters; today, they construct houses and dwellings to prepare against wind and rain. When there is no wind or rain, living in the wild brings utmost joy. Yet if one waits until floating clouds arise and wind and rain descend before building a house—by then, drenched and chilled, one would already be ruined. This is the Perfected One’s third folly.

Let me recount another matter for the Perfected One. Since the era of High Antiquity, sages have established governments, built walled cities and deep moats to prepare against unforeseen calamities. In times of peace, all remains tranquil and untroubled. But when disaster strikes and petty men seek to defile and disrupt the noble, only then do they order the people to construct walled cities and deep moats—how could this ever suffice in an emergency? This is the starkest proof of the Perfected One’s extreme folly and blindness.

Let me further illustrate with another example. Weapons of war are instruments of ill omen, which the noble person fundamentally should not possess. Those below despise them, so they should be placed in sheaths, securely stored, and never prized. Neither should their possession nor their use be valued. They exist only to prepare against the unforeseen. Yet when an urgent crisis arises, only then do they command artisans to quarry stone for iron, smelt it into molten metal, and then have master smiths forge it ten thousand times to create a Moye blade—could this ever suffice in time for battle or defense? One would already be subjugated, life and death surrendered. Is this not the Perfected One’s sixth instance of profound folly?

Indeed, indeed. To err is not an error if one reflects deeply in one’s heart before acting. Thereafter, do not speak lightly or recklessly.

Indeed, indeed. Let me impart to the Perfected One a minor principle, which, when reversed, illuminates the greater truth.

The ancients, those sagely and wise, devised combs and fine-toothed lice combs to prepare against tangled hair and lice infestations. Yet if one lives without ever grooming, hair becomes irreparably matted, nits and lice multiply beyond counting, and together they feast upon the scalp until sores erupt—only then does one seek fine wood from the southern mountains or rare ivory fit for crafting, commanding skilled artisans to fashion them. By then, the hair is beyond untangling, the lice too numerous to eradicate, and the scalp already ravaged. Is this not another instance of profound folly?

Let me now present to the Perfected One this minor principle, using the small to illustrate the great.

Consider the rivers, seas, and five lakes: near their waters, mosquitoes and horseflies abound. Yet if one fails to prepare in advance what might shield and defend against them, when the swarms rise and descend to feed upon men, cattle, and horses—when cattle and horses thrash their heads and stamp in vain, and men grow desperate, nearing death with no respite—only then does one seek means to repel them. By then, all is already lost.

Does the Perfected One not clearly see this?
Indeed, indeed.

You have already awakened to this. The finest remedies can repel scabies mites, and fine clothing with proper dwellings can ward off fleas and lice—yet if one fails to prepare them in advance, only when affliction strikes does one seek means to dispel them. By then, one is already plunged into profound distress and suffering.

Do you understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

These are but the most trifling of worldly provisions—how much more so the vast and weighty matters? Between heaven and earth, at every moment there arise violent ghosts, malevolent spirits, calamitous omens, corpse-curses, and deadly visitations. When they descend upon a person, it is as if arrows from blades, bows, and crossbows have pierced the body. The pain is unbearable; in the most severe cases, one gasps for breath without respite, cannot stand upright, and the body is seized by violent frenzy. It is like being in a desolate pavilion, far from the reach of the emperor’s officials, where one’s words are blocked and obstructed, unable to report the crisis. Only then does one seek skilled masters and elders to save oneself—yet by then, all is already lost. Words can no longer pass, and no plea remains to be heard.

Do you understand this? Yes, yes. Go forth—you have now awakened. Thus I am especially urgent about this matter of death, the greatest calamity under heaven. Therefore, my writings—*dōng-dōng*—instruct those of virtue and rulers to prepare in advance. The most wise, upon seeing my words, will surely awaken fully; those of middling wisdom, upon reading my writings, will partially awaken; the foolish and unenlightened will not awaken but instead mock my words for failing to grasp their essence—thus they have already reached their limit. For heaven, earth, and the emperors, there is no matter more pressing than this.

Now, as the qi of Great Peace arrives and the virtuous lord of yang rules, his reign should endure long. Yet death among the people of the world is no small matter. Once dead, one never again beholds heaven and earth, sun and moon—flesh and bone become mere mud. Death is a weighty affair. Each person dwelling between heaven and earth is granted but one life; none may live twice. Only those who have attained the Dao may be reborn after death—those who undergo *shijie* (corpse liberation). These are the ones heaven and earth favor in secret, not even one in ten thousand.

Thus, for ordinary people, once dead, there is no return to life. Therefore, one must prepare thoroughly. Even in the era of Great Peace and years of abundance, perverse qi still lingers. It is like a household that is mostly good yet harbors wicked individuals—only by enduring one another is harmony maintained. For this reason, it is all the more necessary to gather those skilled in the Dao and its arts, so that when the unwholesome arises, it may be swiftly eradicated. If not removed promptly, it will take root and grow. Thus, I teach preparedness and the multiplication of such people.

The purpose of great learning is to accumulate those of virtue and power, ensuring they may be sought when needed. Without prior cultivation and gathering, they cannot be obtained in haste. Should an unforeseen crisis arise and one wish to consult ancient and modern precedents, without those of profound virtue and power already at hand, none will be able to respond promptly or resolve the matter. The ruler, left in darkness and obstruction, will face doubts and questions that cannot be decided in time, only later seeking wise and virtuous masters from distant lands—how could this compare to having them ready at hand?

Perfected One, do you understand? Yes, yes.

"Excellent, you have now greatly awakened. Though your every utterance may invite reproach, without inquiry, ignorance would persist. I wish to resolve one matter for you: whether of high rank—ten thousand men—or middling—several thousand—or low—several hundred—how could they be swiftly obtained and swiftly accomplished?

Excellent indeed is your questioning of affairs. Simply instruct ten or so men to perfect it, and let them naturally transmit and transform one another. In urgent need, they will produce swift results, and those who succeed will emerge. Command the Virtuous Dao Lord of Supreme Power to esteem and cherish them; for those who achieve merit, bestow rewards.
