The multitude will then aspire to it, and as their aspirations grow, they will follow in great numbers. Let them act, and for those who attain, let all honor and cherish them together.

The spirits of the four seasons, five phases, heaven, and earth, seeing them esteemed and cherished, will all rejoice and delight, bringing good fortune to people. The Virtuous Lord will long enjoy their auspicious blessings, and whether among the multitude of worthy and profound or the foolish, none will not vie to act thus. As those who do so increase day by day, in time, great and small will all be transformed. When all can act thus, then select from among them those of the greatest merit, gather them all, appoint those of great achievement to their positions, and reward those of lesser merit. None under heaven will not desire to act thus.

Yet fear not their great numbers—how could they be too many to record? Why worry over scarcity? Perfected One, how profoundly foolish, benighted, and deluded you are! A single matter, once decisively settled, must not be abandoned; those who merely indulge in grand words are of no benefit to others. Simply follow the model: those who consistently achieve success are those who grasp the intent of the Dao and are greatly trusted by others. Those who know but a few words yet produce no great effect have not grasped the intent of the Dao and speak recklessly—they are great flatterers, unfit for use, and only bring chaos to the Dao.

Perfected One, do you understand? Yes, yes.

Go now, be cautious and vigilant. Recite and study my writings, ponder their higher and lower meanings, and let like follow like. Use them to verify and complement one another, and you will attain great comprehension, knowing the direction in which my Dao points. Yes, yes."

**Secret of the Five Spirits’ Attributes, One Hundred and Eleven**

I wish to ask of a great secret: why does the spirit of the East hold a spear?

You need not ask.

The Perfected One must know this already.

Yet I ask because, Master, you graciously pity later generations. By setting forth the method, if I do not ask, those of future ages will not comprehend the intent of Heaven’s Dao.

Very well. This is the image of Heaven. All things follow their kind.

The East is where things first sprout, heads breaking forth, all growth benefiting as they pierce the earth and emerge—its essence resembles a spear. Thus, it is the spear. When the spirit-officials of the East arrive, they take this as their insignia.

The South: all things hang branches and spread leaves, like a halberd. Thus, its spirit holds a halberd. When the spirit-officials of the South arrive, they take this as their insignia.

The West is the bow, crossbow, and axe. The West is the image of Heaven’s crossbow of slaughter. The bow, crossbow, and axe are the greatest instruments of harm. Thus, when its spirits arrive, they take these as their insignia.

The North is the shield, buckler, and blade. The North is where things hide and flee. Shields and bucklers serve to protect the body; blades are wielded by petty men, ever used to evade and harm—these are not the possessions of noble gentlemen. Thus, when its spirits arrive, they too take these as their insignia.

The Center is thunder, the drum, and the sword. The Center is Earth, the ruler of the Five Phases. The drum is the chief of the five weapons; the sword is worn by gentlemen of virtue and power, and is also the chief of the five weapons. Thus, when the spirits of the Center arrive, they take these as their insignia.

These are the true and natural credentials of Heaven and Earth. Just as a person is born with a head, so too must they bear their proper insignia. When the authentic credentials arrive in response, anything else is not the true spirit-official. If other spirits falsely arrive in response, all becomes disordered governance. Over time, such chaos is difficult to pacify. Therefore, all seek the true credentials.

Perfected One, do you understand?

Yes, yes.

This discourse moves from the shallow to the deep, for even what seems insignificant must align and harmonize with the qi of Heaven, Earth, the four seasons, and the Five Phases.

Excellent, excellent. Proceed—Perfected One, you understand this well.

Here ends the method to suppress evil and transform all into the Dao to save lives.

*End of Scroll Seventy-Two of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Scroll Eighty-Six of the Scripture of Great Peace follows*
*Collected Writings of the Three Daoist Texts, Method One Hundred Twenty-Seven*

The Six Perfected Ones of the Six Directions all respectfully bowed. Having previously received the Celestial Master’s teachings to compile and present a solemn memorial, each returned to their respective posts, pressing their hands to their hearts to ponder its meaning. For seven days and seven nights, the Six Perfected Ones convened thrice to deliberate, yet remained perplexed.

These three assemblies were held in the open, where they witnessed three celestial omens in the form of shooting stars. First, they saw a star emerge from the Gate of Heaven and enter the Door of Earth. Next, they saw a star depart from the Great Yang and plunge into the Great Yin. Third, they saw the constellations stream into the Celestial Prison.

Fearing that the Celestial Master’s threefold scriptures might be severed below, preventing their ascent and causing Heaven’s wrath to deepen, they deliberated together. If the qi of the Supreme August One could not descend, then the virtuous sovereign, though steadfast, would continue to bear the lingering disasters of former kings, enduring sorrow and hardship.

Alas! The Six Perfected Ones, having come on behalf of the August Spirit to inquire, must now redouble their efforts for Heaven’s sake.

I have observed that among all disciples, none surpass these Perfected Ones. Now, let them explain the meaning of the shooting stars.

Your six disciples, though dull and benighted, dare not remain silent.

First, a star emerged from the Gate of Heaven and entered the Door of Earth. The Gate of Heaven is yang, the sovereign. The Door of Earth is yin, the ministers and people. Now, if the ministers and people do not ascend in their conduct to attach themselves above but instead turn to bestow favor downward—if the door and gate, which govern communication, now see the lower gate fail to ascend while the upper gate opens downward—this signifies that the lower petition is severed, preventing its ascent.

Excellent, Perfected Ones. Your words leave nothing to be added. Though weary, proceed to explain the second omen.

Yes, yes.

The second omen showed a star from the Great Yang streaming into the Great Yin. The Great Yang is the sovereign; the Great Yin, the ministers and people. The Great Yang is luminous; the Great Yin, dark and obscure. Now, the obscure should flow upward into the luminous, just as ministers and people, benighted and impoverished, should attach themselves to a radiant king and sagely lord to seek redress for their grievances. Yet here, the luminous descends into obscurity—this mirrors imperial edicts bestowing grace, their downward course severed. The obscure remains unilluminated, internal governance descends into chaos, and the darkness veils the sovereign above.

It also resembles petty officials and local leaders who, together, conceal Heaven and Earth’s calamities and omens, preventing their transmission upward. In darkness, they deceive their superiors alongside the ministers and people, serving as proof of their collusion in villainy.

Excellent, excellent! Your words, Six Disciples, leave nothing to be added. Though weary, proceed to explain the third omen.

Yes, yes.

The third omen showed the constellations streaming into the Celestial Prison. The constellations are stars of goodness and rectitude, yet they flowed into the Celestial Prison—the place where Heaven metes out punishment. This portends that worthy and virtuous men, wishing to serve the sovereign and present memorials to communicate Heaven and Earth’s counsel, are instead resented and maligned by distant officials in the wilderness. Later, these officials fabricate charges to harm them, causing the constellations to stream into prison.

Excellent and precise! Your words, Six Disciples, leave nothing to be added. Now, why do you alone seem aggrieved, as if weary of inquiry?

We dare not. We have always heard the Celestial Master say that the Perfected Ones come from Heaven to inquire. If we were to cease now, we fear Heaven’s words would not be conveyed. All human lives belong to Heaven and Earth. If Heaven and Earth are displeased, they will instead afflict people with illness, preventing them from fulfilling their allotted years.

Excellent! The Perfected Ones’ words are correct and unerring. Now, I shall speak to you all without daring to omit or slacken. We Perfected Ones are equals, our lives all belonging to Heaven and Earth. If we withhold our words or speak and then cease, Heaven and Earth will together harm us. Thus, I dare not speak recklessly or stop.

Proceed, then, and explain fully for the Six Perfected Ones.

The Six Perfected Ones have newly emerged to ponder Heaven’s concerns, seeking to eliminate Heaven’s afflictions, and to contemplate the thoughts of a virtuous sovereign, seeking to resolve disasters and secure peace. Let the Six Perfected Ones thoroughly discuss their intentions, expressing all they wish to say, so that nothing is severed or obstructed.

Yes, yes.

We dare not fail to exhaust even the meager wisdom of a sparrow or mouse in speaking all we know, as the Celestial Master has commanded.

Most admirable.

Yes, yes.

Now, the world fears the closing of mouths, for none dare speak recklessly. Even the sun, moon, and stars—spirits of Heaven’s constellations—stand in awe of one another. Thus, when the sun rises, the stars flee and hide, not daring to appear, fearing its majesty.

Within the four borders, a stern sovereign commands the realm, and all are struck with terror. Even those far from the capital dare not speak when an imperial edict arrives. If a province has a powerful governor, the entire province dares not speak. If a commandery has a strong magistrate, the whole commandery dares not speak. If a county has a harsh magistrate, the entire county dares not speak. Even if a remote post has a severe post captain, the entire post dares not speak. Yet this post captain is but the lowest of officials—how much more so for ministers?

All fear harm and seek only to absolve themselves. Though they may harbor good intentions, they dare not express them to their superiors, causing the Dao to be severed at this point. Now, if even a single village has a stern and upright man who upholds its order, the entire village dares not speak, fearing later resentment and harm.

Should but a single household have a man of martial vigor and unyielding qi who holds sway, even that household dares not speak. Yet within a household, all share flesh and blood, born of the same kind—still they loathe and fear one another so. How much more so for those of different generations?

Since the High Antiquity of the Supreme Dao, the Way and its virtue have been largely lost, replaced by governance through might and coercion. Those who press and compel obedience mete out grave harm to any who resist, inflicting wounds so deep they flow to descendants. Thus, though the people witness celestial portents and ominous calamities, they dare not speak rashly of them, fearing those near and bound to them. Such silence accumulates over time, passing burdens from one to the next. By the Latter Antiquity, the affliction grows even more severe: should any minor figure seek to memorialize the throne or speak his mind to the emperor, those nearby who hold his life in their hands will kill him outright—or if not immediately, later conspire to harm him through connections and favors. Thus, ministers and commoners alike seal their tongues and shut their mouths in darkness, though they see sorrow, injustice, and evil, they dare not transmit it upward.

Though the emperor’s wisdom is peerless, celestial anomalies multiply daily—clear proof of this. Now, the people are born and receive their mandate from Heaven and Earth, taking them as father and mother. When they witness disasters, omens, good or ill, these are the words of Heaven and Earth, their very speech. Yet all are so terrified, so threatened by those near and bound to them, that they dare not speak or reveal the matter. Instead, they admonish one another, turning their backs on Heaven and Earth, cutting off all communication, blocking the words Heaven and Earth wish to convey. They thus obscure and wrong Heaven and Earth, preventing their voices from being heard, leaving them long embittered and unexpressed.

Though the emperor may be divine and sagely, he is but one source, nestled within a hundred layers of men, beyond ten thousand li. Even if those within the hundred layers wish to convey words, they are coerced by those near them and cannot reach him. Though the emperor may possess the benevolence and wisdom of ten thousand men, each person is pressed and cowed by fear. Heaven and Earth, the most divine and supreme, are merely gazed upon from afar—people rely on them only to absolve themselves in the moment. How could the emperor’s divinity surpass that of Heaven and Earth?

We six fools once encountered a fierce tiger in the distant wilderness. All six halted, dared not move, dared not speak, dared not turn our heads, dared not close our eyes. Such is the coercion and fear that men endure! How excellent, how excellent! Now, hearing the words of the Six Perfected Ones, we understand that Heaven alone has long suffered grievous injustice, its words unable to reach above. Though it creates ten thousand strange anomalies as its speech, below they are blocked and severed, unable to ascend, leaving only pent-up bitterness over time.

Thus, the wind now stirs the Perfected Ones, instructing them to admonish and charge this matter of the scripture’s transmission. Therefore, the Perfected Ones, trembling and weary, are Heaven’s envoys. Very well. We revere Heaven’s majesty and shall ponder its essential meaning for you in full.

Now, the Six Perfected Ones ask: of these matters, which is the most severe? We six fools deliberated for seven days and seven nights on this matter of the scripture’s transmission, convening thrice and thrice witnessing meteors, taking them as Heaven’s command to instruct and charge men to inquire. Moreover, all six of us ingested qi, yet it could not descend and pass through, instead reversing and rising upward. At that moment, our ears and eyes grew dizzy and blind, and we were all astonished, discussing it together, unaware of what it portended—greatly alarmed and terrified. Only the Heavenly Master explained it to us fools.

Excellent! The Perfected Ones have grasped the ancient transformations and their full meaning. Hearing the Perfected Ones’ words, we now know of the Three Dao Scriptures. Yet the Perfected Ones will soon be blocked and severed again—why? We wish to hear the decisive meaning.

Now, the nine orifices correspond to the divisions of the Nine Provinces. The Perfected Ones themselves say that when they ingest qi, it [blocks] and does not pass through, leaving them dizzy and without light—this is the pressing coercion among the great and small of the Nine Provinces, where urgent words from below cannot reach above. Qi is that which conveys the mandate of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. Heaven and Earth transform the mandate of the myriad things through qi and wind. That qi [blocks] and does not pass through is clear proof that the Dao of Heaven is obstructed and cannot reach its destination.

Heaven wishes the Perfected Ones to admonish this matter, thus stirring and moving them through qi. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Proceed—you have understood well.

So be it.

Heaven instructs the Six Perfected Ones: should I speak to the utmost on this matter? Let the six of you sit at ease and expound the Way fully for all disciples.

For those who fear the governors and officials of their provinces and dare not speak, let all the virtuous and wise within a province seek one another out and convene in another province to deliberate. If they fear the officials of their commandery, let them convene in another commandery. If they fear their county, let them convene in another county. If they fear their township or ward, let them convene in another township or ward. If they fear their village, let them convene in another village.

In all cases where prohibitions and fears constrain people, let the transgressions and omens they report be judged according to their severity, and let their original offenses be increased by one degree. Why so severe? It should not be severe—yet we still fear it may be too lenient.

Now, Heaven and Earth cherish a virtuous emperor-king and wish to fully inform him. Yet humankind, born of Heaven and Earth, turns its back on them, severs the celestial discourse, and causes Heaven to fall ill. The accumulation remains unremoved, pent-up and obstructed, unable to convey its message to its children—this is a grave and heinous crime.

The people and ministers are the envoys of the emperor-king, his hands and feet. They ought to clarify and convey his wisdom, ensuring that above, he may rest without worry, and together, they may align with the heart of Heaven. When Heaven rejoices, it grants the ruler extended years. Yet now, those below act disloyally, betraying Heaven and Earth, blocking the emperor-king’s wisdom, and causing him distress. He constantly reproaches himself for governance gone awry, while disasters and omens multiply, leaving him perilous and uneasy. All this stems from disloyalty, unfiliality, faithlessness, and great transgressions against the law—such offenses are not worthy of pardon. How, then, can severity be questioned?

When the celestial discourse cannot flow, Heaven and Earth grow enraged, slaughtering all living things, thus destroying Heaven and Earth. Such is a year of utmost calamity, a realm bereft of wisdom, a nation in grave peril. This crime defies description—it is a transgression deserving of death and beyond.

Do the Perfected Ones understand? Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, for you have now understood. The reason I dare not remain silent is that I see the Six Masters come to inquire of affairs, and I recognize your commission as envoys of Heaven. How, then, could the Perfected Ones dare to withhold their words? Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

If I do not speak now, it would be called misleading those above. The Virtuous Lord, upon seeing these writings, commands all who submit memorials to ensure that those with great merit are duly rewarded. In this way, none under Heaven will fail to rejoice, delighting in exerting their utmost strength to submit memorials and speak of affairs. Let it not be that only a solitary voice is heard—all must gather to deliberate. If one person speaks falsely or with deceitful flattery, it would cause the ruler to lose grasp of reality, and such grave errors must not be heeded.

In recent years, those who have submitted memorials have done so with increasing reliability, and many have rendered great service. Yet those of the highest rank who gather in numbers are often too few—when only two or three assemble, there are invariably many among them who harbor deceit and falsehood. Why is this so? I wish to explain.

When many gather, those who submit memorials naturally restrain one another, fearing that matters may be leaked, that their strengths and weaknesses may be exposed, or that they may be accused of deceiving their superiors or be reported by others. Thus, they dare not speak unless they have thoroughly verified the facts. If they do not verify, they dare not speak, nor dare they conceal anything, for they fear the consequences that may follow. This is why their words are entirely trustworthy.

Consider a village of a hundred households engaged in deceit: among its men, women, children, and elders, there will always be someone who reveals the truth, and neighboring villages will come to know of it. The wise and cautious in that village will not dare to conceal it, fearing they may be implicated. How much less, then, can matters in a prefecture, a commandery, a county, a township, or a post station be hidden? If a commandery experiences extraordinary events, how can they remain concealed? They will inevitably be exposed by others, and thus all good and evil will come to light. Heaven will rejoice greatly, disasters will be dispelled, and the realm will flow as smoothly as running water. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Moreover, when great assemblies deliberate, none dare deceive, for if one or two attempt falsehood, the rest will refuse to comply. Should any seek to deceive or act in bad faith, the multitude will immediately record and report it. Such conduct—defying Heaven and Earth, deceiving the sovereign, engaging in grand treachery and unrighteousness—incurs the wrath of Heaven and the hatred of humankind. Their crimes admit no pardon.

Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, for you have now awakened. Once the memorial is submitted and you return home, those who resent your actions may seek to harm you by submitting slanderous petitions—what the left bureau terms "resentment memorials"—whose transgressions remain unforgiven. Yet when the three channels of memorials flow unimpeded, none dare obstruct them. Thus, Heaven and Earth rejoice, the sovereign’s accumulated burdens of disaster and misfortune are largely dispelled, and the realm attains Great Peace. The primordial qi of the Highest Sovereign descends in full, aiding the Virtuous Ruler in governance. The Six Perfected Ones shall not fail.

Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, for the essence of the Six Perfected Ones has greatly advanced, purging Heaven’s afflictions and dispelling the sovereign’s calamities. Their merit is already inscribed in Heaven, and the king’s rule grows daily in strength and clarity. The Six Perfected Ones, in their goodness, have fulfilled their measure. They must strive diligently—caution, the utmost caution!

Indeed, indeed.

I humbly ask for one great secret: may the Celestial Master reveal it? How can we know whether the memorials’ circulation has fully harmonized with the divine spirits?

Yes, there is a great verification, for the Dao of Heaven does not deceive. Like seeks like in its search. Let the Virtuous Ruler frequently dispatch trusted officials to inquire among the people: how many suffer from ulcers, pestilence, or scabies? If many bear such afflictions, the memorials have not yet fully harmonized with the divine spirits, for residual suffering remains—worms still consume people, and thus the worms govern them. This is the effect of the lower ranks teeming with immoral subjects, who, like worms, devour the people. Where no ulcers, pestilence, or scabies exist, it is because only the good hold office, and no worms remain. In this, not one in ten thousand errs.

Excellent, excellent!

Does this alone suffice as proof, or are there further signs?

All calamities and anomalies under Heaven arise in response to governance, each with its own manifestations. If one but reflects deeply upon the matter, one shall come to understand—why single out ulcers, pestilence, and scabies? Other disasters are merely visible in the myriad things, yet none is more severe than worms devouring people, and thus it serves as verification.

Excellent, excellent!

Had we not earnestly inquired of the Heavenly Master, we would have had no means of knowing this. Now that the Perfected Ones have spoken, we understand at once—this was but a gesture of humility.

We dare not, we dare not. We six foolish students, having received the Heavenly Master’s solemn instruction, shall return to our respective dwellings and contemplate its essential meaning. Yet the Heavenly Master’s writings urge all, from the highest to the lowest, even to servants and slaves, to gather and jointly submit memorials reporting calamities, anomalies, good and ill omens—is this not overly burdensome?

We wish to hear the reasoning behind this.

Excellent! You six have been tasked with inquiring of Heaven’s affairs—proceed with utmost care, for the Perfected Ones speak by Heaven’s decree.

The reason for extending this to commoners and even slaves is this: under Heaven’s vast expanse, regions a myriad *li* apart differ in sky and earth; five thousand *li* apart, they differ slightly; a thousand *li* apart, their *qi* and winds diverge; five hundred *li* apart, they differ again in small measure; a hundred *li* apart, their yin and rain vary; fifty *li* apart, they differ once more in minor ways. Within a single county, anomalies, calamities, strange phenomena, good and ill omens all manifest uniquely.

When the August Heaven sends forth calamities and strange transformations, they do not necessarily appear only in the imperial palace, the halls of local officials, or before high-ranking magistrates. Such anomalies are most often seen in the wilderness and among the common folk, where the lowly and humble learn of them first. Yet each conceals them out of fear for their superiors, daring not speak. Officials, too, conceal them out of fear for their lords, and so the discourse between Heaven and Earth is severed.

Each seeks to flatter their superiors, desiring their names to be praised and their merits swiftly recognized, so they collude in wrongdoing, suppressing Heaven and Earth’s calamities and anomalies, blocking their transmission to the emperor. Thus, the Son of Heaven is cut off without cause, deprived of wisdom, unable to grasp the will of Heaven and Earth. His governance grows perilous and chaotic, fraught with sorrow.

The emperor is born by the mandate of Heaven, with Heaven as his father and Earth as his mother, making him the Son of Heaven. When ministers and people together act without the Dao, they sever the discourse between father and mother, preventing it from reaching their child. What crime could be greater?

To jointly sever the discourse of Heaven and Earth, to deceive one’s superiors, to be unfaithful and untrustworthy as ministers and people—how could such offenses be named lightly? Do you now understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Moreover, all people, ministers, servants, and slaves are born of Heaven, nurtured by Earth, and governed and sustained by the emperor. These three matters constitute their very lives—without them, there would be no means to be born, to grow, or to nourish and order themselves. Yet they all turn to deceive their superiors, collectively ignorant of Heaven and Earth, rendering the emperor devoid of wisdom and obstructed. Their crimes merit ten thousand deaths, and even then, their guilt would remain unexhausted—how grave is this!

Perfected One, are you so benighted as not to comprehend? People are born of Heaven and nurtured by Earth. When Heaven and Earth suffer distress and illness, they manifest anomalies and transformations to admonish their child, desiring joyfully to see governance rectified. Yet the foolish people jointly sever the discourse of Heaven, incurring the great wrath of Heaven and Earth.

The emperor is the father and mother of the people and ministers, yet they collectively deceive their parents, causing them constant mental anguish and hindering the peace of their rule. What fault could be greater? Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the accumulated hardships of karmic inheritance have all arisen from this. Thus, the people are permitted to submit memorials.

Now, the Radiant Virtue Lord governs, and Heaven, grieved by its difficulties, has sent me to speak. Excellent, excellent indeed! Come, let me now explain this to you, Perfected One.

Today, a solar eclipse—a most extraordinary omen in all under Heaven—may be witnessed by some yet unseen by others. The myriad calamities, anomalies, and transformations in the world are all the discourse of Heaven and Earth, the shifts of yin and yang. Some kingdoms may not witness them, yet their provinces do; some provinces may not, yet their commanderies do; some commanderies may not, yet their counties do; some counties may not, yet their townships do; some townships may not, yet the people do; some in one village may not, yet those in another do.

Thus, in the governance of the ancient worthies and sages, even the lowliest were encouraged to report strange occurrences, aligning with the will of Heaven and Earth to secure their own well-being. Therefore, their rule alone remained perpetually peaceful, in perfect accord with Heaven.

Now, as the qi of Great Peace flourishes, even a single matter left unresolved disrupts harmony, and the upright qi of Heaven fails to arrive. It is like foolish people draining the waters to fish—no dragons will appear. This is what it means.

Therefore, all the people are now permitted to speak, so that not even a hair’s breadth of Heaven’s will is lost, and governance may be secured. Let the people exert themselves to submit memorials, and let local officials, fearing they may lag behind, swiftly dispatch clerks to inquire about what the people have witnessed, promptly reporting it upward. In this way, no calamity or anomaly will be overlooked.

Thus, the August Heaven and Revered Earth will rejoice greatly and cherish their emperor. How is this made clear?

Yet there are signs: when the sun and moon radiate their great brightness, when the arrayed stars hold to their courses and do not err in their movements—these are the proofs of Heaven’s joy. When Earth rejoices, the hundred rivers flow in order, never surging forth in reckless motion; the myriad things appear nurtured, growing well and inclined toward goodness—these are the proofs of Earth’s delight. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

Indeed, indeed.

The Heavenly Master deigns to pity this foolish student, allowing one who has grasped the matter to advance questions. Because I have been treated with such generosity, I may now ask all that I doubt. Now, why is it that the people are made to record calamities and anomalies?

Excellent, your question is apt. When such events are observed, they should be recorded at once, whether at dawn or dusk, door by door. At month’s end, these records are gathered and deliberated together. What is fit to be reported is sent upward; what is not yet sufficient waits for further omens in the following month. In this way, the magistrates of each district and commandery will attend to the times of dawn and dusk among the people—then it may be said that not even a hair’s breadth of Heaven’s portents is lost.

Officials will stand in awe of the people, and the people in awe of the officials. Both, fearing one another, will ensure that all reports are truthful, not erring by even a fraction of a tael. Thus the emperor may sit in his secluded chamber without worry. When the people, ministers, and common folk—great and small—all act with perfect loyalty and good faith, their true sentiments may reach him, and the realm will know nothing but joy.

Should there be those who obstruct this, they must be recorded together: these are the treacherous ministers, the disloyal and unfilial, the ignorant of Heaven and Earth, who conspire to deceive their superiors, severing the clarity of those above. This is a grave transgression, and so they must be swiftly recorded as one. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, and should you have doubts, return to ask.

Now the Six Perfected Ones all return in reverent contemplation, while only the Heavenly Master commands the senior officials. The people are to record together all calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences—what sort are these?

Excellent! The Six Disciples inquire with such thoroughness, not deviating from the heart of Heaven nor failing the Virtuous Lord. This is deemed meritorious before Heaven and Earth, and all things under creation shall benefit therefrom.

The reason is this: as they inquire of Heaven’s affairs with meticulous care, exhausting every detail, nothing is lost even by the weight of a fraction. The yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, the Three Luminaries, the Five Phases, the Four Seasons, the spirits and deities, and the myriad things—all that they wish to express may be seen. Thus is their great merit.

Do you understand?
Indeed, indeed.

Go now, and for the Six Perfected Ones, I shall expound this in detail; follow closely and record it.
Indeed, indeed.

Now, great calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are Heaven and Earth’s great discourse. Moderate calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are their middling discourse. Minor calamities, anomalies, and strange occurrences are their small discourse.

Do you wish to grasp their essential meaning? It is like a person’s great affairs and great discourse, middling affairs and middling discourse, small affairs and small discourse. These, whether great or small, all convey meaning—they are not empty signs. Heaven and Earth do not deceive humanity.

When great auspicious omens appear, it is their great joy. When moderate auspicious omens appear, it is their moderate joy. When minor auspicious omens appear, it is their minor joy.

When great inauspicious portents and ill omens appear, it is Heaven and Earth’s great wrath. When moderate inauspicious portents and ill omens appear, it is their moderate wrath. When minor inauspicious portents and ill omens appear, it is their minor wrath.

When all is tranquil, with neither auspicious nor inauspicious changes, it is their state of neither joy nor anger.

Do you understand?
Indeed, indeed.

Disasters, anomalies, and strange transformations—whether great or small—must be recorded without the slightest omission. Why so thorough? Foolish Perfected One, all transgressions, great and small, must be observed; likewise, the goodness or evil of all things, great and small, must be fully seen and known. For good deeds, one must acknowledge their merit and respond with goodness that surpasses the original act. For faults, one must repeatedly admonish them to align with the intentions of Heaven and Earth.

Do you wish to know their effects? Heaven is like a ruler or sovereign. If a minor request is not heeded, it harbors minor resentment. If a moderate request is ignored, its resentment grows greater. If a major request is disregarded, harm ensues. Thus, all things, great and small, must be recorded so as not to provoke Heaven and Earth’s resentment or wrath. Excellent, excellent!

I wish to hear the meaning of these records. Record anomalies, disasters, strange transformations, illnesses, and diseases—whether great or small, many or few—as well as unusual winds and rains, and the sufferings of the people and all things. All, great and small, must be gathered, deliberated upon, and recorded. The purpose of having all record these is this: officials will know one another’s strengths and weaknesses, the people will know one another’s strengths and weaknesses, those dwelling near mountains and hills will know the changes of mountains and hills, those near markets and walled cities will know the changes of markets and walled cities, those on level land will know the changes of level land, and those near low-lying fields and waters will know the changes of low-lying fields and waters. Thus, high and low, inner and outer, all will be known without omission—this is the method to swiftly attain Great Peace. It is the principle by which emperors and kings should govern, the way to never lose the great intent of Heaven and Earth.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.
Go forth, for you have grasped it.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, the prevalence of inherited calamities stems from the failure to record matters down to the common folk, from the failure to collectively record all things, great and small. When strange changes occur, officials from other jurisdictions are sent to investigate. Each governs only within their own boundaries, and local officials conceal and suppress the truth, jointly hiding it. Thus, the words of Heaven and Earth are severed, unable to ascend and reach their emperors and kings. The harm runs deep, causing Heaven’s sorrow to deepen, disasters to multiply, and misfortune to accumulate—all rooted in this.

When officials from other jurisdictions come to examine matters, how can they know the long-standing sufferings of the people? Some, bound by close ties, repeatedly collude to conceal the truth. Others, harboring old grudges against certain households, falsely amplify disasters and fabricate incidents, further concealing them. This severs the discourse of Heaven and Earth, compounds the grievances of the innocent, and drives the people below to follow one another in bribery and corruption. These three matters all constitute grave harm, knotting the qi of injustice and further exacerbating disasters. Thus, governance becomes impossible to rectify.

Now, when the Great Yang arises and the qi of peace flourishes, a virtuous ruler should govern, and all under Heaven should attain Great Peace, each finding their rightful place. For this reason, the Six Perfected Ones have come to inquire in full, and I have explained it all to them. Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

Thus, when Heaven intends to favor and assist an emperor or king, it first ensures they possess their own intent. From ancient times to the present, whenever Heaven has favored and assisted a ruler, it invariably bestows upon them extraordinary texts and uncommon strategies, enabling them to govern by their precepts—whereupon all their undertakings prove greatly auspicious.

When Heaven does not intend to favor or benefit a ruler, it severs all such extraordinary texts and uncommon strategies, preventing their attainment. Even if obtained, it renders their minds dull, so they fail to comprehend or apply them. When Heaven intends to benefit a ruler, it opens their minds to clarity and delight, so they gladly employ them.

This is Heaven’s unchanging law, which does not deceive humankind. Therefore, those destined for prosperity tend to favor goodness, while those destined for decline tend to favor evil. Those destined for fortune are easily guided, while those destined for misfortune resist counsel and offend others, making them impossible to guide.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

Thus, Heaven constantly assists the good, and the Dao longs to return to those of virtue. Heaven refuses to assist the wicked, and the Dao refuses to cling to the foolish and benighted. Therefore, it frequently instructs the Perfected Ones to entrust governance to virtuous rulers.

The purpose of meticulously recording all omens—great and small, good and evil, internal and external, near and far—is to enable virtuous rulers above, together with their worthy ministers, to trace the origins of these anomalies. All the world’s strange portents and calamities arise as reflections of affairs, modeled upon conduct, and generated in accordance with their kind. When worthy ministers gather to deliberate, their thoughts become as vast as the matter itself. By examining the categories of events and inquiring into their patterns, the truth is revealed.

Then Heaven and Earth rejoice daily, and the emperor and king attain daily peace. Thus, virtue reaches its fullest harmony, and no spirit or deity fails to respond. To witness its great efficacy: all the world’s afflictions, sufferings, and anomalies vanish entirely; ministers and people all act with goodness, responding to edicts with precision, not erring by even a hair’s breadth. Below, none dare deceive their superiors—this is the manifest proof.

Where many harms remain, deceit abounds; where few harms remain, deceit diminishes; where no harm remains, no deceit exists. By constantly observing what is presented from below, one may gauge the great and small, the loyal and faithless among ministers and people. Matched against events, it is like gazing into a bright mirror, speaking face-to-face.

How wondrous is the Dao when thus practiced! This is the bright mirror by which Heaven assists the ruler of supreme virtue in governing all under Heaven.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

Go now and deliver this to the ruler of virtue—make haste!

If a single person submits a memorial, it is called a "dropped document," and entrusting governance to a single confidant is called "great deceit." This incurs Heaven’s profound resentment, and the Dao of Heaven is perpetually disrupted. If two people jointly submit a memorial, it is called "Great Yin," a collusion of treachery and deceit. Two cunning individuals conspire in secrecy, harboring shared grievances to fabricate falsehoods—this brings misfortune upon Earth, and the Dao of Earth is thrown into great disorder.

If three people jointly submit a memorial, their collaboration remains insincere. Though they may instruct one another, if they share a common grievance and submit a matter to settle private scores, their deceit of their superiors is assured. This makes an enemy of the harmonious mean, throwing the qi of harmony into chaos. If four people jointly submit a memorial, there is often one who fears the truth, whose flaws are exposed by others, leading to accusations and false charges. Though it may resemble truth, its unreliability disrupts the four seasons.

If five people jointly submit a memorial, it may seem true but remains unverified—its falsehood disrupts the Five Phases. If six people jointly submit a memorial, it approaches truth but remains uncertain—its falsehood disrupts the Six Harmonies. If seven people jointly submit a memorial, it appears credible. Eight approach truth, nine approach sincerity, and ten nearly attain it.

Why, Heavenly Master, do you harbor so many doubts?
I wish to hear the essential point.

The reason for these many doubts is that in the Five Directions, cunning individuals often harbor private grievances, using public matters to settle private scores. They readily conspire to become great deceivers and treacherous schemers, disrupting the Dao of Heaven and Earth to mislead their superiors. Thus, I dare not hastily trust them.

However, if a matter is small, gather people of all ages—wise and foolish, men and women, down to servants—and deliberate together. Falsehood cannot prevail, nor can private scores be settled. If any among them feel uneasy and speak out, whether foolish, loose-tongued, unable to conceal, or elderly with little to fear, or even women and children who chatter carelessly, their collusion will be exposed.

Thus, the truth of the matter is revealed, and no treachery remains. When truth is attained, the hearts of Heaven and Earth are harmonized.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

The fundamental reason emperors and kings have borne successive transgressions and responsibilities, why governance continually loses the heart of Heaven, and why disasters flow unceasingly—with those that cease only to arise anew—is that the August Heaven remains unsettled. Harmful qi and illnesses abound, preventing long-lasting great joy. Even fleeting moments of happiness soon turn to misfortune. The root of this great fault lies precisely here.

Cunning and treacherous people jointly turn their backs on Heaven and Earth to deceive the emperor and king. Yet people regard Heaven and Earth as their mandate and the emperor and king as their parents. Fools who betray this mandate and collude to deceive their parents incur the shared hatred of Heaven and Earth and the emperor’s wrath. By law, their evil deaths are insufficient to expiate their crimes, and their punishment extends to future lives.

Thus, disasters never cease, harm multiplies daily, human lifespans shorten, and the myriad things remain in constant disorder. The true fault lies here.

Have you now fully awakened to this, Perfected One? Have you deeply understood it?
Indeed, indeed.
You may be said to have grasped it.

Therefore, I know the August Heaven profoundly detests such evil. Thus, I have made this text repeatedly emphasize it for balance. To lose even one matter is to invite its rise. What was lost in the past may be regained in the future—this is especially grave, for Heaven greatly abhors it.

I know its import and hereby instruct the Perfected One, entrusting it to a ruler of supreme virtue and power. If he obtains and practices it, he will differ not from the divine. Then the upright qi of the Great Peace and Supreme Sovereign will naturally establish itself.

My text dares not betray Heaven and Earth, nor the ruler of supreme virtue, nor the people of later generations and future ages, nor the myriad things. Practicing it yields immediate results.
Excellent, excellent!

I wish to ask: why does one person’s memorial to the throne disrupt Heaven? Why do two people disrupt Earth? This occurs when each follows their own household, and their strategies resonate in mutual influence—this is the natural law. Do you understand?
Indeed, indeed.
Go forth, for you have already grasped it.

All under Heaven follow their own kind. I venture to ask, Heavenly Master: now that this text has been revealed, can its words be fully verified in practice so that all under Heaven will believe without doubt?

Indeed, all under Heaven will believe without doubt.

I wish to hear the meaning of this.

Then let me speak to the Perfected One of its essential import. Now, the governing officials and magistrates fear that the people will expose their affairs, and so they employ the Six Inquiries to examine them, thereby securing their trust. The people, too, fear the county authorities, and if they uncover their faults, they likewise believe. The county authorities and magistrates, dwelling among the people, also fear those who travel to other regions to submit memorials, and if they uncover their faults, they believe them as well. Those who travel to submit memorials also fear the county magistrates and the local people, and if their faults are exposed, they too are believed. Each fears the other, and thus none dare speak falsely, nor can they conceal anything.

Therefore, when memorials are submitted from three sources—the county authorities, the local people, and the traveling petitioners—they all align at dawn, not deviating by even a fraction. How divine! The Dao operates thus. I wish to ask: when should those who gather to deliberate assemble?

Excellent is your question. All shall be recorded beneath the abode of the Great Peace and Coming Good. Why must it be here?

For there are extraordinary methods and exceptional texts that may be deposited in the abode of the Great Peace and Coming Good, where good and evil are deliberated beneath it, and matters from the four directions are collectively submitted. If only one person deliberates, they may regret and cease, or be stopped by others. If a memorial is submitted but then halted along the way, the intent is abandoned, and the concealed matter is punished as a crime.

Through such writings, all under Heaven will be secured, and the emperor and kings will long wander in leisure.

Excellent, excellent!

Herein lies the accumulation of the Celestial Master’s writings—where ought they all be deposited? Those texts intended solely for the sovereign shall remain with the sovereign; all that pertain to the affairs of all under Heaven shall be fully disclosed. Do you understand this?

Indeed, indeed.

Proceed. The sovereign of supreme virtue is moved by Heaven itself to possess a sagely mind, and through this, naturally harbors good intentions, naturally issues virtuous decrees and rites—this is the celestial law, not erring by even a hair’s breadth. The matters are too numerous to record in full; the writings are ever a burden. Proceed.

Indeed, indeed.

To the right: Heaven’s decree to the Six Perfected Ones, instructing them to deeply comprehend the threefold Dao in the transmission of written texts and oral instructions.

*End of Scroll Eighty-Six of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Beginning of Scroll Eighty-Eight of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Method for Establishing the Abode of Coming Good, One Hundred Twenty-Ninth*

The Six Perfected Ones of the Six Directions bow and ask, wishing to pose a single question.

Proceed with your words.

The Celestial Master previously commanded this humble student to compile and collate the essential texts of the High, Middle, and Low Antiquities, as well as the finest discourses of the wise and enlightened—matters transmitted orally. Now, within and beyond the four borders, some regions lie ten thousand leagues from the emperor, yet if there exist good writings, though their content be scant, they are carried from afar to the capital. Or if there be extraordinary texts, rare methods, or wondrous arts, scholars and recluses of profound learning, though duty-bound not to shun the journey of ten thousand leagues, may travel to the emperor to offer and expound their moral teachings. Or among the common folk—young and old, weak and small, field-dwelling infants, women, and children—each may harbor in their hearts good characters, oral instructions, or a few lines, yet their meager offerings prevent them from dispatching someone to carry them to the capital. Or among the barbarians of the four borders—hidden sages, Hu and Mo tribes—those deeply versed in secret Dao, though they know of the radiant and virtuous sovereign in the Central Kingdom, cannot bear the distant journey to present their rare texts, good strategies, or exceptional methods.

Now the Celestial Master has gathered all the divine writings of the Yellow River and Luo River, the good texts of antiquity and present, along with the oral instructions of the wise and enlightened, to form the *Scripture of the Utmost Profundity*. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, all disasters may thus be eradicated, and the emperor may long wander in leisure, ruling with folded arms and without care. Yet if even one matter is left incomplete, residual calamities may remain—hence the need to gather them all. But how are these rare methods, exceptional strategies, and good characters to be fully obtained?

Excellent, excellent!

The Perfected Ones ponder deeply, for the celestial spirits have already descended to instruct them. The qi of the Supreme August One comes to assist the virtuous sovereign—

Proceed. Now, Perfected Ones, you have asked on behalf of the August Numinous Heaven. My duty is to expound fully for all under Heaven—how dare I be remiss?

Understood.

Let the Perfected Ones be seated, for I shall now explain all to you.

Indeed, indeed.

This scripture shall be entrusted to the August and Virtuous Emperor of the Supreme August One. Upon seeing the celestial texts, he must ponder their essential meaning and command the provinces, commanderies, and distant counties, towns, and villages of the four borders to each construct a fine abode along the great thoroughfares of the cities. Let it stand three *zhang* high, with a breadth and depth of three *zhang* as well. On all four sides, create good petitions, sized to match a person’s face, with openings wide enough for hands to pass through, and shelter their doors well—lest unauthorized persons force entry. Hang writings upon its exterior, clearly displaying the texts, and inscribe the abode’s purpose on all four sides.

The writings shall state: The emperor seeks rare texts, exceptional methods, good strategies, oral instructions, and the constant thoughts harbored in people’s hearts—whatever they can articulate. Let all be written down and deposited in this abode, with their names and surnames recorded. Then, summon and examine them, appointing positions according to the magnitude of their moral abilities. For those whose contributions are too numerous to verify, command the local officials of counties and towns to appoint them to office. For the elderly, weak, and women with good words, command the responsible officials to reward them. For those with great merit who cannot be appointed, grant them exemptions. For those beyond the four borders who present good and rare strategies with great efficacy, bestow generous rewards.

Thus, within and beyond the four borders, all shall simultaneously rise in great enthusiasm, rejoicing to devote their efforts to the emperor. From top to bottom, from inside to outside, no rare text, good character, or exceptional method shall remain hidden in distant lands. In a single day, all people shall turn to joyfully embrace goodness. Hidden recluses dwelling in caves shall emerge to wander the cities, beholding the emperor’s abode of Great Peace and Coming Good—none shall conceal themselves. Wind and rain shall arrive in due season, the Three Luminaries shall illuminate brightly—this is the sign of Heaven’s great joy.

When the worthy sages of the eighty-one domains among the Four Barbarians hear that the Central Kingdom is governed by a sovereign of great virtue in this manner, none shall not delight in coming to submit, all bearing their rare treasures in continuous procession. Not one in ten thousand of my writings shall be lost—how could this not bring immense joy?

With governance of such great virtue, do the Perfected Ones now comprehend?

Indeed, indeed. You have already awakened.

Where the writings within a household are exceedingly numerous, the master of the house shall expand its doors to gather the texts therein. These shall be brought before the senior officials and assembly of worthies, who together shall arrange the good among them by category, removing the harmful and eliminating redundancies. Ordered by matter and sequence, they shall be presented to the emperor. The emperor shall again command the assembly of worthies to arrange them, removing redundancies and harmful or improper passages, categorizing them anew before placing them in a separate repository. Further writings from the four directions shall be awaited, then arranged in sequence and by category, with later arrivals to follow in due course.

From the good households of the four directions, once the most extraordinary and uniquely excellent writings and strategies have been selected, the remainder shall be securely sealed. Where accumulated texts are abundant, they shall again be arranged and presented. Thus, the flow of submissions from the four directions shall gradually diminish, nearing completion.

The assembled worthies, in their wisdom, shall compile and order the submissions, binding them into the *Scripture of the Utmost Cavern*. Thereupon, the greatly awakened worthies shall disseminate them to the people below. In a single day, the hundred clans and myriad folk shall all be transformed toward goodness, no longer knowing the ways of evil.

This is what it means to fully win the hearts of Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the Four Barbarians—great joy arriving daily, all uniting as one household to achieve a single governance. Do the Six Perfected Ones comprehend this?

Indeed, indeed. Proceed, for the Six Perfected Ones have already understood.

When the Yi and Di hear of this, they shall daily retreat, and the Central Kingdom shall daily expand, growing stronger without battle or conquest. Heaven and Earth shall aid in the removal of evil—an occurrence unseen since the opening of Heaven and Earth. Thus, the world shall rejoice greatly, as the spirits of Heaven and Earth together dispel the emperor’s inherited burdens. Disasters and omens shall vanish, and his governance shall differ not from that of the divine.

The people of the world shall gain access to wondrous methods of the Dao and virtue, all inclining toward good writings and upright words, no longer engaging in wickedness. The submissions shall grow ever more excellent with each year. Thereafter, a minor compilation shall be made every three years, and a major one every five, with the subsequent texts appended and returned to the people, so that all shall delight in goodness and be unable to restrain themselves.

From these, the most excellent matters beneficial to the emperor’s upright governance shall be retained and not disseminated below. Do the Perfected Ones understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Now, Perfected One, Heaven has sent your disciples to inquire—since this is a matter Heaven itself has asked, you shall compose the *Scripture of Great Joy* for the Virtuous Lord. Exert yourself and do not slacken.

Heaven shall repay your merit, for you remove afflictions on behalf of the August Heaven and Earth, and dispel the accumulated disasters and poisons of inherited burdens for the emperor. Your lifespan shall surely be extended. My words do not deceive the Perfected One. Take heed.

Indeed, indeed.

Go forth and return. Strive with utmost diligence. If you have doubts, come again.

Indeed, indeed.

Perfected One, step forward.

When you first came to ask these matters, I had long intended to depart. Thus, I had already spoken words of parting with you. Yet seeing your earnestness, I knew you were aided by the yang essence of August Heaven. The reason for this is that I saw your sincerity, and that the Middle Kingdom shall flourish in great peace. The eighty-one domains shall send forth good people to return and submit to the Middle Kingdom. Therefore, I remained to explain everything to you in full.

The reason for this is that I saw you ceaselessly inquiring on Heaven’s behalf, and feared you might incur great fault, bringing censure from Heaven and Earth. Thus, I dared not abandon the Dao and depart midway.

Do you understand, Perfected One?

Indeed, indeed.

Go, and strive to complete this with utmost sincerity. Do not forsake the Heavenly Dao. Ask this one final question.

Indeed, indeed.

I humbly request to ask: Master of Heaven, what did you observe in the bustling crossroads of the capital that led you to establish a chamber for the *Scripture of Wondrous Methods and Secret Strategies* to bring about Great Peace?

Excellent, Perfected One, your difficult question has grasped the essential meaning. Heaven has long been grieved. Has the emperor sent you to ask this? How skillfully you present your words!

Yet from my dwelling in the heavens, I have observed what can be seen. It was not in vain that I established this abode of August Peace at the crossroads. The Heavenly Duke asked: Why is it so difficult for the world to attain peace and security? The divine officials of the Five Phases replied: Now, the emperor dwells within a hundredfold enclosure, separated from the four borders by ten thousand times ten thousand *li*. Those most distant suffer from deep-seated grievances, and the good and evil of their deeds cannot ascend to reach him. Wondrous methods, rare writings, and extraordinary strategies are cut off and never arrive before the emperor.

The people and ministers, bound by grievances, cannot petition or communicate. Over time, the four directions become obstructed and blocked. The worthy and learned conceal themselves, harboring their virtue and power, growing despondent until death. The emperor, deprived of their extraordinary strategies and uncommon words, cannot bring peace to the world. The great fault lies in the closure and obstruction of the distant borders on all sides.

Thus, in accordance with Heaven’s will, I have established this abode for the Virtuous Lord of the Dao and Great Peace at the crossroads, to gather and bring forth the finest *qi* of the Supreme August and the Tranquil Peace. I wish to delight the four directions, so that all may know the Virtuous Lord has issued these teachings. They shall rejoice as one, each bringing their good offerings and rare methods to present and return them to the throne, no matter how distant. There shall be no more obstruction.

Excellent, excellent!

Without the Master of Heaven’s inquiry, this would not be known. Yet if people truly possess the nature of Heaven, they may know it themselves—this is the highest. Those who cannot know it themselves must inquire—this is the next best.

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

I humbly request to ask one more matter.

Speak.

Why must it be made three *zhang* in both length and height? Excellent, your question indeed.

First, three is the beginning of numbers. The celestial numbers also conclude at ten, the terrestrial numbers also conclude at ten, and the human numbers also conclude at ten—thus it is made three *zhang*. It is to delight and harmonize Heaven, Earth, and Humanity, causing all to rejoice together, and so it takes the form of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.

Now, I ask: why do the three numbers all conclude at ten?

It is because Heaven possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang; Earth possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang; Humanity possesses the Five Phases and also has its own yin and yang—thus they all reach ten.

Excellent, excellent!

Is it only Heaven, Earth, and Humanity that are thus?

Are all things in the myriad realms also thus?

Indeed, all things in the myriad realms take the form of Heaven, Earth, and Humanity. Thus, Heaven, Earth, and Humanity all follow the Four Seasons and Five Phases in their flourishing and decline.

Do you understand, Perfected One?

Excellent, excellent! Truly, you may be said to have understood.

I humbly request to ask one more matter.

Speak.

Why must one create these openwork patterns on all four sides, aligning them with the face?

It is because the openwork allows worthy scholars to inscribe their strategies. The openwork delights in the free flow of the four directions, no longer obstructed or cut off. It enables the worthy to each record their words and submit them to this Chamber of Great Peace and Coming Goodness.

As for aligning with the face— the face is the finest part of a person. The portion of Great Yang mirrors the Dao of Heaven, delighting in each person following the heart of Heaven, contemplating goodness, and joining forces with the virtuous ruler to bring peace to the world together. Thus, it is made to align with the face.

The face possesses the Seven Corrects: ears, eyes, mouth, and nose, through which qi flows, and spirits and deities come and go. It delights in great worthies inscribing their strategies, so that from the four directions, eight extremities, and distant lands, all that is keen and bright may arrive.

Now, though the emperor dwells within a hundredfold enclosure, separated from the people by ten thousand leagues, his radiant teachings and commands flow unimpeded, never losing the heart of Heaven and Earth, thereby securing his person.

Excellent, excellent!

Would you inquire, which officials should be appointed to guard this abode?

The chief officials shall directly oversee it, proclaiming its name as the Abode of Great Peace and the Hall of Delight in Virtue.

Excellent!

The foolish student has known that Heaven is already greatly joyful, Earth already profoundly pleased and cautious in conduct, humanity already governed by Great Peace, and the myriad things already settled in their proper places.

Now, how does the Perfected One know this?

The foolish student has seen that the Heavenly Master, as the Virtuous Lord of Great Peace, has established this grand abode of joy to facilitate the discourse between Heaven, Earth, and humanity. Now, it enables the people and ministers below to each present their words to their ruler, allowing the emperor to obtain extraordinary strategies, exceptional writings, and unique methods that ensure his long-term security.

Moreover, Heaven and Earth may communicate their discourse, and even the humble commoners may convey their virtuous words, thereby dispelling the gloom of Heaven and Earth and aiding their ruler in becoming wise and enlightened.

Heaven and Earth, together with humanity, as the foremost of all things, thus achieve complete communication—hence, the great joy.

The Perfected One speaks truly; excellent indeed! I have nothing to add.

Your words on this matter deeply enter the true Dao.

I would now ask to resolve one doubt.

Speak.

Now, Heaven itself is gloomy and wishes to speak—why then does it instead employ humans to discourse? Excellent indeed, your challenging question has grasped the essence.

Yet the Dao of Heaven turns and operates through mutual dependence, each employing the other. Thus, *dui* serves as the mouth of Heaven and Earth, and humanity does likewise. Like seeks like, and so humanity becomes the voice of Heaven and Earth.

Perfected One, do you understand this? Indeed, indeed.

Go now, for you are easily enlightened. Strive on, strive on. Indeed, indeed.

Yet this discourse is but briefly concluded—ask no further, lest the Way’s texts become difficult to comprehend and only deepen confusion. Indeed, indeed.

Go now, and heed this one matter for the Perfected One: you have already collated the texts of exceptional methods. Roll and append a singular, excellent method—the foundational art of nurturing inner nature—beneath the scrolls, so that all worthy ones may recite and study it. This shall become a scripture of profound extremity. Those who complete it shall gather these methods to cultivate themselves, recite this art to preserve their wholeness, and each shall find lasting joy in their existence.

The most worthy may serve as pillars of the state, the moderately worthy as minor officials, and even the lowliest who cannot hold office may long nurture their kin and steadfastly safeguard their descendants. Excellent, most excellent!

The world shall know great joy and delight, for goodness shall have no equal, and evil people shall cease to exist. You have already understood this—go now, reflect upon it, and hold it in your thoughts.

Since you have undertaken this inquiry on behalf of Heaven, do not grow lax. Indeed, indeed.

To seek goodness and thereby bring about Great Peace, uniting the world in a single day to dwell in the joyous abode of the Supreme August One.

*Here ends the eighty-eighth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*The eighty-ninth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*The One Hundred and Thirtieth Text: The Eight Trigrams’ Return to Essence and Recitation*

Mysterious brightness illumines within, the great darkness teems with qi. Sharing rank with the worthy, it resides in the domains of *ren* and *gui*, the body united with *hai* and *zi*. Circulating in mutual embrace, utmost yin gives birth to yang—this is called the First Nine.

When the One unites to generate beings, yin halts and yang arises. Receiving bestowal in *hai*, conceiving in *ren*, it flourishes in *zi*. From child to grandchild, yang enters within yin, its generation unceasing.

Contemplate the outer to penetrate the inner; lifespan doubles, yet this cannot be swiftly attained—it is fitting for long duration. Lesser yang holds qi, sharing its position with the liver, in *jia*, *yi*, *yin*, and *mao*, akin to the color green. The essence of the myriad things emerges in profusion, front and back intermingling, benevolence and kindness imprinted upon the heart.

When a valiant warrior is about to set forth, let him recite and behold these characters: his radiance shall be as the sun at its first rising. A hundred illnesses shall be cured, and his years shall increase threefold. Greater yang abounds in qi, akin to the heart, dwelling in the house of *bing* and *ding*, nurtured in the positions of *si* and *wu*. Beholding it, a hundred evils depart, and the body daily grows upright. One’s intent should be gentle and luminous—this must not be forcibly sought. To see the character is to gain longevity, its light like the brilliance of the sun at midday.

The qi of central harmony connects with the spleen, extending to the four seasons’ quarters before returning to *wu* and *ji*. Dwelling centrally in *chen* and *xu*, with *chou* and *wei* as its root, one who contemplates its meaning and follows its sequence shall cure illness. When the essence resembles the Yellow Dragon and this character is seen, disease vanishes, years increase fivefold, and people become filial and compliant. Ministers shall love their lords, and children their fathers.

In the lesser yin’s cycle, it joins with the essence of the teacher, the numinous fan exhaling qi. Its position belongs to *geng*, *xin*, *shen*, and *you*, where righteousness punishes the cunning and treacherous. Bandits shall not arise, and evil shall not harm people. When the kidneys’ abundant qi increases lifespan a hundredfold, utmost yin generates yang, and the state shall greatly prosper. Constantly contemplating it, one shall know no death.

Yin ascends and yang arises, thus the Dark Warrior marks the beginning. The Dragon’s virtue is born in the north yet resides in the east, thus it follows thereafter. The Vermilion Bird governs illness; the yellow qi stands at the center. When the ruler practices this, his lifespan shall be boundless. Ascending to hold balance, a hundred evils shall perish.

The Eight Trigrams reside within, spirits arrayed in ordered ranks. The White Tiger follows behind, punishing calamity and annihilating misfortune. The upright Dao arrives daily, and perverse qi vanishes. To contemplate essence without cease is the principle of extending years. If one embodies and internalizes it, what worry can there be?

To follow below what is above is called the Dao of compliance. Without fault or transgression, a myriad illnesses shall heal themselves. Reciting the characters and beholding their forms, love shall be as between father and son, bringing constant joy and boundless illumination.

Those who examine and apply this shall see its effects immediately. Keep it always with the scripture, and daily wander with the spirits. The Dao follows nature, being profoundly empty and non-being. In a single day, it shall come of itself—this Dao is benevolent and good.

Children shall thereby be filial, ministers loyal and trustworthy. Those who understand it shall cherish their bodies, dare not speak recklessly, and by steadfastly guarding it, their lives shall know no end. The scripture does not emerge in vain; contemplate it in connection with the Dao. Deeply comprehend its meaning, and the spirits shall come of themselves.

At the outset, contemplate the form of the character and return to the primordial essence of the Dao. Attain spirit illumination, and nature shall be effortless. The Dao of Heaven is manifold, yet within humans it may be practiced. When the Dao accomplishes its work, how can one not refrain from wrongdoing? If people do not exert themselves, whence shall upright qi arise? To act without ascending is to daily invite good fortune and distance peril.

When the great person practices this, the state shall know Great Peace. When the petty person practices it, calamity shall depart and blessings arrive. Contemplate its profound forms, and all pursuits shall be fulfilled. If children uphold the Dao, whence shall disorder arise?

To contemplate without cease is to attain Great Peace. With the heart undisturbed and no perverse inclinations, to guard it without cease is to daily renew life. The Dao does not emerge recklessly; it is entrusted to those with virtue and returns to its proper person.

*Here ends the text on the Eight Trigrams’ Ascent to Peace and the Six Jia’s Pursuit of the Dao to Return Essence.*
*Here ends the eighty-ninth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*The ninetieth scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace*

**Remedy for Grievance, Disaster, and the Pursuit of Rare Methods, One Hundred Thirty-First**

Before the Perfected One, you study this. In all matters, accumulate knowledge, and you shall understand the great principles by which the world is ordered. Only then may you speak of affairs without doubt.

Now, when common folk die, they cry out in great grievance, beating their breasts and calling to Heaven, casting themselves down to wail to Earth. Is this not perverse? One ought to refine the Dao with precision. Let this be recited and read for ten thousand generations as an enduring law, never to be forgotten.

Today, the Celestial Master has issued stern teachings. How dare this foolish student not strive to speak a word?

Proceed without doubt. Yet death is a grave matter for mortals. To cry out in great grievance, beating the breast and casting oneself down, exhausting all strength in endless sorrow—this does no harm to life. But for whom should one grieve? And why grieve for all?

When a person dies, they are utterly extinguished, reduced to ashes and dust, never to be seen again. Living between Heaven and Earth, from the time of their opening and division, each person has but one life, never to be reborn. Since the moment they were named "human," they have been the foremost of all harmonious things, noble and honored, akin to Heaven and Earth. Yet with a single death, they vanish forever, through all time and space, never again to be called human, never again to rise and walk. Thus, they are mourned, and great grievance is expressed.

Alas! Your words align with the vulgar, yet in truth, they are not so. This foolish student fails to grasp their meaning. What should one do when a person dies? I wish to hear it, only from the Celestial Master.

Now, all things that live must come to an end. Human life, too, must end in death—this is the ordained pattern of Heaven and Earth. Yet within it, there are those who die in grievance, or who perish young before their time. Heaven and Earth, parents to all things, fear that some may die in grievance, weeping and wailing to Heaven above and knocking their heads upon the Earth below, lamenting their short years. Thus, Heaven has provided the true Dao and rare methods by which one may defend oneself and attain a modest longevity.

All living things naturally age and perish, yet foolish people refuse to diligently study the true Dao and virtuous methods. How can they slightly extend their years, delaying death and aging? Instead, they treat themselves lightly, neglecting to seek rare methods, and mock the true Dao. They turn to deception and falsehood, disrupting the Way of Heaven, deceiving their superiors, and competing to prepare burial mounds for death. They adorn and tend to these places in anticipation of death, making death pacts and inauspicious arrangements, seeking only to die. What is there to grieve?

When one’s allotted years and fate are exhausted, it is like the sun rising and inevitably setting. Perfected One, why do you grieve for this?

Your words, Perfected One, too often align with the vulgar, as if you know nothing of humanity. For whom, then, should one grieve? I wish to hear it.

One should grieve for those who die young, before they have gained any knowledge, before they have sought ways to defend themselves. Thus, they are to be grieved.

One should also grieve for those who are ever cautious and good, who fear dying young, who constantly discipline themselves, seeking the true Dao, virtuous power, and rare methods. They act with constant goodness, never harming in secret. Yet they may meet with disaster and die prematurely, or reach old age with strength exhausted, never having encountered an enlightened teacher, even for a moment, to fulfill their allotted years. These are the truly grievous cases, worthy of sorrow.

But those who grieve without cause, who do not seek rare methods or the true Dao yet die, and then beat their breasts, weep, and wail to Heaven and Earth—such people bring this upon themselves, blaming Heaven and Earth. They are rebellious people, deeply despised by Heaven.

Perfected One, if you grieve for these, it would be better to mourn early for your own failure to learn the true Dao, for your ignorance of the great principles of Heaven and Earth, of yin and yang, and of the divisions of the world. Long have you suffered without an enlightened teacher, harboring sorrow as your allotted years draw to a close. This is truly lamentable. Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed! This foolish student is deeply alarmed. My fate rests with the Celestial Master. I humbly beg the true Dao from you, that I may strive without ceasing. Why should the world lack it? It is only that one does not seek with sufficient diligence. If one’s sincerity moves Heaven to tears, then Heaven will not withhold it. If one does not slacken in the Dao, one shall obtain it before long. Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed!

Foolish people do not cherish and love themselves. They do not seek rare and extraordinary methods that could grant them even a moment more of life. Instead, they prepare their funerary objects and burial places in advance, seeking death. The laws of Heaven are like those of a compassionate father, a wise mother, or a sagacious ruler—they do not deprive one of what may be sought.

This is the natural principle of seeking. If one attains what one seeks, there is no need for great grievance. Thus, the ancient sage-kings and emperors, who deeply cherished and feared death, thought day and night of seeking rare and extraordinary knowledge. They revered those who practiced the Dao, exhausting their wealth in the pursuit. Their sincerity moved the August Heaven to tears, and Heaven responded with auspicious signs. Masters of the Dao and its arts all came to their aid, enabling them to live long lives or even transcend the world.

Yet there were some who sought and did not obtain, for their sincerity was insufficient. They clung to worldly affairs, treating their lives lightly, believing they could be regained. Now, Heaven and Earth regard humans as their children, and emperors as the most honored of Heaven’s children. How could they not cherish the true Dao and rare methods?

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed!

Thus, the ancient sages deeply contemplated and planned for the future. They knew that the wealth of the world is not permanently possessed. While one lives, wealth is merely entrusted to the body. When one dies, it passes to others. Therefore, there is nothing to cherish. They used their wealth to the utmost to seek the true Dao and extraordinary knowledge. Thus, their bodies endured, and their wealth remained, ever belonging to humanity.

Therefore, one must exert utmost effort until wealth is entirely spent. Wealth is but a fleeting pursuit, obtained in an instant. To lose wealth is merely to return it to the world, for it was never truly one’s own to keep. This is what marks the wise and sagacious: they nurture the body with the Dao, understand the proper use of wealth, and thus attain long life. Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed!

Proceed. Those who would be teachers of others face many difficulties and reproaches. This Perfected One grows heavy-hearted, so let me further clarify for you and fully expound my meaning.

The Dao of Heaven has its fixed principles, and it does not favor the familiar. If you wish to truly understand this, consider how after the winter solstice, the world grows bitterly cold and claims lives. Yet by the fifth month, the first signs of yin qi appear in the well’s clarity, growing stronger day by day. By the time the winter solstice arrives again, the cold becomes deadly, and one cannot survive without clothing. The wise prepare in advance and thus enjoy great joy, unharmed by the cold and free from worry. The indolent, however, who make no effort to prepare, suffer hunger and cold, falling into destitution. This is the way of things.
