Thus, those who study my writings should scrutinize them carefully, from the highest to the lowest, pondering their essential meaning, grasping their secrets, and becoming no different from the divine luminaries. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

As for the three divisions of the realm: when many attain the Dao, they see spirits and can command them. The most enlightened among the great worthies govern ten out of ten perfectly and may serve as the Emperor’s ministers, those who ward off evil and dispel wickedness. Some, after long practice, may enter the thatched chamber and transcend, no longer entangled in worldly affairs.

Only after guarding the One can one fully discern good and evil, faults and failings; only then can one guard the Dao. Only after entering the thatched chamber for refined cultivation can one guard the spirits—thus, this is the third rank. The worthy obtain and collate the divine texts of past and present to verify one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

The middling worthy, by guarding the One and entering the Dao, may also personally witness the divine governance of nine out of ten and serve as a great minister to kings and lords, together dispelling evil. After long practice, they too may hope to enter the thatched chamber. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

The lesser worthy, by guarding the One and entering the Dao through study, may also witness divine governance in eight out of ten cases and serve alongside the common people to dispel evil and remove harm. They too should collate and verify ancient and modern Daoist texts to confirm their own understanding—only then will the foolish gain clarity and fully believe in the Dao. If one merely reads a single scroll without conviction, they will not only disbelieve but may even speak against it, justifying their own doubts. Thus, evil will daily arise, bringing harm to others. If the great worthy, the middling worthy, the lesser worthy, and the common people all guard the divine Dao and practice it together, then the spirits of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons will all flourish, and evil will naturally vanish. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

In this way, the spirits of the world above and below, of the four directions, the six relations, and the six kinships will all rejoice and flourish, aiding people to bring fortune and dissolve evil harm. Above, they will remove disasters and illnesses for emperors and kings; in the middle, they will cure ailments for the worthy; below, they will dispel malevolent qi for the common people, preventing wicked ghosts and spirits from acting. Excellent, excellent!

There must be great secrets and precepts to see the spirits and divine affairs. To say one is accurate in ten out of ten cases is to align with the spirits of Heaven; to say nine out of ten is to align with the spirits of Earth; to say eight out of ten is to align with the spirits of humanity. Beyond this, such words are unreliable. Some may initially see spirits and be perfectly aligned, yet over time grow increasingly inaccurate—this is the Dao of spirits testing them, causing their inaccuracy. If they recognize this and renew themselves, earnestly correcting their faults and striving for purity without evil intentions, their conduct will daily improve. They may then meet the spirits’ expectations, achieving perfect accuracy or even surpassing it, or hitting one in ten with ever-increasing precision. Such are those who daily cultivate goodness and grasp the intent of the Dao. Thus, it is called progress. Using this to divine for oneself, one will not err in ten thousand cases.

Some may initially see spirits and divine inaccurately, yet later reverse course and achieve great accuracy—these are people who refine their understanding of the Dao’s intent and daily advance. Others may remain unchanged, neither progressing nor regressing—these are those whose dedication does not deepen. Those who daily decline are the indolent. Divining thus, one fails to grasp the Dao’s intent. Those who are tested and remain unaware, stubbornly persisting in evil, will be collectively deceived by the spirits. They will be led into depravity, bringing unpredictable fortune and misfortune, falling into heretical teachings, or suffering from lingering illnesses.

Thus, the great worthy, the middling worthy, the lesser worthy, and all common men and women who practice the Dao must use this to divine for themselves, never erring—for the divine Dao tests people. All matters under Heaven are subject to trial and failure. Heaven and Earth test people, so humans, in imitation of Heaven and Earth, also test one another. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

Do you wish to further know the great truth and evidence of the mutual resonance between the Dao of Heaven, the divine spirits, and the people? When their intentions align and their hearts are in accord, sincerity and trust prevail; when their intentions diverge, deception arises. Thus, in high antiquity, people’s sincerity and trust aligned, so superiors and inferiors did not deceive one another. In middle antiquity, half were misaligned, so half deceived one another. In later antiquity, none believed, so superiors and inferiors made deception their sole affair. Thus, in high antiquity, all undertakings succeeded; in middle antiquity, half succeeded; in later antiquity, none succeeded, leading to peril and ruin.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of old constantly used this to divine whether they had attained resonance or not, ensuring no mistakes. With this, I admonish you, Perfected One. I see you constantly toil in hardship, so I deeply caution you—you are to serve as the eternal emissary of Heaven and Earth, resolving the flowing disasters of Heaven and Earth and removing harm for rulers. Your merit is immense and nearly unmatched. I fear you may grow indolent in your practice of the Dao, so I use these divine matters to warn you. If you serve as the emissary of Heaven and Earth and daily encounter fortune, it is because you have grasped the intent of Heaven and Earth. If you daily encounter misfortune, decline, and evil, it is because you have lost their intent.

In your interactions with the Dao and the spirits, if your days are fortunate and good, it is because you have grasped the Dao’s intent. If your days are misfortunate and declining, it is because you have lost the Dao’s intent. In your interactions with others, if your relationships daily grow deeper and kinder, it is because your intentions align. If they daily turn hostile and cold, it is because your intentions have diverged. Consider farming: those who harvest abundant, fine grain have applied careful attention and great effort. Those who harvest little, poor grain have been careless and exerted little effort. Even plants and trees respond to the diligence or negligence of human effort—how much more so the spirits of Heaven and Earth and humanity? Can you not be cautious?

Perfected One, this admonition may seem slight and insignificant, but if you deeply ponder it, you will find it profoundly weighty. This is precisely the gateway to safety or peril, fortune or misfortune. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

I, the foolish one, have awakened—how solemn the charge, how solemn the charge!

Now, the virtuous and enlightened, as paragons of supreme virtue and sovereigns, have collated and examined the writings of high antiquity, middle antiquity, and recent antiquity, arranging them by category to mutually verify one another. Thus, the Dao/Way is rectified in a single day, no different from the sun and moon. They further gathered and assembled the great worthies, middling worthies, lesser worthies, and even the spoken testimonies of men and women among the people, again arranging them by category and cross-verifying them. The written texts then align perfectly, as if fitting a double compass to a square—without the slightest discrepancy.

The strategies of Heaven, Earth, and humanity converge as one. In this way, the sentiments of Heaven, Earth, and humanity are all encompassed, and the twelve thousand things follow likewise. Therefore, the sovereign of virtue must exert great effort in this endeavor, and calamities will depart in a single day. The world will govern itself, free of any remnant of perverse texts or corrupt words. Once all is purified and rectified, no vestige of perverse qi remains.

For perverse texts and corrupt words are the root of disasters. If you wish to further comprehend their clear and trustworthy effects, consider this: when someone records perverse texts against a ruler, or when someone slanders with corrupt speech, resentment and blame arise daily in abundance. People then turn to mutual resentment and slander, and the ruler, listening to these, strays from the correct path. His wisdom and clarity become obstructed, incurring the disapproval of Heaven and Earth, and his governance falters with inauspicious words.

Moreover, those below may use perverse texts and corrupt speech to deceive and confuse their superiors. Over time, when this is discovered above, ruler and ministers will likewise blame one another. Thus, perverse texts and corrupt words arrive daily, serving as the gateway to misfortune and evil. Therefore, one must vigorously collate and expunge them.

Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Thus, when a virtuous ruler fully employs correct speech, the calamities and perils of inherited burdens since the opening of Heaven and Earth are entirely dispelled, and no further disasters arise. Perfected One, do you wish to further comprehend its great truth?

Indeed, correct texts and correct speech serve as the fundamental root of the Dao, Heaven, Earth, humanity, and the myriad things. Therefore, the great sages and worthies of high antiquity, who acted in accordance with correct texts and correct speech, found Heaven and Earth aligned with their correctness, the Three Luminaries aligned with their correctness, the four seasons and Five Phases aligned with their correctness, the people and all things aligned with their correctness. Thus, correct texts and correct speech are the great and efficacious root of correctness for Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things.

Do you wish to further clarify and understand its truth? Consider this: when someone praises a ruler with correct texts and correct speech, the ruler gains great wisdom and great clarity. In all undertakings, nothing strays from correctness. Above and below thus attain the will of Heaven and Earth; the Three Luminaries do not deviate from their courses; the four seasons and Five Phases do not err. The people are all joyful, exclaiming, "Excellent!" The myriad things each find their proper place. Grace extends to the spirits and deities, and one’s fame spreads to distant lands. The host of spirits and auspicious omens emerge in delight. The worthy and learned of the world all gladly come to assist their ruler, and nothing remains concealed. Immortals and divine spirits then bestow upon him the methods of agelessness. Demonic influences are eradicated, and the people govern themselves. With correct texts and correct speech, no mutual resentment arises, and blame is entirely cut off.

All goodness emerges in the world, while all perversity and evil conceal themselves. The virtuous ruler need only sit with folded hands, and governance proceeds of itself—what worry of peril or ruin remains? This is the clear proof and efficacy of my correct texts and correct speech as the root of goodness. How could one not strive to uphold correctness? Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

How astonishing! Having heard the Heavenly Master’s words, I am now profoundly awakened. This foolish one now knows the world has already attained Great Peace. If the virtuous ruler heeds and applies them, his life will be prolonged. Excellent! You may truly be called one who understands affairs—a student who has thoroughly grasped the Way.

Joyful, oh joyful! The Heaven’s anxieties are resolved, and the Earth’s afflictions are removed. Perfected One, how do you know this? Indeed, all perversity and evil are now destined to be eradicated, and the great afflictions of Heaven, Earth, the people, and the myriad things have been eliminated. Now that the correct texts and correct speech have been compiled and rectified, we know the great afflictions of Heaven and Earth are gone.

Excellent, excellent! You have indeed fully understood. If the emperor and kings diligently practice my texts, they will align with the profoundness of Heaven and Earth, and no further calamities will befall them. Excellent, excellent! These are the most essential words to convey to the Perfected One.

When a ruler of supreme virtue obtains my texts, Heaven’s patterns and images will govern his ministers—from divine transcendents above to the lowliest and most humble below, encompassing these nine ranks: divine immortals, perfected transcendents, Daoist sages, worthies, scholars, common folk, servants, and slaves. Among these nine, those who possess true faith, loyalty, and goodness, who delight in the authentic Dao and come to assist the virtuous ruler—all should be questioned regarding their abilities and appointed accordingly. Take care never to assign them roles unsuited to their capacities, nor to dismiss them unjustly.

Those who resist are called "obstructive people." With diligent and devoted hearts, Heaven is not human, yet it acts according to evidence and entrusts them with tasks, each questioned regarding their particular strengths—thus, nothing will remain ungoverned. The virtuous ruler should test them: those who daily produce good results should be promoted, with no oversight; those who prove ineffective should be swiftly dismissed. These are called "defilers of Heaven’s offices," preventing the arrival of correct *qi* and placing blame upon such wicked people.

The truly good, with hearts ever inclined to secretly assist and worry over all matters, are called "those who bring forth true goodness." The wicked, with perverse hearts, do not wish to secretly aid or benefit any affair—thus they bring forth wickedness. This is the natural standard and law of August Heaven. Therefore, they must be dismissed at once. If not dismissed, they will provoke Heaven’s wrath, causing the Earth to emit killing *qi*. Thus, they must be swiftly removed—this is a matter of great importance.

Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

The foolish truly fear this. If you know to fear it, you may be called one who understands the affairs of life, and Heaven will protect you.

—It is not so, it is not so.

There is no room for refusal here. It is not I who cause you to be protected by Heaven; by doing good, you naturally attain it. Thus, the conduct of the sages of old never dared stray from the plumb line, for they observed Heaven’s warnings and clearly discerned good and evil, each for their own sake. Therefore, they constantly sought to govern alongside the worthy, ever fearful of provoking Heaven. To offend Heaven is to have no recourse in prayer.

Thus, the ancient emperors and kings, with minds clear and penetrating, dared not recklessly collaborate with fools in governance, and so they alone enjoyed enduring good fortune. Perfected One, do you understand?

—Indeed, indeed.

Since the middle antiquity, half of humanity has been foolish, regarding selection and appointment as minor matters, failing to examine them carefully. Half the time, they obtain the wrong persons, half the time they disrupt Heaven’s offices, and half the time governance turns inauspicious. In later antiquity, inheriting the negligence of the middle era, they further allowed matters to proceed with ease, again failing to examine them carefully. In selections and appointments, they often fail to secure the right people, defiling Heaven’s offices. The Three Luminaries become unaligned because of this, and the evidence appears in the heavens—Heaven is displeased. Thus, inauspicious years persist without end, and when they briefly cease, they arise again. Yet people do not deeply reproach themselves, instead blaming the times and fate.

In ancient times, when such things occurred, the Way of Heaven was not at fault. Yet people, in their excess, attributed blame upward to Heaven, while the foolish below did not reflect on their own transgressions. Instead, they repeatedly joined together to shift responsibility, laying fault upon the emperors and kings. Heaven names such people "greatly rebellious subjects." The fault lies below, yet they deceive their superiors, calling evil good and good evil, collectively bringing about these disasters, then shifting blame upward to Heaven. Those who shift blame to Heaven further reproach their ruler. Such utterly perverse ministers and subjects are without justification.

Now, the spirits of Heaven and Earth together detest them, so Heaven has personally dispatched me to descend and, for the Virtuous Lord, renew the system of laws. In selecting and appointing people to official positions, one must be meticulous and thorough. Perfected One, do you wish to know how to scrutinize these wicked ministers and subjects?

Consider a household where parents raise several children. The children together deceive their parents, behaving wickedly. The parents, sitting silently in a room, know of their children’s violent and thieving conduct, yet the people instead collectively blame the parents: "The parents are evil, so they bore evil children." When the county officials apprehend them, they do not justly execute the wicked children but instead repeatedly blame the parents.

Parents, in raising children, always desire them to be worthy and good. When have they ever wished for their children to behave wickedly? To shift blame back to the parents is to be a greatly rebellious and unfilial child.

The ruler’s relationship to his ministers is the same: he always desires them to do good. When has he ever taught them to do evil? Yet the ministers and subjects below collectively engage in violent and wicked conduct, bringing disasters from Heaven and Earth, then shift blame back to reproach their ruler, causing the common people to suffer hardship. Thereupon, cunning officials also join in reproaching Heaven, calling this "ministers and subjects collectively committing rebellion." The crime cannot be absolved.

They exhaust their reproach of the ruler, and when the situation becomes dire, they further shift blame upward to Heaven and downward to Earth. Such is the rebellion of humanity—should their lives not be shortened and they not be swiftly executed?

Thus, in later antiquity, all have met with truncated destinies, their lives and deaths untimely. It is like a household wishing to slaughter livestock: if they suddenly decide to kill, they kill at once. Even good livestock are pitied in death, while wicked livestock are left to die of illness.

Perfected One, do you understand?

—Indeed, indeed.

The foolish and ignorant deeply revere the majesty of Heaven. You, disciple, have now awakened. Bring forth this text and have the virtuous ruler display it to all worthy scholars. Take heed not to conceal Heaven’s joy—release it with utmost urgency.

—Indeed, indeed.

Let me impart to you, Perfected One, a matter of great importance. When a ruler of great virtue employs ministers, each assigned to their proper place and aligned with the heart of Heaven, they must then know the arts of governing the people and eliminating harm. Yet those who dwell in distant regions, concealed and hidden, are exceedingly difficult to know. The benighted masses, each seeking their own advantage, instead deceive their virtuous ruler. It is incumbent upon the wise and enlightened to correct this together, for only when all is rectified will the heart of Heaven and Earth rejoice greatly, ensuring the emperor’s enduring fortune.

Heaven, in its wisdom, knows that the people of later ages are foolish and difficult to govern. Thus, it has deliberately issued this written covenant, called the *Celestial Writ*. The nature of writing is to make things manifest and clear, so that all under Heaven may record matters and act in accordance. It serves to document the writings of all people, not for the sake of a single, solitary individual. Therefore, all under Heaven use it to record every affair.

The sages employ it to record the patterns of Heaven and Earth, while the worthy use it to preserve the words of the sages. All people must study and read it together, only then can they grasp its meaning. The categories of writing are such that they must be collectively examined, collectively deliberated, collectively recorded, and collectively recited, so that deceit may be eliminated.

Thus, from ancient times to the present, the writings of the worthy and sagely—how many have been collated, how many transmitted, how many verified, how many collectively preserved—still inevitably contain residual errors and misleading phrases that cannot be entirely eradicated. Therefore, the great worthies and masters of the Dao traverse the world, scrutinizing words and studying speech, comparing differences to enlighten the ignorant. Yet even so, they may still mislead the innocent, causing them to recklessly expound their learning, rendering them unfit for office and unworthy to serve as ministers to the emperor.

Thus, when a single original text proliferates into many chapters and sentences, divergent interpretations arise, throwing the Dao of Heaven and Earth into great disorder and confusion, thereby giving rise to the calamities of *chengfu*. Do you understand, Perfected One?

—Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, for you have awakened. Now listen further, and I shall tell you of a great precept.

The reason people of later ages have long lost the favor of Heaven, causing Heaven and Earth to remain in constant sorrow, is that rulers rely on solitary words and isolated judgments, verifying matters without truth, and thus greatly deviating from the clarity of their intent. Perfected One, if this persists, it leads the multitude of worthies throughout the world to collectively examine texts yet remain ignorant, all falling into misguided learning. Hence, calamities and anomalies arise without cease. Heaven deeply abhors this, giving rise to disorder and illness, where yin and yang engage in unending strife.

Thus, Heaven commanded me to descend and correct these errors through careful collation. Since the Great Middle Antiquity, people have trusted solitary words and isolated judgments, often regarding the scrutiny of subordinate texts as disrespectful. They collectively use this as a standard for blame, thereby relying on solitary words and isolated judgments to respond to and draft documents for governance, thus incurring Heaven’s resentment and disorder.

Heavenly official documents were originally meant for people to collectively deliberate their right and wrong. Instead, they allow a single person to secretly compose the words. Even sages cannot alone fully comprehend the Dao of Heaven and Earth. Therefore, the works of sages and worthies across generations differ, as Heaven has stated that each excels in but one aspect and cannot entirely eliminate disasters. Thus, Heaven commanded me to gather and collate them all.

Now, instead, they trust the words of one person—how can this be acceptable? Therefore, Heaven instructs that the Three Dao Documents be circulated, allowing the great and the small, the worthy and the unworthy, men and women, to collectively interweave and deliberate, jointly determining right and wrong, all ensuring the verification of truth. Only then may they be presented. If one among them seeks to deceive, it shall be recorded. In this way, the illnesses of Heaven and Earth will be eradicated, and the emperor will bear no *chengfu* responsibility.

Heaven and Earth, free from illness, will rejoice. The emperor, secure in his rule, will rejoice. The worthy will attain self-realization and rejoice. The common people, freed from unjust suffering, will rejoice. Households will prosper, and people will be content, rejoicing. Servants and maids will find just masters and refrain from wrongdoing, rejoicing. The four seasons and five phases will proceed in harmony, and the people, cautious and untransgressive, will rejoice. The myriad things, each in its proper place and unharmed, will rejoice. Ghosts and spirits, witnessing the virtuous ruler’s accumulation of goodness, will also delight. Evil qi will no longer rise to obscure the heavens, and the sun, moon, and three luminaries will rejoice. The Supreme Peaceful Qi will come to govern, and the king, in his rule, will rejoice. Evil qi, once subdued and hidden, will no longer manifest to incite punitive expeditions, bringing joy. The barbarians will remain in their lands, no longer frequently waging war on Heaven’s behalf, rejoicing. Generals and commanders will rest their weapons, and soldiers will avoid death in battle, rejoicing.

In all between Heaven and Earth, such joys are too numerous to record. I, Perfected One, have outlined the great principles and shown their beginnings. Reflect on their meaning, and by analogy, you shall grasp all. When the virtuous ruler implements this, the world will submit in harmony.

Thus, Heaven particularly urges the circulation of these Three Daoist Writings—take heed not to abandon them again, lest disasters persist. To sever the celestial patterns is to revert to governance by the deaf and blind. Such governance is the root of chaos and peril, the calamity that destroys the self—how could one not be cautious?

These writings are what all under Heaven must jointly examine and practice; they cannot be trusted on the word of a single person. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, texts and human testimonies have been transmitted and cross-examined to verify their clarity. Without such verification, they cannot be practiced alone. To act solely on one person’s word is to court danger and ruin—this is the great loss and harm of the world.

Therefore, my writings dare not tolerate solitary words or isolated phrases. Thus, I instruct the Perfected One to collate and compare ancient, middle, and recent texts to illuminate their coherence, and to gather and verify the testimonies of all under Heaven to confirm their covenants. Only then can all between Heaven and Earth be rectified, and the interactions of yin and yang remain free of affliction.

Examine past and present celestial patterns, earthly spirit-writings, and human testimonies with my texts—they will surely resonate like an echo, indistinguishable from the divine. Only then can my Dao be deemed trustworthy. Thus, I do not speak of the Dao idly; I seek its trial in practice. Without practice, how can one know whether my Dao aligns with Heaven and proves true?

Today, practice it, and it will be as if conversing with Heaven—ten out of ten, fifteen out of fifteen, with no omissions. Wondrous is the Dao when thus pursued! Truly, it may be called the greatest joy. Does the Perfected One understand? Indeed.

Proceed, and enlightenment will arise.

I impart to the Perfected One a great secret: this begins with guarding the One, focusing on goodness to grasp its essence, thereby entering the Dao. Thus, I follow it with the writings on the Dao. Pursuing the Dao leads to entering the chamber, entering the true Dao, and entering the chamber requires knowledge of the divine—hence, I follow it with the divine precepts.

Having guarded the One, attained the Dao, and attained the divine, one may ascend to become a virtuous ruler or a worthy minister. Ministers must assist the virtuous ruler in harmonizing the six directions and eight realms of Heaven and Earth, grasping their essence so the nation may enjoy enduring peace.

To achieve this peace, one must rectify texts, words, and speech. Thus, collating and verifying writings and testimonies brings great rectification. Only then will the multitude of worthy scholars and superior gentlemen emerge to jointly assist the ruler, serving as his enlightened ears, eyes, and limbs. Hence, I follow this with the nine officials.

When the nine officials each fulfill their roles, they will jointly harmonize Heaven and Earth, and all under Heaven will unite in purpose. They must constantly communicate, reporting good and ill—thus, I follow this with the Three Daoist Writings.

Once all have mastered guarding the One, entered the Dao, attained the divine, and embraced rectified texts, with officials of all ranks in their proper places, and once the six affairs of the writings are practiced in unison, all under Heaven will share one heart. None will dare to harbor hatred; all will love and benefit one another as if born of the same parents. Thus, the virtuous ruler deeply aligns with Heaven’s will, delighting in the absence of strife.

Fearing omissions in the Dao might leave Heaven and Earth’s writings incomplete, I further append the *Great Collection of Difficulties* to resolve doubts. The profoundest matters are placed below, and the complete writings are presented to be entrusted to the virtuous ruler. Should the world’s calculations shift even once, it will spontaneously govern itself for the better.

This ease is like fire ascending dry heights or water flowing downward—no instruction is needed, for it moves naturally and cannot be restrained. Thus, the teachings of the Great August Heavenly Dao will swiftly take effect. When the virtuous ruler practices them, he is called the Divine Son of Heaven, styled the Supreme August One, resembling the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth. Thus, all spirits under Heaven may be commanded.

Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, there has never been a celestial scripture or divine text like this, transmitted by the Perfected One as a record of the true Dao. Entrusting it to the virtuous ruler, it is called the Mother of the Dao.

The qi of the Great Yang, the fire phase, exists within it. To practice it is to attain its truth; to neglect it is to render it unreal. Does the Perfected One understand? Indeed.

With utmost sincerity, I entrust this to the careful stewardship of the people, delivering it to the virtuous ruler—dare not retain it long. Go forth, for you have already understood. The celestial scripture must not be kept long, lest the heavenly spirits examine men and bring misfortune. Take heed and depart. Indeed, indeed.

The Six Investigations harmonize with the Utmost Seven Boundaries, arranging texts by category so they align, eradicating all calamities and ushering in the auspicious writings of the Utmost Extremity.

**Enduring Humiliation, Emulating Heaven and Earth’s Utmost Sincerity, and Resonating with the Spirits: The Great Precept, One Hundred Fifty-Three**
The Perfected One steps forward. Indeed, indeed.

Now I shall impart to you one great precept. Our Dao is for governing Heaven and Earth, pacifying emperors and kings, and giving life to what Heaven and Earth cherish—thus, one must cherish the true Dao and true virtue. Therefore, Heaven is the truth of the Dao, the warp of the Dao, the faithfulness of the Dao, the means by which the Dao operates through interdependence. Earth is the chief of virtue, the weft of virtue, the foundation by which virtue comes to rest through interdependence. Thus, it endures as the mother of the myriad things, constantly enduring humiliation by dwelling below, never boasting of its toil and hardship.

As the virtuous ruler, I instruct the benighted below, taking these two matters of Heaven and Earth as my foundation. Thus, I always follow the laws and measures of Heaven and Earth, never deviating from their gateway. My writings are the words of Heaven conversing with Earth, deeply and uniquely resonating with the spirits, like outer and inner. Each step follows the other, like compass and square. Those who proceed in accord gain the intent of Heaven and Earth; those who lose it meet with misfortune and decline.

Now I precept you, Perfected One—ponder my words and ever be vigilant. Indeed, indeed.

Go forth. Seeing your devotion to true Dao and virtue, your goodness unmatched, I shall reveal one further word. Now, the superior person delights greatly in the true Dao and good virtue; the middling person is half-inclined toward them; the inferior person, devoid of form, utterly lacks Dao and virtue—all are those who commit great rebellion and defy the Dao. The greatly inauspicious, those without virtue, stand alone within Heaven and Earth, unrecognized and unknown, not beloved by Heaven’s constancy. Thus, those without Dao and virtue have no mandate under Heaven and Earth, sharing the same fate and fortune as birds and beasts.

Now, if you do not understand, I shall tell you the essential meaning. Very well—Perfected Six, listen clearly.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, Heaven is purely of the Dao, Earth purely of virtue. These people without Dao and virtue share no resemblance to Heaven and Earth. Heaven’s movement ought to embody the true Dao, favoring the manifestation of life. Earth ought to embody good virtue, favoring nurturance and growth. Now, those without Dao and without virtue—thus Heaven and Earth do not pardon them.

To know this with clear certainty: consider how those of Dao recognize others of Dao, and those of virtue recognize others of virtue, each gathering and embracing their own. Thus their destinies are mutually sustained. Therefore, those of Dao delight in elevating others of Dao, and those of virtue delight in elevating others of virtue. Those with Dao and virtue do not align with those without Dao and virtue, and so refuse to gather or embrace them—thus their destinies are not bound to Heaven.

Excellent, excellent. You wish to hear the meaning of sharing the same fate as birds and beasts. Well said—you have deeply grasped this principle.

Now, the destinies of birds and beasts are bound to the four directions. Their nature is to butt and clash, devoid of Dao and virtue, with the stronger prevailing. The ignorant and base among people, also devoid of Dao and virtue, likewise delight in clashing and contending, with the stronger prevailing. Their qi is the same as that of birds and beasts—thus they share the same fate.

The Dao of Heaven serves as the standard, by which the superior and inferior among people are distinguished. Thus this is known.

Now, all named destinies under Heaven follow their kind. Thus one knows to which destiny they belong. Those who embody the Five Natures in abundance resemble yang and are benevolent; those who embody the Six Passions in abundance resemble yin and are greedy. Those who receive more yang endowment become male; those who receive more yin endowment become female. Those who receive more of the flourishing qi are noble, honored, and long-lived; those who receive more of the waning, declining, or captive qi suffer frequent illness, die young, and live in extreme poverty.

Thus, for all who are born, their destiny is bound to the qi of which celestial movement they resemble, and to which of the Six Jia cycles their fate is tied. By classifying them accordingly, not one in ten thousand is misjudged.

Therefore, the sages of antiquity deeply investigated all matters and understood human nature through this. Do you, Perfected One, understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Excellent, excellent.

Now, the people of this later age bear the burdens of their ancestors’ miscalculations, gradually severing the Dao and virtue together. Day by day, over long years, they cut themselves off from Heaven and Earth, their essence and qi no longer flowing through them. Unaware of their own destiny, they revert to sharing the fate of four-footed creatures. Thus, Heaven and Earth detest them, and the spirits and qi of the gods no longer protect them. Their illnesses are countless, their deaths untimely—this is the great fault that lies here...

Yet the ruler of supreme virtue, whose fate is bound to Heaven and Earth, must emulate them and govern through the Dao and virtue. Therefore, I have once more set forth the Way of Heaven and entrusted it to those above. Heaven delights in their goodness and does not wish them to persist in the ways of four-footed men. Thus, I reiterate these writings with utmost urgency, desiring that they awaken fully. Therefore, I have compiled the Six Calamities and the Great Collective Adversity to deliver and return them to their rightful place.

Do you, Perfected One, understand?
Indeed, indeed.
How astonishing! How joyous, how joyous!

Perfected One, how do you know what is so astonishing and joyous?
When I, a foolish student, heard the Heavenly Master speak, I realized that when the true Dao and virtue emerge, the people transform in a single day. All will uphold the Dao and virtue, emulate Heaven and Earth, and no longer act as four-footed men. Each person will follow the Dao, each will embody virtue—thus I know the profound joy of this intent.

Excellent, Perfected One! Your words are beyond improvement.
Now, I wish to take this opportunity to ask the Heavenly Master one question.
Speak.

When people seek the Dao and virtue, or when ordinary men act, what should they regard as their most urgent duty? How can they come to know it, and how can they resonate in response with Heaven and Earth?

Excellent is your question! They must act with utmost sincerity, with the five inner organs true and sincere—only then can they attain it. If they do not act with the five inner organs true and sincere, they incur the resentment of the Dao and virtue. Seeking goodness will be in vain, and the spirits will not respond.

Now, I wish to hear: how does utmost sincerity move Heaven and Earth and the gods?
Alas! Perfected One, in this you are particularly foolish. Have you not yet grasped the texts I have written? Your ignorance is deep and long-standing—it cannot be dispelled in a single day. Yet you are also greatly humble. Listen carefully now, and I will explain the meaning of utmost sincerity moving Heaven and Earth.

Indeed, indeed.
Heed my words.

Utmost sincerity is so named because one looks up to Heaven and acts, emulating the Way of Heaven. One looks down to Earth and acts, emulating the virtue of Earth. One reflects that Heaven and Earth, like parents, gave me life and do not wish me to delight in evil. Thus, one returns filial piety to the heart and acts accordingly.

The heart is the most revered spirit within the deepest recesses. The heart is sacred, the pure yang movement of fire. Fire moves upward, sharing the radiance of Heaven. Thus, the sun is the ruler of fire, the essence of Heaven, illuminating all without fail. When a person embodies utmost sincerity, the heart’s upright distress moves the sacred spirit of the heart, which then ascends to report to the sun. The sun, in turn, reports to Heaven. Thus, utmost sincerity within the five inner organs moves the spirits.

How can one not be cautious?
Perfected One said: How awe-inspiring! How awe-inspiring! I, a foolish student, have overstepped in asking this—it fills me with great dread.

To know dread is the root of life. To be without dread is the gate of death. Safety and peril lie within yourself, not elsewhere. Though you ask the Heavenly Master repeatedly with fear and trembling, only by asking will you receive the decisive answer and profound understanding. Without asking, there would be no way to know.

Indeed, your words are correct. If one remains in darkness and does not ask, when will clarity ever come? Speak—what else would you ask?

Now that I have heard how utmost sincerity moves Heaven, I wish to hear how it moves Earth.
Excellent! Your words grow ever deeper, and you spare nothing in your inquiry. Sit calmly, and I will explain it to you. I fear that if I do not speak, I may fail you.

It is as if Heaven itself grieves that later generations lack utmost sincerity, and thus sent the Perfected One to take up these questions.
Very well.

Now I will tell you—listen clearly.
Indeed, indeed.

Go forth—when a person’s utmost sincerity takes hold of a thought, the heart aches with such pain that they cannot eat, their innards churning. What bears this thought is the heart, the mind; heart and mind do not forget. The liver is most benevolent, and so the eyes serve as its master, weeping tears—this is the utmost sincerity of concentrated thought. The heart is the essence of clarity. To hold a thought without ceasing is the work of the mind, of the spleen. The heart is pure yang, its station belonging to Heaven; the spleen is pure yin, its station belonging to Earth. When utmost sincerity fixes upon a single thought, the heart aches and tears flow. The heart commands the mind to direct the thought’s course, sending word to distant places. The mind is yin; when yin harbors sorrow, it must report to yang, thus ascending to inform the august spirits of Heaven. The spleen is yin, its home on Earth, and so it descends into the Earth to report. Thus Heaven and Earth shift on its behalf, and all spirits are moved by it.

Would you know its great effect? I do not deceive you, Perfected One. Simply sit calmly in a secluded chamber, concentrate your heart and ponder the spirits—they will all come of their own accord. Is this not clear proof? This is the truth of utmost sincerity that I tell you; I have never spoken without method.

Thus, in seeking the Dao and virtue, all human conduct proceeds from utmost sincerity, and Heaven and Earth respond, spirits come to inform. Without utmost sincerity, one cannot move Heaven and Earth or stir the spirits. After the era of *chengfu*, people of later ages truly lacked faith, lacked utmost sincerity, and could not move Heaven and Earth. Together they deceived Heaven and Earth, and so the spirits ceaselessly harmed them.

Would you hear how this is made clear? There is great evidence in the sun and moon. Now I would hear it. In later ages, people born of father and mother together neglected their parents, turned their backs on them—among ten thousand, not one was filial. Those who gained understanding from a teacher, who awakened and departed, then neglected their teacher, no longer treating them as their teacher, instead submitting to toil and hardship. Having risen from poverty and low station to wealth and nobility through their lord, they then turned to instruct their superiors, all joining in daily deception of those above. Among ten thousand, not one possessed sincerity and trustworthiness. The foolish masses together deceived the Three Bonds, acting in rebellion and without faith. Their transgressions were manifest, impossible to conceal below, all visible above to the sun, moon, and Three Luminaries. Thus Heaven and Earth deeply detested and despised them, cutting short their lives and bringing early death.

If one does not deeply reflect tenfold upon their grave transgressions, but instead weeps and wails in vain, calling Heaven cruel—what grievance is this? You bring suffering upon yourself; when has Heaven ever wronged you? How dreadful! Excellent, excellent. Foolish student, I have received your command.

Should you uphold this as a solemn warning, then for ten thousand generations and beyond, you shall know no affliction.

With these words concluded, doubts arose once more, and the questioner returned. "Yes, yes," he assented.

**The Great Collection’s Difficulties on the Dao’s Utmost Sincerity and Heaven’s Admonitions, Shown to the Worthy**

*End of Scroll Ninety-Six of the* Classic of Great Peace
*Scroll Ninety-Seven of the* Classic of Great Peace

**First: The Jealousy of the Dao’s Non-Transmission and the Recluse’s Aid to Transformation**

A truly foolish and benighted one, whose ignorance daily worsens, unable to comprehend the profound and impenetrable, bows twice in reverence and asks: If I act upon one matter, my words will surely incur fault; yet if I do not ask, my foolish heart cannot resolve it alone.

"Go on, speak."

This foolish student has privately heard that the secret Dao and essential virtue are the treasures of Heaven and Earth, the rarest and most wondrous things under Heaven. Thus, they are called the "Utmost Dao, not to be transmitted"—for they are not what ordinary people should hear, speak, or employ. Yet now the Heavenly Master has fully opened the path of Great Peace learning, commanding all to expound the essential texts of Dao and virtue, forbidding concealment. He declares that those who hide them incur Heaven’s condemnation, a sin that persists even unto death and flows into later generations. All are to be granted the true Dao and secret virtue—is this not grand indeed?

Yet when the petty and the noble are not distinguished, this foolish one believes that the true Dao and secret virtue should not be heard, spoken, or used by small-minded people.

"Alas! You now speak thus, bearing a ten-thousandfold deathly guilt before the August Heaven and Earth, a guilt that shall never be absolved. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, later generations have grown ever more shallow, envying the Dao. Small-minded people sever the treasures of Heaven and Earth, and this loss has accumulated over time, giving rise to *chengfu* (inherited burdens), causing Heaven’s disasters to never cease. Thus, within Heaven and Earth, not a single year passes in peace; calamities, omens, and bandits abound, and the state is plunged into sorrow and suffering—all arising from this.

What you now say is precisely the cause: it confounds Heaven and overturns Earth, plunging governance into chaos, making the people ungovernable. Precisely so.

You now speak thus—do you not heap heavy enmity upon Heaven? Wrong, wrong! Your merit is undone. How so?

When the essential Dao and good virtue are revealed for instruction, even small-minded people, upon obtaining and upholding them, will emulate and learn from one another, daring not to act wrongly. Among them, the lesser worthy who gain good Dao and virtue may become upright and compliant officials. The greater worthy may ascend to assist the state. Even the most ignorant at the lowest level will still become good people.

Heaven employs the essential true Dao to generate all things, extending even to the six domestic animals and birds. The four seasons and five phases are the true essential Dao of Heaven and Earth, their divine treasures, the stored *qi* of Heaven and Earth. The six domestic animals and birds embrace it as their nature; grasses and trees obtain it and then grow. If Heaven did not bestow the complete essential Dao, how could they generate and grow one another?

Yet you, True One, say that small-minded people should not hear the essential Dao, should not speak it, should not use it. Do the divine protectors of Heaven and Earth preserve all species, while humans alone are less good than the six domestic animals and grasses? You yourself know that what you now say incurs a ten-thousandfold deathly sin, never to be absolved.

This foolish student has served the master but briefly and shallowly, not deeply understanding the Way of Heaven. Upon hearing the Heavenly Master’s words, I now realize my grave sin: I have failed the August Heaven above, the Earth below, and the virtuous lord in between. Yet your self-reproach is justified.

In all undertakings, can one not be cautious? The August Heaven alone observes the words of people’s mouths—why else would echoes follow human voices to determine fortune or misfortune? Thus, echoes respond without missing a single *zhu* or *fen*. Have you never observed this proof of Heaven and Earth’s resonance?

You should be cautious where you fall short; do not force reckless speech, for its harm is grave.

You now say the Utmost Dao is not to be transmitted to people—then how is it to be known? If the Utmost Dao is ultimately untransmittable, and the Way of Heaven is impartial, for whom alone should it exist?

This disciple will be cautious and vigilant; my conduct has been most improper.

Do you wish to be like the vulgar and small-minded, teaching others to envy the Way of Heaven? "I dare not, I dare not."

True One, be meticulous in your vigilance. Once Heaven’s wrath is aroused, the sin incurred shall never be absolved. The Way of Heaven is precisely ruined by such words—do you now add to them?

That emperors and kings cannot govern their realms and frequently suffer disasters is entirely due to those like you. If you now speak thus, you cause the true Dao to be severed, heterodox ways to arise, and governance to become unmanageable.

Do you understand? "Yes, yes."

I have awakened; I am ashamed to have failed the Heavenly Master.

Always be cautious in your conduct. "Yes, yes."

I often reflect that my words incur fault, and wish not to speak, yet I do not know.

Speak plainly.

What is it that people should not hear, should not speak, should not use?

It is not that ordinary people should not hear the true essential Dao or true essential virtue. Thus, when inferior teachers instruct small-minded people, they do not employ the essential secret Dao and true virtue to admonish and teach them. Instead, they use superficial, false, and artful writings to instruct ordinary people. Among them, the greater worthy who learn these false and artful writings proceed to deceive their lords. The middling worthy who study false writings become cunning officials, flattering and deceiving their superiors above while craftily oppressing the good and compliant people below. The inferior and small-minded who obtain these writings act without principle, deceiving their parents, outwitting their neighbors, or becoming unstoppable bandits.

The worthy and unworthy, officials and commoners, all engage in deceit and falsehood, unable to restrain one another. Witnessing this heterodoxy and impropriety, they disrupt the celestial patterns above and the terrestrial principles below, harm the accomplishments of the five phases, and rebel against the nurturing of the four seasons. Together, they deceive their superiors, plunging the state into chaos. The harm is extreme, beyond recounting.

Yet you, True One, say that small-minded people should not hear the essential Dao and virtue, and should instead be taught with false and artful matters, causing the people under Heaven to be dazzled, to learn and practice falsehood unknowingly, and to become utterly without the Dao. Is this so?"

Thus, the True One incurs the guilt of ten thousand deaths, a sin that cannot be absolved. What the world ought not hear, ought not speak, ought not employ—precisely this false literature, born of deceitful cunning and great treachery, arises from this. Therefore, I lay down the law for Heaven and establish teachings for the virtuous ruler, daring not to approach such matters, thereby exclusively opening the gate of the Dao and virtue while sealing off the paths of craft and deceit. Thus, my writings root themselves in the essence of the Dao and virtue, casting aside the methods of false texts and artful deceit, which are entirely excluded. Do you alone find this unremarkable?

This is deemed an affliction by Heaven and Earth, a harm by emperors and kings. I shall once more explain it fully to the True One: it concerns employing the essential Dao and virtue to instruct the small-minded. The most worthy may thereby uphold goodness and integrity; those of middling virtue and above may become the empire’s most virtuous ministers; those of lesser worth may be transformed into compliant and good officials; even the most foolish may still become cautious folk, unaware of how to harm one another.

Thus, from Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, the five phases, the sun, moon, and constellations, all together nurture the myriad twelve thousand beings with the true Dao and essential virtue. Even the six domestic animals, dung, and grasses are clothed in its secret Dao and essential virtue, thereby attaining growth. Now, if the True One persists in such speech to the end, are such people not inferior to the six domestic animals, dung, and grasses?

Do you now persist in speaking thus, unaware that your error is one of ten thousand deaths, a sin that cannot be erased? There is a deadly error, a deadly error. Do not feign ignorance—you simply fail to comprehend. What now is to be done about this error? To absolve it, on the day of purification, go to a vast wilderness where four roads meet, prostrate and kowtow in each of the four directions, performing five prostrations in each. First, gaze upward to Heaven, then turn and kowtow to the Earth. Assent, assent.

Now, why does the Heavenly Master urgently instruct this foolish student? The urgency does not arise from the True One’s former status. Rather, the True One’s words violate the taboos of Heaven and Earth. Since the Highest Antiquity and Middle Antiquity, those who teach humanity have often been jealous of the true Dao and good virtue, instead teaching one another to flee and conceal it, to seal and cut it off, and to instruct with deceitful and cunning ways, leading the foolish into wrongdoing. The greatest worthies flee and withdraw from the world; only those of middling worth become officials, lacking the true Dao and thus disordering the people. The most foolish, devoid of the Dao, rise as bandits. When both people and ministers turn to heterodoxy, their clamor gathers like mosquitoes to shake the thunder, together rebelling against the celestial patterns, destroying the heavenly Dao, defying the will of Earth, reversing the qi of the four seasons, and disrupting the five phases. This gives rise to countless calamities and omens; the Three Luminaries lose their proper radiance; emperors and kings are plunged into great sorrow, falling into chaos and confusion, unable to govern in peace—all arising from this.

Does the True One truly not recognize the gravity of this sin? Heaven will not absolve it. If I do not instruct you, you must perform the rites of atonement.

Thus, one must conduct oneself in the wilderness, in places of clarity and brightness. The reason the Way extends in all four directions is that the Dao governs all affairs. The reason it extends in all directions is that it is entrusted to the four seasons, which Heaven employs to convey qi, thereby enabling you to ascend and commune with Heaven. The four seasons, benevolent in their generation and completion, also dissolve your transgressions before Heaven and Earth; all who later commit faults are but reflections of you.

From this day forward, Heaven will severely punish those who do evil. Therefore, the noble person must always err on the side of great goodness and never on the side of great wickedness. Be cautious, be ever cautious. If even you act thus, how much more so the common and foolish? Mutual instruction breeds jealousy, and the Dao conceals itself—this is the way of things. What you have spoken is ever good.

Yet a single word today may be called a great rebellion against Heaven and Earth, the very sorrow that has afflicted rulers from ancient times to the present. Before you, True One, how could one be born a noble person? It is all through learning. To learn the Dao is to embody the Dao; to learn virtue is to attain it; to learn goodness is to become good; to learn the supreme Dao, goodness, and power is to live long into old age, ever increasing in virtue and excellence.

Thus, those who embrace the essential Dao, goodness, and power are called the recluses of emperors and kings, the foremost and most excellent of people, capable of aiding the noble in their transformation. Those who do not serve in office are the most reverent of people. Those who learn evil become evil; those who learn refinement become refined; those who learn deceit become deceitful; those who learn cunning become cunning.

Among those who learn, the most worthy may master eloquent speech, while those who study texts may craft artful writing. When petty people acquire such skills, they become treacherous. In your heart, can you truly refrain from teaching this? Therefore, the essential Dao and hidden power are what align with the heart of Heaven and the will of Earth, enabling the long-term peace of the state and bringing joy to emperors and kings. Yet they are suppressed and not vigorously promoted, so that when people offend Heaven, their sins remain unforgiven.

Heaven acts through the supreme Dao, Earth dwells in supreme virtue, and together they generate the myriad things, concealing nothing and favoring none. Thus, the sages of antiquity modeled their conduct on Heaven and Earth, using the supreme Dao and essential power to instruct the foolish, making them reverent and good, so that governance became easy.

In this age, such teachings are often obstructed and severed, so the foolish collectively become treacherous. They lose the Dao of Heaven and do not recognize their own wrongdoing. The fault lies in the failure to practice the true Dao, goodness, and power, so people are frequently punished by Heaven, their deaths unforgiven. The foolish, lacking the Dao, disregard taboos and together violate Heaven and Earth, all because they do not know the essentials of Dao and virtue.

The reason I write these words, repeating and exhorting with such earnestness, is that I fear people will accumulate folly and, upon hearing a single word, fail to believe my text. Thus, I reiterate. People have long been accustomed to heterodoxy, and some may even call my words false. If the gates of the true Dao and hidden power are again severed and cease to function, Heaven’s wrath will not abate. Emperors will remain in sorrow, officials and people will have nowhere to turn, following one another into chaos, unable to save themselves. Test my words before Heaven, for they are precisely meant to resolve and dispel this fabricated Dao.

People are all entangled in heterodox texts, their folly accumulated over time. Therefore, I constantly command the True One to bring forth my Dao and entrust it to a ruler of supreme morality, to show it to the worthy, and to swiftly test my Dao. Only then will they know the truth of my writings, which resemble Heaven and Earth. Without use or testing, how can one know their validity? Now, to ensure my Dao is not mistaken, I seek to have it tested—not just a single scroll.

True One, be cautious. Indeed, indeed. Go forth and always heed my words; do not take them lightly or speak carelessly. Indeed, indeed. Do not conceal them; let all people, in their speech and learning, recognize what is gained and lost, and no longer act recklessly. Indeed, indeed.

**Right: Resolving what people should not hear, should not speak, should not use—severing heterodoxy and revealing the true text.**

**Serving the Master as One Serves a Father—Words to Become a Decisive Method, One Hundred Fifty-Five**

Now, when the foolish speak, their words often miss the mark of the Heavenly Master’s heart, incurring repeated punishments and transgressions. They dare not ask about their faults, and even as the year draws to a close, they still do not know the way. I wish to ask one more question. How can the Way be leveled? Why be modest? To ask when one does not know is the proper course.

Now, to teach the supreme essential Dao and power to ordinary people—have they truly not understood it greatly? Excellent are your words. What great understanding could there be? Why do you doubt this? I have heard that if a son’s wisdom surpasses his father’s, a disciple’s surpasses his teacher’s, or a minister’s surpasses his lord’s, it is called a lesser worthy’s wisdom surpassing their superior, which is deemed improper.

Your words are both correct and incorrect. When the wisdom of inferiors surpasses that of superiors, it is indeed inappropriate. If the wisdom of inferiors is used to craft cunning and deceit, surpassing their superiors, they will deceive those above them. If you wish to see the effects, consider this: in teaching and learning, if a disciple’s skill surpasses his master’s, he will harm his master. When those below study treacherous, deceitful, and devious ways, they collectively confuse and deceive their superiors.

Thus, the great sages of antiquity dared not recklessly teach treacherous, cunning, or deceitful arts. They always deeply contemplated the root and severed the branches, preventing the foolish from knowing them. To govern a state with treacherous wisdom is to be a great thief of the state. Therefore, the sages of old always focused on teaching the true Dao and never imparted superficial, deceptive, or cunning arts. Knowing the great harm they would cause, they constantly closed the paths of inauspicious learning and opened the roads of auspicious conduct, so that people would remain reverent and unaware of how to do wrong.

If you wish to further confirm this truth, consider that in the era of the Three Sovereigns, rulers treated their ministers as teachers, like fathers. At that time, ministers each embraced the essential Dao and power, and there were no cunning, deceitful, or treacherous people.

Thus, in that era, ministers’ wisdom all surpassed their rulers, enabling them to serve as teachers to emperors and kings. Their instruction was like that of fathers, and so rulers treated them as both teachers and fathers—this was because their Dao and virtue exceeded those of their rulers. Therefore, they could cause their rulers to sit at ease, governing with folded arms and free from worry.

Thus, those whose words hit the mark ten times out of ten could assist emperors and kings; those who succeeded nine times out of ten could aid great ministers; those who succeeded eight times out of ten could serve as minor officials. Below this, their counsel was not worth heeding. Words that missed the mark were called reckless speech, misleading and confusing their superiors.

Do you understand this?
Yes, indeed.

Come, if you wish to further confirm its great effect: by the time of the Five Emperors, the Dao had slightly declined, and so rulers and ministers could no longer inquire of one another regarding Dao and virtue. Those who shared the same school became cliques, and those of like mind became friends. Though rulers and ministers shared knowledge, they could no longer greatly surpass one another. The essential Dao and secret virtue were slightly obstructed and no longer flowed freely, so they could no longer be treated as teachers or fathers, but only as friends.

By the time of the Three Kings, those who taught were often jealous of learning, blocking and cutting off the true Dao and extraordinary virtue. Their disciples grew increasingly foolish and ignorant, instead indulging in superficial embellishments, causing rulers to become confused and their Dao and virtue to grow shallow. They were no longer worthy of being treated as fathers or friends, so they were treated as subordinates. Their wisdom was scant, and so they could not assist emperors and kings in discerning the difficulty or ease of governance.

Thus, Heaven and Earth grew greatly enraged, and disasters and calamities arose in succession, impossible to suppress or eradicate. The great fault lay here.

Do you understand this?
Yes, indeed.

Having realized this, child, I shall now elucidate it further for you.

In the age of the Five Hegemons, none of their ministers possessed true Dao or virtue. All were adept at crafting cunning deceits, employing the arts of fraud and treachery to deceive one another. Their ministers, steeped in wickedness, flattery, and falsehood, mastered the ways of startling and confounding others—sometimes even surpassing their rulers. Thus, rebellion arose: sons slew their fathers, ministers murdered their lords, and subordinates killed their superiors. All harbored the hearts of barbarians, devoid of righteousness. Each person wielded deceitful schemes, every heart concealed treachery, and none held fast to the true Dao. Hence, rebellions occurred time and again.

For this reason, the executioner’s axe and drill were ever at the ready, and ministers were regarded as entries in a death ledger. Their ministers, in turn, were filled with flattery and embellishment, their cunning and deceit rendering the Way of no weight. Thus, they were treated as mere livestock—this is the clear proof.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of antiquity, aligning with the will of Heaven, embraced the true Dao, honored virtuous scholars and benevolent men, and banished the flattering and deceitful. In this way, they fulfilled the heart of August Heaven. Hence, our Dao opened the gates of fortune and sealed the doors of misfortune, never tolerating the cunning and deceit that might surpass a ruler.

Do you now understand this?
Yes, indeed.

Beware of this.

In the highest antiquity, ministers often attained immortality and long life, and thus could grant longevity to their rulers. In middle antiquity, ministers were often wise and embraced the Dao and virtue, and thus could ensure their rulers remained free from care. In later antiquity, ministers, lacking the true Dao and being foolish, often made their rulers exceedingly foolish. When a ruler is foolish, his governance is perpetually chaotic and confused, failing to align with the heart of Heaven.

The ministers of hegemonic rulers are all flatterers and deceivers, full of cunning and crafty deceit, together deluding their ruler, causing him to lose the true path of Heaven and instead enter the gates of misfortune—thus becoming a great enemy of Heaven. Do you understand this?

Therefore, their governance is entirely inauspicious and cannot endure for long. The Perfected, in serving Heaven’s affairs, should be vigilant daily and not indulge in reckless or baseless speech. Words should become standards; if they do not form classics, it is better to remain silent. If one’s words miss the mark, the sin is profound and ineradicable.

Yes, indeed.

Go now, for you have understood.

**Right: The Difficulty of the Wise and Worthy in Surpassing Their Rulers—Hard to Resolve**

*This concludes the ninety-seventh scroll of the* Classic of Great Peace.
*Here begins the ninety-eighth scroll of the* Classic of Great Peace.

**Divine Governance: The Secret of Guarding the Root and Hidden Protection—One Hundred Fifty-Sixth**

Someone asked about a great matter of doubt.
Speak.
Now, the Heavenly Master has broadly opened the path of the Dao of Heaven, thoroughly collating the texts of ancient Daoist scriptures to discern the true essential and secret Way.
The true Way is largely good, and its writings enter into the divine—thus enabling one to behold the divine and govern alongside it.
If what is governed enters the divine as the divine does, then the Way is truly realized.
Yet many attain this in secluded chambers—some are enabled to transcend within the chamber and depart, while others enter and exit but cannot yet leave; still others merely glimpse the divine yet remain bound to it through the ages.
Of those who transcend and depart, not one in ten thousand succeeds.
Of those who attain great longevity, not one in a thousand succeeds.
Of those who attain lesser longevity, not one in a hundred succeeds.
Only those who fulfill their Heaven-appointed years match these proportions.
Among all the people under Heaven who study and inquire, not one in ten thousand obtains a high office; not one in a thousand obtains a middling office; not one in a hundred obtains a minor office.
As for those who till the land to sustain life, not one in ten thousand gains a hundred million; not one in a thousand gains ten million; not one in a hundred gains a million.
All affairs are like this.
Thus, those who begin are many, while those who transcend the world or attain wealth and nobility are few.

The foolish student deeply worries: what should be the great precepts of the Dao to attain full completion? What should be the great precepts of study to obtain high office? What should be the great precepts of managing life and accumulating wealth to achieve success?

Now, unable to reach the Heavenly Master’s power to resolve these doubts, I fear remaining forever benighted, never enlightened, and thus unable to know the truth.

Excellent, excellent! When the various Perfected Ones ask about doubtful matters, Heaven sends you to inquire. Very well. Sit calmly, listen attentively with your whole being, and I shall now fully expound it to you, Perfected One, so that it may be clearly known and remembered by your own effort. Yes, yes.

Go forth—later generations who obtain my writings shall have the true Dao’s path widely opened for them, and they will surely all study the true Dao. The true Dao often interacts with spirits, and the spirit-way is solely concerned with human affairs. Spirits delight in those who are kind to people, yet startle those who do not see them; they do not contend in speech with people but appear like flocks of birds coming and going without end. Some speak of people transcending and departing, some of people becoming wealthy and noble, some of people falling into poverty and lowliness; they praise or slander others, bring people great joy or constant bitter resentment.

Spirits have no fixed form—they are beings of endless transformation. If one can focus the mind and guard oneself, refusing to heed their words, examining the heart before acting, keeping the mouth sealed to avoid transmitting their speech, and not following their sorrows, angers, or joys, steadfastly holding to the original foundation without wavering, striving to secretly benefit people and all things without wishing harm—then, after a year of knowing the Dao, one will always act with supreme goodness, seeking benefit without injury, pursuing the Dao and goodness until the end of one’s years without daring to slacken. Even if one fails to transcend the world ten thousand times, one will encounter great fortune rather than misfortune even once.

In this way, the host of spirits will together protect and assist such a person, causing them to delight daily in goodness and no longer commit evil. Does the Perfected One understand? Yes, yes. Go forth—you have now understood.

Go forth, and I shall tell you, Perfected One, of those who bring chaos and ruin upon themselves. When a person’s mind and intent are not single-minded and pure, when they are easily pleased or angered, easily startled or confused, when they are glib of speech and quick-witted, always desiring to speak of good and evil with no ability to conceal—when they encounter something and cannot restrain themselves from speaking—then the host of spirits will come together to deceive them.

Some, being petty, will ascend to utter perverse words and die; some will engage in constant quarrels and reckless speech; some will be startled by ghosts and spirits, falling into madness and illness. When the mind is greatly distracted, not devoted to one thing, when joy and anger are without constancy, when actions lose their correctness, when one is confused and without direction—then one may lose worthy friends and good advisors, thereby facing peril and ruin.

The greatest fault lies in not loving benefit: those above do not seek to benefit those below, listen to evil spirits, and instead desire to harm. Thus, the worthy depart, and one loses their aid. As for the petty, they do not honor and respect their superiors but instead listen to the deceit and falsehoods of evil spirits, uttering perverse and reckless words. This is the path by which the Dao is not accomplished, the gateway to misfortune—I cannot foresee or recount all its forms.

Generally, when a person’s mind cannot remain single-minded, firm, and secretive, they are easily swayed. Their actions often bring misfortune, their conduct mostly leads to harm and calamity, and their faults and transgressions accumulate in great number, beyond full recounting. I merely outline the great principles for you, Perfected One, revealing their beginnings, so that the wise and discerning who deeply examine my writings may carefully follow and investigate them, thereby surely understanding.

Does the Perfected One perhaps not comprehend? Yes, yes. Go forth—you have now greatly awakened. Hold fast to my writings as profound precepts, and those who practice them may avoid misfortune and harm for ten thousand generations. Truly... Thus, later generations who read my writings, from beginning to end, fully grasping their essential meaning and putting it into practice, will not fail even once.

Hold to this without ceasing, and it will naturally be fulfilled. With a single-minded, kind intent, one may interact and unite with spirits. With a perverse, evil intent, the Dao is surely lost. If the great do not listen carefully, they may lose their rightful position; if the petty do not listen carefully, they may join with perversity. These all become harms to one’s person—one cannot but greatly guard and be cautious against them.

In all matters, when people commit transgressions, they bring them upon themselves. Calamities and changes arise close at hand from within the heart and mind, not from elsewhere. Does the Perfected One understand? Yes, yes.

How astonishing! How astonishing! If you know fear and awe, then you may be said to have truly entered the Dao. The foolish have now greatly awakened—let the worthy take this as their practice. In accomplishing affairs, one may long enter the gate of fortune and avoid the door of misfortune. The paths of life and death may be clearly seen for a long time. Follow this in practice, and misfortune will daily recede while fortune draws near. Yet you have already understood this—why should I repeatedly caution you further? Indeed, indeed.

Go forth and practice the Dao for your sake. Those who study and attain high office must be resolute in their intent. In all people’s learning: today they enter the gate of study, apply their minds with single-minded focus, constantly seeking protection and benefit, loving without false speech. From youth to old age, they study until they can learn no more, yet take no joy in attaining office. They simply delight in learning, striving to master the classics and the Dao, accumulating goodness without cease. Their conduct and reputation are established, and the classics and Dao are fulfilled. They deeply understand the origins of ancient and modern calamities and changes. Their conduct and learning benefit those above and aid those below. Their accumulated goodness cannot be concealed, and their fame spreads far and wide. Enlightened rulers favor them, summoning and appointing them, while the common people all say, “Excellent!” and “Most auspicious!” This is such a person—others speak of their joy on their behalf.

Such a one is a good person, one who studies to transcend the world. Do you, Perfected One, understand? Indeed, indeed.

The One Hundred Fifty-Seventh Admonition on the Failures and Successes in the Dao

The Master continued his discourse to the disciple, saying: Those who do not transcend the world harbor intentions that, upon entering the gate of learning today, take no joy in contemplating and attaining the true Dao and its virtuous teachings. Instead, they seek only broad knowledge and extensive observation, believing these can exhaust the sagely Way. They take no joy in promoting and practicing goodness, but rather delight in the superficial and ostentatious, which can be used to deceive and falsify.

Some, having already entered the study of the classics and the Dao, yet apply their minds without singular focus, constantly desiring to speak falsely, to excel in clever speech, and to make harming others their vocation. They neither respect their superiors nor benefit and cherish their subordinates. Their conduct and the classics and Dao are truly empty and hollow. They are unfit to be worthy ministers to emperors and kings, and instead become mere keepers of the status quo.

Others use wealth and goods to aid themselves, desiring high office to establish their reputation. Thereby, they steal and seize wealth and profit, turning public resources to private gain, betraying those above and exploiting those below. These are the ones who disrupt and corrupt proper governance, the scourge of Heaven and Earth, the thieves of the state. They are tigers and wolves among the people, wicked children to their parents. Heaven and Earth detest them, and the spirits loathe them. Thus, when their crimes are exposed, they are often punished by emperors and kings to align with the will of Heaven and to relieve the people of great harm. These are the ones who obtain office through deceit.

Some, their minds unfocused and truly empty without genuine commitment, instead constantly contemplate desiring office. Office is the celestial office of the constellations, bestowed upon those of virtue and rewarding those of merit. It is not recklessly given to those without merit. Those without merit are disregarded by Heaven and Earth and unloved by the divine spirits. The foolish below, unable to deeply recognize their own faults, recklessly and ceaselessly desire celestial office. Thereupon, demonic forces collectively descend upon their minds, causing them to speak falsely and utter inauspicious words, unable to restrain themselves. Thus, there are those who die from perverse speech—this is what it means. Not only in the pursuit of the Dao, but in all things, failing to grasp its essence brings misfortune.

In all human conduct, one should not delight in goodness to avoid all misfortune. Perfected One, exert yourself. You are fortunate to have a virtuous intent, always desiring to cherish and benefit as your endeavor—you have transcended. Nevertheless, for both the Perfected and the common, whether one transcends or not does not lie in the beginning but in the end. All failures stem from not cherishing oneself, from taking oneself lightly, from claiming to have transcended, yet harboring faults within and thus failing to transcend.

Therefore, if I now speak without ceasing, it is because the Perfected One compels me to continue. If I were to halt my discourse midway, taking myself lightly and remaining silent, I would fear incurring the Perfected One’s resentment. If the Perfected One resents me, he would look up to Heaven, and Heaven would in turn bring harm upon me. Thus, I dare not speak lightly, taking my studies lightly and ceasing midway. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Thus, the harm that befalls the common is like this. It often arises from not comprehending, from not aligning with the fundamental. Therefore, one loses the Way. Since you have rendered great service to Heaven, exert yourself, exert yourself. Indeed, indeed. I dare not take my studies and the Dao lightly.

Go forth. You have already understood the art of self-transcendence; I have nothing more to add. The Master continued to expound to the Perfected One in detail:

There are those who delight in managing their households and accumulating wealth, attaining riches and honor. In their youth, they are capable of labor and, as they grow, contemplate their affairs, exerting their strength to the utmost before ceasing. They are able to extol goodness and conceal faults, always delighting in doing good, constantly and reverently contemplating respect for their superiors. In all matters of doubt, they are cautious and vigilant, daring not act recklessly. They cherish their subordinates and desire not to harm others, do not pervert the king’s law, and take no joy in following perverse rituals or indulging in feasting and drinking.
