In all non-urgent matters, they dare not partake. Those who knowingly conduct themselves thus continue until old age without ceasing. Though they may appear empty in substance, their words are not frivolous. Thus, they are able to amass treasures and accumulate wealth, thereby becoming accomplished individuals.

People, whether worthy or unworthy, differ in their intentions. There are those who are not good, who disrespect their superiors and harm their subordinates, delight in following perverse rituals, and frequently engage in non-urgent and improper conduct. They are glib in speech, unable to restrain themselves in the marketplace, and are indeed people of misfortune, disorder, peril, and ruin—these are not followers of the Dao. Do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Thus, those who follow the Dao must concentrate their minds, seal their mouths, and refrain from reckless speech.

Therefore, the sages and worthies of antiquity observed the luminous patterns of Heaven and so were able to practice the Dao and uphold virtue. Heaven is singularly devoted: day and night it follows the Dao without speech, and thus it alone attains auspiciousness. Earth, too, day and night follows the Dao without speech, nurturing the myriad things, and thus it alone endures in tranquility. The four seasons alone follow the Dao, ceaselessly moving day and night, and thus they alone perpetually flourish and reign without end. The Three Luminaries alone follow the true Dao without speech, and thus they remain eternally bright, revolving in accord with Heaven. The Five Phases alone follow the true Dao without speech, and thus they endure as constants with Heaven and Earth. All under Heaven who practice the Dao emulate these examples without exception.

Thus, those who cherish and benefit others, whose mouths do not speak recklessly, may attain the Dao. Those who treat matters with frivolity and disregard, who contradict these words, will invariably be harmed by the Dao—there is not a single exception. Since you, Perfected One, have come from afar to seek answers to your doubts, I offer this admonition to you. Ponder and reflect upon this text; I do not fail you. I speak on behalf of Heaven to admonish the people of the virtuous and noble ruler. Heaven bestows upon the virtuous ruler, who must surely favor the Dao, and the common people will emulate their ruler, all taking this text as their great precept. Thus, they may attain good fortune and distance themselves from misfortune.

This scripture is issued to admonish the ignorant; guard it well and do not conceal it.
Indeed, indeed.
Proceed.

This discourse on admonition may seem small yet yields greatness, appear shallow yet proves profound. What does this mean? Though its words may seem minor, its admonitions are truly vast. Though its language may resemble the arguments of common sophists—seeming too slight to transmit—its guidance for cultivating others is indeed profound.

Thus, when I compose the Dao for the Perfected One, in its vastness it penetrates to the boundless, and in its subtlety it permeates without enclosure. In exaltation, it reaches the utmost heights; in humility, it extends to the lowest depths. Therefore, it encompasses the divine and the enslaved alike. The reason for this is to ensure that whether the great or the small, the worthy or the common, all may find its words sufficient. Why is this so?

Would that I might hear your intent.
Excellent is your inquiry; you have grasped its meaning. Thus, I compose this scripture for the ruler of Great Peace. When the ruler of Great Peace governs, they must emulate Heaven as their model, not like the lord of a small state, who rules only within a single domain.

Therefore, Heaven’s emulation as a model is exalted without superior, humble without inferior, vast without exterior, and minute without interior. It embraces and nurtures the twelve thousand things, whether good or evil, great or small, all are benefited and protected. It endows them with primordial qi to bring them to life and does not harm or injure them in the end. Thus, it is most fittingly called the divine, the supreme ruler without peer.

Now, as the qi of the Highest August arrives and the virtuous ruler governs, they must emulate this as their model. Thus, my Dao ascends and descends, sinks and rises, so that the multitude of worthies may together examine it. Therefore, in the southeast lies the Earth’s Gate, where waters sustain Heaven’s pillar, not resisting even the smallest flow. Whether good or evil, great or small, all return to it.

Do you, Perfected One, understand?
Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, for I would expound further on the boundless discourse, weaving its grand patterns—yet for now, pause and rest, each returning to ponder these matters within your hearts. To practice the Dao without grasping its intent is like pointing south while asking about the north. With such a misdirected mind, even after ages of study, nothing will be attained. You dare not proceed further—you have already understood.

*(Right: A collection of questions on the Dao’s precepts, the governance of life, and the origins of success and failure, fortune and misfortune.)*

**Verifying the Texts: The Formula for Longevity, One Hundred Fifty-Eighth**

I wish to ask about one doubtful matter.
Speak.
Now, while the Heavenly Master is still here, I wish to inquire about the formulas within the texts: Is there a way for a person to live truly long, to work alongside others without ever growing weary? May I hear of this?
Indeed, do you seek to examine all texts to discern where the worthy reside?
Yes.
Be seated, and I shall explain it to you, Perfected One.

To amass texts by the hundreds of millions yet fail to attain longevity—what benefit is there to one’s life? To fill a chamber with writings yet fail to govern with order—what benefit is there to governance? To fill the court with ministers yet fail to bring the ruler great peace and joy—what benefit is there to the emperor? To father a hundred children yet leave one’s parents to hunger and cold—what benefit is there to one’s kin? To pile remedies as heavy as a cartload yet fail to extend life—what benefit is there to human destiny? To endlessly expound on matters yet fail to rid the ruler of disasters—what benefit is there to the court?

Such examples are countless, beyond enumeration. I merely raise the essentials for you, Perfected One, that all worthies may reflect deeply upon them.
I wish to see their effects.
Do you truly wish to know?
Yes, Heavenly Master.
Very well. Sit calmly and focus, and I shall explain it to you.

Among hundreds of millions of texts, only those that can lengthen life, enrich destiny, and secure the body are true texts—the rest are not. Among chambers filled with writings, only those that align with Heaven’s will and bring order to governance are true texts—the rest are not. Among ministers filling the court, only those who bring joy to their ruler and assist in achieving great peace are the true ministers and worthy officials of the emperor—the rest are mere functionaries. Among children born to a person, only those who ensure their parents’ constant joy and freedom from hunger and cold are filial and virtuous—the rest are but numbers fulfilled. Among remedies piled as heavy as a cartload, only those that extend years are true remedies—the rest are not.

Such comparisons in the world are too numerous to list in advance. Perfected One, ponder their meaning deeply. My words use one to infer ten thousand, sufficient to illuminate the Dao of all under Heaven. Thus, I instruct you to transmit the Dao to the ruler of Earth’s virtue, to gather and examine all common texts and the words of scholars, clarifying them for all worthies so that together they may awaken from delusion and confusion.

Once all common texts have been examined, disasters will depart by the day. For false texts and deceitful words are the masters of calamity and treachery. True texts and upright words are the officials that expel evil and wickedness. When texts are rectified and words are rectified, treachery has no master and thus nowhere to abide.

False texts and deceitful words as masters of treachery are like thieves and bandits with a host to shelter them. Once the host perishes, the thieves and bandits have no way to return and rest. Perfected One, do you also understand this?
Indeed, indeed.

Go now—the Dao of Heaven’s method is to take the One to illuminate the myriad, yet it cannot be fully inscribed. Perfected One, having received this, you must deeply ponder its essential meaning. The wise and enlightened, whose hearts possess nine apertures, readily comprehend; upon seeing the text, they awaken of themselves. No further questions are needed.

*Textual pause.*

Indeed, indeed.

Excessive texts bewilder the mind; it is better to raise a single guiding principle, so that the ten thousand strands arrange themselves and unfold. Thus, the teeming masses, though numerous, are not equal to one emperor. The countless stars, though innumerable, are not equal to the brightness of a single sun. The clamorous words of crawling creatures filling the heavens are not equal to one worthy minister in a kingdom. The Dao of Heaven is vast and boundless, without end—yet it is not equal to the single primordial qi that holds the mandate’s guiding thread with Heaven.

The ruler of supreme virtue, if wise, deeply reflects on my words, and longevity will naturally extend. If later generations together ponder my words, fathers will be kind and sons filial, their virtue daily expanding and brightening. Mothers will be loving and wives obedient, and the entire realm will rise at dawn as one, all worthy and good. Great and small will vie in goodness, and the latter will have no strength to resist. No longer will there be false texts, nor will flatterers find refuge in them. Disasters and omens will be wholly dispelled, and the two luminaries will shine clearly. This is the art of spontaneity, uniformly practiced by the celestial spirits.

Is this how the Dao is enacted? What sorrow could remain in such great joy? To take this as the method is to follow Heaven’s course. Who records it? It is the numinous work of Heaven and Earth. The texts of verification resonate in harmony with Heaven and Earth—this is the tally of Heaven’s trust.

Rulers and worthies should together examine these words. Those who practice them will daily prosper, aligning with the times as if by appointment. They will attain what Heaven and Earth desire—how auspicious! When yin and yang flow in accord, wind and rain come in season, and the ten thousand changes vanish. By the verifying texts, I do not praise myself. Truly, I know this—not merely embellished speech. You should swiftly put it into effect.

Perfected One, do you understand?
Indeed, indeed.

Go forth, go forth. Refine it in detail, and the Dao will come of itself.
Indeed, indeed.

*Textual division:*
**Method of Male and Female Reversal of Form, One Hundred Fifty-Ninth**

I wish to ask once more about a doubtful matter.
Speak.
In the texts Your Celestial Master previously bestowed upon this foolish student, there is mention of "male and female reversal of form." I wish to hear its meaning.
Ah! The text has already briefly explained what can be seen—why do you ask again?
My dull heart is closed and slow to open; I can only inquire of Your Celestial Master for the decisive teaching.
Very well. Be seated, and I shall now explain it to you.

The nature of Heaven and Earth is such that yang loves yin, and yin loves yang. Thus, yang ought to transform into yin, and yin ought to transform into yang. All principles of yin and yang are like this. They mutually love one another, so their refinement and cultivation progress swiftly. However, one must □□ with graded instructions—it cannot be directly taught to others. Otherwise, one falls into heterodoxy.

Now listen carefully: the yang transforms its form to become the yin form, and the yin transforms its form to become the yang form. It is precisely through one’s own body that one embodies the other’s appearance. It cannot be directly attained, or one will fall into heterodoxy.
Indeed, indeed.

If you still doubt after understanding, then—
Ah! Why is this so difficult for you to grasp? Simply use your own body to assume the other’s form. The yang becomes like the body of a yin person, and the yin becomes like the body of a yang person.
Indeed, indeed.

You have now understood. Go forth, and the matter will become clear.
Indeed, indeed.

*Here ends the collection of difficult-to-comprehend texts, the essential methods distinguishing the worthy from the unworthy, and the true principles of yin-yang reversal of form for governing the Dao.*

**Method of Embracing Heaven and Enveloping Earth, Guarding Qi Without Ceasing, One Hundred Sixtieth**

I wish to ask Your Celestial Master one more matter and then cease.
Speak—what doubt remains?
The Dao embraces Heaven and envelops Earth—who sustains its qi and observes its signs?
Profound, far-reaching, and wondrous is your question!
Why do you ask this after seeing what you have seen?
I have seen and witnessed the Way of Heaven and Earth, yet I do not understand its ultimate limit, so I ask in wonder.
Excellent! Your words penetrate subtle meaning.
The reason the Way of Heaven and Earth endures long and forever is that it guards qi without ceasing. Thus, Heaven relies solely on qi for fortune and misfortune; all things perish without qi. If you do not wish to meet your end, you should unite with qi as the Mysterious Female, emulate Heaven’s work—how then could you die?

Yet this cannot be swiftly attained; it requires entering the secluded chamber. Within the chamber, contemplate the Dao, naturally abstain from food, and join with qi. Thus, you become one with the spirits of Heaven and Earth, no longer bound by worldly governance. You ascend to follow the Great One of Heaven, pay homage at the Central Ultimate, receive the talisman, and traverse the six directions and eight distant realms without end. Reflect on the words of this text, and you will attain it—the steps to becoming a spirit will be visible.

Departing the world to ascend to Heaven and govern, you will no longer be seen. If you wish to further witness its clear effects: in this world, one cannot long possess and govern alone. Thus, those who attain the Dao fly upward to Heaven—this is their departure from the world. Those who refuse to diligently cultivate the Dao descend into the earth at death, unable to long dwell in the middle realm. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, sages have departed to seclude themselves; their sacred texts remain as constant models, yet their persons are unseen—this is the clear proof.

Those who do not die and attain the Dao ascend to Heaven; those who die descend into the earth, unable to long remain on the harmonious path of the middle. If you grasp my text, ponder its meaning deeply. If you delight in ascending and wish to live forever, joining your strength with Heaven, partaking in the seasonal sacrifices and feasts of the world—strive to practice the true Dao, for this is its purifying method. If you do not delight in eternal life but delight in death, abandon the Dao and follow the vulgar, and you too will return to the earth below, no longer able to gaze upon the sun, moon, stars, and celestial cycles.

My text is □□—ten thousand times ten thousand, not a single word is amiss. Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity have all departed, and none remain visible—this is the great proof. Reflect for yourself: if you delight in ascending, you will ascend; if you delight in descending, you will descend. None can wrest your will from you.

Thus, I, the Virtuous Lord of Great Peace, have established this method without resentment toward any single person. When the qi of Great Peace arrives, if even one person harbors grievance and does not attain their desire, then the balanced qi of the Supreme August cannot fully descend. Therefore, Heaven has commanded me to broadly open the path, allowing each to freely choose what they may do.

Those of wisdom and clarity who delight in life may study my text, contemplate its meaning, enter the chamber to accomplish the Dao, and attain life. Those of gentle virtue who delight in assisting emperors and kings in governance may model their actions on my text to bring about Great Peace. Those who delight in managing households, nurturing life, and accumulating wealth may ponder my text and live out their Heaven-appointed years before dying. Thus, each attains their heart’s desire, and none harbors great grievance.

Therefore, the qi of Great Peace comes forth. The term "peace" means level and without grievance—hence, it is called "peace." Thus, when the Virtuous Lord governs, the qi of Great Peace arises. The reason is that the world harbors no grievances; each attains what they delight in. This is why I have charged the Perfected Ones to entrust it to the lord of supreme virtue.

The lord of supreme virtue must be benevolent, worthy, and enlightened. The enlightened do not wrest away what others desire but must win the hearts of all under Heaven, wishing to align with Heaven’s will and return to the Dao.
Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

**Chapter 161: The Key to Appointing Officials and Their Gains and Losses**

Proceed with utmost caution, Perfected One, in even a single word, that your governance may resemble the movement of Heaven. The Way of Heaven does not wrest away what others desire to do. The Way of Earth likewise does not wrest away what others desire to do. The enlightened lord delights in emulating Heaven and Earth, never wresting away what others do. Thus, in resembling Heaven and Earth, he alone endures and is called Heaven and Earth, winning their hearts.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
Indeed, indeed.

When Heaven turns malign and the year portends great calamity, it is ever because it harms what people strive to do. Thus, the people reap nothing, and the year brings famine and cold. When Earth turns malign, it injures what nourishes people; roots weaken and sicken, harvests fail, and the people suffer hardship and poverty.

A declining, wicked lord courts disaster when he appoints officials without regard for their fitness for office. This is called deliberately disrupting Heaven’s bureaucracy, violating Heaven’s prohibitions, and forsaking Heaven’s norms. He reverses course to impose blame and punishment, never considering whether one’s strength is insufficient or human capacity falls short. It is like suddenly commanding a lord to walk a hundred *li*—one fears he cannot reach the end and halts midway. What humans cannot achieve is precisely this.

Thus, to appoint men without selection and recklessly assign them office is to be called one who distresses the people and endangers the state—one who throws governance into chaos and invites ruin. Heaven and Earth are supremely numinous and luminous, yet even they dare not wrest away what others desire to do. To do so is to bring a year of great calamity—how much worse for mortal men?

Perfected One, have you awakened from confusion and gained clarity?
Indeed, indeed.

Should one truly follow each state’s customs to transmit the Master’s writings, adapting teachings to local ways and clarifying their meaning, then you, disciple, may be called one who understands the workings of life—Heaven does not thwart human aspirations. By walking the upright path, you naturally align with Heaven’s mandate, and your years and days will only increase without end.

You study not for worldly honor or glory—why then seek to grasp Heaven’s intent and prolong your years? Now that I have told you this, can you still say no? Indeed, receiving such great favor brings boundless joy, leaving no room for regret. Yet I fear that in striving to the utmost and disseminating the Master’s texts, you may not achieve universal transmission in a single day. Why must it be done in a day? Persist without ceasing, and like a boat carried by the current, you will not long remain distant.

Very well.
Having received your solemn charge, I dare not stray even from the guiding line.
Now that you grasp its meaning, I need not admonish you further.

Go—this minor discourse concludes, and the matter is complete. Should you have doubts another day, return again.
Very well.

**Right [Section]: A Grand Compilation of Difficult Questions on Heaven and Earth’s Qi and Seasons—Whether They Constitute the Dao, and the Auspicious or Inauspicious Effects of a Ruler’s Appointment of Officials**

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the Ninety-Eighth, Concludes*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the Ninety-Ninth*

**Riding Clouds and Mounting Dragons Diagram, the One Hundred Sixty-Second**
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the Ninety-Ninth, Concludes*
*Scroll the One Hundredth*
*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the One Hundredth*

**Eastern Wall Diagram, the One Hundred Sixty-Third**
*Inscribed on the Eastern Wall—A Diagram of the Ancient Divine Person’s Admonitions to Disciples and Later Learners on Cultivating Goodness*

Acts of hidden virtue bring constant blessings to others, and their merit multiplies. Acts of overt virtue prompt others to respond in kind, yet their effects dissipate. Hidden virtue, however, is known to Heaven, Earth, and all spirits—thus its merit multiplies.

Those who accumulate virtue are cherished by the wealthy, and their goodness comes to them day by day. What men praise, the spirits and gods also praise, and so they protect and aid them. Those who embrace the Dao attain long life, for they share the concerns of yin and yang, follow the movements of the August Spirit, and align with the nature of Heaven and Earth. Grasping its principles, they gain Heaven’s protection; losing them, they fall into chaos, and Heaven does not protect them.

To seek goodness through goodness—nothing in this is strange. To attain it through benevolence is the beginning of the Dao. To attain it through virtue is the harmony of the Dao. To attain it through the Dao itself is the highest Dao.

Alas! Be cautious, be ever cautious—act without recklessness. Ponder deeply this text and transmit it to later generations, that no harm may come. To move in accord with the four seasons is the highest Dao.

Goodness arises of itself; evil brings illness upon itself. Matters of fortune and misfortune all emerge from within, calling forth their kind—thus one does not lose oneself. The Dao of Heaven is impartial; outcomes arise from one’s own conduct.

Thus, those who came before as disciples leave behind a legacy of good qi, and those who pursue learning without cease fulfill their destiny, attaining yang’s fruition. Some gain long life and an unblemished body—this is the result of goodness. The inner and outer spirits then turn to remove their harm. The disciple stands before them, and the master faces them in response.

All things have their natural course; the affairs of the world each follow their kind.

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the One Hundredth, Concludes*
*Scroll the One Hundred First*

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the One Hundred First*
*Western Wall Diagram the One Hundred Sixty-Fourth*
*Admonition of the Ancient Divine Persons and Perfected Ones to Later Scholars on the Portents of Evil*

The ancient divine persons and perfected ones warned later scholars through diagrams of the consequences of evil. Those who act as yin’s thieves, disdaining harmonious affairs and instead delighting in harm and jealousy, bring upon others death and misfortune.

The Dao of Heaven cannot be forcibly seized; those who seize it will meet death by arms and the loss of power, extinguishing the world and the Way. Sacred texts will be destroyed, and what was sought as gain will turn to harm—this is the resonance of Heaven and Earth’s nature. It leads to the juncture of the spontaneous, where those who carefully delight in it endure, while those who are reckless perish. Be cautious, be ever cautious.

Do no harm, nor seek it; goodness arises of itself, and evil collapses of itself. Contemplate these two portents and ponder their benefits and harms.

All matters under Heaven follow their kind; even in the space of a hair’s breadth, there is no deviation. Yet people fail to refine themselves, remaining ignorant of their own nature. Once the name of guilt is affixed, nothing can be done. Those who do not preserve their root will die with lingering transgressions, for evil arises within, and perverse qi summons its like from without.

Thus, before them lies the harm of imprisonment, and behind them, malevolent spirits—all hastening to contend, unable to cease, leading to the destruction of the self. Therefore, these diagrams are drawn to admonish later worthies, serving as a great warning.

The foolish do not believe in the Dao, treating matters with indifference. Yet the texts are precise in their words, not erring by even a fraction. Thus, those who embrace softness attain long life, while those who delight in strife bring about their own ruin.

Matters follow their kind and cannot be reversed; though one may repent, it is of no avail, for the spirits have already attached themselves. Heed the warning and awaken, returning in due time. Now, while no harm has yet come, one may still become a person of goodness.

The good ascend, while the evil descend. The Dao of Heaven is impartial, yet it operates spontaneously, never deviating from its law—its workings are like those of spirits.

*Inscribed on the Western Wall.*

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll the One Hundred First, Concludes*
*Scroll the One Hundred Second*

**The Divine Person’s Preface on the Illustrations of Robes and Colors, Scroll the One Hundred Sixty-Five**

In my youth, I studied without cease, my spirit ever fixed upon it, tears often welling up. Through long accumulation, by the great grace of August Heaven, I was fortunate to encounter the Heavenly Master in the wilderness. My early studies were deficient, and my inquiries trivial—mere superficial embellishments. I had originally sought the method of *guarding the One* and nurturing nature, comprising three hundred chapters, yet upon meeting the Heavenly Master, I found his discourse boundless. Thus, I dared to ask: *Can the body attain enduring existence?*

Not yet having heard the Heavenly Master’s boundless teachings, I ventured to inquire about minor governance. Only after hearing his discourse without limit did I dare to ask in full: *Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, how have emperors succeeded one another, bearing sorrow and hardship? Why do celestial disasters and strange omens never cease? How may they be eliminated? Furthermore, why do the host of spirits, without cause, harm humanity, preventing people from fulfilling their allotted years? How may this be halted?*

Now, having received the Heavenly Master’s stern instructions and profound warnings, when ought this book—meant to suppress deceit and revive the Dao of Heaven and Earth—be revealed? It shall emerge in the year *yisi*, entrusted to couriers for dissemination. Thereafter, in every year marked by *xuanjia*, it shall be brought forth, for this is the first of Heaven’s celestial stems, the supreme beginning of the cycle. It aligns with the primordial *qi* and shall be presented to the state, front and back, to resolve the successive calamities inherited since the inception of Heaven and Earth.

By what title shall it be conveyed? Its teachings are layered and profound, its characters known only to the deeply initiated. Do not allow the leakage of the harmonious *qi* of August Heaven or the foremost Dao. It shall be transmitted to those capable of receiving and expounding it. When the time of *xuanjia* arrives, should one appear eager for this book, present it first to those who *guard the One* amid superficiality. Having entrusted it to couriers and *fangshi*, it shall be delivered to a ruler of utmost virtue.

What does this mean? *One who obtains it and practices it is the rightful recipient; one who does not practice it is not.* The Perfected One must not release it prematurely. For Heaven’s wrath is fierce—it slays in retribution. My warnings are fully set forth herein. Thus, I speak cautiously, truly fearing Heaven’s judgment.

Now, the Heavenly Master instructs his foolish disciple, whose heart is heavy with reverence, as if already foreseeing the consequences. I dare not betray this trust. I earnestly ask: *How ought the illustrations of divine robes be depicted?* They must all emulate Heaven’s law, not follow worldly custom. Those who do not comprehend Heaven’s law depict figures arbitrarily, clothing them as they fancy. Robes, however, follow the colors of the Five Phases.

Now, let the mother envelop the child within, arranging colors in sequence. The most layered robes have five; the moderately layered, four; the lesser layered, three; the subtly layered, two—symbolizing the union of *yin* and *yang*. The grand assemblage robe has six layers of chaotic hues.

*What does the five-layered robe represent?*
It symbolizes the harmonious convergence of the *qi* of the Five Phases.

*What does the four-layered robe represent?*
It symbolizes the cyclic generation of the four seasons.

*What does the three-layered robe represent?*
It symbolizes father, mother, and child—the harmonious union of *yin* and *yang*.

*What does the two-layered robe represent?*
It symbolizes the mutual support of the sovereign and ministering *qi*.

*What does the six-layered robe represent?*
It symbolizes the intermingled colors of the six directions.

Thus, the world possesses variegated hues—this is what it signifies.

Excellent! Excellent! Go forth, and guard the secret illustrations with care.

"Yes, yes.

Now, though your disciple is most foolish and lowly, by grace I have long been permitted to study the texts of the Heavenly Master. In all matters, my understanding has been swift and complete. Yet I still wish to ask one further question.

Speak plainly.

What is it?

I have observed that since the opening of Heaven and Earth, texts and scriptures have emerged not once but many times, accumulating in great number. Moreover, many have come forth from the Yellow River and Luo River. Why, then, does this present text not require their emergence?

Excellent! Excellent! Your question is apt, for Heaven has moved you to speak—you have grasped its intent.

Today, Heaven has fully charged me to reveal to emperors, kings, and the people the full account of *chengfu* (inherited responsibility and retribution). The accumulated texts are too numerous to be brought forth solely through the River and Luo writings. The River and Luo texts are vast in their revelations, and their divination slips too numerous to be fully known through divination alone. Thus, Heaven acts through people to bring them forth.

Heaven knows me deeply and has entrusted me with this message. Knowing the difficulty of such questions, it has instead sent you to transmit its essential words with me. You, too, must understand: if one studies without attaining the heart of the Dao, what purpose does a Perfected Person serve?

Now, I am dull and benighted, unaware of myself.

[The preceding question concludes the section on the secret illustrations of robes and texts.]

**Rank and Transmission of Texts; The Sealed and Obstructed Bring Illness—Decisions 166**

You have come from Heaven to seek answers, and I am Heaven’s instrument to instruct you.

I wish to understand the meaning of this decision. By what is it made clear?

How is it further clarified?

When a virtuous ruler obtains my texts, comprehends them in his heart, and practices them, consulting with worthy ministers to transform the common people, he will surely resonate with Heaven’s response—this is its clear proof. My Dao is perfected through admonition, not through false words or self-serving teachings.

Yes, yes.

Your disciple is unworthy and has often troubled the Heavenly Master in vain.

If you do not ask, there is no way to know. I have long held this learning, yet there has been no one with whom to speak, so I have not transmitted it in due time. Now, if people cannot distinguish black from white, the fault lies with me.

Today, I am truly overjoyed to transmit this to you, a Perfected One. It is like ascending a tower in spring and emerging to behold the boundless sky—what could compare?

Heaven’s grievances have accumulated, and illnesses and transformations never cease. This pent-up stagnation, now released through speech with you, brings joy. Why does the Heavenly Master not go forth himself to establish the ranks?

My office is in Heaven, while yours, Perfected One, is on Earth. Earth gives birth to the myriad things, and thus Heaven nurtures what it generates upon the Earth. Therefore, I transmit the Dao to you. Earth gives rise to rulers, common people, and the twelve thousand things, all receiving the bestowal of *yang* and emerging from *yin*—thus, you transmit it to humanity.

Excellent! Excellent! This foolish one marvels greatly.

Had I not earnestly questioned the Heavenly Master, there would have been no way to know. I merely guessed and dared to ask presumptuously.

Well done! You are one who understands matters—this is not your effort alone. Truly, Heaven has bestowed its intent upon your heart to speak.

Now, though you were once benighted and unaware of your own conduct, you have come to great self-knowledge, illuminated like the light of the sun and moon. If you doubt my words, consider this: though Heaven may wish to reveal something, it does not speak directly to people, making its will difficult to discern. My texts follow Heaven’s commands, clarifying the cinnabar and azure.

If you were to conceal or suppress my writings, refusing to bring them forth in due time, Heaven would afflict you with illness and misfortune. If you continue to obstruct them, you will meet with calamity. This is Heaven’s way of sending you to seek answers—its clear proof that the Perfected One must bring them forth as a testament of faith.

Excellent! Excellent! Perfected One, take heed and guard this warning.

Yes, yes.

The Heavenly Master’s duty is to cover all under Heaven, and I cannot refuse.

I wish to ask one more question.

Do you dare not speak?

Go ahead. Are all matters under Heaven carried out by Heaven’s envoys?

Is it only the Heavenly Master and this foolish disciple?

Ah! You grow ever more foolish. Do you not know that all things under Heaven serve as Heaven’s envoys, each with its own office, together completing the Dao? If even one thing were lacking, the Dao of Heaven would be incomplete. How could you not understand this? How profound is this obscurity!

This ignorant one has not yet fully grasped it. With the Heavenly Master’s explanation, it becomes clear.

Go, you have been sufficiently instructed.

Go, and strive with all your might. Every person has their office and serves as Heaven’s instrument—how could one dare to act alone by natural inclination?

I dare not, I dare not.

Go now."

The One Hundred Sixty-Seventh Scripture on the Essential Formulas of the Canonical Texts

At the origin of Heaven’s numbers, when Heaven and Earth were yet undivided, the accumulated qi coalesced as one. Then it divided into two, forming husband and wife.

Heaven bestowed upon Earth, conceiving in the Dark Obscurity, and it was named *jiazi*. Its roots spread to the northeast—*chou* and *yin*. First appearing at *mao*, it fully grew in the southeast—*chen* and *si*. Its branches hung in the south, nurtured at *wu*, aging in the southwest—*wei* and *shen*. It matured in the west, the sun setting at *you*, and was wholly concealed in the northwest—*xu* and *hai*.

Thus the numbering begins at one and ends at ten. Ten is the beginning of the Ten Celestial Stems and the root of the Five Phases. Multiplying one by ten yields one hundred, and thus it is complete.

Heaven generates within a hundred days, and thus all things reach their end. Therefore, the Dipper is established at *chen* and broken at *xu*. "Established" means to stand—thus all things strive to reach full growth. "Broken" means to decay—all things wholly perish at *xu*. The numbers follow the eight directions of Heaven and Earth, and with ten, the yin-yang establishment and breaking are complete. By this, they cycle back and forth to their origin, following the Dipper’s pointer to illuminate affairs.

This scripture is written to dispel harmful qi, modeling itself upon Heaven as its standard.

Above is the written inquiry to the Heavenly Master, verifying the luminous essential formulas.

*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll One Hundred Two—end
*Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll One Hundred Three—[beginning]

**The Chart of Emptiness, Non-Action, and Spontaneity—Admonitions Fully Realized, One Hundred Sixty-Eight**

**On Emptiness**
Emptiness is inwardly replete yet outwardly void—being as though non-being. Reverse the womb and embryo to dwell with the Dao. Preserve the heart alone, suspending the dragon’s thoughts. Thus becomes the chamber of spirit, gathering the Dao in emptiness. Roam only with qi, hence "emptiness." In qi and spirit, all else is cast away. With the heart as master, one attains freedom from deviation. Examine its meaning closely; do not forget the true scripture. Attain this, and you cross over—able to wander long. Why not hasten to refinement, only to dwell among fools? Once misfortune arrives, great disaster befalls. Forsake true simplicity, and you return to dust and ash. The wise, upon seeing this text, take heed and hold it true.

**On Non-Action**
Non-action is action without contrivance. It connects with the Dao, emerging before infancy, entering the seamless. Reaching the Great Beginning, it returns again. At the inception of Heaven and Earth, the source of yin and yang—enter the art of non-action, and the body may be preserved whole. To abandon root for branch is the Dao’s affliction. Depart from the Great Beginning, and preservation becomes difficult. Drift far from life, and you approach death’s gate. Indulging in worldly affairs harms the hun and shen. Clinging to duality while forgetting unity severs their mutual resonance. Can one not take warning? This is the origin of the Dao. You, who guard the One—this is the wellspring of benevolence and wisdom. The Dao of Heaven acts through the One, thus remains complete. The Dao of Earth acts through the Two, and draws near to ghosts and spirits. Truly know non-action, and you align with the Dao’s most numinous aspect. Reflect deeply upon this, and the Perfected Ones take precedence. Seal your golden gate; let nothing depart its threshold. Silent and soundless, spirit is prolonged. When spirit and qi are complete, the gate of immortality opens. How effortless is the Great Dao—no longer troubled! The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality, yet turns toward the benevolent and wise.

**On Spontaneity**
The law of spontaneity connects with the Dao. Hold to it, and fortune follows; lose it, and calamity arises. Consider how the myriad things arise whole—one root, ten thousand branches, yet none possess spirit. Ponder its meaning, and the Dao reveals itself. All trace back to the primordial chaos, emerging from the wondrous gate. Neither increase nor diminish—guard spontaneity. All living things possess spirit, but of the eighteen hundred breaths, man is supreme. Thus may one avoid death and attain long-lasting transcendence. Those who perish early lose spontaneity—even beasts endure, how much more so man? Fools despise the Dao, sinking low to join the earth. The benevolent and wise esteem the Dao, ascending swiftly to Heaven’s gate. The spirit-way does not die; the ghost-way meets its end. Should you desire this, it is like a ring without end. Beware of deviance—it brings harm to the self. Neither abandon it recklessly, lest it cause death. The nature of Heaven and Earth uniquely honors spontaneity. Each follows its course; none dare oppose it. The Dao flourishes through non-action, emptiness, and spontaneity. Superior persons delight in it; inferior persons resent it. Study diligently under a master; do not speak idly. With a master, the Dao is clear; without one, transmission is difficult. Learning without a master’s instruction, the noble person remains silent. Acting recklessly brings chaos; inscribing the body invites misfortune. When the Dao is fully realized, spontaneity is achieved.

**Admonitions on the Dao Fully Realized**

**Nineteen Essential Formulas: One Hundred Seventy-Three**

For those who practice the Dao, obtain the formula by marking it inside or outside the chamber. When the full number of days is reached, open the door and enter to inspect it. If the mark was made within, do not enter to view it. If the mark was not made within, then those who delight in it may enter to view it. When opening the door to enter, those who wish to leave may do so freely.

For the three Daoist scriptures in circulation, obtain the formula through collective deliberation, treating it as Heaven’s trust, and thereby establishing it for those above. For the true spirits and numina, obtain the formula through the unanimous clarity of ten thousand people, treating it as Heaven’s trust. For any text requiring correction, obtain the formula through verification and collation, treating it as Heaven’s trust.

For those who wish to know the trustworthiness of our Daoist texts, obtain the formula by swiftly enacting them, for they resonate with Heaven’s response. The good shall daily increase, and the evil shall daily diminish—this is Heaven’s trust. For those who wish to appoint and employ good persons, obtain the formula through nine individuals.

To inquire whether one has entered the chamber and succeeded or not, obtain the formula through complete clarity and understanding—form without concealment or obstruction is Heaven’s trust. To know whether one has attained the Dao in the body and become deathless, obtain the formula through the body’s transformation into spirit, thereby transcending the world—this is Heaven’s trust.

For those who wish to thoroughly understand the meaning of our texts, read them from beginning to end, and all shall become self-evident. The heart shall be greatly enlightened, and doubt shall no longer remain. Once its meaning is grasped, it cannot be abandoned.

To test the authenticity of our texts, observe whether they bring about the governance of the world toward Great Peace—this is Heaven’s trust. To know whether longevity can be attained or not, obtain the formula from the era after Great Peace. If Great Peace has not yet arrived, the disasters of former generations shall harm the people, making it difficult to fulfill one’s destiny—this is Heaven’s trust.

For the sun to know Great Peace, obtain the formula from the severing of metal. For water and fire to suppress and eliminate treacherous ministers, if no formula is available, obtain it from the severing of metal, the decline of the market, and the offering of wine.

For those who wish to see the great flourishing of the Dao’s laws, obtain the formula through the verification and collation of all texts, and the oaths of ordinary people. For those who seek efficacious medicine, obtain the formula through the verification and collation of all medical texts, and test them.

For those who wish to swiftly attain Great Peace, obtain the formula by fully revealing the true texts and utterly eliminating the false and deceptive ones. For those who wish to cherish people and no longer kill or harm women, obtain the formula by allowing each to dwell in their place, providing for their clothing and food according to their ability, and preventing them from returning to the sorrow and suffering of their parents, thereby averting rebellion.

To eliminate illness and widely propagate the Dao, obtain the formula through the cinnabar script and the swallowing of characters. To know the formula for collecting and practicing the scriptures, follow their words and repeatedly exhort, strictly adhering to them. Practicing them for a single day shall dispel the harm of a hundred cunning hearts, and in one morning, all shall turn upright—this is Heaven’s trust.

**Discourse on Auspicious Omens: One Hundred Seventy-Four**

Someone asked: What is the meaning of the term "auspicious omen"?
Why do you feign ignorance?
I do not dare feign ignorance; I truly do not understand. I hope the Heavenly Master will not abandon me and will instruct me with a single word.
Proceed, sit calmly.
An auspicious omen is purity, tranquility, uprightness, correctness, focus, and unity. The heart aligns with Heaven and Earth, without violating the seasons’ commands.
May I ask how one knows it is pure, tranquil, upright, correct, focused, and unified?
Excellent is your question. The nature of Heaven and Earth, from ancient times to the present, ensures that the good attain goodness, the evil attain evil, the upright attain uprightness, and the perverse attain perversity. This is the spontaneous method—there is nothing strange about it. Thus, when a person’s heart is upright, pure, tranquil, and utterly sincere, it moves Heaven, harboring no evil intent, and auspicious omens and good things shall manifest for them.

Would you like further confirmation of this great trust? The great sages and worthies of antiquity all cultivated pure, tranquil, focused, and unified hearts, and thus were able to bring forth auspicious omens. Those who are treacherous and deceptive in their hearts shall receive no good responses. This is the great and luminous proof of Heaven and Earth.
Do you understand?
Yes, I do.
Are there also corresponding responses?
Indeed, the perverse attain perversity—this too is their response. The disharmonious attain disharmony, and the harmonious attain harmony. This is the clear and evident response of Heaven.
Excellent, excellent! Now this foolish student understands.

**Loyalty and Filial Piety: On Presenting Rare Knowledge, Secret One Hundred Seventy-Five**

May I ask: when one does good, how should the most filial sons, the most loyal ministers, and the most obedient disciples regard their lords, fathers, and teachers?

They should present rare treasures—precious and seldom-seen texts. This is what it means to offer the highest.

Loyal ministers, filial sons, and obedient disciples should always delight in such service. Why then do they not present common knowledge but instead offer rare knowledge?

Common knowledge is already possessed by their superiors. Why present it again?

This foolish student does not yet grasp the meaning.

Very well, let me make it clear for you.

Of all the treasures in the world, those most precious are the ones never before seen—presenting these to one’s lord is the act of a most loyal minister. Offering fine foods never before tasted to one’s parents is the act of a most filial son. Sharing teachings never before heard with one’s teacher is the act of a most obedient disciple.

Do you understand now?

Yes, yes.

Then why, when presenting something already possessed, do they offer it again in excess?

Because such repeated offerings are done out of obligation, and the fault remains unabsolved.

Why is this so grave?

You still do not grasp it. What people already possess in abundance, they grow weary of—why present it again? To offer what they already disdain is called "obligatory presentation." If one lowers oneself to such obligatory offerings, would you not consider it improper?

This foolish student now understands.

Thus, when one obtains auspicious omens and rare treasures—things seldom seen—they should be presented to one’s lord, father, or teacher. But what they already possess, take care never to present again.

From ancient times to the present, this has been the principle by which the great sages governed all affairs: discarding the common and selecting the rare, thereby aligning with the will of Heaven and Earth. This is the meaning of it.

Do you now comprehend?

Excellent, excellent!

**Scroll on Storing Away the Writings on Disasters and Illnesses, Secret Teachings, One Hundred Seventy-Six**

May I ask: Master of Heaven, how can one know when your writings should be put into practice, and how can one know when they should be concealed?

Do you wish to understand this?

Observe the signs of disasters and illnesses. When they emerge and afflict people, Heaven desires that the writings be stored away. When they retreat and afflict people, Heaven desires that the writings be brought forth and enacted.

How can this be further clarified?

By the movement of Heaven’s qi through the four seasons, which gives life and nurtures the myriad things, all follows Heaven’s will. If all things delight in emerging yet are forced into concealment, it is greatly inauspicious. If all things wish to retreat and hide yet are compelled to emerge, this too is greatly inauspicious. Both violate the mandate of Heaven, and great disasters will follow.

Do you wish to delight in knowing Heaven’s ways? Whether Heaven delights in action or stillness is determined by these omens.

Do you, Perfected One, understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Thus, from ancient times to the present, whenever affairs are undertaken without thorough consideration, Heaven’s Dao is lost, and the burden of inheritance arises. This leads the people into lawlessness, disrupting Heaven’s correct Dao. Governance becomes disordered, and the people and the myriad things suffer unjustly.

May I ask: Lawlessness is a crime punishable by the most severe penalties—why does the Master of Heaven not establish heavy punishments and capital laws, meting out justice according to each offense?

In the present age, matters are judged according to their offenses to maintain balance. Why, then, does the Master of Heaven not punish lawlessness as it deserves?

It cannot be done.

Why not?

Because the ancients committed only minor errors in their practice of the Dao, which do not warrant punishment. Later generations inherit and accumulate these faults, turning them into transgressions. Though their actions may be empty and perverse, even to the point of death, later generations learn from their predecessors. Though they stray from Heaven’s Dao and govern through lawlessness, this is passed down from teacher to teacher, each instructing the next. It is not the fault of a single person, so they cannot be subjected to heavy penalties.

Consider the sins of those in later ages—they are grave enough to warrant death. Yet the divine sages, in establishing laws, cannot suddenly impose heavy punishments and extinguish the generations of humankind. Therefore, Heaven sent me down to reform their conduct, remove their burdens, and without exposing their faults, allow Heaven, Earth, and humanity to govern together, causing spirits to afflict them with illness and disaster. Later generations will see this as the manifest efficacy of the teachings I received from Heaven.

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

The discourse complete, Heaven’s words ceased, and the transmission was entrusted to the Virtuous Lord.

Indeed, indeed.

Proceed, and ask no more.

Indeed, indeed.

**The above contains all the secret teachings on auspicious omens, recorded below.**

*This concludes the one hundred eighth scroll of the* Classic of Great Peace.
*This begins the one hundred ninth scroll of the* Classic of Great Peace.

**Essential Record on the Two Hands of Heaven, Scroll One Hundred Seventy-Seven**

Heaven possesses two hands, which together accomplish all matters. If one hand is afflicted with sickness or evil, nothing can be brought to completion. Heaven deeply resents this, Earth regards it as taboo, and the world falls into chaos without success—all due to the one hand’s malevolence and failure to join in effort. If all affairs remain unresolved and the six directions are not at great peace, it is likewise because the two hands are diseased or evil and do not unite their strength. Good fortune and misfortune, safety and peril—all arise from these two hands.

Perfected One, do you truly comprehend this in depth?

If not, only the Heavenly Master can reveal its essential meaning, enabling you to understand. Otherwise, you will remain forever in darkness and confusion, with no way to attain this knowledge.

The Heavenly Master is the root of all teachings and transformations in Heaven and Earth. Though it is difficult, how could one refrain from speaking of it?

Excellent indeed are the Perfected One’s inquiries into these matters!

Has Heaven appointed you to raise these questions?

The words are essential and—

Yes.

Be seated, and I shall fully expound this meaning for all the Perfected Ones.

When the world models itself upon this and acts accordingly, no further misfortune or disorder will arise.

The gods of Heaven name this the "Two Hands’ Strategy," a crucial record. If a nation practices it, it will endure long; if common people practice it, they will enjoy lasting prosperity.

The essential Dao is about to emerge, and it lies near within the body of ordinary people. Now, I shall distinguish and explain it for all the Perfected Ones.

Indeed, indeed.

Heaven and Earth are the Two Hands that give birth to all things.
The Four Seasons are the Two Hands that transmit and nurture all beings.
The Five Phases are the Two Hands that transmit and complete the mutual bestowal of all things.
Man and woman, husband and wife, are the Two Hands that transmit and continue the Yin and Yang of Heaven and Earth.
Master and disciple are the Two Hands that transmit and teach, enabling the circulation of all affairs, texts, and the Dao-virtue.
Ruler and minister are the Two Hands that transmit and govern all affairs, the people, and the myriad things.

These six matters merely lift the guiding principles to reveal their governance—there are more than can be written.

All affairs that rely upon one another to achieve completion are the Two Hands. In Heaven, this is called "Overlapping Compasses and Repeating Squares," for all must correspond to one another.

If one hand is evil and unequal, nothing can be accomplished. In Heaven, this is called "the governance of great disorder"; in the six directions and eight distant regions, it is called "widowers and childless heirs," and the sun daily wanes in brightness.

Nothing can be accomplished because these Two Hands do not unite their strength.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed!

May I ask why this is rightfully named the "Two Hands" in Heaven?

Excellent is your question, for you have grasped its meaning.

The "Two Hands" signify their equal and united strength, with no advancing and no retreating, so that later affairs may be accomplished. If the Two Hands do not unite their strength, affairs cannot be accomplished.

Thus, all affairs should model themselves upon these Two Hands, each finding its proper person. When strength is united and hearts are of one mind, like these Two Hands, then the qi of good fortune, safety, and great peace will swiftly arrive.

Those who do not model themselves upon these Two Hands will, for billions upon billions of years, be unable to bring forth the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Highest Sovereign.

The qi of Supreme Peace constantly desires to emerge, just as Heaven constantly desires to act through these Two Hands. If they are not long harmonized and guided, they will remain blocked and unable to circulate, emerging to govern with frustration and resentment—what blame is there? The fault lies in these Two Hands not being harmonized.

If the Two Hands are balanced and harmonized, then the qi of the Supreme Peace of the Highest Sovereign will emerge, arriving one after another without delay.

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed!

Thus, if Heaven and Earth do not unite their strength, the myriad things and all affairs will have no way to emerge.
If the Four Seasons do not unite their strength, all things will have no way to grow.
If the Five Phases do not unite their strength, all things will have no way to be completed.
If ruler and minister do not unite their strength, all affairs will have no way to be governed.
If husband and wife do not unite their strength, descendants will have no way to flourish, and the family way will have no way to be established.
If master and disciple do not unite their strength, no knotted affairs will find resolution, the Dao-virtue will have no way to flourish, the dense fog will have no way to clear, and the great transformation of the six directions and eight distant regions will have no way to spread.

Thus, all must unite their strength, likening themselves to the Two Hands, so that all may be communicated. Without likening themselves to the Two Hands, misfortune will daily arise.

Even if one seeks to remedy this, it will be of no benefit, and there will still be no way to achieve success. Only prolonged sorrow and suffering will follow, with misfortune growing day by day.

Therefore, in modeling upon these Two Hands, selection and appointment must find the proper person. Those who do not find the proper person are, in the eyes of the gods of Heaven, "half-dead." If one does not hold to both hands and act alone, how can there be any success or accomplishment of affairs?

Perfected One, you have come from afar to inquire on behalf of Heaven. For all matters of doubt, you should deeply ponder this meaning with a sincere heart. The heart is born of fire, and it should return to be entrusted to fire, governing and modeling the people. Then, you will prolong your years and increase your lifespan, with not a single loss. I do not deceive you.

Convey this to the virtuous ruler, convey it to the common people. Let the worthy each ponder its meaning, and let none dare to transgress it.

To employ this is called "enriching and nurturing oneself"; to not employ it is called "bringing sorrow and suffering upon oneself."

Wondrous indeed is my Dao, for it is purely the will of Heaven. One may only advance and not retreat, only comply and not oppose. Compliance purely attains the heart of Heaven; opposition brings disorder. When disorder and calamity surge, human intent goes west while Heaven’s intent goes east—this is called "being at odds with the will of Heaven."

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed! Go forth, for you may be said to have awakened to this knowledge.

**The Four Auspicious and Four Inauspicious Decisions, One Hundred Seventy-Eight**

Perfected One, when common people today recommend scholars to present to the emperor and entrust to the state, if they obtain the proper person, this is the first great inauspicious matter.

If the person is evil, then their learning is abandoned, defiling the legacy of former teachers and sages, and bringing misfortune upon their master—this is the second great inauspicious matter.

Moreover, if those who recommend them are untrustworthy, jointly deceiving their superiors, presenting an improper person, disrupting the celestial order, and defiling the constellations, Heaven will detest them, Earth will resent them, the lord of the state will despise them, and sages and worthies will condemn them—such a one is a flattering, deceitful child of the age.

For this offense, if they are not punished by Heaven, Earth, and the spirits, then people will surely harm them, disgracing their ancestors and bringing misfortune upon their wives, children, and descendants—this is the fourth great inauspicious matter.

To commit these four great inauspicious acts by presenting an improper person causes the emperor to suffer and grieve, and governance to become chaotic.

Once harmful qi stirs and arises, it cannot be stopped. Affairs before and after fall into disorder, with mutual blame and burden. Heaven and Earth grow furious, the host of spirits engage in battle, the six directions are displeased, the eight distant regions fall into discord, and for all time, there is no governance. In Heaven, this is called "the tally of diminished years and shortened lifespan."

Why is this called "the tally of shortened lifespan"?

When governance should be long, it is instead made short; when years should be many, they are instead made few. In all undertakings, one encounters misfortune, bringing no benefit to oneself. Heaven and Earth are displeased, deducting from one’s allotted years. Thus, in Heaven, this is called "the tally of shortened lifespan."

Excellent indeed, excellent indeed! Foolish student, I have heard your command.

Yet you may be said to have grasped this in part. Guard this celestial text well, and present it to the virtuous lord, to all worthy ones, and to the worthy among the common folk.

When one in high position seeks officers, one must examine them with care; when one in low position recommends officers, one must do so with loyalty. Let later generations transmit and recite this text, binding it within their hearts. If they hastily appoint officers without following this, Heaven and Earth will no longer be pleased. To know this and yet act contrary—how grave the transgression! Perfected One, be vigilant.

“Yes, yes. I sincerely receive your instruction and dare not violate the prohibitions. I shall practice it with all my strength.”

You may be said to be prudent in affairs, having received the Mandate of Heaven.

[Here ends] *The Celestial and Terrestrial Hand-Tally for Recommending Officers: Four Auspicious Signs, Four Inauspicious Signs, the Tally of Shortened Lifespan, the Tally of Extended Life, the Tally for Pacifying the State, and the Prophecy of Gaining the Hearts of Heaven and Earth and the Host of Spirits.*

[*The following section is missing a large portion of text.* See the collated edition.]

**The Book of Great Merit for Extending Years: Admonitions on Time, from the One Hundred Tenth Scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace**

The Way of highest antiquity was to cultivate the self and rectify one’s conduct, never daring to transgress what the numinous spirits record. Only then did one dare seek life and petition for survival from the Celestial Lord, never daring to act wantonly, fearing one’s wholeness would not be preserved. Daily, one contemplated the vitality of life, serving the spirits as a subject and manifesting one’s kind. One desired to offer words of utmost loyalty and uprightness, and to the spirits governing each domain, one clearly distinguished right from wrong, only then daring to trust in the governance of fairness. How could one forget this even for a moment?

Above, there are those who observe humanity, fully discerning right from wrong. What can be concealed? What can be disbelieved? Thus, one attains self-governance, seeking to contemplate the root of all things, never entering even the slightest realm of ungoodness. One merely cherishes being human, relying upon and revering the primordial qi, so that even the creeping and moving creatures do not witness calamities and anomalies. Yet humans betray trust in their sworn words, and mutual disbelief arises, leading to unrest.

Within Heaven and Earth, the harmony of above and below each maintains its own trust. Humans do not comprehend its essentials, yet ask why there is good and evil alone. From whence do all calamities and anomalies arise? Humans ingest the qi of the Five Constants, receiving and relying upon it in all things, moving through all things. Why then do they alone fail to honor and understand it? From ancient times, have there been those who knew how to extend goodness to others?

This is to lose goodness and follow evil, causing one’s life to be incomplete. How can this be right? Thus, the Celestial Lord declares that there is good and there is evil, and goodness can be made uniform. The reason for this is that there must be distinction. One cannot follow one’s own inclinations: goodness should ascend, and evil should be punished. How can evil be allowed to reach goodness?

From human perspective, this too is understandable, for there are those who ought to be upright. Thus, evil is established to clarify the intentions of Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the Five Phases, so that one may know that completing life and engendering existence are of utmost importance, thereby extending one’s years of life. Having received the Dao of life and completion, one upholds its prohibitions and dares not transgress its taboos.

From this, it is clear that Heaven knows the foolishness of humans is profound, yet harbors no intent for retribution. To oppose what Heaven enacts, to contradict what Heaven ordains, and to impose upon others what one enacts—this is to invert the proper order, rewarding evil and punishing goodness. Thus, the sage understands the convergence of yin and yang, the worthy one governs fairness and rectitude, resolving what is unknown, so that each knows their allotted portion and does not resent others. Goodness naturally extends life, and evil naturally shortens it. What is there to doubt or resent?

Are humans truly inferior to the six domestic animals, birds that fly, beasts that run, and creatures of the water? Is it that humans are without form, and Heaven makes it so? Heaven desires only that humans do good and does not wish them to do evil. If good and evil were to share the same suffering and joy, then wealth, honor, longevity, and old age—all that Heaven enacts above—would be unable to distinguish beauty from ugliness, allowing ignorant people to boast, saying, “I am equal to you all.” What need is there for practicing goodness? Thus, goodness is advanced and extended, prolonging life. Those of shallow understanding consider it equal.

Those who compare themselves to evildoers who lose their lives and then wish to correct their errors, follow goodness, and turn away from evil—day and night, they examine and reflect upon themselves, repaying what they have owed. Though they may not ascend as immortals or transcend the world, they may complete their allotted years without dying prematurely. This is sufficient.

The advantage of ordinary people lies only in the fleeting moment. Not contemplating long life, they may yet rise to become those who understand, possessing the heart that seeks life, and thus refrain from evil. Heaven sees their goodness and allows them to act with ease, further seeking wealth and descendants. Though they may not attain all, they still have hope. Why then persist in evil, inviting long destruction, believing they may complete their years? They do not know that Heaven dispatches spirits to record their deeds—no transgression, great or small, escapes Heaven’s knowledge.

The registers of good and evil are examined and tallied by the year, month, and day. From past to present, years are deducted, and if evil does not cease, one is brought before the Ghost Gate. The Earth Spirit summons and interrogates them, comparing their words and deeds. If they remain unrepentant, they are tormented by the suffering ghosts until they submit. Their names are then sent to the Celestial Bureau for final reckoning. When their tally is exhausted, they are to enter the earth, and their transgressions will flow into future lives. Is this not the result of evil?

Why do humans not desire life? Having no mirror to see themselves, whom can they blame? Among children born in the same month, why does one alone persist in evil without cease? How can they hope for longevity? The calculations of the foolish scholar—why do they not align even with small goodness?

They pursue trivial and non-urgent matters along the Way, each person’s actions differing in their schemes. They believe their own way is right, yet in all they touch and transgress, they seek only their own benefit, while others do not wish to benefit them. The benefit of goodness brings fleeting life; the benefit of evil does not endure. With goodness, one does not long remain upon the earth.

Does Heaven and Earth not know this? Heaven causes humans to do good, thus giving them life, yet they turn to evil. Thus, the ghost that presides over evil follows them relentlessly. If they do not cease, other ghosts ascend, each generating their own affairs, so that the ghosts follow the person without respite.

Do you not understand? This scripture first advances goodness and retreats evil—such is the literature of past and present. Yet if one does not follow the path to long life and instead pursues evil, there is nothing to be done; the ghosts cannot be exonerated. Thus, those who transgress vanish into the earth. Their spirit is not at peace, and they know not where to rest—whose fault is this?

Let each person reflect deeply upon their conduct, seeking ease and tranquility without wrongdoing. Their words and phrases may repeat, their teachings may not be singular, hence the repetition. Your life lies close within yourself—why then do you strike your breast and cry out to Heaven? If you do not purify yourself, whom should you purify? If you do not cherish yourself, whom should you cherish? If you do not perfect yourself, whom should you perfect? If you do not reflect upon yourself, upon whom should you reflect? If you do not reproach yourself, whom should you reproach?

Ponder these words, and you will bear no grudge against ghosts and spirits. When they witness goodness, they affirm goodness; when they witness evil, they affirm evil—all is not the same. Do you understand this? If words cease briefly but evil does not, the written records will not end; only when the person perishes will they stop. This warning makes clear that evil is self-inflicted, not imposed upon others—do you understand?

Act in accordance with these words, and let them never leave your heart; to depart from them is to invite ruin. If you cannot be redeemed, you will share the company of ghosts—how then can you live? To contemplate life is to attain life—this is wisdom. Evil will inevitably come to an end and cannot endure—do you not understand this?

Yet again, some engage in trivial matters. All who dwell between Heaven and Earth are granted the gift of being human—how can they forget the grace of Heaven and Earth? What manner of folly is this? If they cannot change, what hope remains? If they desire Heaven’s reward, they must reproach themselves, weeping with sincerity as they act. They say, *"I have received the grace to be human, set apart from all things. Heaven has bestowed upon me distinction—speech, discernment of beauty and ugliness, knowledge of good and evil. How can I not attend to these matters?"* Yet their words defy Heaven, and their disobedience marks them as the most rebellious and unprincipled of people. How can Heaven long abide such conduct?

Thus, malevolent spirits are dispatched. The ancient observations return, echoing the words spoken: the person does not incline toward goodness. The Heavenly Lord declares, *"The records have not ceased. The department overseer shall descend to seize their soul, their bones and flesh entrusted to the earthly lord. There is no need for delay."* The wicked cannot be repeatedly admonished, so they bring ruin upon themselves through their own wrath. They return to refinement, transforming their evil, gathering all virtues and internalizing them, placing the heart within the heart.

The spirits say, *"We receive the heart’s decree from Heaven, charged to follow the human heart without the slightest deviation. Good and evil are immediately witnessed by attendant spirits, who also perceive the heart."* The spirits grow ever more sorrowful, uncertain of fortune or misfortune, and thus they fear being counted among the ranks of the wicked. Day and night, they reflect, unsure where to place themselves, and so they dare not entertain even the slightest unvirtuous thought. They rely solely on the forbearance of the gods, allowing them to reproach themselves. If they disregard divine admonitions, they will be punished without resentment.

The Heavenly Lord sends a great spirit to declare: *"This person has reproached themselves and repented of their transgressions, no longer violating the prohibitions. Grant them forbearance, grant them forbearance. If they later commit wrongdoing, it will not be too late to seize them."* The spirits, seeing their words and ceaseless sighs, fear that their transgressions may not yet be fully expunged. Long cut off from the qi of the Great Yang, they remain among the ranks of the dead, growing ever more afflicted, uncertain of what to do. Though they have received the decree to exhort, they have not yet attained understanding. In quietude, they examine themselves, reproaching the faults they bear and offering thanks to Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, the Five Phases, and all the spirits of their departments.

The Heavenly Lord listens, commanding them to reflect deeply. The people of antiquity possessed wisdom and foresight, never daring to violate the prohibitions. They cultivated and corrected themselves, fearing any lapse, for even the slightest misstep would be seen as defiance of the mandate, forfeiting their years. For this reason, they dared not relax even slightly. Every transgression incurred punishment, and thus they constantly examined and cherished themselves, revering the prohibitions and never daring to harbor wayward thoughts. When reproached, their hearts trembled with fear, their qi dismayed. They bore the burden of Heaven’s heart, for even the slightest discrepancy would bring verbose records and immediate investigation to verify the truth.

Their words and trustworthiness could earn them renown, yet if they lacked integrity, their years would soon be lost. Thus, they reflected unceasingly, never losing sight of their own hearts, ever fearful and anxious, never daring to rest. They acted with restraint, always longing and yearning, desiring to align with Heaven and Earth, the four seasons, and the Five Phases, bearing the mandate together without the slightest error or deviation. Their hearts chastised themselves, ever mindful of the profound intent before and behind them, never straying from constancy. They cherished grace and never violated sincerity, desiring life and hoping to live—how could even the smallest evil reach the ears above?

They bound their bodies and conducted themselves in accordance with duty, never daring to slacken, fearing they could not fulfill the highest intent. They knew not what to do, their hearts ever more anxious, finding no solace in self-comfort. The gift of Heaven’s longevity is difficult to obtain; once lost, it cannot be regained. Having long distanced themselves from the vulgar, to be suddenly cut down midway—how could they not look below in dismay? Thus, they admonished themselves with trembling reverence.

Ever fearful that even the slightest discrepancy might lead to their dismissal, sorrow and melancholy filled their hearts as they reproached themselves for their faults. Having received Heaven’s grace, they sought to fulfill their former mandate, never forgetting the pangs of hunger and thirst, content merely to live. The great spirits, moved by compassion, recorded and instructed the common people, who received qi from the Heavenly Kitchen and rode upon the qi of Heaven. Yet their conduct was meager, their duties many, and they could not afford the slightest lapse.

Though their bodies were humble and unworthy of honor, they were not despised for their unworthiness. Truly, with their hearts, they sought advancement and the pursuit of life. They entreated the great spirits to review their words, allowing them to witness the generative and transformative power of the four seasons and Five Phases, and to see the difficulty of repaying the sun and moon. They feared being cast aside midway. The upright and diligent dared not distance themselves, prostrating themselves in devotion.

The great spirits declared: *"This person has followed the teachings of their master to such an extent—why should they fear lacking protection?"*

In times past, there was such a person whom Heaven, in its mercy, kept close at hand. Now, having served long in office and grown rich in knowledge and foresight, all that they knew of antiquity was profound. Whatever they spoke found favor in the heart of the Heavenly Lord.

Thus, they prostrated themselves, weeping upon the earth, and spoke: *"Awakened by your decree, I recall the loyal and sincere hearts of those who came before. All that I have learned and known, I hold within and heed—how dare I compare myself to those of former times?"*

The great spirits replied: *"We speak to one of trustworthy word, that you may emulate and compare your conduct to theirs. Yet some fall short in their time."*

The disciple said: *"Great spirits, you have made all things clear and distinct. Among the many, I alone am singled out for favor, granted insight and reflection—this grace is most profound. When shall I ever repay the great spirits?"*

The great spirits said: *"Reflection arises from within; it is the fervent thought that repays."*

The disciple said: *"I know not how to offer my devotion. Though Heaven bestows rare and wondrous treasures, I think only of presenting them in return. Moved by your decree, I stir my resolve and contemplate with fervor. This is true acceptance, not mere words of empty courtesy. Day and night, I ponder without ceasing, never daring to slacken."*

The great spirits said: *"The admonitions are many, and the remonstrances come not from one alone. That we speak to you at such length is out of deep regard for your sincerity. Your words reveal profound favor and exceptional mercy."*

The Heavenly Lord, hearing this, summoned the great spirits and asked: *"From whence did this disciple arise, to merit such extraordinary words from the great spirits?"*

The great spirits replied: *"This learner is especially trustworthy, and thus we speak of the difficulty and ease of the Dao."*

The Heavenly Lord said: *"To see the good and advance it, bringing one to such a state—this is as it should be."*

The great spirits said: *"The Heavenly Lord’s inquiry confirms this trustworthy disciple."*

The disciple said: *"I dare not hope to stand at the left side of Heaven. I wish only to remain in a place without office, exerting myself in loyalty."*

The great spirits said: *"All must have a domain to govern, that their trustworthiness may be seen in reason."*

Thus, by such sincerity, they were deemed fortunate indeed, attaining great distinction. They dared not fall short in even the smallest measure.

The great spirits said: *"This disciple, transformed thus, should advance further and may yet equal the ancients."*

The disciple said: *"I dare not seek long life—it is what others covet."*

The great spirits said: *"This is Heaven’s wish."*

The disciple said: *"It is only by the great spirits’ protection that I dare not transgress their warnings."*

The Heavenly Lord, knowing of these two who admonished and instructed one another, approved deeply and commanded them to teach each other.

The Way of the sages of highest antiquity arose naturally. Their hearts knew the governance of Heaven above, and all they enacted was foreknown. Their voices resonated clearly, and they understood forms and appearances, perceiving the heart’s brightness and the mind’s enlightenment. They knew what must be saved, the convergence of fortune and misfortune, all clearly discerned. Within their hearts, they rejoiced, knowing they had received Heaven’s blessing. They saw the affairs of those who came before, all cautioned with earnest clarity.
