Reflecting on the grace of their favor and encounter, having long accompanied the six spirits and received their teachings and warnings, they were kept from peril. Gazing upon the four directions, above and below all was open and unobstructed, their sorrow deepening. Yet their hearts rejoiced, drawing near to their appointed time, attaining even what they had not heard—all through the transformative power of Heaven’s great spirits.

The great spirits said: *"All the spirits know this: those who advance have their destiny. The records are true, and before their birth, their years, months, days, and hours are inscribed in the Bureau of Longevity. Their years increase, and their names are made known, governed by the Perfected One of the North Pole. Their bones are transformed, their bodies become light and lustrous, radiating brilliance. At the appointed time, they receive the elixir, refining their essence. Wherever they go, their transformations are unfailing. They move from the subtle to the hidden, traversing the space of a single hair—what is there they cannot penetrate?"*

The sage said: *"Truly, those who follow the common ways, who eat what the earth provides, whose yin spirits emerge—how can they not be esteemed? The ease of transformation is itself the highest ease."*

The great spirits’ grace cannot be repaid; their merit is vast, their favor profound. The thought of such great kindness is unbearable. Even in moments of respite, their depth is beyond words to repay.

The great spirits said: *"Heaven endows human life and destiny in equal measure. This is not by the will of the great spirits. To see the good and recommend them is the blessing of the spirits—what repayment is needed? Yet, fearing future doubts, we impose strict prohibitions, that the sages may instruct and later generations may understand. The sages know of themselves; no decrees are needed."*

The sage said: *"Though I have received such favor and my name is recorded, there may yet be teachings I fail to grasp."*

The great spirits said: *"This disciple’s words are fittingly humble—this is as it should be."*

The disciple, offering repeated thanks, expressed all that was needed. *"Only by the great spirits’ grace is my resolve fulfilled. Though I am but one among many, I dare not grow complacent or arrogant. I ask to exert myself further in quiet seclusion, heeding the great spirits’ teachings and mindful of my inadequacies."*

The great spirits said: *"All that has been said, before and after, is clear. There is nothing more to admonish."*

They parted, each reflecting on the other’s words.

The disciple said: *"From the day I received the precepts, I have not dared to slacken even for a moment. Yet I fear I may not see them through to the end. Only by your support may I live and hope again. My heart is ever inclined toward you. May the great spirits, from time to time, remember and instruct me—this grace is no small thing."*

The great spirits said: *"This disciple’s words are fitting indeed."*

The disciple said: *"Indeed, indeed. I dare not rely on myself for defense."*

The great spirits said: *"Those who attain renown benefit from diligent progress, and their domains are not few."*

The Heavenly Lord, hearing the exchange between the great spirits and the sage, deemed them persons of understanding and commanded that they not grow negligent. Their destinies would reach boundless longevity. Each returned to their domain, and when they saw the good, they advanced them to the great spirits.

The sage said: *"Having all received the Heavenly Lord’s teaching, we will strive with all our might, never growing weary in our efforts."*

The Heavenly Lord said: *"Those who become perfected do so by their own efforts."*
*"Indeed, indeed."*

Only the Dao-attaining persons of highest antiquity, even before the establishment of laws and registers, were recorded in the *Scriptures of Longevity*. When the time of the stars’ conjunction arrives, their names are transmitted to the Central Ultimate. The Central Ultimate is also called Kunlun. The domain overseers must go and record the names of these persons without omission. They are repeatedly sent to activate their limbs and joints, bending and extending, turning and inclining, instructing and admonishing them. The spirits follow their flexing and bowing, administering medicinal draughts to open and refine their bones and joints. Though they may not meet often, they know whether one is steadfast or not, for their resolve does not waver.

Those who covet life and abhor decay aspire to join the gods of heaven. The spirits are frequently dispatched to verify their years and accomplishments, and only then are they permitted to receive the *Scriptures of Insufficiency*. Their spoken words and utterances are made known so they may understand the prohibitions and defenses to be observed. These teachings are transmitted to learners, who must not disregard the divine texts. If one claims to have brought their own books to completion, the spirits will recognize their words in conversation. After accumulating one thousand three hundred and twenty days, they are led to meet the great spirits, to circulate primordial *qi*, and to practice spontaneity.

The Heavenly Lord reviewed the secret decrees and commanded that all investigations be conducted without private trust or biased intent, lest the heart be swayed and the mind altered, leading to errors in conduct. The great spirits said: *"We have calculated the provisions lent by all the spirits. On the last day of the eighth month each year, the registers of all mountains, seas, mounds, marshes, connecting rivers, bridges, the Huai, Ji, Yangtze, and lakes—recording all that enters and exits—must be clearly divided."*

The Heavenly Lord’s rewards and labor records are signed before him and repeatedly verified, then stored in the Golden Chamber. Those with sincere hearts are appointed to answer the Heavenly Lord’s inquiries. They must heed his teachings day and night without negligence. The chamber attendants must not lose track of their assigned domains. Separate records are kept to identify those with sincere hearts, and their names are duly registered.

The spirit envoys are tasked with tallying the names of all who ascend or descend. One hundred days in advance, all documents must be submitted without omission or error. If any document is inconsistent or the accounting officials fail to act, they will be held jointly liable. Prior decrees forbid violating the words of the divine texts. Three years and eight months after the release of this text, it may be shown to the common people. Those who possess the *Scriptures of Daoist Faith* may be shown it in full.

The Heavenly Lord instructed: *"This person bears prior burdens. Command the spirits to resolve and conceal them. Those not yet concealed must be concealed."*

The great spirits said: *"This person has long suffered poverty and emptiness, fearing they cannot preserve themselves. Having gained the Heavenly Lord’s trust, the spirits are ordered to conceal their records. If their overseer has not yet concealed them, they may not fulfill their words as promised."*

Previously, they had petitioned for decrees, offered thanks, and received grace. Though the appointed time has not yet arrived, all concerned are to be notified one month in advance. The Heavenly Lord said: *"Among the spirits, generals, soldiers, and people in the fields and lands below, none must miss the time for concealment. Record their names so that the earth spirits may revere and guard them. Let the divine powers come and go, and those who seek to fulfill their wishes may do so in good faith. Thereafter, they must be cautious."*

The great spirits said: *"Thus, all within the seas will hear and know. Those who love the Dao will support and uphold one another, serving and revering it."*

The Heavenly Lord said: *"Those who have merit shall naturally be revered."*

The great spirits said: *"This person’s years are not yet complete, and their allotted time has not arrived. We request that when the time comes, they be taught how to repay their gratitude. For now, their dwelling remains empty, and they have nothing to clothe themselves. Let those who possess the Dao provide them with sustenance until the appointed time."*

The Heavenly Lord said: *"This is a small matter. Let the celestial offices provide for their households—those with households and sincere hearts."*

The great spirits said: *"We request that it be done as instructed. Command the celestial officials to provide what is due. This person has long been empty; let them be given enough to eat."*

The great spirits said: *"Order the celestial officials to record their names and ensure they do not suffer want."*

The Heavenly Lord said: *"Well said."*

Only the people of highest antiquity all received the responses of heaven. Those with faith could succeed, and upon receiving their mandate, they were protected and watched over by the spirits, who feared any deficiency. Day and night, they divined their fate. Seeing them do good, they assisted and rejoiced; they did not wish to hear of their wrongdoing. They were placed in the offices of longevity, their hearts set on goodness, never turning to evil. They were encouraged to advance in virtue, fostering filial piety, loyalty, and obedience.

Those who received and practiced the teachings dared not act on their own will but followed the instructions. Others might call them ignorant, but the spirits saw and knew them. When someone showed great kindness or compassion, they rejoiced in their own strength. Yet if others remained suspicious after long acquaintance, they detested such mistrust above all, fearing it would lead to their own ruin. They restrained and disciplined themselves, dreading offense against evil persons, living in constant trepidation, uncertain of what to do.

Heaven endows people with knowledge of good and evil. Those who practice goodness with faith—heaven does not wish to hear of their wrongdoing. Thus, they covet life and abhor death, daring not to violate prohibitions, lest they harm themselves. Therefore, by aligning with the *qi* of heaven, they engage in discourse with those who commune with the Dao. Their words flow freely, understanding human sentiments. Seeing another’s misdeeds, they withdraw and reproach themselves, fearing that their names might be sullied in the records.

If one’s intent at the time is to bestow favor upon another, one must not dare to confront them directly with intricate reasoning but instead reflect on one’s own conduct. Failing to please others, one’s transgressions multiply and are difficult to erase. Thus, when people come to regret their actions, their circumstances shift, and their sharpness wanes, believing their fate can be regained. Yet heaven sends the great spirits to divine their fortunes, and the omens are dire. They enter the earth prematurely, and so they console themselves, enduring in silence, daring not to incur further wrong.

Even slight deviations in their words or intentions, having received heaven’s grace, are granted a brief respite to revive and sustain the hope of long life—this is heaven’s dispensation. Thus, they gain a share of intent, though their lives may not endure long. For this reason, they grow ever more despondent, their hearts filled with shame and remorse.

They long to meet the heavenly spirits, to seek compassion, instruction, and admonition, to illuminate what they do not know, and to prepare for what is to come. If their hearts align with heaven’s will, they may attain a small measure of their desires. Those who covet advancement and deliberation ponder good and evil alike, striving to avoid the decrees they cannot see.

Then the great spirit appeared, and the seeker, both bitter and willing, spoke of their own life. Those who cling to worldly desires and covet advancement thus cultivate and rectify themselves. Only the great spirit’s decree exposes their insufficiencies, awakening them to hope for admonition from the left side. The great spirit, in compassion, examines those who seek life.

The great spirit asked: "Why惜 the prohibitions and precepts?" Reflect deeply upon this. Let your words each express your true feelings, but fear they may not match your speech. Consider carefully, for thoughts arise from the heart and should be pondered thoroughly.

The seeker replied: "Overwhelmed with gratitude and fear for what I have received, how dare I not speak from the heart?"

The great spirit said: "Such resolve is commendable. Return now to a quiet place and reflect. Seek only where you find insufficiency."

The seeker said: "I am slow of understanding and lacking in wisdom, yet to fully grasp the manifest precepts. I prostrate myself, awaiting your instruction, before daring to advance further."

The great spirit replied: "If you devote yourself with utmost sincerity, merit may yet be attained. Strive and reflect upon your life thus far—your progress in merit, the resolution of your ancestors’ burdens, and the lifting of those burdens. When transgressions are exhausted, you shall ascend. What doubt remains? Be cautious in your words and guard against wayward thoughts."

The seeker said: "Having received your decree and admonition, I dare not withhold effort in pursuing goodness. Yet if I alternate between good and evil, I toy with my own fate."

The great spirit said: "Even the virtuous should humble themselves. Though their days of toil may bring momentary hardship, if they persist without wavering, blessings shall follow."

The seeker, having received the decree, withdrew to a secluded place, reflecting on their faults and reproaching themselves.

The great spirit said: "Thoughts that arise from within are known to the heavenly spirits. Do not grow weary."

The seeker persisted until the end of their years.

The great spirit said: "With such conduct, why fear failure to advance? The Heavenly Lord, having heard of this, further charged the great spirit to observe those who seek progress, recording their deeds over months and years, assigning each to their proper rank. Those with merit shall ascend, their names filling vacancies.

In ancient times, the hearts, words, and speech of people were attuned to human nature, governing without artifice. Their inner and outer selves were in harmony, and none betrayed their trust. Heaven’s essential decrees, when violated, brought swift disgrace, and transgressors were promptly questioned and held accountable for their faults. Thus, they trembled all the more.

Moved by the boundless grace of heaven, which allows them to remain whole as humans and discern right from wrong, they ponder how to repay such profound kindness. Though their hearts yearn to advance with loyalty and sincerity, and though they strive in word and deed to uphold every command without the slightest deviation—fearing that even minor lapses might be reported to the spirits above, cutting short their allotted years—they grow ever more sorrowful and anxious, unable to find solace, yet hoping to repay heaven’s benevolence.

Truly, they covet life and, together with the heavenly spirits, align with heaven’s will. For those with goodness, even minor transgressions are absolved, allowing them to fulfill their years. Those with great merit may have their lives extended and their years increased. Serving the primordial *qi*, uniting essence and radiance, they perceive all that is known and receive profound grace—beyond words to repay, their hearts alone left uncertain.

Only the great spirits, in their compassion, record and examine, offering instruction to enlighten their understanding. They come to know heaven’s many decrees and prohibitions, which must be upheld without fail.

The great spirits, ever mindful of their insufficiencies, admonish them not to forget their duty, nor the grace that sustains their lives."

The great spirit said: "You are one who understands. What further instruction is needed? Simply follow heaven’s will and do not oppose it. Upon receiving admonitions, act upon them at once without omission. This is how one aligns with heaven’s intent. Rewards and punishments vary in weight—each must be met with sincerity, without error. Even minor precepts should be heeded. Consider your words carefully, ensuring they are practicable. Should small falsehoods arise, reflect inwardly and turn toward goodness—this is a minor precept. All else in life’s conduct should be deeply guarded, lest you fail the spirits’ intent.

From childhood, you have not yet grasped the greater duty. Thus, the great spirits repeatedly admonish you. Their insight is vast, their wisdom boundless, encompassing all things. The great spirits urge you to embrace their virtue and not oppose their words. Reflect deeply and await further admonition."

The great spirit said: "These words reveal heaven’s dispensations, the knowledge of earthly conduct, and the ways of all things in between. The laws correspond without discrepancy. Those who instruct you follow their masters—simply do not oppose them."

The seeker said: "I am resolved to uphold the precepts. Though the laws are uniform, my understanding of their intent remains shallow. Heaven’s will is difficult to fathom."

The great spirit said: "All this is true and without deceit. Those who foresee the Heavenly Lord’s intentions are foremost among people, worthy to stand at his left side. For their merit, they receive rewards, yet they remain humble, refusing to accept all, and strive ever harder, their minds refined and their efforts great. Thus, the Heavenly Lord personally charges and instructs them—this is your fortune. With many under your care, govern with an impartial heart. This is sufficient."

The seeker said: "I dare not aspire to stand at the Heavenly Lord’s left side. To live is enough. I think only of loyalty and filial piety, fulfilling my duties according to principle. I dare not accept great rewards, fearing I lack merit. Yet when even small deeds bear fruit, my life grows brighter, and I see my days prolonged. My thoughts are boundless, never ceasing to reflect on my faults, even for a moment. To receive your gentle words fills my heart to overflowing. The great spirit dwells with me, guiding without need for thought. Truly, I have received grace—moving between heaven and earth, occasionally admonished—this is the great spirit’s benevolence, beyond repayment. My heart’s longing remains ever present, never wavering."

The Heavenly Lord, having heard this, knew that the conduct of such a learned person never fails to fulfill their aspirations. Those who constantly examine their own faults and harbor no ill intentions—when the great spirits admonish and instruct them—ascend without weariness. The most virtuous of people are born of nature itself, each with their own destined record, inscribed in the register of goodness, named the *Record of the Virtuous*. They consistently embody virtuous conduct, never bearing an evil reputation. In all their movements, whether going or coming, only good intentions are heard, never evil—thus they are called *the virtuous*. Their every action advances them among others; the multitude marvels at what they cannot see, and they attain the highest reverence. Those in high station observe them, some admiring their words, some coveting their virtuous deeds, some their sincerity, some their beloved presence, some their filial loyalty, some their long-standing counsel, or their trustworthiness—such is the excellence of the virtuous. Thus they are named *virtuous*. At times, they receive favor and glory, yet still desire to wander long, to attain the state of spirit immortals, to reach the rank of deathlessness, or to command the host of spirits—these are the desires of the virtuous. Their conduct, revering goodness, aligns with the trust of heaven and earth, the four seasons, and the five phases; the spirits cherish them, the wise instruct one another, rare texts and extraordinary strategies are shared, and vacancies are filled through mutual recommendation and assurance. Even minor disagreements are corrected through admonition, and precious treasures are exchanged. Together, they ascend to the heavenly spirits, seeking reverence, correction, and reflection on their faults, fearing they may not measure up to the great spirits of heaven. Day and night, their hearts advance with steadfast devotion; they embrace goodness from within, yearn to hear virtuous words, and hold fast to loyalty and integrity. They cherish their lives and years, ever fearful of even a moment’s lapse into slight unvirtuousness. When they hear of others’ faults, they aid in their repentance. They guide those with understanding, heed good counsel, adopt others’ words, and witness their glory. They teach others to seek the Dao of life and the path to survival—this is the utmost of the virtuous. Yet they dare not defy the wishes of the spirits, their longing ever present, and they attain what others aspire to. Only the great spirits of heaven, mastering all discourse, inspect and command their conduct, enforcing prohibitions. Even minor lapses are met with forbearance, allowing them to reflect on their intentions. Heaven’s grace is vast, its compassion boundless, enabling self-reflection, repentance, and prolonged life—this is the great dispensation of fate. Yet they fear failing to fully repay this grace, and only the great spirits pardon their shortcomings. They wish to receive unseen admonitions, to dwell in joyful reflection, their aspirations broad and far-reaching, ever mindful of repeated instructions.

The great spirit said: "Heaven and earth each have their own patterns. To know how to advance but not how to retreat—this is natural. They do not withhold admonition or instruction out of reluctance. When they see the virtuous, what doubt remains? What further correction is needed? Simply ponder their words carefully, and act accordingly. This is the aspiration of the virtuous, and it is fitting to make it clear."

The seeker said: "I am unworthy, my conduct impure. Thus I have personally received the great spirits’ prohibitions and admonitions. Repeatedly, I have been shown great favor, my thoughts ever remembered, and my presence openly acknowledged. Yet I return again, insatiable—heaven has made it so."

The great spirit said: "You have received your nature from the Dao; heaven sent you to inquire, knowing your alignment—or lack thereof. What cause for suspicion is there? Those who secretly wish to receive instructions speak only from their true feelings, with few embellished words. Few are those who correct themselves from the heart, hence vacancies are filled through mutual supplementation. Your shortcomings are evident; you must remain vigilant and not grow lax."

The seeker said: "My nature is slow and dull. Though I strive not to err, I rely on written precepts for restraint. I can only lament my inadequacy."

The great spirit said: "This too arises from understanding. Knowing goodness, one acts with goodness; knowing trust, one acts with trust; knowing loyalty, one acts with loyalty; knowing obedience, one acts with obedience; knowing filial piety, one acts with filial piety. How could evil ever gain ground? You understand this yourself—thus I emphasize it further."

The seeker, deeply moved, said: "What I have heard is the greatest goodness. Within it lies profound admonition. The great spirits’ teachings are thus—how dare I harbor any thought of negligence? This is the intent that sustains my life. To receive such favor, I know not how to repay the great spirits’ grace."

The great spirit said: "These matters are observed, yet they need not serve as admonition. Reflect on what can be practiced, and your name will surely be established. Ascend without doubt; your conduct will naturally attain it. What need is there for repayment or gratitude? Your words are already virtuous—there is nothing more to be said."

The seeker said: "These admonitions prolong my life, giving me hope for survival. I will ponder your words in my ignorance."

The great spirit said: "Know that your words must not depart from your heart. Those who come to learn have always been admonished thus, before and after."

The seeker said: "Who would willingly instruct me so?"

The seeker’s fate and life delighted the great spirits. They summarized all prior instructions, yet he felt he could never match such grace, ashamed and at a loss.

The Heavenly Lord, having heard this, said: "This is the excellence of the excellent, the finest among the virtuous. It may be applied across all departments without fail."

The great spirit relayed to the seeker: "The Heavenly Lord’s command is thus gracious. You must not transgress it." The seeker assented.

Those of supreme virtue dwell between heaven and earth, accomplishing the work of transformation, each fulfilling their aspirations. The virtuous are inscribed in the *Record of Goodness*, never deviating from constancy or propriety—this is supreme virtue. Nothing remains unaccomplished, nothing unachieved. They do not lose their clarity or their truth, nor do they fail in the generation of yin and yang, the ingress and egress of the life-giving qi of the four seasons, the completion of the five phases, the courses of the sun, moon, and stars, their measured cycles, the timing of fortune and misfortune, the signs of calamity and anomaly, the records of flood and drought, or the length of human life—never losing the essence of their allotted fate as determined by the stars. This is the conduct befitting those of supreme virtue.

Thus it is said: the person of virtue illuminates all without exception, perceives all without obstruction—above, below, and at the center, each attaining its proper harmony. In accordance with their virtue, none lose their rightful name. This is the scripture of constancy and long life, from which none fail to receive glory.

All things sprout forth, breaking through their husks to grow; they droop their branches and spread their leaves, serving as garments. Mist, dew, frost, snow, and timely rain serve as drink and food. They grow and mature, their foliage and fruit providing cover, sustaining the earth’s bounty—known as the "water mother," called by the people "melon." In the scorching heat of high summer, it serves as water and broth, relied upon by all under heaven, consumed by young and old alike. Such is the virtuous person, who bears the mandate of heaven, completing heaven’s form upon the earth to provide sustenance for the people. Bestowing kindness and spreading bounty, none are left untouched by their virtue, thus filling themselves to abundance—this is the grace of heaven.

Yet it is not so. Heaven’s bestowal of life is vast, and to defy its decree by claiming all is "natural" is to invite deafening rebuke. Therefore, the virtuous person, understanding heaven’s intent, instructs the people in the proper way, never straying from heaven’s will, nurturing growth and maturity so that they may become fully human. Those who further comprehend the patterns of scripture, whose conduct perfects virtue, may ascend to the ranks of the celestial scholars.

In the affairs of heaven, merits are graded by distinction. The virtuous person presides over the affairs of earth, enabling the people to depend upon and witness anew the grace bestowed. Yet they cannot repay it in full measure. When the virtuous act as heaven’s agents in circulating qi—above, below, and at the center—those who fail to receive their due turn and belittle heaven’s works. This is precisely what provokes heaven’s unceasing wrath, causing the spirits to withhold their love for humanity, encroaching upon lifespans. Yet people blame heaven instead of themselves—how profound their folly!

Thus, the divine scriptures are sent down, establishing commands and prohibitions to firmly restrain the people from transgression. Those who foresee coming events, shun evil and pursue good, and do not violate the prohibitions will further witness the transformations wrought by heaven’s teachings, none failing to follow them. Therefore, the ruler is made their ally, guiding head and tail, completing their works like the walls of a city, clear and discernible for all to know.

They understand the great transformations above and regulate the primordial qi, while also comprehending human affairs. These are people of fortune and destiny, all foreknown. As they transform in accord with others, their allotted time may be extended, and heaven cherishes them. Benevolent spirits follow and protect them, shielding them from harm. Their hearts incline toward goodness, and the wicked cannot compare. Thus, heaven values goodness, allowing them to fulfill their aspirations, neither encroaching nor overpowering, but maintaining equilibrium. Those of exceptional ability who surpass in goodness have their lifespans further increased by heaven, spared from peril and entanglement in wrongdoing—this is great grace indeed.

How can one hesitate to repay it? Those who have performed great good, whose conduct aligns with heaven’s will, draw near to its left side, where no malign qi approaches. They dare not look upon it, and their lives extend without end—such grace is beyond repayment. Yet repayment need not be in rare treasures. Simply inscribing one’s heart in sincerity, being true and steadfast in word and deed, never betraying one’s promises—this is true repayment, the repayment of understanding. Do you comprehend?

To know goodness and act accordingly, to see trustworthiness and embody it—this is the excellence of humanity. One should reflect upon this and harbor no doubt. Those who were trustworthy in the past have attained boundless longevity, transforming into divine spirits, their capacities fully realized through merit. Do you understand this as well?

Thus, the virtuous person, a scholar of understanding, advances upward, cherished by heaven. Without their writings, they know their fate and do not resent heaven. Each conducts themselves with care, avoiding wrongdoing and perversity. Teaching others to do good, they align with heaven’s will, and their lives naturally lengthen. All affairs proceed from the Heavenly Lord, with no room for delay.

The common people are difficult to transform; they must be guided gradually, without haste or violence. Weigh your words carefully, lest they be recorded by the spirits. Each must attend to their own duties, for the scriptures and ledgers have their own measures and limits—do not overstep them. When you see goodness, advance it; when you see evil, correct it. Harbor no doubt.

Those who cherish life never forget heaven’s works. Thus, they are held in esteem, for they truly value human life. To contemplate goodness is to attain goodness, and longevity is assured. Does the Heavenly Lord cherish trustworthiness and understanding? Reflect carefully upon the divine scriptures, and do not test them of your own accord.

Of all matters under heaven, filial piety, loyalty, sincerity, and trustworthiness are paramount. Thus, one must not indulge in recklessness, nor seize the lifespans of others, for such actions cannot endure. Be cautious, be ever cautious, and do not grow lax. Laxity breeds doubt, and doubt renders one unworthy. Do you understand? Do you understand?

**Right:** *Celestial Writ of the Six Poles, Great Compendium of Heavenly Scriptures, Collated in the Eighth Heavenly Month in Accordance with the Laws of Heaven and Earth to Dispel Disasters.*
**End of** *Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll One Hundred Ten
**Beginning of** *Tai Ping Jing*, Scroll One Hundred Eleven

**The Great Sage’s Petition Formula, One Hundred Eighty**

Only those of supreme sagely virtue may receive the primordial qi and naturally respond to its radiant essence, thereby becoming great sages. They fully comprehend what ought to be enacted, aligning invariably with the celestial will without straying from the intent of the primordial qi. They ever act as grand divine ministers, akin to dukes and ministers in a kingdom. Their minds grasp the directives of the great spirits, their petitions and memorials flowing in accord with celestial writ. Each petition duly recommends the worthy, ensuring that those who speak are preserved, their words heeded by the Celestial Lord. When the Hall of Luminous Clarity receives the writ, it is promptly transmitted below without delay, and the grace of the celestial court is bestowed.

The Celestial Lord declares: Those who do not discuss the court’s decrees, entrusting them to others, and whose memorials are all balanced and just, shall know no grievance or dispute. Each receives their due portion of grace, with rewards and punishments meted out accordingly. How could there be contention over such distinctions?

The great sage foresees the affairs the Celestial Lord must enact—how could there be error? The common folk, unaware, liken this to a local magistrate—how could they comprehend the edicts and writs that ought to descend? In the celestial realm, voices carry afar, and nothing remains concealed. This is governed by the natural order of mutual verification—how could there be a moment of escape?

The Celestial Lord, day and night, foreknows all matters—great and small, hidden and subtle—within the harmony of heaven, earth, and the center. How could the myriad spirits act with impunity? Thus, the records of good and evil at the beginning and end are entrusted to the spirits for transcription. The Celestial Lord personally follows the monthly cyclical governance of the Dipper’s handle, ensuring no deviation from the constant intent. All is rectified, and none dare transgress.

Thus it is said: The celestial mind-spirit dwells within the human abdomen, gazing afar to heaven, voices carrying between them. How could the good and evil of the people remain unknown? The Celestial Lord promotes the good and trustworthy, demoting the evil and untrustworthy. Not only in heaven is this so, but also in the harmony of earth below.

People, failing to deeply understand future affairs, cultivate enduring resolve in their hearts, walking the same path as the great spirits—this is what heaven draws near. It is like a kingdom with loyal ministers and upright officials, never far from the ruler’s side. Yet people do not trust heaven—when would heaven ever trust those of two minds? Are those who do not serve heaven not inferior even to the common folk?

Even insects and ants—by what cause or condition do they gain the favor of heaven’s intent? Those who covetously cling to life yet fail to draw near in due time—calamity arises among the people, and the thirteen [lunar mansions] are gathered in the end, each with its allotted years. When the resolute, unmindful of worldly affairs, covet advancement and seek life, the spirits reveal their hearts.

Those of steadfast resolve may be engaged in discourse and entrusted with matters; those without resolve cannot. They consider only the mouths to feed, seeking profit, desiring warm clothes and full meals, with礼 and expense trailing behind. They drive the poor and weak, exalting themselves as lofty and wise—these are not the heart and mind of heaven. Their conduct lacks purity, yet they still seek the Dao and long life. This is precisely what cannot be obtained. Their transgressions are grave and weighty, with little hope of pardon.

Do you understand? Those who ascend in broad daylight, seeking life, have their names inscribed in the celestial register, recorded in the inner ledger of the Northern Culmen Celestial Lord, with copies of their allotted span. How could those without resolve have their names recorded? Those who forcefully study the Dao and gain heaven’s heart and mind may fulfill their celestial years.

Those who exert themselves with exceptional thought and effort, achieving merit, may have their names transferred from the register of death, gaining a lesser life. When shall they ride the refined qi and act as heaven’s agents?

Thus, one may know: When the writ moves the heart, tears flow in self-reproach, saying, “I, like the child of the tenth month, have acted, yet alone fail to meet the celestial intent, remaining among the ranks of the dead. What single act of mine has failed to please above? It is my own fault.”

Heaven, earth, and the harmony between them all ought to follow the grace of heaven, yet many do not believe—this is a grievous transgression. What can they hope for? The celestial spirits, hearing this, say, “This person reproaches and repents, sparing no day or night, accumulating years of merit. They may be pardoned.” They report this to the Celestial Lord.

The Celestial Lord declares: “Those who reproach and repent of their transgressions shall have the spirit of life’s register transfer them to the Bureau of Longevity. The hundred and twenty spirits shall grant them continued generations, providing descendants to the poor and reducing the progeny of the short-lived among the wealthy and noble.”

Why is this? The wealthy and noble, with descendants, grow powerful and self-sufficient, unafraid of heaven and earth. They lightly harm others, extinguishing lives, amassing wealth to obstruct, killing and injuring without number. Thus, heaven does not grant them descendants. If their evil does not cease, how could they be granted goodness and longevity?

Do you understand? The great spirits dispatch lesser spirits to transmit decrees, each receiving their mandate—matters of long and short span proceed without doubt. Reflect again upon the written words, knowing that even small thoughts afterward may have omissions or errors—these must be recorded.

**The Virtuous Person’s Register of Fortune and Destiny, One Hundred Eighty-One**

Only those of supreme virtue possess their own principles, deeply understanding affairs yet to come, illuminating above and below, with nothing left unopened. Their thoughts never depart from within, exhausting all they know to uphold the great transformation, rightly ordering all under heaven. What they ought to transmit is never amiss.

Their sincerity reaches the four directions, their intent ever in communication. They rectify the fundamental principles, establishing the stellar lodges in their proper places, arrayed in the four quarters. Each arrangement has its pattern, each action its constancy, their destinies linked above and below, each with its short or long span.

On the day of life’s inception, the overseer awaits in the chamber, recording and inscribing the register—nothing may be forgotten. Those born in the *zi* and *wu* [hours or years] have long destinies. Those born in the *chou* and *wei* [years] do not lose their earthly abode. If their lives are brief and meager, they ought not to commit evil, lest they be consigned to the earthly abode.

If their allotted span is not yet exhausted, their names remain recorded in the ledger. Though they encounter prosperous phases and monthly cyclical qi, their lives shall not be prolonged.

Thus it is that those born in the earthly abodes—where the domains of *Kun* and *Gen* lie—have their lifespans naturally diminished. Born on days aligned with the seasons, the three earthly phases gaze upon one another. Yet if one is born on such a day without advancement, their worth becomes as mere coin of their own making. From year to year, they seldom encounter favorable times.

In the years of *chen* and *xu*, where Heaven’s Gate meets Earth’s Door, and where the celestial and terrestrial soils converge, all things take their origin. The celestial soil gives rise to the grasses and trees above, the terrestrial soil to those below; the celestial soil produces sages and wise ones, while the earthly soil bears the virtuous. Though there be balances and ranks, they do not interfere with one another. Yet people, unaware of this, instead declare that years in *chen* and *xu* bring destructive clashes in the monthly cyclical *qi*, deeming them most inauspicious. Heaven’s Gate and Earth’s Door stand in opposition, yin and yang gaze upon each other, and birthdays align with their proper stations. When the day of *wu* once more aligns with the year’s birth, such a one is a person of great virtue, unobstructed in all things—rightly should they feel no fear. The earthly soil yields the virtuous, and the treasury of soil is their dwelling. What evil could there be? Yet people, not understanding, take soil as mere substance, all belonging to the earthly treasury.

Lifespans have their appointed terms: those aligned with sages become sages, those aligned with the virtuous become virtuous—this is the eternal law of Heaven, and their allotted destiny follows accordingly. Some may even attain transcendence. In the years of *yin* and *shen*, such persons resemble tigers. The sun and moon align, yet they cannot be compared. The reason lies in *yin* being the domain of literary refinement, the abode of wood, where mountain forests and fierce beasts cannot be withstood. They ought only to maintain purity and cleanliness, for Heaven sends them to hunt—but they should not be seen too often, for many fear them, and thus they are called tigers. Those born in the year of *yin* have long destinies, and if three *yin* years converge in their birth, they may endure for a great span. *Shen*, however, stands in opposition, never to be lost, yet they fear the night and can only climb trees up and down, beset by many terrors. Their destiny lies in metal, and their actions harm and wound others. Thus their lifespans are short—this is readily known. If they neglect the spirits or grow remiss, if they indulge in perverse and oppressive fears without constancy, they will seldom encounter favorable times.

In the destinies of *mao* and *you*, each aligns with its respective month, and their months coincide. *Mao* governs the East, striking the Eastern Star in its charge, fostering abundant livelihoods and the sustenance of the people. Thus *mao* is called the East, and the true *mao* stands at the East’s center. In spring, it brings flourishing blossoms; in summer, it ripens fruit—nothing it does not bestow, none it does not bless with virtue. Therefore, the Eastern Star is named *Ren* (Benevolence), for it cannot bear to harm. Heaven cherishes human lifespans, and thus grants them long years. Yet the true *you* lies in the domain of metal, delighting in strife and battle, and cannot endure long. To act wickedly is natural—how could one hope for long life? Even if they encounter the prosperous phases of the monthly cyclical *qi*, their fate remains unchanged. Of six or seven evils, half their days are lost—this, too, is readily known.

For those born in the years of *si* and *hai*, each is assigned its month, and their names are likewise given. With double yin and no yang, their lifespans are naturally short. When the three yin phases converge, it is said that *si* and *hai* govern the opening and storing away. *Hai* rules the Northwest, *si* the Southeast—whatever they face or undertake, little aligns with propriety. Their livelihoods are difficult to advance, and their lifespans hard to prolong. Thus it is said that the ten celestial stems circulate in mutual correspondence, their names denoting merit, and their reckoning subject to Heaven’s calculations. By measuring their short and long spans, destiny is determined—how could one follow their own will in Heaven’s workings? Therefore, those of great virtue now oversee these patterns, their names recorded in the registers of the stellar lodges, their destinies held in the celestial bureaus. Within and without, above and below, in all eight directions, all follow these principles—how could one act as they please?

People, not grasping these calculations, instead ask what debt they owe to Heaven. By doing good, one may fulfill their allotted years; by doing evil, they forfeit length for brevity. If wickedness is not halted, calamity extends even to the unborn—what hope can there be? One reaps what one sows. If their destiny is meager and they do not exhaust their allotted span, their surplus is stored in Heaven to be bestowed upon the virtuous. They ought to warn their descendants to be cautious. If they repent and correct their ways, they may yet complete their years—each outcome is clear. Let them tally their deeds and not resent the celestial spirits.

Strive to do good, and your descendants shall enjoy long years; otherwise, the fault lies with you—blame not Heaven. If one first rectifies themselves but later wavers, they should reflect and restore balance. The noble and benevolent naturally cherish their years, as recorded in the *Life Bureau’s Verdicts*, Scroll One Hundred Eighty-Two.

Only the Most High’s virtuous ones conduct themselves thus: they foreknow the inner and outer workings of Heaven and Earth, moving in and out of yin and yang, guiding their principles, and awakening to the thoughts within—never forgetting the Dao. They act in accord with Heaven, daring not to doubt, and thus succeed, upholding Heaven’s great bestowals. Their thoughts dwell within, their actions bear no transgressions, subtly receiving the natural order. They repeatedly encounter warnings—past and future are known. If people bring harm upon themselves, they have no one to blame.

Since ancient times, few have been trustworthy. Those who claim trustworthiness seek only to deceive, heedless of the consequences. Thus Heaven and Earth grow dark with unceasing wrath, and even the wise and sagely, though they know, can only regret. Heaven instructs through its own ways, not through human words. Yet people turn away with malice, ignoring admonitions, seeking only their own satisfaction. Such people are more ignorant than beasts. For this reason, they ought to reproach themselves for their faults—from where does their recklessness arise? Day and night, they should reflect on their failings, relentlessly examining their transgressions—what cause have they to resent or blame? Yet they remain unrepentant, heedless of their faults, acting recklessly and inappropriately. They do not heed the great teachings but instead indulge themselves, shortening their own lives—what cause have they to resent or blame?

At times, they recall the transcendent ones of high antiquity who ascended and escaped the world—how did such thoughts arise? In all the writings they see, it is said: be loyal and filial, honor and serve your parents, live in harmony with your siblings, without inner or outer discord, in unity above and below, knowing Heaven’s prohibitions. Let the spirits govern the principles, openly acknowledging faults without ceasing, cultivating the self and reflecting inward—only then may one attain life. Lifespans have their appointed terms—how can one act as they please? The thought pains the heart, tears soak the garments, and there is no end to the sorrow. They cherish their years, fearing they may not live long. When they see those of long life and inquire of them, they are told: be loyal and filial, never losing the intent of Heaven and Earth; assist the four seasons in their generation, aid the Five Phases in their completion, and dare not destroy the things that ought to live.

Those who do good never encroach upon others, deceive, or betray; they are sincere and trustworthy, never daring to break their word. Their conduct wins the favor of the multitude, and they dare not fail their kin or bring harm to their village, always repaying what they owe in due time. They never lie drunk in the streets in broad daylight. The worthy and wise follow them, paying no heed to fools. They bear gratitude toward Heaven and Earth, never expecting repayment, only reproaching themselves. Yet when faults recur, they trace their origins to inherited burdens, reproaching themselves for years on end until moved to remorse.

Worldly folk commit many transgressions and debts, never finding release. They walk in sorrow and bitterness, not knowing where to turn. Whenever they see others at fault, they turn to blame themselves, unable to find peace. They seek out virtuous texts and precepts, hoping for good fortune, and when they encounter the sacred scriptures of Heaven’s great spirits, they ponder them again and again, their thoughts consumed without end. They bow their heads, strike their breasts, and weep aloud, their bodies unable to correct themselves, yet full of grievance. The weight of the prohibitions presses upon them, and they transgress, shortening their lives. Day and night, they repent.

Hoping for even a brief reprieve, they dare not commit further wrongs. Instead, they resolve to practice kindness and bestow alms, striving to grasp the principles. No harsh words pass their lips—only tears, their hearts filled with sorrow. The heavenly spirits hear and descend to ask: “Who is this person, so full of grief?” They observe one of great virtue, whose life is long and enduring. When asked, they say: “This one merely acts in accord with Heaven’s heart and Earth’s intent—thus they attain longevity.”

Returning to their quiet dwelling, they reflect as the virtuous of the Highest Dao have taught, examining themselves. When the spirits see their remorse and repentance, they ascend to report to the Way of Heaven: “There is one who weeps and laments without ceasing, fearing they will not live, and so reproaches themselves.” The great spirits hear and say: “The Heavenly Lord has often commanded the spirits: those who perform good deeds, are loyal and filial, and obedient—such words refer to this person alone.” They then report to the Heavenly Lord, who says: “I have heard that this person has reproached themselves for their faults for many years. Though once a worldly person, their unceasing self-reproach has made them one of the highest good.”

The great spirits frequently visit to observe their conduct, discerning whether their intentions are virtuous and if they seek advancement. Their destined years are then recorded in the Bureau of Longevity, where their deeds are reviewed to make up for any deficiencies. The great spirits say: “This person has reproached themselves for so long that their inherited burdens are dissolved. We request that their deficiencies be filled, and they be named a virtuous one of the Highest Dao, to repay those below who have fallen short.” The Heavenly Lord says: “The conduct of the virtuous of the Highest Dao must be as you have said.” The great spirits repeatedly command that they be protected and guided to ascend as spirits, ensuring their allotted years are not diminished.

The great spirits say: “This person was originally without a recorded name, but by decree, they have been placed in the Bureau of Longevity. We request that their deficiencies be filled in order, without skipping ranks.” The Heavenly Lord says: “When the day comes to fill the vacancies in order, their names shall be repeatedly submitted without missing the appointed time.” The great spirits assent.

Only the benevolent of the Highest Dao accumulate merit and deeds in Heaven. Heaven heeds and trusts them, sending them to assist the Eastern Star in arranging the creatures that ought to live, providing blossoms and fruits to nourish the people, ensuring warmth and fullness. Their bodies grow strong, nurturing one another in turn; yin and yang unite, and male and female take form. Old and young follow in succession, receiving their destined lifespans from Heaven’s decree. Among the twenty-eight constellations, they revolve and complete one another; the sun and moon illuminate and inspect without fail, taking turns to generate life—how could there be rest?

Yet people do not understand, believing each to be self-governing. Though names may imply autonomy, they are in fact mutually restrained. The reason is this: human lives have varying lengths, and the seasons of spring, autumn, winter, and summer bring constant cycles of life and death. Thus, they are made to govern one another, transferring and inquiring in turn. Lifespans increase or decrease, passing from one to another. Therefore, it is said that the four seasons, Five Phases, sun, moon, and stars all hold sway over life. The good are granted increase, while the wicked retreat on their own. The severity of transgressions is measured by unchanging laws—how can one escape if the laws are followed as they should be?

Heaven above and Earth below support one another like the outer and inner, with various spirits also working in concert. Thus, it is said that the Heavenly Lord commands the bureaus, each transferring their duties in turn, taking up their respective talismans without the slightest partiality. From above, they observe below—how could there be failure? Those of inherent nature, free from ill intent, may commit minor wrongs but repent of their deeds, and their faults are dissolved. Their records are regularly entered into the registers: the wicked are sent to the lower bureaus, while the good are reported as good, and the wicked as wicked. The spirits of fortune and misfortune each follow where they are assigned. If the wicked repent, their names are transferred to the registers of the good. If the good turn to evil, they are moved to the registers of the wicked—how could there be rest?

Among the living on Earth, even those still in the womb have their names and destinies recorded in the Register of the Undying. When their years are fulfilled and their conduct complete, those who are born are recorded, and those with guarantors are elevated. The reason is this: their lifespans are difficult to sustain, so their guarantors are held accountable for any transgressions. Thus, those who are neither loyal, filial, obedient, nor meritorious have no guarantors—they merely continue the merits of their ancestors, ensuring sacrifices are made. Yet if they persist in evil without cease, how can they expect to partake in future generations’ sustenance?

How could those who feed on filth ever hope to serve alongside the great spirits of Heaven for long? Even among the filth, there are those who respond to Heaven’s scriptures and are sent divine teachings. When the appointed time arrives, the Heavenly Lord commands the guardian spirits of the Great Heavenly Granary to sever their attachment to material forms. They are nourished by the qi of the Great Heavenly Granary, their bodies refined and their spirits lightened, moving between the profound and the obscure. Their names are then recorded, no longer in the ledgers—how could they seek life? How could people know of this?

If one is good and never loses Heaven’s heart, the great spirits stir their mind, making them delight in life, whether they follow the Dao or remain worldly. The reason is this: if one commits evil without a single good deed, merely coveting fine clothes and carriages, following their desires without restraint, their allotted lifespan will not be fulfilled—but Heaven and Earth will not deny their wishes either.

The wicked shall not long behold the sun, moon, and stars of Heaven, but must return to the eternal night—how could they remain? Such persons, unable to discipline themselves toward goodness, are known to Heaven for their enduring evil, and thus are made to consume only the food of form. They are buried beneath the earth, becoming servants to the earth spirits, never to be reborn. This is why the scriptures reveal it, that they may know.

Some undergo *shijie* (corpse liberation), their forms dividing: the bones and body separate. The corpse remains in one place, while the spirit becomes a wandering phantom, appearing to people as though dead. Yet those who understand may see them still alive—these are the *shijie* immortals. Over time, as their years and merits accumulate, they next ascend in broad daylight to Heaven. When their merits and years are complete, their radiance shines forth, aiding the celestial spirits in their all-pervading work. They return to dwell among the clouds, and within their appointed domains, all are *shijie* immortals who govern the affairs of humans and ghosts.

In the families of the Dao, those who depart may be enfeoffed as the most revered of spirits, known as *Dilingqi* (Earthly Numinous Spirits). They, too, may wear the purple, mugwort-green, and yellow. Their governance extends above and below, with each ascending to their proper station. If one’s evil is heard of, they may be demoted to consort with ghosts—do you not understand? Thus it is said: the paths of life and death diverge; how could they be compared?

Proceed, and when minor transgressions arise, still the mind and reflect. For those who later falter or fall short, this shall be explained. Only the actions of the Most High’s good persons manifest the affairs Heaven and Earth must carry out. Each has their charge, each their words, each their cultivation, each their spiritual attainment, each their merit, each their loyalty, each their governance, each their bestowal upon others, each their advancement in the Dao. Each gains the trust of Heaven and Earth, each does not lose the generative and transformative cycles of the four seasons and five phases.

Thus, those who respond to the goodness of the Most High are Heaven’s faithful and Earth’s safeguarded. All attain the harmonious heart-mind of Heaven and Earth, understanding the ebb and flow of human affairs, carrying out commands without daring to defy the will of the Great Sages. Below, they do not transgress the prohibitions of the myriad spirits. They constantly strive to perfect others, making them delight in goodness. They align with the hearts of Heaven and Earth, their inner and outer selves in accord, achieving success in their persons and attaining longevity. Their names are inscribed in the ledgers of the undying, and they serve alongside the great spirits in their appointed roles.

They discern right from wrong, their loyalty and sincerity directed to Heaven. They behold the sun, moon, and stars without losing the measure of the Dao, nor straying from their resolve. Constantly desiring to live, they contemplate serving Heaven’s transformation and understanding Earth’s principles. Their hearts rejoice, for they know the registers of fortune and misfortune, the affairs of survival and demise, and aspire to walk the same path as the natural order. Even slight greed or evil is seen, and the great spirits’ admonitions stir compassion for the unenlightened, illuminating their shortcomings so they may enter the records of long life. They witness the Celestial Lords bestowing life upon them, their names enduring in the ledgers of the undying.

They perform the affairs of Heaven above and comprehend Earth’s principles below. What they see and hear is vast: their eyes are bright, their ears keen, and they know the boundless past and future. Their writings and words are clear, and they grasp the essential and wondrous. Such is the aspiration of the Most High’s good persons. Only the great celestial spirits perceive and guide their wishes, as they yearn for the natural and inscribe their deeds in harmony with the generative *qi*, without end.

It is ever said: Heaven does not deny a person’s wishes, nor does Earth deny their peace. Thus, the natural order dares not bear even a hair’s weight of entanglement to trouble the spirits, so deeply do they cherish the written word. Day and night, they reflect on their failings, fearing they may fall short of the Most High Lord’s intent. What do they惜 or love that they would not exhaust their loyalty, sincerity, and filial piety? They must declare the grace they have received, the honor bestowed, without thought of repayment. Heaven’s heart holds them in profound love, yet they reproach themselves for their faults, offering little in forgiveness.

Only the great spirits may pardon and admonish them, not out of attachment but from compassion. They dare not distance themselves, constantly mindful of the unrepayed grace, their sins clinging to them. Fearful of being unable to explain or absolve, they can only grieve. Though pardoned and shown leniency, they are made to reflect on their failings.

The great spirits say: The Most High’s good persons reflect on their transgressions and reproach themselves; their words and writings ascend to be heard above. Their words extend far, yet they fear being misunderstood. Heaven’s faithfulness especially honors them, and they may attain boundless longevity. They should set their hearts afar, never forgetting the great gifts bestowed by Heaven’s generative power.

The Most High Lord praises them, saying: Life arises from the mandate of good life, unconcerned with wealth or sensuality. Seeing others live, they constantly desire to share in their longevity—when would they act recklessly or without heart, failing to repay such profound grace? They only regret that, since their years began, they have not seen the great measure of Heaven’s bounty. Only by receiving the grace of teachings and admonitions do they understand their allotted principles. They say: Knowing fate, they do not resent Heaven, nor dare they resent themselves and hinder life. How could their hearts harbor greed? They only fear their years may end before witnessing Heaven’s great dispensation of its ordered domains.

The Most High again admonishes the ignorant and benighted, granting them the wisdom to reflect—a great grace beyond words. They must concentrate their hearts and minds, ever mindful within, never forgetting their hunger and thirst, seeking the precepts and the living. Only by receiving pardon and leniency may they proceed.

The great spirits say: We originally advanced to the Celestial Lords from among the spirits, without the slightest fault, aiding Heaven and Earth with meritorious deeds. Our names are recorded in the Celestial Lords’ ledgers—when could we ever be forgotten? We humbly present our words of self-reproach, for we have long yearned for Heaven’s transformation. Are such persons recorded in the ledgers or not?

The Celestial Lord says: Those who reproach themselves act in accord with the natural order and are aided by the spirits. Let those who oversee the celestial registers examine them. If they have reproached themselves, the spirit in charge of the living ledgers is commanded to review the records, and their names are indeed found therein.

The Celestial Lord says: Those who conduct themselves well from birth, transgressing no prohibitions, achieve this through their own actions. The great spirits should further investigate, for there may be omissions in the records of those who have rendered service.

The great spirits say: Since the Great Beginning, those spirits whose merits have gained Heaven’s favor have advanced—yet there remain some vacancies.

If there are persons whose conduct merits it, their names should be duly recorded above.

The Celestial Lord says: The duties of your offices are many and onerous. Calculate their merits and offset their transgressions, ensuring they no longer violate what has been decreed.

The great spirits say: These most exalted persons naturally follow the correct path, and their faults and burdens are few.

The Celestial Lord says: Reconsider them. If any remain uncommended, hold their guarantors accountable to fill the vacancies.

The Celestial Lord says: Matters of this court must not be treated carelessly.

The great spirits say: As your decree states, before a hundred days have passed, the spirits of Heaven will vie to vouch for them, and we great spirits shall report our judgment.

The Celestial Lord says: Let each be assigned to their fitting role, sent to attend to their duties, and thus gain further esteem. Those who are trustworthy shall be appointed as Perfected.

The great spirits say: Let us dispatch envoys to summon them above, first transforming their appearance.

The spirit-envoys go forth, and their transformations shine with abundant radiance.

The great spirits say: Report back.

The Celestial Lord says: The person has already transformed into a spirit and now stands outside the gate, not yet having entered.

The Celestial Lord says: Let them proceed to the office of the overseer to pay their respects.

The great spirits say: We shall report as the great spirits have stated.

Yes, yes. Let the report be made as stated, and we shall observe their conduct accordingly.

The Celestial Lord says: It shall be as the great spirits have reported.

**Dialogue on the Longing of the Knowing to Meet the Great Spirits, One Hundred Eighty-Third**

Only those of supreme knowledge, the Knowing Ones of the Most High, foreknow the affairs of Heaven and understand what should be done and what should be upheld. Their actions arise naturally, and when primal qi converges upon them, they attain maturity—all becomes clear and known. They transform their hearts to accord with the natural, residing in what they do. Thus, the Knowing Ones comprehend both inner and outer, and in all their comings and goings, nothing fails to reach fulfillment. Nothing remains unachieved, and all transformations occur in due time. Revering the majesty of the spirits, they perfect their merit and name their virtue. Ever unwavering in loyalty and trust, never remiss, day and night they grieve and tremble, never departing from their inner resolve. Inclining and yearning, they long to achieve union and meet the great spirits. Through discourse and the exchange of words, they practice the Way they follow and advance what they know. Constantly contemplating success, they render grace to the spirits, prolonging life and increasing years. Thus, the Knowing Ones look inward to see outward—what is there they do not know? What is there they do not perceive? Their minds are clear and their thoughts distinct. They but crave the Way of long life, desiring to mount the carriage and serve as envoys for the great spirits. Wherever they arrive, they dare not speak falsely, responding in the moment as if already present, longing for their hearts to open. Receiving the words of the spirits as the spirits themselves do, knowing the spirits’ actions, they act with self-assurance and only then dare to speak, seeking merely to be granted life and audience. They dare not seek high office, only to be shown mercy. Though they witness matters of life and death, their hearts tremble with fear. Having received the great teachings, they must act to communicate them, bestowing grace and spreading kindness, benefiting those above and those below. Their names are inscribed in the ledgers, and they abide in the ranks of the undying. Their hearts rejoice and delight, exhausting their efforts in service to the Celestial Lord. Over the years, their merits accumulate, and they advance in speech.

Only by the great spirits’ intercession for their insufficiencies, knowing the weight of their words, do they thus crave advancement. Receiving their secret decrees, they roam the gates and chambers, daring not rest, desiring instruction and admonition to remedy their shortcomings. They wish to be examined and not contradict what is said, awaiting the commands and warnings of the great spirits’ words.

The Knowing Ones of the Most High perceive much, yet they cannot fully know the bounds of Heaven’s domains—what then should they be cautioned against? The spirits of Heaven all observe them. The words of the Knowing Ones of the Most High are but to know what is spoken, what is taught, and what is practiced—what cause for doubt is there?

The Celestial Lord says: Constantly command the spirits to advance the names of those who are loyal, filial, sincere, trustworthy, and meritorious. These Knowing Ones of the Most High, coveted by their allotted destinies, thus clarify their hearts.

Yet they fear that their written words are but their own speech—why would they withhold reverence for Heaven’s teachings and admonitions? They often say they suffer from having no scribe to respond, fearing that inner and outer may not correspond. If they wish to advance their knowledge and understanding, broadening inquiry and deepening comprehension, this too is what they should know.

Proceed, and heed the words of the great spirits. Heaven’s heavy admonitions must not be treated lightly, must not be disrespected, must not be held in awe too little—only then is it possible. The admonitions are many; one must grasp their essentials and further open one’s ears, eyes, and heart.

Yes, yes.

Thus, emerging from within, the great admonitions of Heaven decree that all who seek advancement and long life must advance what they know. To know and not speak is to listen in vain—this is to lack the heart for self-advancement. Those whose hearts hold knowledge must contemplate advancement. Those with aspirations must advance their aspirations. Those with sincerity must advance their sincerity. Those with filial piety must advance their filial piety. Only thus do they become the heart and core of Heaven—nothing must be left unadvanced.

The Celestial Lord foreknows human sentiments and permits no failure to advance or to expound the Way. To conceal knowledge and hide abilities—Heaven detests such persons, ensuring they do not appear in the ledgers of longevity. Is this not to know?

Not only do they not appear in the ledgers of longevity, but their essence is first lost, departing from their bodies, and their years perish. Can they not be cautious?

The Knowing Ones of the Most High act thus because the Celestial Lord knows what is known and what is not. They know themselves—what doubt remains? They need only carefully ponder the spirits’ words and not betray them.

The Knowing Ones of the Most High, though lowly and ignorant, press forward with questions beyond their reach, desiring to be granted what they do not know. How dare they conceal knowledge or hide abilities, causing the Celestial Lord and the spirits to hear of it and further forfeit their lives and lose their years, shortening their longevity? This is the root of calamity and misfortune, and even the destruction of their bodies would not suffice to repay it. How dare they advance thus?

Only may the great spirits illuminate and pardon their inadequacies.

The great spirits say: Those who seek life and abhor death naturally possess hearts and aspirations that cannot be otherwise. Yet they fear there may be times of confusion.

The one seeking life says: "I myself know not the precepts, yet by the great spirits’ gracious forbearance, I am taught thus. How dare I grow complacent and not advance what I know and what I can say? May only the great spirits record what has come before and not dismiss it."

The great spirits say: "What has come before is not easily matched. Only those who preserve trust and faith can align with the Celestial Lord’s will and thus hope for life. Take heed of this."

The seeker, truly coveting life, therefore exhausts his loyalty and sincerity, never daring to slacken or rest. He reflects on his faults and reproaches himself—how dare he waste day or night? The Celestial Lord, having heard his words, says: "This is the speech of one who possesses knowledge in the Most High." It is known that this person’s name appears in the ledgers, though with some deficiencies. The spirits charged with the living registers are commanded to examine the ledgers where this person’s name is recorded. Though his name is listed and he is naturally good and knowledgeable, he must fulfill his years and not lose track of the spirits governing his months and years.

"Yes, yes."

**Method for Accumulating Conduct to Repair the True Self, Scroll 184**

Only those of the Most High who possess intention each know their allotted portion. Each has their own Dao, their own conduct, their own offerings, their own advancement, their own declarations, their own words, their own destinations, and their own movements. If the heart is not stirred within, they constantly strive to fulfill loyalty, trust, and filial piety. Truly, they render service to Heaven, accumulating conduct over the years without ever slackening. Yet they do not forget gratitude or their allotted portion, ever mindful of their desire for life. Having received the protection of the host of spirits above, they dare not withhold even the smallest part. They constantly harbor a fearful heart, never at ease, seeking the precepts of the Most High to preserve their lives. How dare they forget the great bestowal of grace?

May the great spirits deign to glance upon their inadequacies. Their hearts ever long for the affairs of the Most High, and what they ought to practice—compass and square, plumb line and inked cord—naturally earns trust. Gazing toward the four quarters, they comprehend the four corners. What Heaven knows, they manifest before it comes to pass. Their hearts contemplate the great spirits’ memorials and communications, what they advance and what they declare. They dare not evaluate these with their own minds but constantly consult with the assembled spirits to determine what may be adopted or not, ever fearful of failing to win the hearts of the spirits.

They consider themselves fundamentally upright, without error. As if moved from the depths of their being, they constantly cherish the preservation of life that harms nothing. Previously, they coveted its radiance, reaching upward to the sound without essence or form, penetrating the Most High’s commands to advance. They dare not grow lax and thereby obstruct the great transformation.

May the spirits examine their desire for life and not depart from the great spirits’ left side. Upon seeing the precepts, their hearts open and their eyes brighten, desiring to abide by the scripture of longevity, to increase their years and lifespan. They strive to advance merit, personally engaging without daring to trust themselves or presume to judge right and wrong, contending over what is insufficient. They yearn for those above to be ever diligent, only beseeching compassionate illumination of the precepts.

When will their gratitude and devotion ever cease? Their hearts long day and night to meet, coveting knowledge of prohibitions and transgressions to stir their minds and thereby perceive their own inadequacies. These are not matters to be repaid with mere words; only by receiving examination may their thoughts pierce the heart’s diaphragm.

The great spirits say: "This is one of the Most High who possesses intention—his conduct is indeed fitting. Seeking to receive Heaven’s solemn precepts and prohibitions, he who possesses knowledge is fundamentally clear and discerning, distinguishing principle. What precepts does he not understand? Holding the heart to aim at the heart, there is no gap for selfishness. From above to below, all know their own master.

Now, those of the Most High who possess intention are close to Heaven and trusted by the celestial spirits. They need only hold fast to their hearts and minds, ever fearful of losing them. The rest is known to their own hearts. They must strive to transmit, widely inquire, and not lose what is said. Those who possess knowledge are mostly clear in their distinctions, only fearing that at times their actions may not match their words. Why suspect they would not openly explain? Such a person, possessing intention, naturally reflects on his faults and debts.

Simply contemplating what lies before and behind, longevity naturally emerges from within, aligning with the Celestial Lord’s heart. The remainder of the precepts for those who possess intention say: This seeker was originally a rustic, seeing those who lived long and aged gracefully, their vital essence and fluids flowing without loss, never witnessing their decline. Though many study, few attain it. Why? Because they do not hold their hearts with utmost care, lightly regarding what is said. Their strategies and records are not fitting, thus making attainment rare.

Now, this seeker, seeing the conduct of those who came before, further corrects and reforms his bearing, opening his heart to retain it. Desiring to raise his voice, he listens well, coveting longevity and cherishing his years. Thus, he dare not slacken or rest. May only the great spirits examine his inadequacies."

The great spirits say: "Those who possess intention shall be granted registration in the ledgers. We request the clerks of the registers to examine the ledgers for this person’s name and report to the Celestial Lord. The great spirits may not act on their own."

The seeker says: "May only the great spirits consider and discuss this. I dare not distance myself, lingering outside, but will personally prove my worth."

The great spirits say: "We request to report the names of those registered in the ledgers. Why suspect they would not correspond?"

The seeker says: "May only the great spirits report on my behalf. On the day of accomplishment, I will devote my life to proving my worth. What need is there to hope for repayment?"

The great spirits report to the Celestial Lord: "Those of the Most High who possess intention all hold their hearts firmly and closely, their aspirations ever coveting the heights and possessing faith. Command the spirits in charge to examine them. If such a person exists, advance and report to the great spirits. Command those in charge to examine whether this person’s name appears in the documents. This person’s name was recorded before his birth."

The great spirits report back: "This person’s name was recorded before his birth, solely by the grace of the Most High."

The Celestial Lord says: "Those recorded in the ledgers shall be seen to ascend. They must take responsibility for their debts and burdens. Command the great spirits to remove the tally of their debts and burdens, to transform their hearts, and to refine them into spirits. When their years are fulfilled, they shall advance."

The great spirits say: "This person’s years and calculations are complete, exceeding the term by a hundred days. Previously, there was no certainty, so for now, it is halted."

The Celestial Lord says: "Command the great spirits to ascend for now, assigning them to their posts in the interim. Where there are vacancies for the true, let them be filled by those who can exhaust their essence and devote their will, knowing how to eliminate and act concurrently."

The great spirits say: "We request to ascend as the Celestial Lord has commanded. Let their refined lifespans and calculations be recalculated. Those who are enlightened shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight."

The Celestial Lord says: "This is what those of sincere heart ought to do, that they may have something to govern."

The great spirits assent.

They request to command the proper officials to carry out the affairs according to the original text.

The great spirits say: "Report to the Ascension Bureau."

The petitioners report to the great spirits, saying: "Request to command the officials of the Bureau."

The officials having reported, they are assigned to interim posts, and where there are vacancies for the true, they are to be filled.

The Celestial Lord says: "As reported by the Bureau."

To the right: In heaven above, good deeds are to be concealed, while misfortune and calamity arise from their disclosure.

*End of Scroll One Hundred Eleven of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Scroll One Hundred Twelve of the Scripture of Great Peace*
*Disaster of Coveting Wealth and Lust, and Admonitions Within the Womb, One Hundred Eighty-Five*

In ancient times, the formless divine persons sought the Dao of life.
