Heaven observes their conduct and further favors them, ensuring that in all their goings and outgoings, none dare offend them. Those who practice goodness—Heaven itself assists them, preventing them from encountering misfortune, for such is the outcome of their deeds.

As for those who do evil yet hope to attain longevity and descendants, this is a failure to discern. Thus, Heaven distinguishes their lifespans: those who can perform the deeds of Heaven, aligning their hearts and wills with the Dao, may attain transcendence, be recorded among the worthy and sagely, and have their spirits augmented—how limitless their years shall be! Therefore, it is said that goodness must not be neglected, for it is beyond what most can achieve. Thus, Heaven cherishes those who are good and does not wish them to harbor evil.

The good and the wicked each have their allotted place—how could they be equated? The words of Heaven’s scriptures are clear: the good are rewarded with goodness, while the wicked are warned, lest they fall into peril and forfeit their years. This is Heaven’s way: it extends the lives of the good and reduces the wicked to less than human—this is plain to see, so why doubt it?

From birth to old age, a person naturally begets children and grandchildren, raising them to maturity and fulfillment. One should follow their inclinations, ensuring their contentment, never opposing their wishes, so each may find their proper place and fulfill their desires. To be a parent is no easy task, and children, in turn, must be filial, heeding their parents’ teachings. Thus, the bones, flesh, and limbs of the good remain whole, and what parents have begotten should be kept intact, free from harm or injury.

What parents have given, one must not dare to repay with words; rather, when there is goodness, it should be advanced. If the household lacks wealth, one should be reverent, gentle, and tender, frequently inquiring after their well-being to know their safety—this is the highest form of goodness. Neighbors and close kin should all be treated with love and emulation, perfecting the practice of goodness.

When encountering violent and wicked people, one must not dare to engage them in speech, lest conflict arise. Once conflict arises, the good person’s virtue is lost, and Heaven, too, comes to detest them. Thus, all must value and guard themselves, lest their descendants suffer. Beware of transgressing prohibitions, lest the household be unsettled—not only unsettled, but affecting kin both near and far. Disturbances within and without may lead to encounters with officials, the loss of property, and ruin.

Therefore, one must be cautious and not violate the words of the scriptures. Those who can foster harmony and peace, without duplicity, each attending to their own duties and accomplishing their tasks—such are the deeds of the truly good. Heaven will surely grant them long life, and spirits and gods will protect them, never failing in their care. The offerings made in the four seasons follow their proper order, and in the marketplace, they select the finest goods without haggling over prices.

The reason for this is that all offerings possess spirit; they ascend and descend in accord with their due, and even slight impurities will be recorded in writing, never overlooked. Thus, one must follow the path of commerce with reverence, and the divine spirits will surely rejoice. They report to the Registrar of Destinies, and the officials of the ancestral shrines proceed in peace. If one personally ensures the purity of the incense, the offerings are accepted, and after the meal, the Five Ancestors are greatly venerated. Then, the food is consumed in its proper place, and all partake with joy.

The household prospers, and the children and grandchildren are all good, without a single wicked child. The commanderies and counties hear of this and summon them to serve as officials of rank, promoting them to the prefecture, where they are assigned prominent positions. The province, too, learns of them and summons them to serve in close proximity, recommending them for their integrity and outstanding talent—such is the result of goodness. Their conduct brings its own reward, and their position is assured. This is also the workings of fate and the allotment of destiny, a clear sign of their virtue, so that evil does not pass their door.

All the gods in Heaven declare that such conduct is especially good—only the will of Heaven remains unknown. Thus, the good texts record the deeds of the good on bamboo and silk, so that later generations may be inspired to advance, perpetuating the goodness of the household for generations. Their descendants never leave the court, beloved by emperors and kings, ever holding virtuous offices—such merit arises naturally, all from the blessings they have earned.

Therefore, those who practice goodness should take this scripture as their model, for its words are trustworthy and not empty. **Above: Heaven’s discourse on filial piety to quell rebellion, repel the barbarians, and bring the world into compliance and ease of governance.**

*This concludes the one hundred fourteenth scroll of the* Scripture of Great Peace.

*(According to the Dunhuang manuscript* Catalogue of the Scripture of Great Peace*, this chapter should be titled* “The Secret of Filial Conduct Revered by the Divine.”*)*

**Scroll One Hundred Sixteen of the** *Scripture of Great Peace*
**A Certain Secret, Number Two Hundred Four**

(Previous text lost)

Their qi converges, aligning with the emperor’s affairs—shared joy, shared heart, shared direction, shared course, shared pivot, shared root, shared intent. Thus the sages of old established the laws, assigning the emperor to the east in spring, the south in summer, the west in autumn, and the north in winter, to act in concert with Heaven’s qi. When qi is aligned, they meet in harmony. This is what is meant by carefully following the Dao of Heaven, sharing Heaven’s qi—thus they respond in accord and find joy. The harmony spoken of by the ruler is this mutual joy. When there is mutual joy, Heaven and Earth remain ever pleased, without strife or anger. Without strife or anger, disasters, harms, treacheries, and all malign forces vanish entirely. Once malign people are gone, the qi of peace arrives. The qi of peace from Heaven descends to govern below, while the qi of peace from Earth ascends to assist above.

If one does not follow this joy, using the qi that the August Heaven and Earth favor, but instead employs abandoned qi, all will fall into disorder and opposition—opposing the Dao of Heaven and Earth, opposing the emperor’s qi, acting contrary to the intent of Heaven and Earth. Heaven and Earth will rage in conflict, myriad changes arise together, treachery and malice flourish daily, leading to unrest and disorder, and the qi of inauspicious years will come. Thus one must deeply understand this.

Excellent, excellent! This foolish student has heard the command. Is it not clear? Heaven delights in this—O Perfected One, be vigilant.

Indeed, indeed. I shall carefully record it and dare not forget.

Excellent, excellent! Since the Heavenly Illuminated Master has no choice but to elaborate, I wish to hear how spring, summer, autumn, and winter each follow their qi according to their proper measures.

Only the sixth month differs: on the summer solstice, the *gong* tone is activated, and throughout the fifth and sixth months, it is purely the *gong* tone. Moreover, in music, one raises the voice in song and dance. The qi of kingship should be stirred—stirring reveals joy, and mutual compliance reveals mutual assistance. The qi of rest, imprisonment, and death all desire stillness and do not wish to be stirred. If stirred, they become displeased, then enraged, and from rage arise malign forces, treachery, disasters, and harms. This is the natural disposition of Heaven and Earth, not erring even once.

Which qi should be stirred? I wish to hear this as a model and dare not oppose a single qi.

One should first stir the emperor’s qi, then the king’s qi, then the minister’s qi, then the observer’s qi, and finally the subtle qi. These qi all lie before the Celestial Dipper, advancing daily to offer assistance and flourishing—thus they are stirred. The remaining qi lie behind the Celestial Dipper, where Heaven’s qi turns away, and their qi wanes daily. Thus they should not be stirred, for to do so would oppose Heaven and rebel against Earth, failing to align with the heart of Heaven and Earth—hence, it is inauspicious. Therefore, what Heaven faces is flourished, and what Heaven turns from is abandoned. This is how to know the seasons and qi, and from this, good and ill fortune, safety and peril may be discerned.

May I ask: if only the king’s tone is stirred, and the five tones are incomplete, how can a proper song and dance be formed?

Excellent, your question! The reason is simply that when the regulators of yin and yang are first stirred, movement produces sound. Thus, when music moves, it always accompanies sound. Yang has sound—hence the first *gong*, third *zhi*, fifth *yu*, seventh *shang*, and ninth *jiao*—while the second, fourth, sixth, and eighth are not named as tones. Punishment belongs to great yin, which acts without sound, thus subtly harming people. "Acting without sound" refers to this.

Then why does the military commander have sound?

Excellent question! The military commander of a nobleman does have sound, but it is merely the music of challenge and retreat, not intended to cause harm. Only when rage erupts and harm is imminent does sound arise from within, and they no longer communicate with words.

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Truly so—now even the slightly foolish student has awakened.

Thus, the sages of antiquity, when preparing to follow the Way of music, bore it on their left; when preparing to follow the Way of punishment, bore it on their right. Auspicious affairs honor the left; inauspicious affairs honor the right. The left belongs to yang; the right belongs to yin—each follows its own kind.

Excellent, excellent!

Therefore, in my affairs of culture, I follow Heaven in intent and Earth in principle. Those who comply find fortune and prosperity; those who resist meet misfortune. If one’s intent differs from Heaven’s, what can one hope for?

Thus, Heaven possesses three qi: the upper qi is called *music*, the middle qi is called *harmony*, and the lower qi is called *punishment*. Music belongs to yang; punishment belongs to yin; harmony belongs to the center.

Therefore, the southeast—yang and music—loves life; the northwest—yin and rage—loves killing. The qi of harmony follows, coming and going, now hidden, now revealed, to avoid harm. Thus, music should only accompany auspicious affairs and matters of life; it must not be used for inauspicious affairs or matters of death. This is the celestial pattern and law—it cannot be reversed.

Perfected One, heed my words with care.

Indeed, indeed.

Now, why do you speak of sound only in terms of the first *jia* day, without explaining it fully? How can one come to know all its applications?

It is proper to collate and compare the writings of all sages and worthies, each drawing from their own school, so that entry and exit, high and low, great and small, all correspond. Use one to illuminate ten, ten to illuminate a hundred, a hundred to illuminate a thousand, a thousand to illuminate ten thousand, ten thousand to illuminate the boundless. When all worthies deliberate together, nothing remains ungrasped. Thus, I merely present the beginning to you and do not exhaust every detail.

The superior person, upon seeing my text, will naturally grasp its full meaning. The middling person, upon seeing it, may yet ascend to understanding. The petty person, upon seeing it, may take it as a model and act accordingly. Without violating the prohibitions of Heaven and Earth, each may cultivate good intent on their own. To explain everything fully would only overwhelm with words, losing the guiding principles and leaving the text disordered and difficult to govern. Therefore, one should only reveal the beginning and allow them to ponder it themselves.

Excellent, excellent!

Go now—my discourse on this minor matter is complete. If you have further doubts, return again.

Indeed, indeed.

May I ask: when sounds are harmonious, can one know whether their intent is attained or not?

One can indeed know.

The qi of emperors and kings is determined by celestial numbers. When the qi of an emperor or king prevails, the resonance of their commands and proclamations issues forth first. This is like an emperor or king first issuing decrees to the world—all people and things follow accordingly, and the world attains peace. Those who dare disobey are rebels and will perish. Thus, when the qi of an emperor or king is first emitted, all else follows.

Excellent, excellent!

If, however, the qi of an emperor or king is not emitted first, and instead the qi of *rest* or *imprisonment* is activated prematurely, forcing the qi of the emperor or king to follow, this is a grave act of rebellion. Such is the pattern and law of Heaven and Earth—it cannot be forced.

Do you understand?

Indeed, indeed.

Moreover, the five tones each have their own correspondences: some draw upon Heaven, some upon Earth, some upon the sun, moon, and stars, some upon the four seasons and five phases, some upon mountains and rivers, and some upon the people and the myriad things. When a tone moves, all that it governs is stirred, each yielding its own effects. Thus, when harmony aligns with its intent, good is produced; when it does not, evil arises.

When tones are activated, the spirits of all things first come to pay homage, and only afterward do their forms respond. Therefore, when activating musical tones, one must always understand the matter at hand, carefully attaining its intent. Then, great peace may be achieved, and baleful qi dispelled. Perfected One, consider this well.

Indeed, indeed.

May I ask: how does musical tone draw forth its correspondences?

Excellent—your question strikes at the essential meaning!

Consider spring, which moves first: when the great *jiao* string stirs on a *jia* day, above it draws forth Jupiter and the Heart Star, while below it draws forth the Eastern Marchmount. Its qi sways lesser yang; its tone sways the phase of wood; its spirit sways Gou Mang; its creature stirs the Azure Dragon; its position draws forth the Green Emperor; its spirits summon the green-robed jade maidens. From the highest heavens to the deepest earth, all come to pay homage in kind, delighting in its musical sound.

Speaking of one is to seek its kind—there is no end to it. If you refine and search for its essential meaning, you will grasp it all. Align it with ordinary texts and writings to form a model. Thus, when music attains its highest intent, one may transcend the world; when it attains its middle intent, one may bring about peace and dispel misfortune; when it attains its lower intent, one may bring joy to the people.

Attaining its highest intent brings joy to the spirits; attaining its middle intent brings joy to the essences; attaining its lower intent brings joy to the body. When all intents are attained, emperors and kings may wander without care, music arises and punishment ceases, and spirits and essences are sated.

I wish to hear the secret of how music arises and punishment ceases.

Excellent, your words are apt!

Music is the essence of great yang; punishment is the essence of great yin. When yang flourishes, yin submits; when yin flourishes, yang submits. Thus, when music flourishes, punishment vanishes.

Why is music yang? And punishment?

When tones are harmonious, their direction is harmonious and good; when tones are disharmonious, their direction is inauspicious and evil. At such times, listen carefully to the tones. Those who understand sound know all matters of fortune and misfortune; those who do not understand sound cannot know them.

Sound is the speech of music. Whether divining near or far, all must be aligned: the day, the hour, the surname, the written characters, the boundaries, the phases of prosperity, decline, rest, and decay—all are taken together to form the discourse. Those who listen with precision will not err.

Excellent, excellent!

May I ask how to use music to dispel disasters, treachery, and inauspicious evil, following the patterns and numbers of Heaven and Earth?

When the Emperor should rise early or late to move his musical instruments and begin the chant, thereby dispelling the qi of sorrow and suffering to bring about Great Peace—excellent indeed! How skillfully you ask about the method.

For long has High Heaven been afflicted by disasters, pitying the Emperor’s sorrow and suffering. It has sent a Perfected One to preside over this inquiry—what doubts remain?

Very well, very well. Be seated. I dare not conceal anything, for to hide the truth would invite Heaven’s censure, subjecting me to prolonged and heavy punishment, to no benefit for my celestial years. Be seated and listen carefully, as I shall distinguish and explain its essential meaning for you.

The Dao of Heaven is like a cycle, ever revolving and returning to its beginning. When music arises, it must always accord with the timely ascendance of the ruling qi. Establish the resonance where the Dipper’s handle points, and let the sound respond to that direction. Stir the tones and voices—whether led by a person’s chant or each following its own pitch.

The numbers derive from the Six Jia and the Five Phases; the Five and Six Jia and Five Phases are the very numbers of Heaven and Earth. The seasonal qi is what Heaven and Earth respond to and act upon. For example, on the day of the Beginning of Spring, when the Dipper points to *yin*, it is called the time of the Supreme Thearch—first strike the Great Horn. At the midpoint of the month, when it aligns with *jia*; in the second month, when the Dipper points to *mao*, and at the midpoint with *yi*; in the third month, when it points to *chen*. Proceed accordingly, adjusting for the earliness or lateness of the seasonal qi to determine the measurements.

First move the Emperor’s tone and Emperor’s strings, then the King’s tone and King’s strings, then the Minister’s tone and Minister’s strings, then the Candidate’s tone and Candidate’s strings, then the Standard’s tone and Standard’s strings, each in their proper sequence. This is called receiving Heaven’s teaching and following Earth’s qi. If Heaven and Earth themselves delight in and employ it, how much more so should humans?

Humans are the most honored of all beings, the children of Heaven. When people reverently and respectfully employ these numbers, Heaven delights in them; when they carefully and obediently employ them, Earth delights in them. This is like a filial child following the teachings of father and mother—how could parents not love and favor them?

Now Heaven has sent you to ask these matters. As I serve as Heaven’s interlocutor, expounding the regulations for Great Peace above, I dare not omit anything. I fear the punishment of Heaven and Earth and dare not deceive the Perfected Ones or conceal anything. Only when not asked do I remain silent; when asked, I speak without reserve. Observing the Perfected One’s inquiry, I perceive that Heaven desires to speak, and so I explain fully for you.

If you, Perfected One, obtain this Dao, ponder its meaning deeply and transmit it to later generations, enabling them to emulate it and thereby eliminate all manner of disasters. Above, this will pacify the qi of Heaven and Earth; below, it will assist the Emperor in governance. It will settle the hearts of all people, preventing them from straying into wickedness, and allow the twelve thousand things each to find their proper place—how joyous this would be!

Great indeed, great indeed! The Perfected Ones may truly be said to understand.

May I ask about the affairs of the Six Caverns and Eight Directions: which are most auspicious and good, and which are most inauspicious and evil?

Excellent, your inquiry. Now listen carefully, as I explain its meaning. That which is mutually accordant and joyful is good and auspicious; that which is mutually opposed and sorrowful is inauspicious and evil. Mutual accord and joy produce good sounds; mutual opposition and sorrow produce inauspicious sounds.

Thus, music is joy in itself. Mutual accord and joy are good music; auspicious affairs alone may be accompanied by music. Inauspicious and evil affairs must not have music—if music is present, it is called "joy," yet misfortune will only multiply.

Therefore, when the qi of the Emperor, the King, or the Minister is ascendant, all reside before the Celestial Dipper—this is auspicious. What Heaven and Earth delight in, they wish to arise; what they share, they employ together. Thus, one should delight in, follow, and prosper it. The qi of rest and decline is what Heaven and Earth jointly abandon and weaken; thus, it should be abandoned, and music should not be performed. To perform music is to go against the will of Heaven and Earth, constituting great rebellion and discord with the seasonal qi.

The seasonal qi is the proper qi of Heaven’s seasons. Heaven and Earth take this as their standard: the qi of ascendance and prosperity governs Great Peace, while the qi of decline and extinction establishes inauspicious years. The qi of ascendance and prosperity generates abundance and many good affairs. Thus, in years of Great Peace, all things flourish, and good things abound—this is clear evidence, the great effect of Heaven and Earth. The manifestations of Heaven and Earth’s delight in goodness extend to the people and the myriad things; this is the great evidence and verification.

Thus, the sages and worthies of antiquity deeply examined and correlated these signs to know the success or failure of their conduct. They clearly understood that like kinds, like affairs, and like qi correlate with one another. When one obtains the image of a like qi or kind, one reforms one’s nature and changes one’s conduct, daring not to act wrongly. The language of Heaven and Earth is revealed through these effects, not through direct speech with people. By observing the images and kinds obtained, one may know for oneself.

The qi of imprisonment, decline, death, and extinction generate little and accomplish no good affairs. Thus, in inauspicious years, little is produced, no good omens appear, and no good things arise—this is the correlation of like affairs and like qi.

Therefore, those who would bring about Great Peace must perform music in full, for music accords with and delights in the ascendant qi, and the balanced qi arrives. But in inauspicious years, music must not be performed, nor may it be performed without cause. The qi of imprisonment and decline opposes Heaven and Earth; thus, in inauspicious years and affairs, music must not be performed.

The qi of ascendance and prosperity is where virtue resides; the qi of imprisonment and decline is where punishment resides. Thus, a virtuous ruler who cherishes life is enabled by Heaven to perform music, while a ruler without virtue may not—this is the clear evidence of Heaven.

Do you, Perfected One, understand?

Indeed, indeed! Today, having fully inquired of the Illuminated Master of Heaven, I now fully comprehend the meaning of Heaven’s music. Before asking, I thought music a trivial matter, something anyone could perform at any time. Now, having asked, I shall never again act carelessly.

Excellent! You, who understand matters, may truly be said to grasp the principles of texts and to have long attained Heaven’s intent.

When the Great Peace arrives, all baleful qi departs.

With reverence, I humbly inquire again concerning the doubts in my heart. Speak plainly and without reservation.

Indeed, indeed!

Now, the qi of Heaven and Earth is half in ascendance and half in repose, like the unceasing alternation of day and night. How then could music be performed all day long? Should it be played only in the direction of ascendant qi, when the qi of kingship prevails? Yet when music begins, it is because the Son of Heaven initiates it—not because the qi of repose does. The same holds for the year, the month, the day, and the hour.

Though this humble one has yet to grasp the full meaning, if one wishes to perform music for the year, it should be done in the east at *mao*, in the second month of spring. If for the month, it should correspond to that month; for the day, to the day of ascendant qi; for the hour, to the hour of ascendant qi. Only thus may one be said to accord with the Dao of Heaven, and baleful qi will depart. To act otherwise is to disrupt the celestial order and invite calamity.

Thus, the sage-kings of antiquity, deeply understanding the intent of Heaven and Earth, dared not perform music during inauspicious affairs. When inauspicious affairs are met with music, those ills multiply daily, growing beyond remedy—hence, music must not be performed then.

Heaven endows each being with its own spirit. When music is good, good spirits arrive; when music is evil, evil spirits arrive—this is the natural disposition, nothing strange. Only the foolish fail to ponder this deeply.

Excellent! Excellent!

The perfected one who wishes to know its great efficacy may compare it to the Dao of Heaven. All that is pure and serene delights in returning to Heaven; all that is heavy and turbid delights in returning to Earth—each follows its own abode, and none can be faulted for this. Thus, delighting in goodness brings goodness; delighting in inauspiciousness brings inauspiciousness, just as water flows downward and fire rises upward, not erring by even a fraction. The perfected one entrusts this text to a ruler of virtue to show to ordinary people. Now that the qi of Great Peace has arrived and Heaven promotes goodness, all are made to delight in goodness, and none may again take pleasure in inauspicious affairs without cause. Those who delight in inauspicious affairs make themselves enemies of Heaven and bring blame upon Earth—their transgressions cannot be erased. Today, those in Heaven name such people who delight in inauspicious affairs as great rebels. The baleful qi of Heaven and all the blames within Earth will descend and converge upon them.

Should an urgent matter arise suddenly and one must perform music for an auspicious affair, yet there is no time to await the ascendant qi of the proper region or the hour of the Dipper’s culmination, what then is to be done? Excellent indeed is your question, for it grasps the essential meaning. In such a case, have the musicians reside in the region of ascendant qi. If they cannot reside there, let the musicians and the assembled people all face the ascendant direction and make their request. They should employ the same tones and the same numerical correspondences. Even if only the person’s surname and given name are used, holding the pitch pipes and calendrical calculations, so long as the tones and qi resonate in accord, one may follow the time of ascendant qi and have them perform the music—this too is permissible. In this way, all acts in accordance with the teachings and commands of Heaven and Earth, and no disasters will arise. To act otherwise is to align with the qi of baleful prisoners, and all manner of inauspicious affairs will arise.

Moreover, when raising voices in song or leading music, one must also employ the auspicious—auspicious tones and good affairs. The qi of ascendant and prosperous phases is like a ruler among men; it does not wish to hear of inauspicious affairs, inauspicious words, or inauspicious tones. The reason is this: the qi of ascendant and prosperous phases serves as the agent of August Heaven, presiding over generation and completing good affairs, thereby aiding Heaven in the generation and completion of all things. Evil tones and inauspicious affairs do not aid Heaven in the generation and completion of all things. Thus, the qi of ascendance does not wish to delight in hearing them, nor does the qi preceding the Dipper’s culmination. Therefore, the sage-king emperors of antiquity all accumulated good words and good deeds, never admitting inauspicious and evil affairs. Such words were called "ominous speech," and the crime was punishable by death. Even if the crime did not warrant death, they were killed simply for the ominousness of their inauspicious speech. Does the perfected one understand the severity of this prohibition?

Indeed, indeed.

Ah, how solemn! Ah, how solemn!

To know early and be alarmed ensures long preservation; not to know is the root of death. Let me expound:

First, by first aligning with and delighting in the qi of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons’ imperial qi, and by amplifying the joy directed toward Heaven threefold, Heaven is greatly pleased. The imperial ruler enjoys longevity, evil and misfortune are extinguished, celestial disasters and harms are all dispelled, and the qi of the Great Yang does not contend in anger, bringing peace to the realm. Those who know to first move in alignment with and delight in this are supported by the Dao of Heaven, and true spirits emerge. Even those dwelling in hidden caves come forth with joy to aid the upright—how wondrous!

Second, by first aligning with and delighting in the qi of Heaven and Earth and the four seasons’ royal qi, and by doubling the joy directed toward Earth, Earth’s qi is greatly pleased and does not contend in anger. This grants the ruler longevity, dissolves treachery, theft, and warfare, and brings prosperity to the realm. Those below all delight in submitting to their superiors, and the worthy emerge to assist in governance. Earth spirits align in nurturance—how wondrous!

Third, by first aligning with and delighting in the qi of ministerial and subtle qi, the qi of harmony and balance is greatly pleased. Ruler and ministers, the people all act with reverence, each preserving their place. Thus, flattery, deceit, theft, and banditry do not arise, and the borders are secure. As harmonious qi daily flourishes, royal qi is born, and all things incline toward goodness.

Fourth, be cautious never to move or delight in the qi of death and destruction, for it brings severe banditry and many sudden deaths. The realm remains in constant peril, unable to find peace, and malevolent qi and spectral beings proliferate, causing grave harm. When extreme, this is called chaos and disturbance. The qi of utmost yin induces rebellion and inversion—beware, beware!

Fifth, do not move or delight in the qi of imprisonment and decline, for it brings much banditry, incarceration, litigation, and a flurry of punishments. Peace becomes difficult, the people harm one another, and chronic illnesses multiply.

Sixth, do not move or delight in the qi of decline and cessation, for it brings many ailing and infirm people. It also breeds cunning and deceitful individuals who cheat one another, fosters much slander and strife, depletes the realm’s wealth, and leaves the people impoverished.

Delight in the three upper divisions—imperial, royal, ministerial, and subtle qi—and Heaven, Earth, and humanity are pleased. Timely rains and disasters are dispelled, for this is called aligning with the good qi of Heaven, Earth, and humanity, thereby bringing forth good affairs. To delight in the three lower divisions—the qi of death, destruction, imprisonment, decline, and cessation—is to invite rebellion and disaster. Heaven’s seasons bring perverse harms in great multitude, which cannot be restrained or prevented.

If these debased qi are stirred and delighted in, malevolent qi is greatly unleashed. The wise and learned withdraw into hiding, the magistrates lose governance, the people and ministers become difficult to rule, and affairs multiply in chaos. One cannot but guard against and be cautious of this!

All matters under Heaven and Earth have their fixed and constant laws. Where qi resides, one should face the honored and desire to express joy; where qi is absent, in decline or death, joy is inappropriate. Thus, to delight in goodness is called "aligning with governance" in Heaven; to delight in evil is called "rebelling against decree." Those who align with governance gain Heaven’s power; those who rebel against decree gain Heaven’s harm. Those who gain Heaven’s power attain longevity; those who gain Heaven’s harm incur misfortune and calamity.

The reason is this: Heaven’s governance is like an echo and shadow—it does not wrest away what brings people peace. To delight in goodness is to receive goodness; to delight in evil is to receive evil. What more need be said? Good and evil, safety and peril each follow their kind and do not err—only the foolish fail to consider this.

Thus, those who delight in the Dao attract the Dao; those who delight in virtue attract virtue; those who delight in martial prowess attract martial prowess; those who delight in uprightness attract uprightness; those who delight in perversity attract perversity. How could it be otherwise?

Therefore, I have deeply pondered Heaven’s laws to admonish the perfected one. How solemn! Heaven’s laws must not be transgressed. Thus, I earnestly exhort you. Indeed, indeed.

The reason for amplifying the joy directed toward imperial qi threefold when delighting in the worthy is that imperial qi is most honored and supreme, symbolizing Heaven’s supremacy, hence the tripled joy. Heaven governs and commands Earth and humanity, thus the threefold amplification, symbolizing Heaven, Earth, and humanity.

When Heaven, Earth, and humanity are seen to delight in and bring order, all things each attain their proper place. Auspicious signs and good omens—twelve thousand in number—all emerge in full. Thus, one first delights in them.

When delighting in them, one should listen attentively with single-minded focus, sit upright in prolonged contemplation, and feel joy and gladness in the heart, utterly content. Be loyal, sincere, and utterly without ill intent, as if sitting before the imperial ruler, daring not to be perverse. Heaven responds to such conduct, and evil, misfortune, and disasters all depart. By honoring Heaven as supreme and imperial qi as authority, Heaven naturally follows the law, and the attainment of Great Peace is not difficult.

How excellent! How excellent!

The reason for doubling the joy directed toward royal qi when delighting in its harmony is that royal qi symbolizes Earth, and Earth dwells alongside humanity, hence the doubled joy to delight in Earth. When Earth and humanity are seen to delight and rejoice, all things are ordered and attain their proper state. Moreover, Earth is humble, thus its joy is less than Heaven’s.

How excellent! How excellent!

Furthermore, royal qi is weaker than imperial qi, humbler by one degree, hence the reduction. The law of precedence between honor and humility is naturally apportioned.

How excellent! How excellent!

The reason for delighting in ministerial and subtle qi in a single measure is that ministerial and subtle qi symbolize harmony and humanity. Harmonious humanity is humbler than Heaven and Earth, hence its joy is less. Humanity governs and orders all things for Heaven and Earth. When humanity delights, it rejoices in goodness; by doing good, all things are ordered. When humanity does not delight, it does evil; by doing evil, all things meet with misfortune.

How excellent! How excellent!

Moreover, humanity is the chief of all harmonious things. When the chief delights in order, all things are ordered; when the chief is in chaos, all things are in chaos. Thus, one first delights in the chief to align with and delight in the Dao of Heaven, Earth, and humanity.

How excellent! How excellent!

Therefore, the qi of supreme goodness is most honored and good, hence the tripled joy to delight in goodness. Thus, the ancient imperial rulers who governed well and aligned with Heaven’s will gained this multiplied joy—clear evidence of this.

Now the qi of Great Peace arrives, thus teaching the flourishing of joy. When the qi of decline and chaos responds to inauspicious years, joy cannot flourish; if one forces joy to flourish, it is called "flourishing joy amidst misfortune and decay"—in Heaven’s reckoning, this is named "great rebellion." Is not the root of disasters and the origin of calamities something to be guarded against with utmost care?

How excellent! How excellent!

Therefore, the next in rank is the kingly qi, whose joy is doubled, yet it does not match the imperial qi, hence its joy is lesser. Thus, those whose governance is only slightly good find their joy diminished. The reason for this diminution is that their qi is weak and not supremely good, so they dare not indulge in excessive joy. Amidst this, inauspicious qi lingers, so they dare not fully express their joy. It is like a household with seven virtues and three vices—though the heart may incline toward joy, this is the meaning of such restraint.

How excellent! How excellent!

Consider this: with seven virtues and three vices, where goodness outweighs evil, can one rest in ease and cease rejoicing? Though the human heart may delight, it occasionally recalls the three vices, preventing pure, unalloyed joy—this is the nature of Heaven. Only when virtue is complete, with not a single worry remaining, does great joy arise. Thus, joy is for delighting in goodness, not for delighting in misfortune.

How excellent! How excellent!

My words are the luminous contract of Heaven, not erring in the slightest. Therefore, the next in rank is the single joy of the ministerial qi and the subtle qi, which governs minor stability. Human virtue is at its least here, not matching the qi of Heaven and Earth. Thus, it is faint and slight, not equaling Heaven and Earth, and so its joy is diminished. The ministerial qi and subtle qi bring minor transformations, governing the central lands where evil often outweighs goodness, so they dare not fully express their joy. To do so would be called "rejoicing in misfortune and evil." Since goodness is scant, their joy is scant as well. The reason for this scantiness is that they only rejoice in the goodness within, not daring to rejoice in the misfortune and evil within. To rejoice in the misfortune and evil within is like a petty person with seven vices and three virtues—can the three virtues alone secure threefold joy? With seven vices, there are instead sevenfold sorrows and afflictions. How can one rest in joy?

The reason for this lies in the principle of tenfold division: ten is divided thrice. The imperial qi is entirely good in all ten parts; the kingly qi has two parts good and one part evil; the ministerial qi has two parts evil and one part good. Thus, the imperial qi mirrors Heaven, which constantly delights in life, harbors no harmful intent, and desires to bestow blessings. The Three Sovereigns emulated this, ever purely good and kind, without evil or harmful intent. Heaven resembles the Three Sovereigns, and the Three Sovereigns resemble Heaven. Thus, the supremely good person has not a single vice, only ever desiring to do good. Does this not mirror Heaven? Does it not mirror the true spirit?

How excellent! How excellent!

The kingly qi mirrors Earth, which constantly nurtures and favors virtue. The Five Emperors emulated this. Though Earth’s nurturing is called "killing," the Five Emperors still employed punishments.

How excellent! How excellent!

The ministerial qi and subtle qi mirror humanity, which has no constant law and frequently changes. The Three Kings emulated this, having no fixed principles. For harmonious qi shifts and alters, sometimes advancing, sometimes retreating, thus there is no constancy in high or low. It observes firmness and follows it; it observes softness and follows it—hence its lack of constancy. The qi of decline, death, imprisonment, and ruin mirrors the myriad things, endlessly changing and chaotic, with no regular pattern of emergence or withdrawal. The Five Hegemons emulated this, their qi disordered and inauspicious, thus they could not possess joy.

The nature of Heaven and Earth is to rejoice in goodness, not to rejoice in evil. The martial power of Heaven and Earth is for punishing evil, not for punishing good. The standards of Heaven and Earth cannot be reversed.

How excellent! How excellent!

May I ask about the meaning of "rejoicing in goodness"? I wish to hear the great secret, that my foolish heart may fully understand and never again dare to question. Could I be permitted to hear it?

Do you yourself not yet understand?

I have gained some small understanding, but I fear that people of later ages, long sunk in accumulated ignorance, even when given these words, may still fail to comprehend and thus violate Heaven’s prohibitions. Therefore, I dare not refrain from asking. The great secret is easy to know.

Excellent are your words, for you have grasped their meaning. Very well, be seated, and I shall now explain it.

Thus, in the most excellent and greatly joyous years, all the myriad things give rise to goodness, and every person rejoices, their hearts ever filled with joy, longing to sing and dance. People silently love one another, never contending, and joy arises of itself. Above and below, none harm or plunder each other, and all delight together. Therefore, joy arises from goodness and rejoices in goodness—Heaven causes this to be so naturally.

Excellent! Excellent!

In the most inauspicious years, not a single thing is good. Every person suffers hunger and cold, weeping and wailing, harming and plundering one another. Silently, sorrow, bitterness, and resentment arise within, and their hearts know no joy. How could they sing, dance, or find delight? Silently, they wither and perish. Thus, inauspicious years and evil times bring no joy—Heaven causes this to be so naturally. This is clear evidence that Heaven does not delight in misfortune and evil.

Therefore, joy arises to celebrate goodness, while martial power arises to punish misfortune. Thus, when the ancient emperors and kings were about to rise, they received the response of joy and goodness; when they were about to decline, they received the response of evil. This is the natural law.

Thus, joy gives rise to goodness, and goodness gives rise to joy; misfortune gives rise to joylessness, and martial power gives rise to misfortune. Non-action gives rise to joy, and joy gives rise to non-action. Martial power gives rise to chaos, and chaos gives rise to martial power. Joy gives rise to song and dance, and song and dance give rise to joy. Evil and misfortune give rise to sorrow and suffering, and sorrow and suffering give rise to evil and misfortune.

May those of later ages who see my words reflect upon and rejoice in them. Here, the explanation of the secret comes to a small conclusion.

Excellent! Excellent!

The five musical tones, when properly activated before and after, align with Heaven, Earth, and humanity in intent, bringing about Great Peace, dispelling disasters, eliminating treachery, and manifesting harmonious qi—thus revealing the great secret.

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 116 concludes.*

---

*Tai Ping Jing, Scroll 117*
**Heaven’s Joy in Obtaining Good People: Text Entrusted to the Fire Lord, Secret 207**

Now, the Perfected One has accumulated goodness and is wise, understanding all matters.

At this time, the Supreme Heavenly Sovereign’s qi of equanimity has fully arrived, and there is an urgent matter in the heavens—do you, little one, know of it?

This humble student is foolish and dull, unable to comprehend. I rely entirely upon the Heavenly Master.

Very well. All Perfected Ones, be seated, and I shall fully explain it to you.

Now, the heavens rejoice in obtaining good people, who can regulate wind and rain and bring forth all the myriad things. Since the opening of Heaven and Earth, those who do good have been few, and even fewer have aligned with Heaven’s will. Heaven has long regarded this as a source of sorrow, for now, among the people of the earth, there are none who meet Heaven’s requirements.

Why does the heavens not simply create people itself, rather than selecting them from the earth below?

The generation of all things by Heaven and Earth arises from the union of two as one. Now, the heavens above unite with the earth below. The birth of all yang must occur within yin, and thus people are taken from this earth. Moreover, humans contain the qi of both yin and yang, and their procreation must occur in the soil and springs, so they all take after the earth from which they are born. Thus, the customs of the five directions differ, and the world, though small, is not uniform. Therefore, among the twelve thousand states, even the people within a single region do not resemble one another.

Do you understand this?

"Yes, yes. Those born among humans who are perpetually good are entrusted to their fathers, and thus good people are ultimately entrusted to Heaven. The essence of the myriad things—those that are good ascend to unite with Heaven and become the Three Luminaries. Those of middling quality are entrusted to humans, enabling them to serve, follow the rhythms of yin and yang, and govern the myriad things. Those of lower quality are entrusted to the earth, causing them to walk and labor. Do you, Perfected One, understand this?"

"Yes, yes."

"Excellent, excellent! Therefore, when Heaven above now desires to harmonize wind and rain, nurture the myriad things, and rejoice in obtaining good people, I have been sent down to select and seek them. With this text, I entrust it to you, Perfected One, to convey to the diligent people, bidding them pass it to the sovereign of fire essence and virtue, so that it may be shown to all under Heaven, that they may together ponder these words of mine. Thus, I entrust it to you, Perfected One—take care never to sever this transmission. Should you fail in this, you will incur affliction. Be ever vigilant in this matter."

"Yes, yes."

Now, the foolish among the living suppose: Does Heaven above, being boundless and upright, unite solely with this earth below?

"Excellent is your inquiry! Though Heaven moves above without bound, it too possesses yin and yang, and the two unite as one. Does the earth below also possess such union?"

Indeed, though the earth moves below without bound, it too possesses yin and yang, and the two unite as one. Thus, one yin and one yang, above and below without end, extending laterally without limit—this is the nature of the Great Dao, the constant law of Heaven. All things take one yin and one yang as their vital axis. This is the art of the Supreme Numinous, operating naturally. The governance of the boundless turns in cycles, returning to its origin, without end or cessation.

I wish to distinguish and set forth the Dao for you, Perfected One, in clear order, that you may fully comprehend it. Thus, I briefly raise its beginning for you, reveal its great principles, and leave you to reflect upon its threads, that the worthy and sagely upon the earth may themselves refine it. Do you understand?"

"Yes, yes."

"I wish to hear your teachings."
"Very well. Commit my words carefully to memory within my teachings, and you shall ascend and rest."
"Yes, yes."

**Heaven’s Reproach: Four Who Shame the Dao’s Precepts (Section 208)**
What great abhorrence exists in the heavens above? It is called *Heaven’s Reproach*.

Perfected One, you have studied and practiced for so long—do you not deeply understand this already?
Now, this foolish one knows nothing of such matters. I wish to hear of them.

Indeed, from ancient times to the present, all who cultivate the Dao take the August Heaven as their model. The most excellent appellation—crowning the unsurpassed, encompassing the boundless, inwardly without interior, outwardly without gap, entering without aperture—serves as the teacher of all affairs under heaven. It is the origin of life, the elder of all matters, the enduring attainment of sages and worthies past and present. It is how emperors and kings secure the heart of Heaven, becoming the parents who bring peace to the people, the source from which all transformations arise.

Do you understand, Perfected One?
"Yes, yes."

The Dao is Heaven itself—pure and luminous, unwilling to be defiled or shamed. Yet now, those who study and practice the Dao all engage in four ruinous deeds, jointly defiling the numinous Dao of August Heaven, throwing into chaos the principles of Earth, and rendering themselves unfit to lead transformation, to serve as models, or to be parents. Together, they destroy Heaven’s precious vessels. Heaven names them all as *greatly rebellious sons*.

You dwell upon the earth—if you do not conform to the models of the Dao, how could Heaven, in its tranquility, conform to your models instead? Do you wish to know the truth of this? It is as if a petty man among the common folk does not conform to the models of the Dao. Would he, standing before the emperor, then conform to those models? If one remains below and fails to conform to the Dao’s models, yet Heaven were to cherish him and take him as its model—would this not mean that those in the heavens above and before the emperor would instead be ruled by those who hoard wickedness? Thus, Heaven above deeply perceives their deviation from the Dao, not out of deliberate malice in reproaching them.

Now, as the Primordial Qi of the Cavernous Upper August arrives, it will no longer tolerate these four kinds of people. These four cause both Heaven above and Earth below to despise those who practice the Dao, instead branding them as *evil sons*. This is why the human Dao daily declines and fades, resting in decay without revival. Today, all under heaven commit evil—this is precisely the ruin wrought by these four.

Heaven above greatly abhors and reproaches them, and thus seeks to select seven others instead.
Do you understand, Perfected One?

This foolish one’s nature is dull and slow—I still do not comprehend. What does this mean? I wish to hear of it.
If you do not immediately grasp this, what hope is there for the common people?

"Very well. Open your ears and listen closely. I shall set forth in detail for you the origins of the Dao’s great flaws and diseases, so that later learners may clearly recognize their deviations from the Dao.

The first is *lack of filial piety*.
The second is *failure to preserve one’s true nature*, leaving no posterity of their kind.
The third is *eating feces and drinking urine*.
The fourth is *acting as beggars*.

These four kinds of people jointly defile the true Dao of Heaven, utterly unfit to inspire transformation or to serve as models for Heaven above and Earth below through the ages. Even if they were to attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, when Heaven examines them, they would be found wholly wicked. Today, they cannot regulate the winds and rains, bring forth the myriad things, or serve as teachers and elders. How lamentable! How lamentable!

This humble one is deaf and blind—I have never known my offenses against Heaven. Now, only the August Heaven and luminous teachers can grant me further clarity. I beg you to explain in detail and distinguish them clearly, that I may gain understanding and enlightenment."

"Very well. Listen carefully, and I shall fully expound their meaning for you, Perfected One, so that it may serve as a model for all ages to come. Let later learners, earnest and good, who practice the Dao no longer transgress Heaven’s prohibitions, enabling them to attain the Dao and ascend to Heaven, where Heaven will rejoice in them. It is like when the Earthly Thearch and kings find good people to govern with them—they too rejoice.

Thus, what Heaven above advances, Earth below likewise does. Is this not excellent?"
"Yes, yes. I have received your instruction."

The Dao is the teacher of August Heaven, the most precious treasure of Heaven. Those who practice it must conduct themselves as if formed by Heaven itself. The Dao ought to be practiced with utmost reverence, for Heaven cherishes and employs those who do so. Yet now, some who have erred and attained the Dao ascend to Heaven, only to be received with inquiry—only to reveal conduct lacking in reverence and filial piety. The Dao is the foremost transformer, and Heaven serves as the model for humanity. How could it reverse its role to shelter and nurture the irreverent and unfilial of the world? If a child harbors such evil conduct, how could Heaven deem it fitting to grant this person longevity and share its work? Would Heaven instead take such a rebellious child as its master? Even on Earth, such a person would not be employed—how could Heaven employ them? Thus, no one who is unfilial and practices the Dao has ever ascended to Heaven. Though they may depart, they are all deceived by malevolent spirits and treacherous ghosts. They will dwell in death upon barren lands, in desolate wilds, their forms punished. Heaven’s response to humanity is as swift as an echo—how could evil conduct yield good reward? Such cases are rare in past and present. Though many on Earth have practiced the Dao, few have been deemed worthy. Now, in Heaven, there are few good people, none with whom to share its work—their conduct is entirely wicked. Why does Heaven not immediately destroy them, instead consigning them to barren lands, to uninhabited wilds where breath ceases? It does not immediately annihilate them because between Heaven and Earth, qi gathers in abundance, fostering harmony—this is called the balanced harmony of the center. It is like human harmony, which encompasses all without exception. Thus, Heaven temporarily tolerates them, for Heaven governs with clarity and brightness, like standing before an imperial sovereign—it cannot harbor the wicked. Therefore, Heaven does not employ such people in its governance, nor does Earth. Heaven does not employ the irreverent and unfilial, just as a sagely king does not employ the irreverent and unfilial. If even a sagely king refuses to govern with them, how could Heaven alone do so? The ancient sages and worthies did not govern with such people because they deeply observed Heaven’s laws and modeled their conduct upon them. To govern with the foolish would incur Heaven’s great resentment. How do we know this? When a ruler governs with such people, Heaven manifests many disasters and omens, and the barbarians frequently invade—this is clear proof of Heaven’s hatred. Is this not as unchanging as the compass and square, as binding as a contract? Now, if even humanity detests and despises such people, how could Heaven itself employ them? What humanity hates, Heaven also hates; what humanity cherishes, Heaven also cherishes. Thus, the ancient worthies and sages deeply understood Heaven’s will and always modeled their conduct upon it, not daring to deviate even slightly. Therefore, they alone enjoyed Heaven’s favor and gained its heart. If one does not align with Heaven’s heart, one does not gain it—and great misfortune follows. If human conduct is already thus, how much more so for those who would become Heaven’s chosen officers? Heaven’s chosen officers must work alongside Heaven, governing the boundless arts. They must join forces for eternity, harmonize their qi with one heart—how could a Perfected One be remiss in this? Be vigilant! My words embody the pure will of Heaven—do not transgress them. Those who transgress will die. □□! Excellent, excellent!

The foolish student’s heart holds but a single good understanding in this. You, too, should refine even this single good understanding—common people do not grasp it, lost in their dark and muddled confusion. Heaven detests this, and so has sent me down to proclaim the great teaching, fully revealing Heaven’s laws. From this point onward, let all learners take heed and be vigilant.

Now Heaven values and esteems the transmission of life in succession, so the four seasons receive Heaven’s Daoist instruction, passing life onward to generate and complete, without end. Thus do all things flourish and endure. Therefore, Heaven is named the Father of Generation, Earth the Mother of Nurturance. Following the qi of the Six Jia, Twelve Branches, and Eight Trigrams as their guiding principles, they take turns generating and employing one another. Thus, the Dao of Heaven remains eternally present, never destroyed or ruined—this is the constant work of its transformative power.

Now, those who study the Dao must be pure and take Heaven as their model. Yet many, though outwardly pure, leave no posterity, jointly extinguishing Heaven’s lineage. The steadfast among them still uphold Heaven’s nature, but their qi is insufficient. The unsteadfast force the matter, obstructing and blocking the Dao of yin and yang. Scattering their seed across the four wilds, some even abandon and kill, leaving their wives and children destitute—these are all people who greatly destroy and lose the Dao. They are unworthy of emulation, beings of great misfortune in every fraction, unfit to serve as teachers or models for others. How could they possibly align with the laws of the Heavenly Master?

The August Heaven is the elder of all affairs, the parent of humanity, the model from which all sages under Heaven take their pattern. Why would one act recklessly, losing the Dao and behaving without posterity, to serve alongside such a one? If Heaven were to govern jointly with such a person, Heaven would be named a master who shelters evil, promoting inauspicious arts—how could this be called sagely, how could one serve as a teacher above others? Therefore, Heaven does not tolerate or cease to stop them.

The ancient sages and great worthies knew well to avoid such transgressions, refusing to govern alongside those without posterity, for in doing so, they would fail to gain Heaven’s heart. Thus, the sages and worthies—whom Heaven causes to be esteemed and to have posterity—jointly detest those without posterity. The sages deeply understood Heaven’s will and always modeled themselves upon it, not deviating even slightly. How much more so for Heaven itself?

Now, for a long time, there have been no good people above in Heaven, so I have been sent down to proclaim these great words, to instruct and admonish those who come later, that the foolish may all come to know. If those above in Heaven employ such people, would Heaven above not instead become a host for those without posterity? Acting in this way, would one ascend to Heaven? Would Heaven above love those without posterity and not favor life? Thus, all such people die in barren lands, lifeless soils, and desolate wilds where no one dwells, each sent to return to their own kind. You do not favor life, opposing Heaven, so you are cast into places where nothing grows. You delight in desolation, so you are cast into wilds where no one lives.

Common people, blind and unseeing, claim they have already transcended the world—this is not true. I dare not deceive the Perfected One. I have personally descended after journeying above in Heaven. Whether one sees or not is like showing the sun to the blind—telling them they are being deceived, they cover their mouths and laugh. Fools are just like this. Perfected One, be vigilant! What Heaven above detests, those above also detest. Excellent, excellent!

The foolish student has never before witnessed such matters of Heaven above—only now has he truly awakened to this. You must strive to perform good deeds. My writings heal the illnesses of Heaven and Earth, relieve the sorrows and sufferings of emperors and kings. When your merit is complete and you ascend to Heaven, you will see for yourself—the efficacy of my words will be greatly proven. Indeed, indeed. I dare not delay, nor dare I be remiss. You must be vigilant and not grow lax. If you truly falter and grow lax, your great mandate will be severed. The foolish student deeply fears Heaven’s majesty and sincerely receives and practices this. Excellent, excellent! You have grasped Heaven’s will.

Now Heaven is pure and bright, the Dao is clear and untainted. Heaven and the Dao dwell highest of all, serving as models for humanity. The pure and bright favor purity and brightness, so the Three Luminaries ascend and reside in Heaven, each following its kind, uniting as if forming a single body. Heaven’s form is like a bright mirror, like a person with two eyes that illuminate all, unwilling to see defilement or disgrace. Before a sagely king, one must always desire purity and brightness, unwilling to see defilement or disgrace. If one defiles and disgraces, one incurs the transgression of destruction and death. Perfected One, do you understand? Indeed, indeed.

Oh, how grave! Oh, how grave!

Thus, the human head and mouth resemble Heaven, unwilling to delight in seeing defilement or disgrace, always desiring freshness and brightness, desiring good things. Therefore, when people in the world indulge in filth, disgrace, and evil, feeding such things to others, Heaven sends down thunder and lightning to capture and seize them. Perfected One, do you recognize this as perverse and wicked? Indeed, indeed. This foolish one deeply fears it.

From the great central high antiquity to now, people claim to be good, utterly distinct from common folk. Yet those who study the Dao often instruct one another to eat feces and drink urine, calling themselves plain and good people—Heaven and the Dao deeply detest this. In Heaven, such are named the great rebellious children, whose human forms Heaven does not wish to see. These are the marks of great evil, the descent of dog and swine spirits.

The Dao gives birth to Heaven, and Heaven possesses the Dao, which serves as the teacher and elder for all affairs. The true Dao is that by which goodness flourishes and evil is eliminated. Thus, when ancient sage-kings and emperors were about to rise, they all received the Dao as their teacher, entering to receive its strategies and wisdom, transforming their people. The teacher was honored, and it was said that they could know Heaven’s will and emulate Heaven in their conduct.

In Heaven, those who follow the good Dao are also revered and esteemed, for it is said they can harmonize with the winds and qi, follow the four seasons, uphold the five phases, regulate wind and rain, assist the sun, moon, and stars in shining brightly, and cause the myriad things to flourish. Now, how can those who eat feces and drink urine serve as teachers?

Today, even earthly teachers fall short, named rebellious children—how could they possibly become teachers in Heaven? Such petty people are profoundly foolish, deeply mired in defiling and disgracing the Dao of Heaven.

Perfected One, having received this ultimate text, ponder its meaning: what the earth below uniformly detests, Heaven above also detests; what Heaven above detests, the earth below likewise does. Thus, when people below detest eating feces and drinking urine, Heaven above also detests it, and so sends down thunder and lightning to strike them dead.

These words are merely to enlighten those on earth, for Heaven’s detestation is far more severe. If even those on earth abhor this, how much more so in Heaven? Heaven is pure, bright, and fresh—how could it instead gather and shelter those who eat feces and drink urine?

Even if one errs by chance and momentarily attains the Dao, they will not ascend to Heaven. All will perish in the lands of the five wastes, where qi is cut off and fortune fails, to follow their conduct, to manifest their transgressions, each returning to what they sought—no deception here.

Perfected One, if your years have reached their virtuous end, be warned and cautious, setting an example for those to come. When the equable qi of the Supreme August One descends, such evil conduct will find no refuge—death for transgression is clear indeed.

Oh, how grave! Oh, how grave! Perfected One, do you understand? If you do and yet allow it, you share in the guilt. If you know and still persist, the sin cannot be absolved. Indeed, indeed. I dare not, I dare not.

Now the nature of the Supreme August Heaven is ever to bestow and grant—thus it presides over giving, over bestowing, over engendering, over nurturing. It governs emergence, not reception; it governs triumph, not submission. To submit is to act in rebellion. Therefore, the Dao of Heaven cannot be coerced by force, for coercion and duress bring about the ruin of humankind.

Heaven presides over goodness, over clarity and luminosity; it takes no delight in witnessing stagnation, defilement, or disgrace. Now the gift of Heaven and the Dao is called the "Peerless Appellation." Thus, emperors and kings model their conduct upon Heaven, styling themselves "Peerless Sovereigns." They dare not lose even a fraction of Heaven’s way—adherence brings fortune, while deviation brings great misfortune.

Now, those who study the Dao to attain longevity must purely emulate Heaven. Heaven delights in life; therefore, those who seek longevity must purely guard Heaven’s primordial life-generating qi, and their conduct must follow the intent of the Dao of Heaven. As for Earth, it presides over disgrace and destruction, over concealment—one must not follow Earth’s intent.

The Dao is the root of the great transformation, the teacher and elder of the great transformation. Thus, nothing under Heaven comes into being without emulating it. Yet now, petty and foolish men who seek the Dao bring no benefit to the people; instead, they collectively defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven. Their rebellion is extreme and without form. In Heaven above, they are named "rebellious sons," men of great misfortune—Heaven does not wish to see them.

What does this mean? The foolish generate knotted, closed-off hearts, and thus have not yet attained it.

Excellent indeed is your question! Heaven has prompted your words—open wide your ears and listen attentively.

Does not Heaven and the Dao favor bestowal, favor life, and favor praise? Why then do they not divine with hexagrams, dispense medicines, and bring benefit to the people, allowing spirits to govern humanity so that illness may surely cease? These three kinds of men may all be called masters, yet they do not profit the Dao of Heaven, nor dare they defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven.

The Dao of Heaven does not deceive; it ever demands utmost sincerity. If one deceives with the pretense of not deceiving, in time, day by day, misfortune and decline will follow. The Dao of Heaven does not delight in defilement and disgrace, nor does it desire to benefit others. Heaven is supreme above all, and the Dao is yet more exalted—it is the teacher and model of the Heavenly Sovereign, loftier even than Heaven. Thus, Heaven and the Dao preside over cultivation and rectitude, ever leading in all affairs. Thereby they harmonize yin and yang, regulate wind and rain, rectify day and night, and array the ranks. Between Heaven and Earth, none fail to receive grace and destiny, each attaining its proper place.

Yet now, petty and foolish men who pursue the Dao instead engage in deceit, arrogance, delusion, and madness. Together they confuse and disrupt the Dao of Heaven, ruin the primal transformations of Heaven, and turn to begging for others’ possessions, bringing no benefit to the people. They defile and disgrace the Dao of Heaven. Though they claim to benefit the common folk, they cannot serve as models for teachers. Instead, they lead later generations to teach one another the Dao, causing people to become deluded, arrogant, deceitful, and defiled, resorting to begging. Thus, their conduct is named the Dao of the deluded, arrogant beggar. They cause all people to revile Heaven together, to despise the true Dao, and to sever the great transformation. Heaven deeply abhors them; the Dao deeply detests them. Heaven above does not wish to see their form.

Now, the Supreme Sovereign of Heaven has sent forth the great rectifying qi. The sun, moon, and stars are arrayed in order, all reverently illuminating the Dao and Heaven. They regulate wind and rain, harmonize yin and yang, and cause the myriad things to each attain their proper place. Yet those who previously chanced upon the Dao and ascended to Heaven found no office there. Heaven questioned them and found them full of transgressions, unfit to serve together. You all dwell upon the earth and are still called deluded, arrogant beggars—how could you be fit to serve as teachers to emperors and kings, let alone as teachers in Heaven above?

Heaven abhors them; the great Dao declines and falls into ruin. The fault lies with the people of later ages who, in learning from one another, lost the proper standards. Heaven is afflicted by this, deeply grieved. The Dao of Heaven is obstructed, and thus it has sent me down to discuss with the Perfected One and distinguish the gains and losses of the Dao. It delights in the awakening of all under Heaven, that they may together know the intent of Heaven above, reform their conduct, transform their hearts, and no longer transgress Heaven’s prohibitions. Then those who study will succeed. If they persist in their former ways, Heaven will not raise them up.

They shall surely return to die in the land of the five disgraceful things, their lives consigned to the five defiled soils, cut off in the desolate wilds of delusion and madness. Above, there are no Three Luminaries; below, no fertile earth. Why is this? I wish to hear: how grave is their transgression? It is not that they are punished without cause. The Dao of Heaven serves as the law, and each follows its kind—this is the deprivation from below.

Why then are they not immediately killed, but instead brought to this? If they were to be instantly destroyed, they would claim to seek long life and profess utmost faith. If they were to be killed outright, they would weep to Heaven and wail to Earth, calling themselves deeply wronged, yet unaware of the source of their transgressions. Thus, Heaven examines and tests them, later casting them into the land of the five disgraceful and deluded things, that they may come to know themselves.

Do you wish to know the truth of this? It is like a wise king examining a person’s transgressions and holding them accountable—not immediately killing them, but rather, according to the severity of their crime, sending them to prison. Great crimes go to great prisons, small crimes to small prisons, where they are governed until the person submits, comes to know their fault, and dies without resentment or complaint. If their words are not thoroughly examined, they may protest their innocence, die with grievance in their hearts, and harbor resentment. Thus, the hegemons of the Five Dynasties had many subjects and ministers who died with grievance in their hearts.

Do you now understand that the administration of punishment in Heaven above is like this? Perfected One, do you comprehend? How admirable! How admirable! To know awe and reverence is the gateway to life; not to know awe and reverence is the root of death. Heed my words well—my words are the soldiers of the rectified Heaven. Do not defy or slight them, for defiance brings harm. Minor defiance brings minor harm; great defiance brings annihilation.

I caution you, Perfected One: the people of later ages accumulate folly, trusting their ignorant hearts, and say, “It is not so,” thereby bringing ruin upon themselves. I personally traverse the realm above Heaven and know its affairs below—ten thousand times, not one is lost. I dare not deceive you. Though I do not fear the Perfected One, I fear the majesty of Heaven. Thus, my words are trustworthy. That I repeat and emphasize them is to guard against those who might stubbornly err. Therefore, I reiterate to make my words more abundant and refined.

The affairs of Heaven above are truly distant and difficult to know, so the scriptures are frequently sent down to align with the earth. Good upon the earth is good in Heaven above; evil upon the earth is evil in Heaven above. Thus, when people do good upon the earth, Heaven above responds with goodness; when people do evil upon the earth, Heaven above responds with evil—this is the ascent of their qi. The five qi are interconnected, above and below as one; the six jia are linked, above and below as one. The twelve branches unite above and below, and none, whether near or far, fail to communicate. If below is good, above is bright; if below is evil, above is inauspicious.

Thus, the Five Phases arise below, and the Five Stars shine above. This is how Heaven enlightens the people under Heaven—all Three Luminaries are likewise. Heaven above and the earth below are connected through the Three Luminaries. When the Three Luminaries shine below, so too in Heaven above; when Heaven above is bright, so too upon the earth. The two respond to one another, harmonizing to form the warp and woof. What is greatly good in Heaven above is likewise upon the earth.

Just as Heaven possesses the six jia and twelve branches, so too does the earth; just as the earth possesses the six jia and twelve branches, so too does Heaven. Thus, above and below ever correspond, not erring by even a hair’s breadth. O Perfected One, be vigilant in this. Though My words may seem distant, guard against concealing them; show them to learners, but transmit them only after fasting and purification. Be vigilant.

Follow the text as law; do not recite it in darkness.

“Yes, yes. I humbly ask: since the Middle Antiquity of the Most High, among those who taught the Dao, many abandoned their homes and forsook their kin, cast aside wives and children, and feigned madness—begging, eating filth, drinking urine. Later learners, following their example, passed these practices down as teachings, each with its own master and method, yet none were empty or careless.”

“Excellent is your challenging question, for it exposes their perverse intent. Does Heaven despise them, that you ask this? How cunning their words—why do you raise this? Long have I wondered at this, yet none dared ask directly, ever holding it in silent distress. Excellent indeed! Has Heaven truly appointed you to raise this matter?”

“Very well. Open your ears, and I shall distinguish and explain it for you. When the Supreme Heaven first revealed the true Dao, it was not like this. All practiced filial devotion to their parents, maintained descendants with wives and children, kept proper appearance, and were not mad—nor did they eat filth or drink urine. All their actions accorded with the Dao and moved within its laws. The highest adepts became teachers and assistants to emperors and kings, transmitting and nurturing their kind without harm.

At that time—like the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors—they acted by the true Dao, striving to benefit and never to harm or injure. Thus, they practiced the true Dao openly, without concealment. But when the Three Kings brought chaos and the Five Hegemons arose, rulers and ministers, the people, all deceived and slighted one another. Hence, they feigned madness, fearing discovery, begging, eating filth, drinking urine—these are the deeds and words of the desperate and destitute.

The Dao, too, has its cycles of decline and flourishing, like the Three Sovereigns, Five Emperors, Three Kings, and Five Hegemons. In later ages, the way of hegemony prevailed: begging, abandoning kin, forsaking wives and children, eating filth, drinking urine—this is the decline of the Dao, the rise of hegemony. Thus, the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors often attained the Dao and ascended to Heaven, some through corpse liberation, others by departing in bodily form. The Three Kings lived out their years, but the Five Hegemons gained no true Dao, all dying in battle upon the wilds. Those who now cling to this hegemonic way in the later age likewise perish upon the wilds—this is what it means.

I do not deceive you, Perfected One: this, too, is a hegemonic Dao, no different from the hegemons and kings. How could they ascend to Heaven? Excellent, excellent! The foolish heart of this student is now truly enlightened. I never imagined the Dao could have a hegemonic aspect. Only through the Heavenly Master’s explanation have I come to know this. Truly, truly… how profound! You may be said to have opened my eyes.

I ask: what should learners of today do? Now, the great cycle of the Heavenly Dao is complete and fully prepared. From this time onward, it differs from the past. If one seeks to practice the hegemonic methods of Middle Antiquity, the true Dao will not come. O Perfected One, be warned and vigilant. If you desire long life and joyful existence, study My texts. Lose even a hair’s breadth, and your life will not be whole—how can you fail to guard it?

The primordial Dao of the Origin-Yuan has arisen; the fire-light practices it. The hegemonic Dao is ended. Though Heaven is vast, it has its own divisions and principles, revealing texts to all people that they may discuss them together. What belongs to the high should be assigned to the high, what belongs to the middle to the middle, what belongs to the low to the low, and what belongs to all—high, middle, and low—should be shared by all. Why do you not see their sincerity and trustworthiness… as if speaking with Heaven?

Excellent, excellent! The qi of the times is now balanced.”

"How does the Perfected One know this? By seeing that Heaven has personally sent the Heavenly Master to speak, one knows the qi of Heaven is now balanced. Excellent, excellent! You have grasped its meaning. I humbly request to ask one or two more things—dare not speak further.

In practicing the Dao from now on, where should one seek it? Seek it always in a quiet chamber, without abandoning parents or leaving wife and children. Proceed gradually, ceasing only when seclusion is complete. If one’s inner self is not virtuous yet seeks seclusion, it will bring no benefit—rather, one may die prematurely.

Each must examine their own truth. Act without betraying Heaven. Though one may deceive others, one cannot deceive Heaven. Do not worry that others may act wrongly. Let each govern themselves by this principle. Those who dare not practice the Dao are wicked people, those who seek to deceive and feign. By this measure, not one in ten thousand will err.

If disciples learn thus, deceit and cunning will vanish, and the good and evil among people will be revealed. This is called *The August Heaven’s Selection of the Worthy*, a text by which the highest may attain transcendence, the middle may serve as counsel to emperors and kings, and even the ignorant and foolish may follow its precepts as diligent commoners.

Perfected One, take heed of this." "Yes, yes."

"May I inquire how one who suffers from *pi-lou* may attain the Dao and depart? If the Dao is achieved, one departs—nothing more. If the Dao remains unachieved, one must daily serve one’s parents, protect one’s wife and children, and practice with gradual purity. Each morning, one will come to understand one’s own intent.

The worthy together uphold this teaching."

"Yes, yes."

*[Right] The Celestial Selection of the Worthy—On the Flourishing of the Dao and the Severing of Falsehood—enables those who abandon hegemony to extend their lives, ease their minds, dissolve cunning, and uphold filial duty to parents while protecting wives and children.*

**The One Hundred Seventeenth Scroll of the Scripture of Great Peace concludes.**

---
